fjXJM8zymkq_T1KaZjrUZQ.text: This was probably the worst place I've had in Vegas.. super over priced for what they serve.. and they don't even try... the ramen was so salty it was unbearable.. I couldn't take a second bite.. the pork shoulder plate was just bad it tasted like cheap bbq pulled pork and the portion was so small.. I would've been better off with in and out down the street..

6IkmABG2FDaZ59BPC84oCQ.text: One of the best pork chops ever! Oysters and cold noodles were okay too. Definately knows how to balance their food. It was kind of hard to decide what to get on the menu. More options would of been better. Would recommend!

jOCUq6UIuD5J99fyMXN9jg.text: So, I was really excited to try this Momofuku because the first one that I tried was in New York! I would definitely say that this location is a lot more pricey than the other one, but they have a lot more options. However, my review would be for the Ramen. Keep in mind that the Ramen here at this location is not on the menu that they first give you. You have to ask for the separate menu in order to check that out. It is still a little bit pricey but, it's pretty much the same price as the New York location. This is to be expected since it's located inside of the cosmopolitan hotel! However, you won't regret coming here because the ambience and the views are amazing, as well as the food!

Y8OVapRKX9UEr_4kjW7Pjg.text: Not firing on all cylinders yet. Very friendly and welcoming service! We were really pushed to try the specials- however, when I go next time, I would stick to the Bun's, as they were a CLEAR highlight. Branzino was interesting, but not sensational. Apps read as sensational, but I'd work with my server more next time, as the quality was uneven- from great to just okay.   I will be back.  This is a fun place to have a meal, and when the food begins to hit the high points they aspire to, it will be one of the best restaurants in Las Vegas.  Expensive.

r3KZ1atnYArBx5Sn7i8t4w.text: The food here is amazing!!! Made reservations for me and my husband on a Friday night, loved it so much that we convinced our friends to eat with us there the next day so we can try the bigger dishes lol The pork belly bun was so tender, the meat just melts in your mouth! The $300+ fried chicken was soooooo good! That skin was so tasty and perfectly crunchy! Cocktails were great, staff also great! We will be back for sure!!

90Iou6_RiifjWTfbGMHdkw.text: Ohh Momofuku!  I am a creature of habit and ended up coming here three times in about a week while in Vegas!! I am also a sucker for GREAT service and good food.  I fell in love with David Chang watching him on Netflix like many people I'm sure did.  His restaurants in NYC are bookmarked in my Yelp as well.  Afraid it would be jam packed, I tried to go at not peak hours to ensure a seat at the bar.  Unfortunately, for what I perceive to be such a great restaurant, the bar was pretty empty with a few chairs for me to choose from on every occasion I went.   First things first, get the pork bun.  The hype is real people! And well deserved. The bun is perfectly fluffy and the bun to meat ratio is on point.  You are not ripping any bun off.  There is no dry bun sticking to the top of your mouth.  It is delicious and amazing, and I ordered two the first time I went.   Next, I ordered the momofuku oysters, which were good but I'm not sure I would order again, as they weren't cheap for six oysters, and while yummy, not what I expected.  Somewhat reminiscent of an oysters Rockefeller but done with kimchi, I thought it would be spicier for some reason?? No spice, but a nice breadcrumb crunch.  Great texture, pairs well with a beer, rather salty.  But in a good way. As long as you're into that.   On my next trip I ordered the pork bun again, the soft boiled egg appetizer and the pork ramen.  The soft boiled eggs I had to get after some serious envy from looking at my neighbor eat it the first time. It's two eggs, halved, soft boiled, with some caviar/roe sprinkled on top, as well as some other deliciousness.  You gotta like eggs to order this. (Duh).  I really enjoyed it, but you gotta love the briny pop of fish eggs as well as have an affinity for regular egg yolks.  After the appetizers I felt somewhat gluttonous, but knew what I came for, so out came the ramen.  Definitely their staple dish, it hit the spot for me.  We have no ramen in Miami (where I live) so this was as good as it gets for me.  Pork belly and shredded pork, noodles with a nice bite, salty but not too salty broth.  It's not a thick, tonkatsu broth, so don't order it if that's what you're going for.  Again, I am no ramen connoisseur so it was yummy to me.  Needless to say I was rolled out of there.   Finally, my last trip I ordered the spicy cucumbers and the chicken karaage appetizer.  The cucumbers were great and a nice respite from my typically fried and carb heavy choices.  And then back to my typically fried choices with the chicken, although it seemed very light.  Best thing about the chicken karaage (which is basically chicken fingers) is definitely the aerated hollandaise sauce.  I wanted to ask for more but refrained.   If you made it to this point in my review, I commend you, and will try to wrap up.  The customer service here was amazing!!! Dan the bartender, took care of me two of the three times I went to Momofuku and he was awesome.  On my second visit he introduced me to his colleague Justin who took care of me as well and remembered me when I came in the third time.  He subsequently introduced me to his colleague (Danny I believe) who also gave excellent service and chatted with me most of the time while also working a full service bar and helping other guests at the bar.  He was even able to order me the cereal milk ice cream from Milk Bar next door--which yes, does taste exactly like cereal milk, with I'm assuming homemade corn flake garnish, because it had an extra element of sweet/saltiness normal corn flakes don't have that was oh so yummy and contrasting.   As good as the food was, the service is why I had to write this review. Great pork buns and great service!!!

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Cucumbers
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Soft Boiled Egg Appetizer (I already ate one--four to an order)

Rqm6hhrO7xpEBQTaDj_6JQ.text: Bartender Erick  such a friendly guy and makes a delicious cocktail! Came in on a whim and got the pork Chashu ramen it was magic in a bowl  can't wait to come back! Thanks for the great service! Xx

30TSllzXlizxIVrrKCB2fQ.text: Fun little place with tasty bites that i have visited twice. I would have given 5 stars but disappointed both times different items on the menus where not available. I would still visit a third time.

SgLVm-kmkzzCDnx4T1-g1g.text: Went here during happy hour and ordered the shrimp buns which were really good.  Loved the steam buns and the pattie was very good! Also ordered the  pork belly ramen and it was really good! Not the best broth I've ever had but it was still good and decent portion size!

M1k8yHBz_3n3DyA1LO_vXQ.text: First night out of our girls weekend and excited to try the highly acclaimed Momofuku.   I must say we were highly disappointed. The menu highlighted large format dinners that would probably be good value but not easy to decide upon with a group.  We each decided to order a bun to start. Both the pork shrimp was tasty and good sized portions. The rest of the menu seemed odd to me. The lesser priced items from the noodles and then a big jump to their higher priced selection. To me, it didn't seem they had much of a selection in the mid range of $30-$40.  I enjoy great food and don't mind paying top dollar but the menu honestly didn't excite me enough. We decided on their noodle dishes. It was bland, with very little flavor. Wish they added some type of protein in top of the dish to make it feel complete.  Service was very slow and very inattentive. Dishes were dropped off to us and our server never really came back to check on us. Our plates sat in front of us when we were done for 20 minutes or so before we had to flag someone down to ask for the dessert menu. It even prompted me to ask "Where IS our server?" as the gal who took our order was never to be found afterwards. Seemed like the switched servers on us, quite confusing and a bit irritating.  Their cake was delicious and probably the highlight of our meal.  Restaurant was crowded and it was a fun atmosphere. Seemed like other tables who ordered the large format dinners received much better service than others. Too bad, this experience didn't live up to the hype to return.

RAXiDxIKBdIN9fMTmld3dw.text: Wonderful memorable meal sitting at the noodle bar. Every dish was different, honest and transparent. The drinks were great. Masterful chefs who were fun and engaging. We'll be back soon! Pickled veggie plate was excellent with two terrific kimchis, cauliflower, beets and ginger. Shrimp buns were incredible, delicate fresh slightly sweet shrimp patties. Chicken soup was an excellent ramen bowl. Meatball appetizer was terrific, the black eyed peas with it stole the show. Samples of Brussels sprouts and sliced pork were wonderful. We sat at the noodle bar and really enjoyed interacting with the chefs and watching them work.   Second visit, equally amazing. Pork buns, Yellowtail sashimi, Momofuko oysters, chilled spicy noodles, a sample of spicy Sichuan rice cakes, all fantastic. Drinks again excellent. Our only repeat dish was the shrimp buns... otherworldly! A remarkable experience.

AgADdnT2FAacwcTbuhmMqQ.text: Walked in at 10:30pm on Sunday night. We were told that the kitchen was closed, and the bar was open. That's totally fine with us, and thank God. From the bar service, we were pretty much know their service, not to mention about food. The service was terrible, the bar tender was very lack of motivation to  serve. At the beginning was a female bar tender handed us the menu in a piece of paper. Then she ran to some where to do her cleaning and totally ignored us, she seems a bit to hyper to wait for getting off from work. Some of the servers came in and asked her what's her plan for tonight. They just like chatting a lot during work and  obviously, more servers around than customers. The male bar tender was cleaning, and serve us with a black face all the time. Maybe he didn't have a good day. When we asked to taste the reisling which was from Austria and the other was Germany.  He was so reluctantly to serve us, and educated us in a unfriendly Mann that we thought we knew better than him. I knew he didn't want to do that little work to make the customers happy. And the other drink was that light that my hubby couldn't taste any alcohol. We were served with no napkins. So funny, so much servers were walking around, they didn't seem what they were doing, or what's customer service. The drinks were not cheap either.  Very first time and ladt

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bad service

ORPkQEcaeln4kE3JdqinHA.text: 3/5 Overall  3/5 Service (see the pre-fix price paragraph on why it is 3/5 stars) 3/5 Food 4/5 Ambiance- If you get the back area, you get the view of the LV Strip, which is pretty nice. It feels a bit more private in the back, but it may be reserved for large groups. (Our party was about 15)  Pre-Fix Price Paragraph: Okay, I want to start off stating I find it weird that EVERYONE pays a "prefix" menu, but not everyone get the same amount of food. For example, we would get 12 scallops for 15 guests...HMM...seems a bit unjust to me. However, there was still plenty of food to go around. For me, if I am paying a pre-fix price, I expect everyone to get the same amount, and not have to share...  I might have to say, besides the Pork Bell Bao, Lobster dish, and dessert, everything was just Meh.  Ordered: We practically almost sampled the entire menu! 1) Spicy Cucumbers - togarashi, toasted almond  - 3/5 good, but pretty simple 2) Crab Deviled Eggs - smoked trout roe, crispy bonito - 2/5 eh, wasn't my favorite dish.  3) Pork Belly - hoisin, scallion, cucumber  - 5/5 $7 for one bun, outrageous! Anyhow, this was my favorite dish of the night. The pork belly was SOO FATTY and well seasoned! 4) Beets - citrus, rye XO sauce  4/5 probably my favorite beet dish ever Market Greens - tomato, gooseberry, ricotta 3/5 good, but probably wouldn't order outside of prefix 5) Hokkaido Scallops - carrot, Anson Mills grains, tasso ham, tomato - 4/5 good, but would've been nice if we had our own scallop for the prefix menu. Steamed Whole Branzino - charred lemon,  brown butter dashi, herbs 3.5/5 good, but nothing special  6) Korean Braised Short Rib - root vegetables, chilies, sesame 2.5/5 way too salty... 7) Salt & Pepper Lobster- lobster and gulf shrimp battered and fried then heavily seasoned with fried garlic, scallions, and chilies 4/5 another delicious and well prepared plate.  8) Korean Braised Short Ribs- Boneless beef short ribs slow cooked with daikon, lotus root, potatoes, and rice cakes.  Topped with chilies, scallions, sesame and presented family style in a donabe with rice. 1/5 inedible ...way way way way too salty.... very sad I barely touched my bowl.  We went a bit crazy on the dessert: 1) Crack pie: 3/5  2) Birthday Cake: 4/5 I typically don't like birthday cake, but this was well made--not TOO sweet 3) Cereal Milk Soft Serve: 3.5/5 good if you're looking for something simple 4) Cinnaswirl soft serve: 3/5 Tasted like a churro--a bit too sweet for me 5) Candy Bar Pie: 3/5 I like the crack pie better if I had to pick

vAoiSlzKgkJc_ItBlhFeIw.text: Had a reservation at Momofuku for July 4. Started with two shrimp steam buns (best buns I've ever had). The shrimp was a bit random, as it came as a pan-fried cake; still, I enjoyed it (my wife did not). We also had the Meatballs to share. I liked these quite a bit - tender and juicy.  For mains, I had the pork Ramen, and my wife had the chickpea Ramen. Mine came with pulled pork (very dry), a soft egg (delicious), pork belly (not bad). Overall, it was fine - however the actual Ramen broth just wasn't that flavourful. Considering we were told by the waiter that Momofuku Vegas is "known for Ramen" - which I have also heard before on Yelp - we were both very underwhelmed. Yusho in Monte Carlo (RIP) had much more delicately flavoured and balanced Ramen.   Having said all that, the restaurant has an amazing view, service was good and the drinks were all tasty. We may give it another chance next time.

gxwG8YhAMfUud7claa5bjw.text: Meh...bc it's way over priced for average quality. Sorry chef for comments about the salty chicken karage but I must honest. Pork belly buns were on point. Menu could be more in my opinion. Minus 2 stars for the hostess being very rude about the open seating at bar. She was very unprofessional and copped attitude. Not necessary. We are all grown adults. 3 stars for the buns and our cute bartender who took care of us. Date: 8/12/17

18NzTImACLJNksxsQz3rLw.text: I used to have high hopes for celebrity restaurateurs, then I went through a phase where I started to expect they were going to be cheap replications of the original.  Momofuku Las Vegas is antithesis of all that, the synergy between the property chef Shaun and David's brand standards is awesome, it's obvious the staff respects their purpose immensely and it really speaks highly to the management team and culture. Food offerings were stellar. From the duck entree to the kimichi apple salad, the truffle @ prosciutto with frozen grapes it was stunning from app to dessert (white truffles and soft serve).  Can't wait to head back and try the other dishes. Great wine and cocktails, Mags our server was incredible..

7oZ5zjyjCdVXVMLg1VM0GQ.text: The pork belly bun - it's OMG good. A must get if you visit Momofuku!!! We also tried the kimchi rice with egg which was good but little bit salty. I wished they had the duck in smaller portion, at least for 2, so we could try it. The service was good overall.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

y9bAxulsddz444_u0cSQXw.text: OMG! I couldn't get enough of this place!! I went when we first landed in Vegas and again two days later when my fiance came into Vegas. The pork belly is absolutely to die for! I've never had porkbelly that was so crunchy on the outside and tender/juicy on the inside. The flavor was so amazing that I decided to skip the sauce, and trust me when I saw I never miss and opportunity to smother sauce on everything I eat. I also had the fried rice, both times that I went, as well as the crack pie which, apparently, they aren't allowed to call it anymore because of a complaint from a customer. I believe it's called a milk bar pie now. Do yourself a favor and leave room for dessert. You will not be disappointed!

XKkdowjVK8ew16hOKhTrvg.text: Here for a dinner date. TLDR: pricey gourmet asian food at a trendy casual setting with excellent service  Ambiance: trendy, casual, a little loud Service: attentive, helpful, warm Food: not the best value but excellent food with the exception of shishito peppers.  - sweet and sour long beans (4.5 stars): fresh, tender, well flavored - uni hash (5 stars): our favorite, fresh uni works well with the fried hash - shishito pepper (1 star): would recommend avoiding. ITS SO SALTY we had to rinse it in water to eat some. All the yellow toppings on top are lime salt and they could almost kill my tastebuds  - grilled lamb ribs (5 stars): amazing, so tender and rich seasoning - black truffle ramen (4.5 stars): full of truffle fragrance, works well with the broth but a little salty for the bf

e2rnk2nEwKtMg2pamX9sgw.text: One night I was roaming through the resorts of the Strip and stumbled upon Momofuku and had heard of this restaurant before. I decided to give it a try and walked in solo.   Took a look at the menu and realized this would be a great place if I had friends (and more money), but nonetheless I was hopeful that the food would comfort me in my loneliness.   I decided to get two of the cheapest menu items, a pork bun and the vegetarian ramen. The food instilled a happiness in me that I did not think was possible. As I think about how good the cheapest items tasted, my mouth waters for the potential foodgasms await me from the menu.   I plan on returning one day once I get some friends. Otherwise, my one night in Momofuku is something I'll cherish forever.

fC9u71uop6X9ON3YGVrmmA.text: Ridiculously awesome.  Every time I am in Vegas, Momofuku is a must.  Thank You for continuously surprising me with amazing food and a top notch dining experience.

6Kq0jT2r1-JlFA0vbyZN8w.text: I've never been disappointed with any of the Momofuku restaurants and I've always tried to go to at least one Momofuku whenever there is one in the city I visit. So of course I had to try this one at the Cosmopolitan while in Vegas. As with every restaurant of David's, they don't disappoint! The service as always was great. Servers were very well informed whenever we had any questions (and we had a couple). We had a pescatarian with us in our group and we had seen the shiitake mushroom bun on a yelp review so we asked to see if we could still order that so she could try the baos. We also ordered the chicken bowl and the ginger scallion noodles as well as the pork belly baos. There were 3 of us sharing all these things and we were so stuffed we hardly finished everything.   The pork belly baos were amazing as always. Just enough sauce to keep it all moist. Deliciously fatty pork belly that just melts in your mouth and a delicious soft bao to wrap it all up and soak up the juices!   The chicken bowl (I can't quite remember the name but it's not the jidori bowl with the poached egg) was super delicious! Super fragrant with the sesame oil. Deliciously roasted chicken and delicious pickled greens and wakame salad all topped with roasted sunflower seeds. I have to say that the toasted sunflower seeds were probably the best part of the bowl. With a hint of smokiness it really elevated the dish and made me keep going back for more. It did get a tiny bit too salty as I ate more of it but I do tend to like milder salt flavours.   The ginger scallion noodles. OMG. What delicious flavours! Such a non exciting sounding dish, but it was amazing! So much flavour packed into those noodles. The noodles itself were cooked to perfection and the toppings were just delightful. I think this was my favourite dish by far.  One in our group ordered the ramen, but she said she didn't really love it. I didn't get to try hers but noodle bar was amazing when I went to the one in Chicago.   So as with all Momofuku establishments, I always recommend! We did make reservations on open table but I don't think reservations are too hard to come by. Walk ins waits shouldn't be too bad as well as I didn't see all that many people waiting and while we were inside for 1:30pm lunch it wasn't completely packed but still quite full.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken bowl
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bao
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ginger scallion noodles

6DdSmkDeS-_g8NNhrCMBGg.text: Really good, but only if you want to spend $50 on a truffle ramen bowl.  While the food was wonderful, the prices were outrageous... so if you are looking to conserve your money, well, stay clear of this establishment (pic of menu and prices)   You can make reservations via Open Table, or the Momofuku website.   we had the pork belly buns, which were amazing. Sweet, and Spicy.  The shishito peppers were good, addictive :) they were not hot, but mild.   The ramen (Truffle Ramen) was wonderful...  the Rack of Lamb was awesome...   but  I would not recommend this place to anyone, unless you are willing to spend the $$$$ (yeah, I give it 4 $)...  Now visiting Las Vegas you should splurge, but this was a little excessive.   I tried it, I can say I did it... but doubt I will return.

YIcbr9fk-1weYIWB2EJ3Rw.text: Momofuku: The word you cuss out while eating delicious food at a David Chang eatery.  Momofuku is located inside the Cosmopolitan Hotel on Level 2 in Las Vegas, Nevada.  Want a tasty unforgettable meal?  Try the family style menu.  We ordered Bo Ssam and a round of Pork Buns.  For the family style menu, I would recommend coming with at least a party of four.  Would I come back? I would definitely come back.  The price range can be expensive depending which course you go with.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bo Ssam Family Style
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. pork buns
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. my beer

zR0YAV3ucB5r2ZZyQLiLHg.text: Didn't get a chance to try Momofuku in New York, so I'm glad they have one in Vegas which is much closer to me. My boyfriend and I told them we were celebrating our anniversary, so the moment we sat down, they gave us 2 glasses of complimentary champagne. Great start. We still wanted to try their interesting cocktails, so we got the Bok to the Beat (made with bok choy) and 24k Magic (made with carrots). For food, we got...  Small Plates - A5 Hokkaido Wagyu Potatoes: O.M.G. this might be one of the best things I've ever consumed. The meat just melts in your mouth, while the potatoes were crispy with some honey mustard and garlic. It was divine.  Large Plates - Miso Black Cod: When I see black cod on the menu, I usually order it, and this did not disappoint. Served with shiitakes, bok choy, and daikon, which in my opinion, are the perfect sides.  Noodles & Buns - Ginger Scallion Noodles: This dish wasn't bad, it was just a little bit too salty. Otherwise, I would have enjoyed it more.  When we thought we were done, the server ended up giving us a complimentary confetti cookie from Milk Bar next door! 5 stars for service. Honestly, the only reason why I knocked down 1 star is the prices. It is ridiculously high for even a Vegas restaurant. Maybe because it only has 2 $$ on Yelp, when it really should be 3. The cheaper items here are the buns and secret menu ramen, but that doesn't interest me as much as their larger family style dishes. Although it's expensive, I will probably be back.

5Qn-veccdsRBK-5kLTRDOw.text: We decided to share a midnight snack and ramen at this conveniently located restaurant.  Shishito peppers-smoked salt and lime. These were flavorful and crispy.  Shoyu pork ramen-flavorful with pork and perfectly cooked noodles in a rich broth.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shishito peppers
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu pork ramen

X9zjiHd0FIJFPFmhbc5N9Q.text: Love this place. Every time I'm in Vegas this is one of the first places I go to. Great place to party and drink and of course amazing food!! Gotta try the ramen as its to die for.

8hYbrkG6r5fHrX95KZnWJg.text: When we passed by this restaurant, my sister wanted to try the Shoyu ramen here since we just had it at the airport before landing in Vegas.  We were greeted by the hostess and seated by the windowing facing PH. Our waiter was friendly and tried to be funny throughout the time we were there.  Everyone ordered the Shoyu pork ramen noodle. It came with pork belly and shoulder, ramen noodle, slowed poached egg, and green onions. The noodle was soft and hot. The pork was soft and melts in your mouth. The poached egg have a bright golden yellow yolk. The pork was good. The dish overall was salty (which is typical for ramen dishes) due to the sodium. This is actually less saltier than the other Shoyu dish I've eaten.  I wouldn't mind coming back again for the ramen.

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Table setup

IjOigl3XnPvB3H9nj-sebA.text: Service was super quick for lunch hour.  The food: Pork belly buns - pork belly was a bit tough but I liked the crisp, fatty parts Shoyu ramen - good, broth wasn't greasy or buttery and noodles were a good texture Striped bass - tougher than expected, I think I was expecting sea bass that was more buttery and soft

iwj2JB16NkNs_l8KRVqfjg.text: Bold, unique flavors and great service. We stopped here for lunch (which actually has more Noodles & Rice dishes available than during dinner) and started with the Pork Belly Buns. Our waiter provided some Korean BBQ sauce to add. These were delicious and the buns were so perfectly soft. For our entrees, we chose the Ginger Scallion Noodles (added an egg) and Shoyu Pork Ramen. Both were delicious and priced well for the portions.  For dessert, we both ordered the Cereal Milk soft serve topped with corn flakes. We could taste the "cereal milk" flavor slightly but it was definitely lacking. I would pass on that selection and try something else for dessert.

XbHAUkdQf2nNlWryOdM-Xw.text: Another great option at Cosmo for decent eats without the fancy fanfare.  I came here with a couple friends after "working" hard at the tables.  They were "thirsty" and I was hungry for a late night snack.    Having had a heavy dinner, I ordered the chickpea ramen - a miso broth vegetarian bowl of goodness.  It was flavorful and light.  The chickpeas were crispy and despite being deep fried, they kept the chickpea flavor.  If you like them soft, soak the chickpeas enough in the miso broth, and they do soften up.  The few bok choy were a nice touch.  They were fresh and crispy.    As for my thirsty friends, they too were happily satisfied because Momofuku has a full bar with some top shelf spirits, including high end tequila and scotch.  As for me, an IPA was the perfect pairing for my ramen.    Service was also great.  Super friendly, engaged and accommodating by serving us an extra drink after the bar closed. This Momofuku is of the same quality and coolness as the one DC which I am a big fan of as well.  Enjoy!

roNTWgOITfZgxqqL1vZnVA.text: Me wife is a noodle snob and she said this is the best ramen she has ever had. The broth and the noodles, everything about it.  The pork belly buns were really good. The best I have ever had. It's more of a slab of pork, larger than a slider and almost burger size. It was filling for sure.   Can order the ramen during dinner, just need to ask them even though it's not on the official menu.

xILO2eto-LiBdh7KCezxKQ.text: Noodles doesn't appears to be customer made or freshly made by noodle specialist shop.  The pork belly slice is not flavored much but nicely fat and crunchy outside.   Not much to say about the soup.  Not sure if it's dried fish and soy sauce are all the ingredients that went into the stock.  Somewhat close to instant ramen's soup...  For as famous as Dave Chang is, I feel the ramen was a disappointment.  Both Orange and Los Angeles County have much more to offer.  *I do like the Dave I see on the screen.  He's straight up and funny, but the food I had really doesn't stand up to his reputation as a chef.

_vXq9Frvt9YqO_7wadq61w.text: Been dying to try momofuku but New York is so far from the west coast so when I heard there was one in Las Vegas, it was a great excuse to take a trip for some great food and a little bit of gambling.   Ended up getting the Bo Ssam bowl, Shoyu pork ramen, and the pork belly buns. Everything tasted absolutely amazing, definitely lived up to the hype. Though I'm a ramen fanatic, I think the bo ssam bowl was my favorite. It's so flavorful and filling!   We also got the infamous birthday cake. To be honest, it wasn't as revolutionary as I was hoping, but it was still a pretty decent cake.   The service was also fantastic. I forget my waiter's name, but he was friendly, helpful, and was quick to refill waters. Can't wait to come back and try the rest of the menu

HQ0uzrbMnQdNpVjT4axKcw.text: Definitely had to stop here while in town for a conference.  The ramen was so good and came out in under 5 minutes after we ordered it; very impressive! The atmosphere is very chill and the staff are probably the best part about the whole restraunt! Will definitely be coming back here with more friends!

9a3qLsMUjqCVIyBDmbGw-w.text: I went here with a few friends for lunch and my expectations were quite high, as I had heard so much about this place. The atmosphere was fun, and the service was amazing. I ordered the pork ramen. The pork belly portion that I got was phenomenal. It was crispy on the outside and deliciously rich and fatty.   Unfortunately, the dish was quite salty overall, which is not a complaint I usually have (I like more salt than the average person.) I probably wouldn't have said anything, but my friend ordered the salt and pepper lobster and it was so overly salty that she bought it up to the waiter. He was so friendly and took it off the bill, but it seems as if oversalting dishes was a systemic issue. I have had phenomenal ramen in the past, and for the price point and the lack of quality, I am not sure I would return to Momofuku.

lIYQaNaJ48vJre56WcoOSg.text: Browsing all the possible dinner options for a Friday night in Vegas, I ended up picking Momofuku - I'd heard about it, the menu looked good, and it wouldn't break the bank. Long story short.. it was good, but not great.  I ended up ordering the ginger scallion noodles and pork belly buns. The pork belly was crispy and came with a delicious hoisin sauce - I think the buns are a must if you're going to hit up Momofuku. They provided a spicy sauce on the side as well. Noodles were tasty, but not a stand-out dish for me. For a beverage, I went with the only vodka cocktail on the menu (Summer Fling - vodka, watermelon, basil, cinchona). It was okay, a little strong for my taste.  I'd come back here if I had a group to go with - they have family style dishes that looked realllly good (I'm thinking about the salt & pepper lobster and shrimp specifically).   Service was really nice and attentive. Atmosphere was cool - doesn't look like much from the outside but they have a relatively large space and nice view of the strip.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly buns
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ginger Scallion Noodles

hiGFpXmX2yXGFhJ0Ep9Gdw.text: I really cannot say enough good things about this restaurant. My friend recommended it to me and said he got the duck here three days in a row the last time he came to Vegas. I was unfortunately not able to get the duck as the smaller portion is only for lunch, so I'll have to come back and get it! We ended up ordering the shishito peppers, pear and burrata salad, rice cakes, and whole fish. Everything was delicious!  The shishito peppers were spicy and the peanut or sesame on top was a good extra. The pear and burrata salad was my favorite, creamy and rich but still light. The rice cakes were crunchy yet chewy. The fish was a great amount for the price and tasted very fresh! Maybe a little too many garlic slices though.  The service was excellent. Our server was very friendly and helpful, giving us tastes of sake before we chose one (the house one is great, get it!) and a spicy cucumber on the house (also great with peanuts and spicy seasoning).  Definitely will be back!!

2JtQXCC8TquvULpmZDBa5A.text: Momofuku is mo'fu'ing good.  We came for dinner but should have come at lunch - we wanted ramen, and the choices are pretty limited in the evening.   That being said, there's a few off-menu ramens offered at dinner time, so just ask your server. Our table sampled a good portion of the menu, and everything was solid and unique.   Ambiance is a dark and vibey but still feels casual enough to hit up before a night at the club. Momofuku takes reservations, so be sure to request a seat overlooking the strip.

7gVXV3pC4F92WQwwmoTCMw.text: The ramen we had was okay but the pork buns we had were super fat and oil. Kinda gross because it was oozing oil when you bite into it. Overall not the best experience at a momofuku restaurant maybe the other dishes are better.

GNfjDGCVicT-BRQ9rBQJUg.text: Stopped in for a quick lunch before I left for the airport. Was dining solo so I wasn't able to try as many dishes as I would have liked. Must return with friends to have a real feast! Sat at the bar and was assisted by Bree who was very helpful & pleasant. She even informed me that I could get one pork bun  (the dish typically comes with two) so I really appreciated the insider tip. The pork bun was perfectly crispy & the sauce really added to the dish. Would highly recommend. I was in the mood for a light lunch after a fairly gluttonous 2 days on Vegas. Opted for the little gem salad with spicy shrimp. It was excellent & full of interesting flavors. I would also highly recommend this dish - it is plenty to share between 2 people as a starter. Overall I thoroughly enjoyed my experience & will be back to sample more items!

VgVP-EJTsJsFSZxgw1pqfQ.text: The best ramen broth I've ever had.   My 6 friends and I came here around 12:30pm on a busy Saturday and got seated immediately. Thanks to OpenTable's reservation of course.   5 of us got the Momofuku Ramen and the other two got the chilled spicy noodle. They ran out of pork belly but they gave us extra pork shoulder, which was unbelievably tender and juicy.   We also got the oysters which were really fresh and tasty. I wish we had a little bit of Tabasco sauce though.   Definitely would recommend going here for lunch if you're not in a mood for a buffet in Vegas! Pretty affordable considering the prices around the strip. I'm definitely coming back to try the large plate family meals.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

PVk-UpsjrjpavFYv7AOO4A.text: Not sure if I knew what to expect coming to Momofuku in Vegas... in my mind, I half-expected just more extravagant, more over the top, more... Vegas. That's kinda what the entrance is like - the Cosmopolitan is a bizzarro Disney packed with mid-20s in various stages of drunkenness, but once you get inside, you appreciate that, beyond the loud, hip, club beats are really high quality staff and servers in a really well decorated space. A David Choe mural adorns the "accent wall" of the restaurant, giving it space an edgy look that otherwise may be steakhouse decor.  Dining experience here is best with a group... with a certain immunity to sticker shock. It's not that the food is undeserving... it is really worth what you pay for it. The lobster tails and the duck were highlights that are worth coming back for.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

YfgVi_Iz6W94BeU-UDATlA.text: Hostess there have a face like they never want to see customers again  Smile a little ladies.  Why so serious

vDFdBUzPD2s94OGqOvhAtg.text: We got the best seats in town, chefs table right in front of the kitchen.  Awesome view of everything prepared and cooked.  honestly, i was not impressed with the momofuku in new york city, but a friend really wanted to come here in vegas so i gave it another try.  this time around, i really enjoyed our meal.  -corn with pesto and roulette cheese -uni hash brown: crispy potatoes serving as nice vessel for some delicious uni -miso cod: delicious, light, melts in your mouth -pork ramen: not on the menu but they had it.  broth was full of flavor. and, of course, dessert! -crack pie and cereal soft serve.  crack pie was on crack..with a shot of espresso=perfection.  loved our seats, loved the food, we were soo full we can barely move.

dSTaK4CcFLVBy0clAtz6mQ.text: Let's start by saying that it's been awhile since I was this unhappy with a restaurant as far as service and food quality go.  The server were half there half gone during our service. Apparently, they charge for water which they did not clarify prior to pouring it or at the time of seating. I get that it's $1 per person, but we weren't informed of this charge nor was offered house water, which we would have gladly drank.  The pork belly buns that people are raved about are no where near decent. The fat wasn't fully rendered and the one I got only had sauce on half of the bun (not top or bottom but sides). The pork belly got a nice crunch to it but lacks flavor.  The pork belly ramen tastes horrible as well. Low quality ramen along with low end soup base. We got a pre-made poached egg (cold center) along with the same flavor-lacking pork belly. The shredded pork was okay but still not amazing. I rather eat instant noodle at this point if you look at the price.  I understand things can be pricey at a tourist location, but this was just a horrible experience that if I could have given it a negative star I would have. Came here because how well known NY Momofuku is, but this is a huge disappointment of the brand name.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

-Dc-55tYA-L5EcnZiGYS9w.text: Momofuku did not disappoint. My father called and made reservations for 9pm, I thought we'd have to sit in the crowded dining area but as the hostess led us to our table we made our way to a quiet section with the best view in the house! Perfect view of the Eiffel Tower and Belagio water shows. Our waiter offered us excellent selections and a complimentary glass of wine for my birthday!  I was not feeling well prior to coming but the food tasted amazing and wish I could enjoy it more. Definitely try and make a reservation as it can get quite crowded.

oE06xR24QB1SiCtlhMs44w.text: I've been here over 10 times aka I'm a dedicated Cosmopolitan Traveler.   I have always been able to get a seat, they are vegetarian friendly, aesthetics on point,  perfect location, staff are friendly, chief  you're the real one  VEGETARIANS!! - just get the  shiitake buns because if you don't, you're playing yourself. AND NO! don't get one and share... don't be that person. Just trust me and get one each and  you will be content.  also always go for the hot chickpea ramen... always

Zr7iozFqIRAr_rt1L3sfuA.text: Came here for lunch on a Sunday and we were seated right away. We ordered the shishito peppers and pork belly buns to start. Unfortunately they were out of pork belly so we got a pulled pork bun as a substitute. The shishito peppers were a great start to the meal! They have a different flavor than most but were definitely enjoyable. I also got the shoyu pork ramen which was also very good. The broth was very rich and savory. Since they didn't have pork belly, they gave us double portions of pork.  All in all this is a great restaurant to enjoy a nice, casual meal. Our server was also very fast and friendly. Hopefully next time they'll have pork belly!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shishito Peppers
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Pork Ramen

1pMh4WE8ljRLyhqbT70rzA.text: I came here for a last lunch before I left Vegas and I am so glad I did!  We had a reservation for 7 at 1130 on a Sunday, and we got there when they weren't too busy and had great service.  We split a few appetizers including the crispy potatoes, sweet and sour long beans (very good) and my personal favorite, the the spicy cucumbers!! After several days of eating terrible food and eating excessively, the spicy cucumbers were so fresh and delicious it helped me feel a little bit better about myself.  If they had sold the sauce they put on their cucumbers, I would have bought a bottle on the spot.   For my main, I wanted to try the black truffle ramen I saw recommended all over yelp, but it wasn't available.  I went with the pork ramen instead and it was so perfect.  It wasn't too salty, it had a lot of flavor, and it was nice and warm and helped me feel better about my hangover before I flew home.  It's been a week now, and I live in Minnesota, and I would love nothing more than a hot bowl of their ramen to show up in my arms as I sit here and wait out the snowiest February in our history.    If I was in Vegas again, I'd try to come back here for my last meal to eat that ramen and cucumbers again.

sDjjYh4nXT05RHLIorcoaA.text: This is one of the few restaurants that I must visit when I visit Vegas. The restaurant is spacious and can fit lots of people. What I like about Momofuku is that it has variety in the menu. They have fancy food when you feel like it, but also have basic simple food when you don't feel like going for fancy. My go-to menu is the 5-spice duck ssam. I feel like it's very fulfilling because it has the duck, rice, lettuce, and also the pancakes. It's like an all-in-one dish. I also like to get the pork belly buns fir appetizer.

NEQku8i0ppN0F2qUs6Tu0Q.text: Finally made it here after wanting to try the food for awhile. Wasn't wow'd though and I so wanted to be.  The milk punch cocktail was good. The big eye tune with shaved Foie gras and strawberry's was very good and super interesting. The pork bun and shrimp bun was a little bland. The pork shoulder was ok. Had the crack pie which we were looking forward to the most and sadly disappointed. It was really sweet and just one note of flavor. Servers where nice and view of strip cool. I might eventually give it another try but a lot of restaurants still on my list in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

pVJ8yQ59chdGg2Altybt0g.text: So much fun was had during our dinner !  We hit up Momo since the darn buffet was super crowded. Good for us !  We headed over and got seated right up at the "Bar".  Ask for the "Bar" to watch the chefs prepare the meals. You sit right up next to the kitchen and we watched them cook up right in front of us for an hour.  Great times !  Food was thumbs up.  Had the pork belly buns... ginger scallion noodles and the black cod.  We don't like sweet food, and the black cod is kinda sweet, which is the way it's supposed to be prepared... so our fault.  All else was super.  We even were intrigued by something one of the cooks was making and he saw me looking... and he gave us a free sample.  HUGE.

6dffcdnBuD30CUfPLzzYFA.text: Definetely a different vibe from the NY location, but the food is on point!  Highlights were:  1. Wagyua Tri-Tip: perfectly cooked and seasoned. No complaints here, though I didn't eat it as a wrap!  2. Chilled spicy noodles: perfect blend of flavors and just enough of a kick to make you go back for more. We demolished this plate. 3. Cauliflower and Brussel Sprout: a great side dish, full of flavor. A little salty when eating towards the bottom bc of the sauce. 4. Pork belly bun: just a good piece of pork belly and the bun is soft and delicious. Definitely recommend.  Lowlights: 1. The duck: i was most excited for this dish. I have duck pretty much anywhere that offers it. The duck itself was tougher than usual (even considering duck is usually tough) and the skin wasn't nearly as crispy as I'd like. The portion was ok, but for nearly $50 it was not worth the cost. We left about half on the plate because it left a bad taste in our mouths. They do put shredded duck on the same dish so that was Ok, but obviously not what you're paying a premium for.   Honestly the overall experience was pretty good, and I'd recommend the restaurant generally, just wasn't too pleased with the duck which I was most excited about.  Stay Cheerful ;)

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 5 spiced duck
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork shoulder
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Brussel sprouts and cauliflower

Bga5ZR-6Qz6Ntbzb90_hhQ.text: I know I'll have the unpopular opinion here, but the food here did not stand out to me in any way. Here are the pros and cons:   The duck confit fried rice was too salty and doesn't work as an entree - it makes more sense as a side. It was too much overstated rice and even saltier duck (which is fine, duck should be salted, but it's not that great along salty rice too). Too expensive for a $30+ entree. I don't mind paying a lot for good food, but trust me when I say this was not worth $30.   The ramen was ok. It features the same pork belly you can get from the pork belly buns. The pork belly was dry and tough, not something that melts-in-your-mouth in the way pork belly is meant.   The noodles were expertly cooked and had wondering texture. However the broth was one dimensional. Definitely did not live up to the hype or the $17 price tag.   Service was good, although the table next to us was seated after us and got their food before us. We ordered the pork buns as appetizers  but they came LAST after the fried rice and the ramen. The purified water tastes crisp (worth the $1 charge) and the drink I got was well made. However the food is forgettable and overpriced/overhyped. It feels like something I'd get at a boba cafe, for $12-$15.  It's not a place worth the wait or the price tag in my opinion.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Duck fried rice comes in a stone bowl. Rice was not crispy though, even a little.

f9y1DLonaRJ6_c6cl-iGFw.text: Impressive! This place in Cosmopolitan was a gem.   Chicken Karaage bun-5/5. Tasty,tasty and tasty.  Roasted Mussels-5/5. Fresh and smoky!   Sweet and Sour Long Beans-3/5. The dressing was too much.  Smoked Pork Belly-5/5. The highlight of the visit. Super good.   Spicy Cucumbers-4/5. It's ok.  Cocktails-5/5. Strong and delicious!   We had a super attentive server. We sat at the bar and had a good assessment of the food prepping!   Customers here were happy!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cocktails.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dry Roasted Mussels. Get it.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Long beans. Too saucy

IvOHbouVMR5VUOVwMdzh3w.text: Fantastic meal and drink. The back part of the restaurant is facing the strip and is actually very elegant.  Totally recommened. The best meal and drink i have had in las vegas.

Xi1UlXOmhGtsYuJGeSarnA.text: Chilled spicy noodles and pork buns are the way to go! Would I spend $7 on another pork bun? Probably not, but let me tell you, that pork belly was tender and super soft. It literally melted in my mouth. The chilled spicy noodles were super refreshing and reminded me of pesto. Mm, the al dente noodles w/ candied cashews, sausage smothered in green pesto sauce made my walk on the hot strip to momo worth it! The service wasn't on par, though. It took us a while to flag a waiter down just to order, and the food also took a long time as well.

yyaIP_t_xYbCiC9eKz7z6Q.text: Momofuku has finally landed on the west coast!  Knowing we had a trip to Vegas planned, I was super excited to see that Momofuku had opened in Cosmopolitan. I've eaten at a variety of Momofuku's in NYC and had good experiences and delicious food there, so I was expecting the same here.  The restaurant is located next to Milk Bar and definitely more blingy compared to it's NYC counterparts. Boyfriend and I sat at the bar with a full view of the kitchen, and we watched them crank out dish after dish. We had the pork ramen, pork buns, and spicy rice cakes (with pork). Are you sensing a porky theme here?!  I know it's Vegas, and it's expected you pay a premium for everything here, but the price point even exceeded NYC, which seemed crazy to us. The ramen was just ok and the broth didn't have the richness we were expecting. For some reason, it didn't taste the same as the Noodle Bar version, and the portion size seemed smaller.   The other issue I had was with the pork buns. Please see photos for a side-by-side comparison of NYC Momofuku buns vs. the ones at this location. The pork buns here were incredibly piddly and the amount of pork belly was literally half of what it should be. Definitely not a consistent experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. NYC pork buns.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Vegas pork buns.

5jj7gOBXjRAnf53ObnEZ1A.text: Beautiful ambience but wouldnt come here for a ramen fix. The shouyu ramen was on the oily side and nothing special. Noodles are the thick soft type which I personally dislike as I prefer thin and firm noodles.  On the bright side, certain tables have a usb port. Tables also come with a hook for the bag. If you order tea, the teapot is an interesting space saving design.

8vSlbYivjOJ7uz1Z90zqWA.text: It was a nice surprise to see Momofuku and Milk as new additions to the cosmopolitan. I think these are great restaurants and its much closer than NYC! I had a nice lunch at Momofuku and enjoyed its extended dining area that cant be seem from the front enterance. The decor was sleek and sophisticated with a lot of natural lighting. I had lunch here to catch up with a friend and we both had a very nice time.  I ordered the the pork belly buns, cold spicy noodles, and the fried Brussels sprouts. The pork belly buns were tender and delicious but it was different from NYC. It was lightly fried on the sides to make it crispy whereas in New York, it was sliced and served super delicate and fatty. Even though they were different, I enjoyed both preparations.  I thought the fried brussels sprouts were good but it was drenched in sauce. After eating half, the rest were soggy and swimming in Asian flavored sauce. I will ask for the sauce on the side next time. The spicy noodles had great flavor from the pork sausage but it was way too spicy for me. I will probably not order that again but it would be great for people that love heat.  Overall, I would come back here because of the ambiance and the pork belly buns.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried Brussels sprouts with an Asian vinaigrette
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Deliciously fatty pork belly with a crisp
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Generous side of pork belly

1mlJG4yCwpHEviIB7UKuWw.text: We had a great experience from our first moments at the bar waiting for our reservation as the bar tenders prepared craft cocktails for all of us with just a few comments of drinks that we liked.    Next this restaurant is contemporary and it's beautiful.   Our server was friendly, took his time explaining the menu, and the ordering process.  We ended up giving him a price per person and let him do the rest.  The Sommolier came over and made great wine recommendations and as the bottles came to our table explained his picks and gave us information on the winery.  It's not a cheap restaurant you are going to spend a few bucks here but we thought it was a great value.

PwBzsQpMAYyTstparkN2Ig.text: I've waited years to have a small taste of David Chang's cuisine, and it didn't disappoint. We tried both the pork belly and shrimp buns, the bread has a consistency of a steamed pork bun, but the experience of the texture and flavor with the filling is divine.  The chilled spicy noodles are not cold, more like room temperature and very flavorful. The next time I go I have to try the duck, it looked incredible and it was recommended by our waiter.   Speaking of, the waiter was acceptable, and may have pushed the review to four stars if not for how friendly the bus staff was.  Really made the experience enjoyable.

3enxWIM4qD8BxQ8MiavrjQ.text: Wonderful dishes as expected. I've eaten at two momofuku's in New York and this was almost as good. Great staff and great atmosphere. This place is definitely worth your time. I just think the experience was at such a higher level for me in New York.  We had the shrimp baos, sesame noodles, pork ramen, and crack pie a la mode. Shrimp baos were delish as always. The sesame noodles were well-balanced but lacked a kick in my opinion and my cousin said the pork ramen was just "okay". The crack pie was great!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sesame cold noodles. Nice amount of spicy kick.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crack pie and milk treat a la mode. Yum.

-HYsfDddOCMLp2KMofoQVQ.text: Okay, so let me be frank. The food was fantastic. We had the pork Ramen, amazing! The broth is masterfully flavorful. The noodles were perfectly cooked. So delicious. We also tried the Shishito peppers, pork bun, and fish bun. The peppers could've used some acid added to them. But the buns were amazingly delicious.

3_87qODsm2tmbsMClIkIFQ.text: I've heard great things about Momofuku and decided to give this place a try. I ordered the ginger scallion noodles and spicy chicken sandwich. The ginger scallion noodles were initially fine, tasty, and not overpowering. But as I dug deeper into the bowl there was a pool of oil at the bottom that was very off-putting. With each bite I could feel the oiliness becoming more and more prominent. The actual noodles were cooked fine and the flavor was light, but the oil brought everything down. The spicy chicken sandwich was okay, but unforgettable. I probably would not return to this restaurant as there are a lot of other choices in Vegas.

eK23svQsfemYwevfRwuSgA.text: Wow, wife and I REALLY enjoyed our visit here, the food is   good. I'd say the hype is real, for the most part. We just about had a feast, and sure did leave satisfied!  Started with Shishito peppers. Butt simple, Grilled and sprinkled with smoked salt.   Next were two "buns", one shrimp and the other Shiitake mushroom. These were fantastic. I was a little put off when they appeared because they don't look like Asian style steamed buns, but rather like a taco. Deconstruction aside, the fillings were so good, the Shiitake bun was pretty simple, sauteed mushrooms/scallions/ cucumber. Good meat like flavor and texture addictive savor that I spent zero time thinking about because it was so good. The shrimp bun was its equal, and sort of had a St. Paul sandwich kind of consistency and flavor. It was actually a shrimp cake, instead of individual shrimp, Not sure if "deep" or "pan" but it was fried. A little spicy, a little mayo, some pickled red onion/ shredded lettuce....I'm telling you, very St. Paul sandwich like.  Next up were cold Sichuan noodles. Loved them. Wheat noodles, with a pesto kind of sauce with Sichuan sausage basil and candied cashews. I sort of expected this to be sweeter than it actually was from the Cashews but really not so. The one mild let down was the chicken which was a little dry, and really could have benefited from some kind of condiment or dipping sauce kind of thing. I'll have to take one star for that, but all in all we really enjoyed our meal here!

OiQTAqVADBKSFt85fqCUww.text: This place is not a 2 dollar sign restaurant.  its one of the most expensive restaurants in Vegas.  fried chicken here costs over a $1000.  I may be back to order a main dish if  I start making a seven digit salary or if I hit the jackpot. I thought the overpriced bao would be good but it turned out being under average.  The pie was okay though

dqWxXEc1J8i4OyU9p0NrNA.text: Had a quick lunch here during a conference. Got two things:   1. Karage Bao - MUST HAVE. This was one of the best non-pork buns I've ever had. The skin on the chicken was way different from what I'm used to. It was light and airy, while still being super crispy. Refreshingly different from other karage I've had.   2. Pork Belly Ramen - OKAY. 3/5 stars. I've had a lot of good ramen in my life....this was decently good but not the best I've ever had. Probably still one of the better ramen options in vegas though.   Service was excellent.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Ramen

c7k0XmG5ooIuRV8_sO27Kg.text: A5 potatoes were way too salty.  The wagyu on top was overpowered.  Waste of good beef.  Setting was nice and prompt service.  Just be delicate with the salt.

WiV0tunEE2B6U9nRHDPL5g.text: I think we were under dressed.  We had kids with us.  We didn't know what we were getting into, but we saw the menu and liked the food.  The wait staff was really nice and the assistant GM (Victor) was great.  They dropped a piece of chicken while delivering it to the table, so they comped us the dish and gave us a new one.  The duck was well worth it.  Best duck and chicken I've had.  I recommend this place.  You can't beat a good meal and good service.

tzsVWSqAxCF7mgi0oTdLIQ.text: In the mood for some high-end ramen? If yes, then this is the place for you. My girlfriend and I like to consider ourselves ramen connoisseurs and thus we have high expectations when it comes to broth and noods.  We both ordered the chickpea ramen and added shiitake mushrooms to it. The mushrooms were OUT OF THIS WORLD. The noodles were fresh and encompassed the perfect amount of chew. The broth was light yet flavorful. However, beware chickpeas can make one rather gaseous...so make sure you're comfortable with your significant other if you choose to take them there.  Pro tip: ask to sit near the window. There is a beautiful view of the strip.

BNrZnSbd7nHk0yQ6Gv001w.text: Momofuku is finally here and I could not be anymore excited. Reservation was set for 8:30pm checked in and the girls up front were very nice and professional. Told us our table would be ready shortly. As we waited we grabbed a quick drink at the bar.  I had the Suntory Highball, definitely different with a very subtle taste. My friend had another specialty drink that was very tasty, I just cannot recall the name.   Our table was ready and we were greeted by our server Tao who did a phenomenal job in taking care of us. He explained the menu in very brief detail and gave us a few minutes to look over it.   Starters, we had their Momofuky Oysters. I did not have any as I am not a fan of oysters but by the way they killed those oysters my best bet was that they were delicious.  Brussels sprouts were cooked perfectly. Crunchy on the outside and nice and soft in the inside.  Then we had the Pork ramen which I loved. The piece of pork that came with it literally melted as you took a bite. It was my favorite thing in the ramen, I just wished there was more. Good flavor overall and the noodles were cooked perfectly.   For the main entree we had the Bo Ssam. Slow-roasted cooked pork shoulder. Yeezus was this freaking amazing. The pork was beyond tender. The meat would fall apart as you would dig your utensils in it. Very rich in flavor and color. It was served with white rice, kimchee, lettuce and sauces. Best thing we had that night... (mouth waters).   Dessert time, or as I call it my favorite part. We had the Chocolate chocolate cookie and the Blueberry + cream. Both were very good just wished they had more of a chew to them. And of course we had to try the self serve milk cereal. It was served in a mug topped with cereal and a little bit of chocolate drizzle. This dessert was really weird to me as it actually tasted like the left over milk from your cereal bowl. Definitely a must try as it was unique and delicious at the same time.   Thank you Neil for setting up our reservation and taking real good care of us. Momofuku is for sure going to be a huge hit here for all the locals and tourist in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Self serve milk cereal.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bo Ssam. Delicious!!!!!!
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork ramen.

lB__HgBDK5v_OxSMZXYAYA.text: Located inside The Cosmopolitan, which for the time being still offers free parking.  I came with a co-resident to celebrate the end of our month of night float together. We made a reservation for two for Wednesday at 6:30PM about a week before dining. The restaurant is actually fairly spacious inside (though it doesn't look so from the entrance), but given the popularity, I would probably recommend making a reservation or else be prepared for a long wait. The interior is gorgeous and very sleek/modern. This restaurant is still only a few months old, after all.  Our server checked on us regularly and explained a lot to us. He was friendly but then we overheard him make an almost identical spiel to a neighboring table, so it felt somewhat scripted.   The menu is not too large, and there are some very tasty looking "large format" meals on the backside good for larger groups. Things can get very pricey, but there are also more moderately priced and filling dishes such as ramen.  My co-resident and I decided to splurge and share a bunch of dishes, including three desserts. We ended up spending about $90 each, though you definitely easily could have spent both more or less, depending on what you ordered.  My yuzu lemonade was sweet and fragrant, but definitely not sour enough for me for a lemonade, and it was not a very big glass for $8 (plus had a good amount of ice).  The "bao" were tasty, though to be honest, I picture a closed circular bun when I hear the word "bao," not the open faced kind that these are. Sure, the buns as served here are a type of bao, but I would not default to this type with the word bao alone (but I'm biased by Chinese usage).  The steamed whole branzino was the winner of the night, with extremely tender meat. Although it was described as steamed, it was probably steamed to cook but then pan-seared to finish.   Overall, the food is tasty, but I would describe it as Asian-inspired more than Asian fusion, as the dishes still felt primarily western.  The desserts were tasty too and from Milk Bar next door, though many items were a bit sweet for my tastes.    Overall, I can see what all the hubbub is all about, and I would definitely recommend trying Momofuku out; now you don't have to travel to the East Coast to do so!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Compost cookie, blueberries and cream cookie, soft serve, and crack pie.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy cold noodles.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Whole steamed branzino.

YBQbs4EjTz-M4vTz1wvVIg.text: Very cool, trendy, spot serving up tasty Asian bites..... Okay I'm a little biased since my brother works here.  But for what it's worth the entire staff, hostess, server, kitchen staff, and bus boys were super friendly and helpful.    We came in with a large group and ordered a bunch of stuff from their menu.  I was disappointed some of the stuff id seen on Yelp weren't on the menu but I guess they rotate their menu items frequently.    Goofing around my friend out his fork on the ground and it was almost instantly picked up.... Hahaha.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. More kitchen staff
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kitchen staff

X3CWgNBvGria2viNL0-GTg.text: Oh my gosh. Too bad there isn't a Momofuku restaurant in Chicago. The chilled noodles I had were so amazing. Best dish I've had in a while. I sat at the bar. It gave me a great view of the preparations. A watched a chef assemble a tomato salad and it took him nearly ten minutes due to his attention to detail. Wow!  I dined here twice during my recent Vegas visit.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

uB7065d3P3nw5xj3AwQJVw.text: The view is really awesome, from where we sat we could watch the Bellagio fountains go off, can't get better than that.  Awesome food and service, the highlight is the duck, carved at the table and served with steamed buns, very nice technique and very tasty. Thank you for the awesome hospitality, will return for sure!

ZPwq9tnwlPpSNb5AYWxdhQ.text: I'll dream about the steam bun for the rest of my days on Earth. We sat at the bar and it was really neat to watch everyone whipping up dishes behind the glass.

anORcuHBUniDBXTOIVz3lg.text: I'll admit, I was one of those who saw this restaurant as a "must-try" like most people after watching Ugly Delicious / Chef's Table on Netflix. I've been to Majordomo twice and once I took off my rose-colored glasses the second time, I was severely disappointed by the experience. But I wouldn't be doing my due diligence if I didn't try his other restaurant.  To put it short, the food in general was extremely over-salted and relied so heavily on fish sauce. I don't believe the cooks know how to use fish sauce properly as some of the food was practically inedible. The service wasn't great either, and it was similar to what we had experienced at Majordomo...waiters were waiting around by the bar/kitchen and it took forever to get any service (The manager was nice however...something needs to be done with some of the servers. They were basically getting free money by doing nothing). The restaurant wasn't even busy. We even got charged $1 / person for tap water...which is something I've never encountered...even in peak drought periods in Los Angeles. All in all, more ugly than delicious.  + BRUSSELS SPROUTS AND CAULIFOWER - This was one of those dishes that was poorly done...primarily cause the cook did not know how to use fish sauce properly. After each bite, I had to drink water to wash it down. We had to send this one back.  + KALBI WAGYU TRI-TIP - The meat was tough and the dish wasn't particularly amazing  + GRILLED ASPARAGUS - The best dish of the night. Primarily since i've never had asparagus as juicy as this.  + PORK BELLY BUNS - To their credit, the pork belly was cooked well..melted in your mouth. Other than that...pretty unspectacular for that $7 price tag. I'd recommend finding a place in San Gabriel Valley for a lot cheaper.  + CHILLED SPICY NOODLES - Good texture on the noodles and good level of flavor.  All in all, not worth the hype. I'd recommend going elsewhere in Vegas (but definitely stop by for Milk Bar).

982qdbgAbeZ8_9WbtToRZA.text: I'm not sure what happened to my last review when I first came here in April.  It somehow vanished, or maybe I wrote a draft and it disappeared?  Anyway, my visit in April was terrible.  I sat at the bar that went right along the kitchen.  The service was subpar that visit.  I was also recommended a rice dish that I didn't particularly enjoy.  I don't remember what kind of chicken on a bed of rice type of dish it was, but the rice to chicken ratio just wasn't to my liking.  Overall, I felt like I was ignored and nobody really came and checked on me.  I clearly remembered these two hot girls sitting perpendicularly adjacent to me (I was at the end of the bar) at the bar and obviously they got tons of attention from the wait staff but who can blame them.  I had ordered an iced tea and I might have had one refill the entire night and that was after I had to call somebody over.  I heard too many good reviews that I had to try this place again.  Yet again, I sat at the bar again because I was by myself.  I ordered the pork belly bun and it was still amazing.  This time, I ordered the pork ramen which was off the menu.  The menu only had 2 cold noodle dishes listed but luckily my waitress said that the ramen did exist and the girl that sat next to me also had ordered it. The components in the ramen were awesome, there was shredded pork, some veggies, a couple of soft boiled/poached eggs, and a wonderfully cooked piece of pork belly.  The pork belly had great texture to it.  The broth was amazing, the ramen were cooked to perfection.  I demolished that bowl of noodles like nobody's business. This time around, the wait staff was much more attentive.  I got my water refilled a bunch of times, my waitress came and checked in on me.  It was also fun talking to the chefs and asking what they were making and cooking back there.    I'm glad I gave Momofuku another chance.  I was bitter and angry at what happened at my first visit, but they made up for it this visit.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beginning of a pork shoulder dish,  saw the chefs bring it out.  These are huge,  the giant bowls make it look small.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork ramen
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bun

zCbvHneRqFMaRySQfUFoAA.text: I do, I did, I done it. It's all the same Momfuku NY, Momofuku Vegas, it's just Momofuku. Them buns tho. No not the bartenders, the ones on my plate. But better yet, my eyes zoomed in on the word CHILLED. At 110F degrees outside. I needed something chill, and nothing better then Chilled Spicy Shezuan Noodles. Hands down, some of the tastiest chilled noodles I've had. The soft delicate texture of the noodles and the mix of cashews, pickled peppers, sausage and small greens, just had me slurping it up non-stop. I recommend this bowl to anyone waiting for the world to end.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

JE4gZuoI8EOenrECkpW37Q.text: A great solid choice with a great view.  We have a Momofuku in DC closer to home, but this one was the only one that really caught our eye and made us want to go in. Besides, it's in Vegas. Splurge a little. We went on an off time because we just checked in and we were hungry.  The place is well kept and stylish. The servers were all cheerful and helpful. We had no clue what to get, but in the end, we were able to get the dishes we were looking for. We ordered the pork ramen with their gochujang sauce and some chili oil. I ordered the salmon sandwich.  The salmon sandwich was pretty good. It would benefit with more flavor in the sauce as the salmon flavor overpowered the whole dish. Besides that, the ramen tasted fresh and there were no complaints on that end. Thus, it may be the dish that I ordered, but it was still a well cooked piece of salmon.   We did had the cucumber as starters and it reminded us of the Din Tai Fung cucumber appetizer in Taiwan... Just with pistachios or peanuts. It was a memorable dish in Taiwan so when we tasted this version, we instantly thought about the one in Taiwan.   The decor was awesome with a high ceiling. The view over the strip was beautiful. Don't think they needed lights as the light from the windows was enough. Kind of wished we came here for dinner to see how the lighting affected the ambiance. When we peered in at night, it looked cool.   For the price point and the service we received, I would say it doesn't get any better than this. We definitely spend more than what we spent here in Vegas and came out less satisfied. Thus, this place deserves 5 stars in my book.

APmb3JKXlvL3TQZW7uBzcA.text: Tried this place since we were trynna get our Vegas trip to a minimum this year and was told this place was pretty good.  We got there and there was no wait unlike other really good restaurants on the strip. We got the roasted potatoes and string beans as appetizers and everyone got a bowl of the Shoyu Ramen.  The appetizers were good; however, I was definately not a fan of the ramen.  It was wayyy too salty.  I usually get tonkotsu when it comes to ramen but they only offered either shoyu or chickpea. The porkbelly was good but the shredded pork they put in it is kinda weird and bland.  Their poached egg was way too raw for me.  Overall I just didnt like it at all, and for the price? I wouldnt go again.

O1XKOGPqTmjZUkrhBZfGlQ.text: The ambience in this place is AMAZING!!!! Views for days of the strip. So beautiful. The interior is really cool and warm.  This place was easy to get into on a Saturday night. The service was a little slow to get a drink. But the food is really good! My friend and I shared the Salmon - and I would definitely NOT recommend the Salmon...unless you're a die hard salmon fan. Anyway - the drinks were awesome and the appetizers were key. Don't Skip out on the Pork Buns. That's worth coming to this place alone!  The bathroom was kind of a joke because they only had 1 toilet for girls and 1 for boys and it was a bidet! So it took forever just to use the bathroom because I'm sure everyone was enjoying their sweet time on the bidet....I mean... If I wasn't headed to a show later, and I had the time, I may have enjoyed it myself.  Anyway - Come here because #1 it's in the Cosmo. #2 The Pork Buns ('nuff said) #3 The Cake balls. I don't do dessert - but I will do some delicious cake balls.   Also - there were people here in fancy clothes all the way to swimsuit cover ups. So I don't really think there's a dress code.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The Salmon :)
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Very cool atmosphere
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Just checkin in!

GLb3H0EvA5r7o8JJOrXzEg.text: They charge you for the tap water lollll I guess the restaurant is in the desert? Customer service could've been better and the portion is relatively small compared to what you pay. Not planning on coming back.

cQADMWaxuEjxlcv-img22A.text: Worth every penny! Came in here today for lunch, got seated right away by a nice waitress. I asked for some recommendations from her and went with the spicy cucumber salad and the lamb ribs. The salad was fresh, crunchy and refreshing, different in a good way. The lamb ribs were one of the best dishes I've ever tried. The meat was so tender it just slid right off the bone. The spicy yogurt sauce wasn't very spicy at all and really added to the taste of the meat. The portion was a nice size, certainly big enough for an entree in my opinion. The service was super speedy. I always had refills and the food came out really fast. Last but not least, I couldn't pass up the birthday cake. Amazing. Just get it. It's big enough for 2 people so don't let the $14 scare you. It's massive. I cannot wait to come back here.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Birthday cake
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sichuan Lamb Ribs

GDgikVh7AB2y782U6pH2qg.text: So I wandered into the Cosmo and wanted something quick and tasty and saw this spot with open seats at the bar, looked at the menu, saw pork belly buns and took a seat.    After further inspecting the menu I realized that most items on the menu were a little pricey, but I decided to stay and go with original plan and get some buns and spicy cucumbers.   I ordered an old fashioned, perfectly crafted and delicious. The bartender was super friendly.  The bar manager walks over and asks if I have any allergies and then hands me spicy cucumbers on the house. Mind readers?! I then instead ordered the smoked mussels and what a good decision it was. The smoked flavor was mind blowing. Will definitely be coming back here next time in Vegas!

XEvZNOe0y3VDUJJFBe8iDw.text: 6 lobster tails and a larger number of fried shrimp that I can't recall. Says it serves 2-4 but 3 big eaters could barely eat two thirds of this bowl.   Those cucumbers with macadamia nuts were delicious.  Pass on all buns, except the pork belly.  And finally, the chilled spicy noodles (not pictured) were the highlight of my night. That and the birthday cake!   Thanks Momofuku for a delightful birthday celebration!

7DCKbRWXJHtwnxrkrkMygw.text: Strangely I enjoyed this meal better than Momofoku NYC. Came mid-afternoon and shared a few things as a group:  Pork ramen delicious spicy cold noodles - a star of the meal. Loved the spice Pork bun - VERY tasty but still hard for me to wrap my head around the $7 price tag :oP Brussel Sprouts - tasty but a little heavily dressed for me.  Still a solid place to visit. service was great and TONS of space. If you can't make it to NYC I reco stopping by.

OJzTYa9p4AIObW0cDAZilA.text: First time at Momofuku. Great service from the entire staff. Ordered the large plate duck meal for four and still had leftovers. Our server, Danielle, was great and Hadley carved the duck table side (see the picture) and kept us entertained. Thanks for a great evening and experience!
