JGf94i9oUimMY-By7Kkm7A.text: We spent half an hour traveling to the restaurant today for lunch only to find they were closed for a corporate event???  If you can post your hours on Yelp and Google why can't you post when you are closed to the public?  Highly disappointed and think the restaurant is overrated and prices exceed the quality.  Last time we attempt to visit...

5QB_WqsgIN2Tth4aR43Qkw.text: Great service ! Great food.. the shoyu pork ramen flavor is awesome.the noodles was served fresh! good job

xWYfrjHQEkHZYgAYioEmPg.text: I was super excited to try this place since it's gotten a lot of hype due to David Chang's fame. I got the pork ramen and shrimp bao. Both were good, but not anything to write home about unfortunately.  The venue was really large, so we didn't have a wait (though we did also get there really early for lunch). The food came out fairly quickly and the restaurant was super accommodating to one of our party who was in a rush since she was heading to the airport immediately after.  The shrimp bao was okay. It comes out in patty form, but has a good chunkiness to it so you know it's really shrimp. Unfortunately, it was a bit under flavored. The ramen was also good, but not what I was hoping for. I love a great, creamy, pork tonkatsu. However, the type of soup they use here is not creamy, just broth. I tried to mix the poached egg in there to give it some creaminess which made it better. The gochujang sauce is a must and makes it so much better.

UBGQVQR4AJ_VGa-vJzGMtw.text: Worth the price! We had oysters, pork buns, prepared peppers with nutritional yeast, amazing cocktails, salt and pepper lobster and shrimp (Jesus christ that was stupid delicious), and finished off with crack pie al a mode. Have really enjoyed watching David Chang on various cooking shows and was happy to see him hire competent staff to run this restaurant. Really enjoyed the art work/murals by David Choe........guess those guys really are buds!

J5QBkrx5vf9hnAZhbXHZnQ.text: First time here on black Friday night. Had reservations for dinner.  Checked in 15 min early and was seated promptly.  The place was packed and they had hip hop dance music playing kind of in the style of the Roots.   Ambienc e is like that of a lively bar.  Noise level is above average.  Service was quick and precise.  Just a note if you want ramen it's not on the men so ask for the options.  We ordered the  -White Sturgeon Caviar Bun $32 -Pork Belly Bun $7 -Truffle Ramen $50 -Chilled Spicy noodles $16 -Crack pie $6.50  They all tasted great.  If you like truffles I'd definitely recommend the ramen.  Also note they don't serve the egg soft boiled, it is dropped in easy Sunny side up.  Some of the stuff is a little pricey, so the unaqauinted may have sticker shock on some of the menu items.  All in all nothing I can complain about, good service, great food I liked the music.  Good job David Chiang.

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bun
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy noodles

nwkOpKnhcK6ZYZzukiv_0w.text: Came here because I am a huge David Chang fan. However, I have not tried his amazing food before. Finally, the time has happened, and I got to try out Momofuku. We had a party of 4, my friend, her husband, my fiance and me.   Ok, just to let anyone know that they do not take walk-in if you are going to dine there. The part of the restaurant that does take walk-in in the bar area. Where they have a smaller set menu. Since my friend couldn't get a reservation at an earlier time we had no choice but did the walk-in bar, and by the way... there is at least about a 40 min wait for seating, and this was at 5:00 pm.   The pricing... It is very expensive. I don't know if Momofuku is considered fine dining because where we were at (the bar), I would not consider it fine dining. So... if you are a David Chang fan, please note you will need to save money to eat here. On that note of money... They do charge $1 for their 7 filtered water on your receipt; however, it is all you can drink for the water. The water itself is DAMN GOOD, and since they are charging you $1 for water (where you can find it else for free) drink all the water you can get.    Decor/Cleanliness I didn't get to see the inside of the restaurant since I was at the bar area. So I'll tell you what the dining experience is like there. The bar area looks like a hip bar with Korean/Japanese inspiration for the decor. Honestly... it made me feel like I was dining in a small Japanese noodle house. The place is immaculate! So don't worry about dirty or sticky surfaces cause they got you covered.    Food Grilled Lamb Ribs (Cucumber, chili yogurt) - Hell to the yes, so good! So tender and pulls off the bone so easily. Get that of all things.  Whole Jidori Chichen (curry, lime, Kimchi) - It's good, however... not my favorite thing that we ordered. Their kimchi is on the side, so you don't need to worry about kimchi in the chicken. The skin is very good and flavorful.  Ginger Scallion Noodles (pickled shiitake, cucumber, wakame) - Yes, cause you need some carbs in your meal! Crack pie (Milkbar) - YUM! $6 Just get it.  Birthday Cake (Milkbar) - Damn it's good. For $14 a slice.... I know how labor intensive this particular slice of cake is and I would say yes get it.   Service Excellent service, although I have to say they can work on their refill drinks for anything other than their delicious water. For their drink service for water, OMG! They are all about it! Your glass will get filled before it hits the bottom. I got the ice tea, and they were not really up to par on that service. However, everything else was wonderful! Their servers were very professional and helpful. The food will come out on time, and their staff does work well as a team, so you have to be impressed regarding that.   Overall Experience  4.5 Stars! Rounding up 5 Stars. My only gripe is the price. For the amount they charge, it's a lot! Including it's not a lot of food. It is the correct portion amount, where you are not disgustingly over stuff. You are not 100% full nor 90% full. You are mostly about 75% full. We could have ordered more, but for what reason? To burn a hole in your wallet? However.... I do value David Chang's efforts of his creation, the location of his restaurant and also staffing the chefs and the team; and I hope he is paying them fairly. Therefore... I'll stop griping about the cost for the meal and the experience. The food is excellent, the service was wonderful, and the decor will take you out of your usual surroundings. My recommendation are... bring people who like to eat, don't bring your kids... it's probably wasted on them, and they are better off eating something cheaper. A perfect place to impress a date, have an excellent meal with your adult friends and family members.   Happy Eating Everybody!

fYyOPx0SYCWEp7jM9zFARg.text: The pork belly bao was amazing. It also comes with a spicy sauce on the side that is pretty much good with everything. The pork belly ramen was really good. A lot of flavor in the broth. We also got the bigeye salmon and that was really good but it is a little on the smaller side. Atmosphere is very cool and has some pretty good views.

ITwcf7kztzFB6sgzwKEAUw.text: Here's what we ordered  Food:  Spicy Cucumbers, Roasted Artichoke w/ Aioli (special), Pork Belly Bun, Shrimp Bun, Ginger Scallion Noodles, Steamed Whole Branzino  Drinks: Hitachino Nest - White Ale Firestone Walker 505 - Blonde Ale Two custom made to order virgin fruity drinks for our daughters (like strawberry lemonade) Still Water  The food was really good.  The roasted artichoke was a bit bitter due to the over burnt leaves, but still pretty tasty. We never roasted our artichoke, so that was a unique way to cook it.  The aioli sauce was delicious with the artichoke.  Everything else was very well done and the noodles are ridiculously tasty.  I don't know if they hand make them or get them hand made, but they are great.  The Hitachino Nest was good, but for $17 I expected to be totally impressed.  The Firestone Walker 505 was really tasty.  As for the water, this is why the score didn't nail it.  Vegas still water is like licking a penny.  A suggestion to add lemon slices to the water is helpfu.

fr6x3ZDrpCZs6iUZmYI6Ig.text: Review for 3/27/18  Went for lunch and sat at the bar.  Not overly crowded, got a seat immediately.  Attentive and friendly bartender.  Two draft beer options was surprisingly limited but found one to my liking without issue.  Got pork bun and the pork ramen. Enjoyed both a lot.  Would come back

ptH9U8yB2cC9k-akAceZ9A.text: An amazing dining experience.  Our waiter told our group of nine to give him a budget for price per head, and that he would wow us. Well, wow us he did. After tax and tip, for about $90 per person, we got:  Sashimi appetizer Cucumber with avocado Stir fried noodle with seaweed and mushroom Pork belly buns Shrimp buns Whole fish Lobster and shrimp Aged steak  Everything was delicious, generously portioned, and ultimately we wound up taking home some of the lobster as well as steak. Service was prompt and always pleasant and energetic, and this was easily the best dining experience our group had during our trip. Highly recommend paying this place a visit!

hKAATmABkd7zMzwXivKEYg.text: We ordered a ginger noodle that was recommended a lot on yelp and a spicy noodle. The ginger noodle was good, but wasnt as amazing as I was hoping for. The spicy noodle on the other hand went beyond our expectations. It was so tasteful and my husband and I both loved it.

2tHLBt5c3OKq5o4h4rJB1g.text: Had a great time at Momofuku Vegas. I had heard about this restaurant on one of the Ringer Podcast Network podcasts (either Bill Simmons or House of Carbs) and drug the family, Mom, Dad, two boys 13 & 11, down to the Cosmo to try it out.  The food was great. We tried three apps- cucumbers/crispy potatoes/peppers. The family loved the Crispy Potatoes and Spicy Cucumbers, but the Shishito Peppers were my favorite (could have been spicier).  Then we ordered three bowls and 2 orders of the pork buns. The pork buns were great, as expected (I've never had a bad pork bun) Bo Ssam Bowl, Ginger Scallion Noodles, and Shoyu Pork Ramen bowls were also very good. We passed them around, and everyone had their favorites. We were stuffed.  The service is tricky to review. Our waiter was adequate, but not terribly attentive. I would have dropped this review to 3 stars, had it not been for our seating location and our interaction with the back of the house staff.  If you can swing it, get a seat at the bar facing into the kitchen. The the food prep was not only fun to watch, but Zach was like our personal chef- answering all of our questions about the menu, the dishes we ordered and were eating. He told us some of the Chang story and generally made the meal. He inquired about our background and made us feel like we were the only ones in the restaurant.  Thanks again, Zach!  @ringer @thehouseofcarbs @momofukulasvegas

yL3JYUlc7NjVDSsl61ZRNg.text: This is the one meal I was looking forward to while in town and I actually made a reservation in advance. Well my overplanning screwed me over because we arrived one day earlier than our actual reservation ! Thankfully, the staff at the hostess stand were very sweet and able to get us in that evening. I would still recommend making a reservation as this is one of the hot dining spots at the Cosmopolitan. Just verify date and time before you arrive. ;)  On to the food--- the menu is simple . I browsed and read reviews in advance so I would have an idea of what to expect. Our server suggested the V&S cocktail which was a mix of vodka, soda , and lemon verbena. It was a bit too tart and bitter for my taste . And $15 ! But to be expected.  We ordered a few appetizers to start-- the spicy cucumber was crunchy , spicy and nutty . I ordered the Shitake Bun (one bun per order) and it was substantial and flavorful. My husband had the Chicken Karaage one which was actually recommended by our server and he seemed to enjoy!  For our entrees, I had the Chickpea Ramen which I was so excited to try! It was nice to have a vegetarian option where they thought of everything including the broth. Most places don't go to that length. The chickpeas were crispy with a nice bite to them and there were ample pieces of bok Choy (my favorite!!!)  . The dish was so delicious and filling. My husband ordered the Smoked Pork Chops. Thankfully he enjoyed (it's a steep $36). They presented it sliced on a plate so all you have to do is eat! Lol.   They offer dessert from Milk Bar next door but we decided to walk over instead.     Overall, great dining experience. The restaurant is hip with a cool mural on the wall as a backdrop. Music is a tad louder than I would like (yes I sound like that person) . Especially when the server has to yell across the music lol.   Great asian option while in Vegas and yay for plenty of vegetarian options!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chickpea Ramen
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Smoked Pork Chop entree
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy cucumber

B_XuDubcUHiE_Oi7uZwy2A.text: Located on the second floor right next to Milk at Cosmopolitan Hotel. I've always wanted to try this place but never had the time to the last time I was in New York. I was excited to see this place open up in Las Vegas.   Sad to say, I was disappointed by the taste and price. We ordered one Pork Bao Bun ($7) and two Pork Ramens ($18 each). Overall, the presentation was well-done. The Pork Bao Bun was delicious (only reason why I gave this place a 3-star, not 2). The bun was soft and warm. The oyster sauce and the gochujang sauce made it savory and sweet. The pork was soft and had a charred, smoky taste to it. However, the ramen was definitely not worth it. Personally, I prefer a thick tonkatsu soup when it comes to ramen. The Momofuku soup was too light and did not have a lot of depth/flavor. The soup was sweet, not savory. I wish there was a little kick/spice to it. I think that would've made it better but didn't want to pay extra $1 for chili oil. It was also weird that they put shredded chicken in the soup. I felt like it didn't really go well with the ramen and the pork. However, the portion was pretty big even though it was pricy.   We were looking for a good hangover soup, but this place wasn't the right choice for us.  For the same price or with a little more, I feel like you can get something way better. I personally would opt out for a brunch buffet next time.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Bun ($7)

XjFaoJ-OSmDZiyrn9ImOiw.text: A little expensive, but all of the food was delicious.  Didn't realize I was going to be charged for tap water, but whatever

IGRkc8Hah0OvAM142HBc8A.text: I was so hyped to go here after seeing mind of a chef, and following David Chang for awhile now. Suuuuper disappointed - only thing I'd write home about MIGHT be the shrimp bun.  If you don't have too many options to ramen you might consider coming here - but as I'm coming from Socal/Norcal - there are so many better options.

pwF6QAxf9mkSxvqOXSnEbQ.text: Outstanding food.  We loved it all, especially the pork buns which are always the best at a Momofuku. Our server, Tara, made excellent recommendations.  We highly recommend this place.  Best bet is to get serveral (5-6) smaller dishes which they bring out one at a time for maximum enjoyment. The decor was great. The staff was incredibly friendly.   Really good lunch.

_yfDXtaPb8fZl0F0GmMMtQ.text: My boyfriend and I went to visit Monofuku a few weekends ago. We waited about 15 minutes to be seated on a Saturday afternoon. We had amazing service and the vibe in the restaurant is great! I would highly recommend this spot if youre in vegas!

MTolpP0IKHmtl6VHuH4y5A.text: Overall the food was really good here and definitely worth a try. I really like the pork belly and chicken karage buns, definitely super worth.  So you read the top part and say to yourself "why 1 star?!?!?" 100% because the hostesses were snobby, mean, rude, and was the definition of RBF with the signature move eye rolls. Is it fair to judge a restaurant by their hostesses? Yes it is because no matter how great the good was the only thing I can remember with this restaurant was how rude and mean they were.   Sour taste in my mouth.

9ivJRK8DG5wdU9M0sYIe1Q.text: Great experience. Josh provided excellent service and coached us through the menu deftly. Our party of four shared several dishes including country ham and bisquits with red eye aioli, pork belly bun, big eye tuna with fois gras and noodles with pickled mushrooms. Dessert comprised of great cookies from the Milk Bar next door. Will return soon and ask for Josh.

RqzNuZJ7DJAMbzO1-spujg.text: Can't stop loving on this place. Absolutely LOVE the pork belly bao here. The pork belly just melts in your mouth and it's so savory! Plus that bao bun though. Light, chewy, perfect. We stopped by for a quick snack because I can't get enough of this stuff ;) They're also bringing in some more Hitachino beers, which is a double win in my books!  We also got the dry roasted mussels. A bit too bacon-y for us...is there such a thing?? Haha I guess we weren't expecting such a strong bacon taste, but the mussels themselves were great!

AbMxD-AICml9H_HKWvkfNw.text: Came here for a late night bite with my boyfriend and we were seated at the bar. We both ordered pork ramen, which has pork belly and shoulder, an egg, and other tasty ingredients in it. I thought it was pretty good. I liked the broth, meat, and egg but the noodles were overly cooked for me.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

NlZcPlzmWmMiXJy9GHVg2A.text: First time here on Black Friday. The food and service is awesome. We will definitely be back. We were lucky to have Josh as our bartender/server. He was great! He made us custom cocktails off the menu and was friendly and fun. We ordered the escolar, pork and shrimp buns as well as the Chinese broccoli, spicy noodles, and cucumbers. Nothing was disappointing. And Josh comped our drinks! Definitely would recommend this to anyone who hasn't tried it yet!  Came back again Saturday for lunch. We had the shiitake bun, cucumbers, pork ramen, chickpea ramen, and the BFC cookie. Everything was awesome! Josh and Leah provided us great service and gave us complimentary sake and cucumbers! This place is awesome

6-DPV9FcWauEQ0ZWlM4c3w.text: It was our first time here and this place is straight fire! Food is absolutely delicious! The shrimp avocado rice bowl is an explosion of flavor with some heat! The pork belly bun and shrimp bun are amazing! Definitely recommend!

v0RlLqowsZ_eB0UAcMyBDw.text: It wasn't as great as I expected. The service was phenomenal. But the food was meh. And coldish

pSIBuqP1dew4aXjelv4CjQ.text: My favorite meal this round in Vegas! Our table split the pork shoulder and it was DELICIOUS. We had 4 adults splitting the meal and there was still plenty left over. Would highly recommend!!

ozFz_6lLVVk3ZqAHRmbH3Q.text: I am rating this based on three dishes.  The pork buns were good, the shrimp tempura was also good, but the ramen wasn't even close to being good.  I would not come back to this place to order ramen.  I have had better ramen in Hawaii, Los Angeles and of course Japan.  I am sorry that this who never had good ramen may think this is good.  No wonder it is an off the menu order doesn't deserve to be on the permanent menu.   If it wasn't for the pork buns and shrimp this would be a two star rating on the ramen alone.

iTf_vkayP13TAKqAiBlPlQ.text: The pork belly ramen was so delicious. Definitely top 3 ramen I've ever had. The thick chunk of the pork belly was soooo flavorful.  I also liked the pork chops which had great flavors and was perfectly cooked. The dish I didn't really like was the schezuan rice cake. It seemed to be a little too fusion for me. The crack pie was tasty when you eat it with thr ice cream The compost cookie was a little hard. I prefer my cookies to be soft baked. The decor is great with the open kitchen concept.

aVC3n3BM__5fUxUw8g_Tyg.text: I love David Chang and milk bar so I was really excited to visit Momofuku in Vegas. I had the ginger scallion noodles with an egg which was delicious. The pickled mushrooms were so flavorful. I also had the pork belly bun which did not disappoint. The Korean Saam sauce is so tasty!  The service was good but the server was cold and not friendly or personable. I was here for work and dined alone at the bar and he seemed annoyed that I didn't order any drinks. I asked for water and received the filtered tap water that they give everyone. When I got my bill, I noticed they charged me $1 for water. It was such a tacky touch to what would have been an otherwise fantastic meal. A little disappointed overall with the service and silly extra charge. It's only $1 I know, but it left a bad taste.

LIXFf9sxmSj-5M2qCztfhA.text: I was very impressed with our dining experience. The service was spectacular and our server went out of his way to make my husband's birthday memorable. Gregory is a treasure. The food was fresh and tasty, and dessert from Milk Bar was a great way to end the meal. I'd give 10 stars if I could.

p9VOsqdsQUyuO50z9k2Yug.text: Creatively delicious!! I'm an avid David Chang fan and finally came to one of his restaurants after reading and cooking from  his cookbook for yrs.  Tried the Hamachi with ponzu and the spicy cold noodle dish. I like things spicy and it delivered. The noodles were yummy and had the perfect chewiness-- there were a lot of flavors going on--with the sweet crunchy nuts, very savory meat, and pickled spicy pepper slices, all in some kind of pesto like sauce.    Of course finished it off with some 'crack pie' to go.   Buttery goodness.    Best to come with a few folks as dinner serves many and you can try more dishes!!

XvJ32OoG6hlzEsLCvEJihw.text: Not much after posting my review, I was contacted by Victor,  the general manager, who had concerns with my visit. I advised him what the issue was and he was very understanding and apologetic. I believe customer service n satisfaction is high on the priority list when running a business like a restaurant..whether it's the food or bad service. Anyways.. After talking to Victor he made things better which says alot about the restaurant and how it's ran. I will definitely be back and dine with momofuku again..i just won't get the truffle ramen;)

0bNZtY_r74Dg9bW-fU1JZw.text: We made reservations , when we arrived it seemed we didn't need them . We basically received the worst table in the house dead center of the room squished in between other crowded tables . We could see a ton of other 2 top tables in great locations with views . Mostly my fault for not saying anything and getting a better table . That being said, request to be by the windows as their is a nice view .  The service was very good water was always kept full and our server was informative .  The food is not like the pictures and lacked the spice and heat we expected .  The spicy cucumber salad was chunk like and not spicy at all . It was good just no spice . Honey crisp apple kimchi salad was a delicious combination of flavors .   Short rib stew , it's was plenty for 2 people and was very good . Again missing the spice and heat .  Crack pie ala mode for desert was pretty awesome the milk style ice cream is freakin awesome . And the pie is rich .  Honestly once I had the crampt shitty seat I was already not happy so it made the rest of the experience an uphill battle .  The food was good just missing flavor . They can do much better for the price .

7MjfpTGKt3VElHwEjmNh0w.text: The Weekend of Craziness!  I've always wanted to try Momofuku and finally had a chance when my husband and I threw our joint-bachelor/bachelorette party out in Vegas.  For our "fancy" meal, we picked Momofuku  because they were awesome to let us reserve our large party via OpenTable without having to put down our credit card number (I don't know what that annoys me...).  Anyway, since we had a party of 18, the server was really awesome in recommending an on-the-fly prefix menu for our table.  Supposedly, we got the best of Momofuku for $70/person.    I'll just go ahead and tell you my favorite: crispy chicken with caviar.  That chicken was crispy on the outside and salted just right.  The meat itself was tender and juicy.  The only complaint I had was that this dish came out towards the end when I was stuffed with all the other dishes that came before it.  The caviar definitely gave it a nice touch.    The other memorable item I tried there was the seasoned cucumbers.  I don't remember the exact name, but it's a cold appetizer dish.  That was surprisingly very memorable not to just myself, but my sister as well.    Overall, we had a great dinner.  Service was great, especially for such a large party, and we all had a wonderful time.

-sKHuXo1HRvM8Fh98yOJgg.text: Ahhh the restaurant that sparked my "LETS GO TO VEGAS!" mode and had me convincing my boyfriend to take me on a weekend trip (it worked.)  I've been a fan of David Chang foreverrrr (he is listed as my "current crush" on Yelp, lol) never got to visit any of his restaurants before this one so I was stoked. Tried to make reservations, but there weren't any available so we tried our luck at a walk-in around 8pm on Saturday 2/18 and we were seated almost immediately.   Lucky us, we sat right there at the ramen bar where we could watch the chefs! My god, you should have seen my face light up that's exactly where I wanted to sit.   FOOOOOOD:   Spicy cucumbers - yummmmm, mixed together with macadamia nuts and avocado these spicy cucumbers were really good. even my avocado hating guy liked these.   Pickled vegetables - we barely made a dent in this. liked the kimchi a lot, radish didn't seem very pickle-y, melon was my least favorite. should have ordered more cucumbers.   Pork belly buns - typical bao, nothing too special about these. they had a bit too much hoisin and the pork was not crispy like I wanted it to be, had a fatty texture. could have used more cucumbers in here too.   Pork chop small plate - given to us by the chef handling meat. omg, amazing. tender to the point it just melted in your mouth. we seriously wanted to drink the sauce it was served in but kept it classy.   Bo Ssam - we were going to order this as both of our entrees with their large scale dining menu, but glad we didn't as I believe this as a whole meal would be too rich for me. Very flavorful and sweet with a bit a spice and falling apart. glad we got to try it, but not my favorite thing I had.   Black winter truffle ramen - My goodness I didn't think I could have a truffle overload, but this nearly did it. I felt I smelled of truffle for the rest of the night lol, but no complaints at all I loved my bowl of creamy ramen. Noodle were the exact texture I look for, they had a nice chewy bite that made me want to keep eating even though I was super full.   ***** STEAMED WHOLE BRANZINO - best piece of fish I have ever had. tied for best dish I had in Vegas and I do not like cooked fish. the brown butter dashi sauce that came along with the beautiful branzino was amazing. another sauce we wanted to lick from the plate. we were most impressed with this dish, I was so glad the bf ordered it.  Our server was adorable. Bubbly and attentive.  Next time will definitely order the momofuku oysters that I somehow overlooked.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy cucumbers. Loved this.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pickled vegetable plate
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Black winter truffle ramen

y_N8FjXKxTjBQWRyFz0izw.text: Let me tell you. I've seen so much press on this place and it is well deserved. This is the best restaurant I've never eaten in. The service is impeccable. The food is magical.   Start off with a pork belly bao. You just have to. I don't care if you hate pork. Just put it in your mouth and chew and watch the flavors do the tango on your tongue.   Honorable mentions: The mussels: I have no idea how they get so much flavor into those things The brussel sprouts: who thought fish sauce and bacon go together Lamb ribs: so tender. Great yogurt sauce. Genius to add cucumbers as a garnish   After you finish go to MILK. Complete your culinary destiny. All hail David Chang!  UPDATE:  Came again for my mom's birthday this weekend and let me tell you, it was wonderful as ever. The staff is so accommodating and helpful. They really made my mom's birthday special. I tried the slow roasted peel family meal and it was perfect for us. As an Asian person, it's so nostalgic to convene and share a meal family style.   While all the food was wonderful, there was two that were in a league of their own. The salmon and the tuna tartare.   The salmon was so perfectly cooked I was blown away by the delicate kiss of smoke and the prefect medium rare. The accompaniment was perfect; I never knew sunflower seeds could be cooked in such an innovative way.   Let me tell you about this tuna. I have never had such a robust tuna. The texture and freshness of the fish was impeccable. And the fois gras shaved on top added such a delicate smokiness and richness to an already perfect dish.   Compliments to the chef, the servers, and the management. THIS IS THE BEST RESTAURANT I'VE EVER BEEN TO.

AA6LfPnm-aoOmxv6v2s3vw.text: We were really excited to come to one of David Chang's restaurants. I personally didn't believe the hype after seeing his pompous tv show, so we came to see what it's worth. In short, it was pretty disappointing, but the service was spectacular.   On first site, the restaurant looks pretty small - kind of like a small dine in you see at Vegas hotels. But it expands and the restaurant itself is really nice.   Our server, Tosh, was incredibly nice and so were the other busboys. We ordered two baos, the pear and burrata salad, and the salt and pepper lobster and shrimp.   The pork and shrimp baos left a lot to be desired. They lacked flavor and were overall really plain; and at 7 dollars a pop, we were sure we wouldn't order them again.   The burrata was the one saving grace of our visit. Although is wasn't a traditional burrata cheese ball, it was creamy and a really well balanced, delicious dish. Definitely would get this again.   Lastly, the most disappointing item was the salt and pepper lobster shrimp. Mind you, this is one of their signature items. My god, I have never eaten something as salty at a restaurant. I love salty food and I tend to over-salt my own food, but this was just insane. It was so salty it stung my mouth as I ate it. We actually felt dehydrated hours after. Tosh graciously offered to replace it and brought out a fresh batch with a cucumber salad to balance the saltiness. Unfortunately, even the new batch which had "light seasoning" was still over the top salty. We had to scrape off the batter to eat it.   6/5 stars for the great service. 2/5 for the food. We really appreciated Tosh's efforts and also the fact that the chef brought out the cucumber salad to balance the salty food. We were excited to go to the new Majordomo restaurant in LA, but we're really not too sure anymore. The lobster needs some serious fixing.

MUAPkfcyDaGzBI3HAwCM4g.text: It's been a couple months since I had dinner here, yet I can't stop thinking about it. Quite possibly the best dinner of 2018. I'm sure the company of good people adds to the reverie for me, but damn, that was an excellent dinner.

X-pcgfrxJCUxbArDpC4KEg.text: Sadly they took off karaage before my visit. They also took off highballs from the menu but the server said they would still be able to make it. Props there. Front staff was really nice and welcoming.  Decided to sit at the noodle bar which puts you on the front lines of the kitchen. Not recommended if you haven't eaten in a while as the smells are wonderful.   I tried out the hamachi and mussels. Hamachi serving size is really small but tastes great. Mussels also came with a lot of flavor and I had to clean the whole plate.

BQBgMvv0kDSWqZY3Ppkkuw.text: Trying new things and new foods is an adventure. This place was one of of many places I had to try and I'm happy I did. Food was GREAT and so was the servers.

4TsGAqo2a0C0iGzQ5rjkXA.text: I heard a lot about the NY Momofuku, wonderful things about the food, so when I heard that it was coming to Vegas got excited.   So we finally decided to visit this place that is located inside Cosmopolitan Hotel on the 2nd floor. It's a bigger place than the ones on NYC, this has more tables, you can choose sitting on the bar area that is right on the entrance, or go for a more formal dinner on the back.   To start we ordered shishito peppers (always a must wherever we go) and the pork Belly Buns, beautiful pieces served with a juicy meat, ready to be devour. I really like this one, perfect evening start. Then we ordered the Pork Noodles, good flavor, nice portion and everything you need your noodles to be.  Also hubby was excited about ordering the the fried chicken and caviar AND WOW! Perfect for a big party -  2 chickens are fried whole, then carved, served with truffle creme and ginger pancakes paired with your choice of momofuku reserve caviar. We loved it, for me the combination of eating this dish in a "taco" form with the pancakes was just PERFECT!  I would recommend this one ONLY FOR  BIG PARTIES, unless you want to have lunch and dinner leftovers for the rest of the week (lol)    The reason of my 4 stars - So I would recommend this place, but for some reason I prefer the NYC location I don't know if its the vibe or food is just a tiny bit different, or is just me. But yes I would say to you, visit this place!   -SPANISH:  Escuche mucho a cerca de este lugar en NY, empezando con la comida que es deliciosa, entonces al escuchar que abririan un nuevo local en Las Vegas me emocione.   Asi que finalmente decidimos visitar este lugar localizado dentro de Cosmopolitan Hotel en el 2do piso. Es un lugar mas grande que el de Nueva York, con mas mesas y la opcion de reservar. Tambien puedes escoger entre sentarse en el bar que esta a la entrada o un poco mas elegante en la parte de atras.   Empezamos ordenando los Shisito Peppers (siempre en donde hay ordenamos) y los Pork Buns, delicioso platillo donde una pieza jugosa de puerco es envuelta en un Bun, listo para ser devorado. Siguiendo con un plato de Pork Noodles, con una perfecta porcion, que contiene todo lo que necesitas para disfrutar de una buena sopa.   La entrada fuerte, donde debo decir mi esposo estaba muy emocionado por pedirla fue Pollo Frito con Caviar - 2 pollos enteros fritos, desmenuzados, servidos con panqueques hechos de trufa y jengibre. Todo esto acompanado de uno de los caviares a escoger. Este platillo es perfecto para grupos grandes! Al menos que quieras tener sobras para toda una semana (jaja)  En resumen la razon de mis 4 estrellas es que si disfrute de este lugar pero mi local favorito es el de NY no se si sea por la vibra, que la comida es buena pero un poquito diferente o simplemente una idea mia. Pero si definitivamente tienes que probar este lugar si tienes la oportunidad!

4yTg-RdTC_9Bdh14E3KYyg.text: Good portions for lunch menu. Bowl of ramen is about $17 dollars and goes up from there. The ramen left spice and fresh herbs to be desired though. 0lGstTkQ0mo2W_epE4IEXw.text: All of my friends recommended this place for the ramen and it did not disappoint! The ramen was really flavorful and just the right amount of salt for me. Noodles were not too soggy and the pork belly was AMAZING! There was a light crunch to the pork belly edges   The staff were really friendly and our server/bartender shared some of their favorites. Ended up going with the melon king crab. It was such a sweet and light addition to our meal, very different from savory crab dishes.  Dranksss: cherry milk punch!! It's good if you like sour types of alcohol. Our bartender was kind enough to explain how our drink is made and yes if you're lactose intolerant don't get this drink because there is milk in it despite not being able to see it (see picture).   Lastly dessert. We got the birthday cake slice from the Milk bar connected to Momofuku. It was sweet and the cereal taste to it made it very different than your average confetti cake!   Overall- YUMZ all around!

xjT1KqimIA9mHPiT21Safw.text: Usually when I stay at the Cosmo and if I'm craving a bowl of ramen and lazy to go out of the hotel I would come here.   I've had the Shoyu Ramen $17 and it's ok. The pork belly and ramen is good but don't really like the dark meat chicken and the poach egg, wish it's was a soft boil egg instead.

8sYzWQLWDgG_OPe2Co3nvA.text: Overall: 5/5. Did not read much into this place, but decided to go based on many recommendations. Well worth it! On the pricier end though, so be careful.  Service: 4/5. Our waiter went through the favorite dishes at different price points and described the dishes well. When things started to get busy around there, she was still able to make time to check on us and make sure that we were comfortable. There was a puddle near one of the tables that took a while for them to quarantine and resulted in a few customers slipping. I believe they compensated the victims for the accident.   Ambiance: 5/5. A great balance of contemporary styles of new world and old!  Value: 4/5. While the food was delicious. I think the higher prices were a result of imported ingredients. Hence, the higher price tags. Please be wary of that when you go in.   Food: I only ordered one lunch plate, but included a photo one of the dishes my mother ordered. I feel like I can only judge the dish I ordered since I spent the most time on it.   5 Spice Duck Ssam: 5/5. Sliced breast, leg confit, and ginger crepe. I was told combining all of the pieces into a lettuce wrap would make for the best experience. I definitely agree! The duck skin was really crispy and the meat was tender. A quality duck breast! The fried rice was savory! I honestly thought the lettuce was fake, because of how bright and vibrant it looked! I was pleasantly surprised. The eggs were soft and cooked to perfection, but would not work without the duck and the rice. The entire thing formed a wonderful asian fusion dish to be proud of!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 5 Spice Duck Ssam
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Australian Waygu Steak

XPyjjTu7vn52A1X2-cG0xg.text: We came in a group of 7 people on a Saturday night.   The drinks were AMAZING! We all ordered a drink from their cocktail menu and loved all of them! I ordered a whiskey drink, I think it was called Toki time? They are all around $17 each...pricey, but delicious. I definitely recommend.   Service was great and attentive. For the food, we went with family style.   Sweet and sour green beans - so thin! But a good veggie to snack on.   Shishito Peppers - like my friends described it, it's like roulette. You may be lucky and get a REALLY spicy one. Great flavor and appetizer to snack on if you like the pepper taste.   Pork belly buns - AMAZING! My favorite besides the drinks. The pork belly was crispy on the outsides, the bun was so soft. The pickled cucumber added a nice crunch to the bun. I would at least order one bun per person...AT LEAST!   Branzino - really well made. Wasn't too dry, and came right off the plate/bone. Delicious!   5 spice roasted duck - a pretty large meal. I enjoyed eating it with the wraps more than the lettuce wraps. They even deep fry the remaining bones/meat and bring it back to the table to not waste any of the duck.   Popcorn cake - In my opinion, this was a little too sweet for me. I was thinking that this would be more on the savory side, but it was pretty rich/buttery.   Crack pie - really good and buttery! It was especially good with the milk soft serve. I really enjoyed this dessert.   Pricey restaurant, but I'd definitely come back for the pork belly buns, crack pie and drinks! I would want to try the ramen too!

jkzgOpqHBS7LU-y1PlTx2A.text: go with lamb and uni hash brown you won't regret I'm Asian and I'm very picky on Asian fusion style bc they usually mean disaster. But have to say this restaurant is a perfect balance btw eastern and western taste.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Uni hashbrown must get
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Lamb so tender and juicy

ZToRV1r30_CKMN_9PN09LA.text: TLDR: Very unique tasting food at a $$$$ price. Don't let the $$ on Yelp fool you; this place is straight up BOUGIE.   We decided to finally try the famous David Chang's Momofuku. The ambience was very hipster and modern, as you would expect. We were seated immediately without a reservation.   We ordered: CHILLED SPICY NOODLES (4.5/5): This was a very well done dish! The sauce was reminiscent of pesto, but not quite that. The sausages were hot, but the noodles themselves were cold. The candied cashews added a sweet kick to each bite. Definitely a great way to start off your meal.  HOZON RICE CAKES (5/5): This was absolutely stellar. It was basically fried Korean deokkboki in a mushroomy sauce. The rice cakes had a crispy outer layer and a chewy inner layer - absolutely divine. The sauce was so fragrant. It reminded me of carbonara and mushroom sauce combined, but did not taste heavy or creamy. This dish was a perfect blend of Korean and Italian flavors. An absolute must order.  WILD ALASKAN KING SALMON (4/5): This whopping dish was $50!! Definitely not worth the price, but the taste and preparation was phenomenal. The dish it really quite simple - it is just a filet of salmon smoked on cedarwood with no garnishes. The filet flaked beautifully and had a delicious smokey taste.   WAGYU TRI-TIP (4/5): This dish was very simple. It was just the steak + some sunchoke on the side. The sunchoke was somehow ridiculously delicious, considering its just...sunchoke. In fact, I may have loved it more than the steak itself. Not that the tri-tip was anything short of delicious. It was so so soft - almost a prime rib or filet mignon quality. Delicious.  BUCATINI (5/5): This was an absolute gorgeous blend of Asian and Italian flavors. The bucatini noodles were cooked al dente, so it had a great chew to it. But what wowed me most was the sauce. The sauce was not heavy - it tasted like a blend of cacio de pepe/salted egg yolk. Nothing like I've ever tasted before.  I think someone was watching us as we were eating. The moment we finished one dish, another was brought to our table. Great, attentive service, and awesome atmosphere.   Ok note though: they charged us $1 each for our water, which confused me. But I guess it's Vegas.   Anyways, I'm so glad I was able to finally dine at one of David Chang's establishments. This restaurant serves absolutely artful dishes, and the price tag shows.

zshc4UiermFBV7MEHcji4g.text: No time to take pictures; too busy eating. We dined on 7/30/19. Our server, Sarah was amazing. She went above and beyond to make sure our meal was as enjoyable as possible and gave great advice when asked about must have items on the menu. The pork belly buns, the rack of lamb and (my personal favorite) the creamed corn was DELICIOUS and bursting with flavor.

njASKGUfwmTGRjcN8TgxBw.text: To my surprise, I didn't realize that David Chang had brought Momofuku to Las Vegas. I was doing a search on Yelp and lo and behold, there's one at the Cosmopolitan. We were lucky to have snatch two seats at the bar where you can watch the chefs in action. That was in itself a treat.   The most expensive on the menu had to be the fried chicken and caviar (Golden Osetra) at $1,488. Since I am not a baller like that, hopefully someone else can comment on that dish.  Instead, I can comment on things that I did have. We started with the spicy cucumbers. It was made with cucumbers of course, some sort of puree with avocado, and togarashi red pepper flakes. It was really delicious and refreshing on a hot day.   Next, we tried the grilled asparagus with miso butter and lemon. It was really good!  Finally, our main course which was the Jidori Chicken. It serves two people because it was a whole chicken. It was topped with curry powder, lime zest, and served with a side of kimchi and rice with ginger garnish on top. The chicken was so tender, it melts in your mouth. Overall, it was a very good meal. I highly recommend this place if you are in Vegas. Also, make sure to make a reservation before going so that you don't have a long wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. That 8oz Golden Osetra with fried chicken $$$ wow

DC5ez3rllJXT6ZD3smRxaQ.text: Been here a few times when I'm in town, my first visit was awesome and every time gets better. The staff is friendly and really knowledgeable about the menu and where food is sourced. Apparently you can have a tasting menu put together by your server for you and your group for dinner depending on what you want to spend per head. Lots of seating at the bar and the space has a great view of the Strip. It's located in the corner of the cosmopolitan on the second floor.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Our delicious lunch, rice bowl, noodles and the sweet potatoes

PJDPqJ7o5Ga0-B2UFocIQQ.text: As someone who discovered David Chang through his guest appearances on Buzzfeed's Worth It series and still needs to watch his Netflix show Ugly Delicious, I wanted to at some point try Momofuku, and this trip to Las Vegas granted me the opportunity!  Momofuku is located in The Cosmopolitan hotel on the 2nd floor along with a variety of other restaurants. If you're driving, I'd recommend parking in the underground parking garage of the hotel; it's free up to the first hour and $7 for 1-4 hours.  We came around 12pm on a Saturday and were seated immediately at the open kitchen bar seating (I find it fun to watch the cooks prepare dishes during meals). The restaurant has a very clean, modern design, and I like the variety of seating it offers: high tables, bar seating, open kitchen bar seating, and a spacious section for regular seating. I like how it gives off a simple yet classy vibe, which means you can feel comfortable dressing up or down when eating here.  We started off with the $16 Spicy Chilled Noodles and two $7 Pork Belly Buns. I REALLY LIKED THE SPICY CHILLED NOODLES AND RECOMMEND TRYING/SHARING IT. They add pesto, Sichuan sausage, thai basil, and candied cashews to create a delicious and more-on-the-unique-side noodle dish. I recommend trying the Pork Belly Buns if you've never had good pork belly buns before, but they're skippable if you've had.  We then had two of the lunch plate options, the $17 Slow Roasted Pork Shoulder Bowl (added an egg on top) and the $48 5 Spice Rotisserie Duck. The slow roasted pork shoulder was some of the best pork shoulder I've ever had in terms of flavor and tenderness, and I highly recommend this dish. The 5 Spice Rotisserie Duck, which included duck breast and leg confit (fattier and tastier than the breast), was good, but not worth the price (see reasoning below).  Overall, if you're eating lunch here, I'd recommend ordering one $16 Spicy Chilled Noodles, one $17 Slow Roasted Pork Shoulder Bowl, and either two of their buns or another dish for every two people. We ordered more because we were hungry and eat a lot haha. I don't recommend ordering any of the duck options (they have different portion sizes) because while good, they're not as worth it compared to specialized roasted duck restaurants.  Momofuku does it right by keeping everything simple, clean, and good, from the service to the interior decor to the menu design and to the food. While you can definitely get some of their dishes at a more worth-it price at more specialized Asian restaurants, Momofuku has done a terrific job of spearheading the category of food it belongs to: Asian Fusion.

T3a315lU5cGWQXsziOwI8A.text: I wanted to LOVE this so badly but can only say I like it enough. I had the Caesar salad (too saucy), mushroom buns (too sweet), ginger scallion noodles (kinda sweet), rice cake (special vegetarian dish, sweet but very good!), and long beans (too saucy). While all of it was really good, it was a bit too sugary/saucy for my liking. I think most people will really love the taste however! My favorite was the rice cake dish, which was not on the menu that evening but special made for the herbivore that is me.  Also I was soooo excited to try the crack pie and birthday cake. Sad to say it was a bit underwhelming, although this could've been due to my high ass expectations. I can definitely see how crack pie is addictive- it has this slightly sweet/slightly salty and chewy texture to it. Delicious :P  The ambiance is really nice- chic, beautiful- perfect for a night in Vegas.

Il3ndkVOdWZe_8DAHqDDTQ.text: Always have a great experience whenever we eat here or order food out to-go. There servers are always friendly. Even though the place is typically busy it's ok cause the food and experience makes it worth it

13RN2ejKSf8e02AmQC0ggw.text: Crazy awesome dining experience.  It was late after landing and we were skeptical since eating at one of the many momofuku places in NYC. That dining experience was average.  This one killed it.  My wife is picky and she was thrilled with everything.    The waitress was amazing, Jenna.  Helps she is from our home state of WA. She guided us through the menu and did not disappoint with suggestions.  She even messed up with one of the orders and comped us for the mistake (expected but very cool way she handled it).    The buns are crazy good- as others recommended. The beans are spot on with crispy on the outside and perfect soft inside. The pumpkin ribs, crazy good. But the Apple kimchi salad with that maple yogurt sauce is off the charts amazing.    Definitely coming back here next time in Vegas!!!

Tyuw3zqQUvk-0RaTxMVP5A.text: Ordered the smoked pumpkin. Does not taste good at all, tastes like someone dumped an entire bottle of five spices on top of the sugary thickened soy sauce.. shoyu ramen is pretty good though. Ive been a big fan of Dave chang, this does not live up to the hype.

XSN_OOEBc-QLkaO4Vrja9Q.text: We came with a large party to celebrate an engagement and were looking for something different. Boy did we find just what we were looking for!  We did a chef tasting menu and they let us choose a price point from $80-150 per person. We went with $100 per and despite being on the lower end it was more food than any of us could handle. Id say we had 6-8 different dishes in total.  They started us out with several appetizers. The most notable were the oysters and shishito peppers. The oysters were fresh and came with smoked roe which gave them such depth of flavor ive never had in oysters. The shishito peppers were covered in a powdered condensed milk (sounds weird i know) but it created a unique balance of spice and cream.  Yet this was a mere precursor to our outstanding entrees. We had the Bo Ssam which is a slow roasted whole pork shoulder that came with lettuce wraps and 3 house made sauces. The lettuce wraps are meant to be eaten with the pork... And wait for it.... More oysters! Very different but once again they make the flavor pairings work.  We also had a pasta dish that was similar to an Italian bolognese but with Asian ingredients (i was so blown away I can't even recall the name). However, as amazing as this was, I haven't gotten to the main attraction.  The most impressive item was the 5 spice rotisserie duck. First they bring out this beautifully roasted duck breast, they proceed to slice it in front of you and place it over a bed of sticky rice and duck leg confit. They added more house made sauces and both lettuce wraps as well as chive pancakes... But that's not all! They took the carcass back to the kitchen, break it down and deep fry it, and came back out with what are basically fried duck wings...   All in all chef David Chang certainly knows how to do Asian fusion and while its not a cheap dinner, you get a ton of bang for your buck. There's many choices in vegas for an elegant dinner, but when considering flavor, presentation, and unique offerings, id take momofuku over anything else.

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork shoulder!
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

AZ_8EV781FfC3FbzdNFUcQ.text: Charlie Rose: "Here's the big question: Is David Chang Einstein or Edison?"  David Chang: "Are you kidding me? ...I'm just a chef."  On March 29th, almost eight months after our first trip to Momofuku, we all came back for another fabulous dinner. As amazing as it was the first time, this second Momofuku adventure blew me away. It could have been because we were seated at the most exclusive table in house. It might be because we were welcomed instantly with a glass of bubbly rose. Or maybe it was because I was spoiled senseless as the birthday girl but what a crazy night --- Three hours of nonstop gluttony with some of my most favorite people in the world.  After the beautiful glass of rose, a dish of birthday oysters were presented. "Other places do the cheesy $0.80 dessert. We do things differently here..." I felt like my soul was being flirted with. Blow out the candle, squeeze on some lemon, a quick oyster cheers with the table, and down it goes. Fresh, oceanic, and clean. I was instantly hungry for more.  After that was a gorgeous plate of bigeye tuna with french strawberries and shaved foie gras. This is no longer on their menu but what Jon H. wants, Jon H. gets. Eat it with a spoon and try not to lick the plate.   Next were the pork belly buns because who goes to Momofuku without getting the buns? Delicious! Use that Ssam sauce liberally because it is dang good.  Fluke tartare? Why not? Cabbage and nori topped with ostera caviar and lemon zest... clean taste throughout with a burst of nutty flavor from the caviar. Delicate textures with a smooth finish. No fishy aftertaste here. Easily one of my favorite bites. It was refreshing.  Miso sea bass with crab butter, mushrooms, and roasted vegetable broth topped with thick generous slices of truffles. Pour the broth on the truffles and enjoy.  An off-the-menu carbonara-esque dish was served and with it, more shaved truffles. Like the pork belly bao, you have to get noodles at Momofuku. It's hard to say what was my favorite bite of the night but this dish was definitely one of the most memorable. The truffles worked insanely well in this dish. So fragrant and well balanced. While being surrounded with a gorgeous grilled steak and a delicately cooked sea bass, this simple dish was the one I went back to time and time again. Jon said it would have been better with avocados [I'M KIDDING!].  Dry-aged cote de boeuf. A beautiful 32 oz. of creekstone prime beef, grilled and finished with marrow butter. Served with wagyu fried rice and charred broccolini with chile jam. Crispy potatoes with horseradish and creme fraice and chives were also served but not apart of the beautiful cote de boeuf offering but also enjoyed immensely. Don't forget to bite the bone... There's flavor on the bone.  Lastly is the dessert and a parting cocktail. The sultry tones of "Happy Birthday" was practically whispered by Hadely, a tray of Milk Bar goodies was set before me, and more candles were to be blown out. The infamous Crack Pie with Fruity [Pebbles] Cereal Milk soft serve and regular Cereal Milk soft serve was presented and devoured. To finish things off, a cold brew cocktail. Light a cigarette for me, even though I don't smoke, because what a highly foodie-erotic and intoxicating evening. My word.   Hats off and many thanks to Victor, Mighty Mags, Hadely, Adem, and of course my friends Jon H. and his lovely wife for such a fabulous meal. I was surprised by this flawlessly orchestrated evening. I'll be biting my fist at the culinary masterpiece memory forever.  TL;DR Momofuku is still Momofukin' bomb.  A ta sante!

iDZek7ObHAwLG1mZ3TQSZg.text: This place has a really cool vibe to it. It feels like you just stepped into a trendy restaurant in New York, except you're in Vegas! My sister and I made a reservation the night prior. We went on a Tuesday night, so it was  definitely easy to grab a table at dinner time. Service was extremely attentive and friendly, so that made our experience all the better.  Onto the food. Between the two of us we ordered the Old Fashioned & Yuzu Lemonade. I didn't really feel like consuming any alcohol that day so lemonade for me! We also got still water which was offered to us once we sat down. Ended up getting charged $1 per person, which isn't bad but I wish they could've just offered me free tap water first. We ordered the pork belly buns, black truffle ramen and miso sea bass.  Out of the three dishes, I would really only recommend getting the pork belly buns. These were AMAZING. It comes with two, but I wish it came with more! I honestly thought it tasted perfect without the additional sauce they provide, but I'll let you be the judge of that.  Black truffle ramen - definitely not worth $50. That's right. $50 RAMEN. THERE WASN'T EVEN ANY MEAT IN THERE. It is jam packed with flavor, I'll give it that. But I don't think I'd get this again. Apparently this might be taken off the menu soon, which was the main reason why we ended up getting it just to try it out.  Miso sea bass. I can see other people loving this dish, but this honestly just tasted like the sea bass dish my mom could make at home. It's nice when a restaurant reminds you of home, but honestly. If I could get the same thing at home, I'd just go home. The outside char on the sea bass was really really nice though. That part I loved. The fried enoki mushroom was a nice touch too.  My sister made the reservation to celebrate my new job and they were nice enough to bring out a celebratory cookie!!! That was so sweet of them. We also got the crack pie. YUM. My sister described it as that sweet asian dessert you could get at asian baguette shops haha. I can't think of anything more similar than that.  I wouldn't mind coming here again. Maybe with a larger group to try out their larger dishes.

Q0uXRrD-svV8S-hv_NY1rA.text: I had to be honest, I went into Momofuku full of high expectations and left rather disappointed.   After a long day and hearing so much about the Momofuku noodle bar, I wanted a bowl of warm soupy ramen so I ordered the Black truffle ramen which comes cooked in a savory broth with shaved truffle mushrooms, scallion, and egg yolk.   As with any food that commands such a high price tag, I expect to leave happy. The thick broth had a good flavor but a bit gritty - whether from the cooked noodles or the winter truffles - I am not sure. The microplane shaved truffle was okay - very light in flavor. The noodle is probably the star of the dish as it tasted fresh and texturally pleasant. I understand truffle is expensive but I have had plenty of truffles in my lifetime, mostly thinly sliced truffles, and they all packed a great amount of flavor. I don't mind the simplicity of the ingredients but, over all, to command $50 for this bowl of ramen is a bit over the top.   I must say the service was excellent here with many attentive and hardworking staff. That's why I would give it a 3 star instead of 2.

B5wHymP3OKCwQHWD0bucvQ.text: My brother Andrew C. turned 30 this month, and Matt B. and I met him and Celestine H. for a celebratory weekend in Vegas. His birthday fell on a Saturday, and we got a late lunch at Momofuku, making a same-day reservation for 2:30 in the afternoon.  I love David Chang's restaurants. I remember going to the original Noodle Bar, Ssam Bar, and Milk Bar with Andrew a decade ago, when he was a student in New York. The Vegas Momofuku is sort of a Noodle and Ssam Bar hybrid, with a Milk Bar set up in an adjoining space in the Cosmopolitan.  The restaurant was large and attractive--there's really no better way to describe it than to say that it looked like a Momofuku joint, trendy in a hipster New York way, with blonde wood and neon and eye-catching murals. It was peaceful when we went, probably because we were there so late. By the time we finished lunch, it was just us and the employees, having their staff meal.  I wonder in retrospect if they needed to get us out of there to clean up before dinner service, because our lunch started out at a pretty frenetic pace. We ordered and then suddenly our table was carpeted in food, eight dishes brought out in the span of fifteen minutes. When I asked them to slow it down, they listened, then checked in on us a number of times, finally bringing out the rest of our meal when I asked, about half an hour later. I feel like they were scared of me, though I swear, I wasn't a jerk about it. The staff was very nice and attentive, though, overall. The pacing was the only issue.  We drank cocktails with our lunch, and these were fantastic. Vegas is full of bad, expensive cocktails, so I was happy to have good, expensive ones at Momofuku. I loved the Garden Gnome, a refreshing highball of gin, yellow chartreuse, and soda with shiso, mint, and snap pea. Likewise the What the Pho?, a sweet and spicy cocktail made with cachaca, basil, jalapeno, honey, and lime. The Penicillin--scotch, ginger, lemon, honey, and smoke--and the Yuzu Negroni--sale, gin, Campari, and Punt e Mes--were both great variations on classic drinks. On the stirred, boozy side, I liked the Boots of Spanish Leather with rum, Oloroso sherry, amaro, and bitters, as well as the Rosita, made with mezcal, vermouth, Campari, and bitters. We were also charged $4 for something called Vero water. I guess the house water wasn't free.  The food was excellent. We started with a couple crudos, as well as the pork belly buns and a tasting of country hams. The Hawaiian kampachi was silky and delicate, served in a flavorful lemon dashi with snow peas and chive. I also loved the bigeye tuna, which came with strawberry and a decadent heap of shaved foie gras. The hams were lovely, served with redeye mayo and juicy slices of nectarine. And I'm always a fan of Momofuku's pork belly buns, pillowy steamed buns loaded with fat slabs of pork belly, hoisin, cucumber, and scallion.  The next batch of food, which hit the table while we were still working on the first, brought our noodle bowls and vegetables. Momofuku's ramen has been divisive since Noodle Bar's inception, but I'm firmly in the pro-Chang camp. The shoyu pork ramen was well done, the springy noodles and rich, soothing broth supplemented with pork belly, pork shoulder, and a slow-poached egg. I also liked the ginger scallion noodles, which came with pickled shiitake and wakame. On the vegetable side, I thought the sweet and sour long beans were fantastic, snappy and intensely flavorful, cooked with ginger, garlic, and black vinegar.  We rounded out our meal with two of the lunch plates and a rice bowl. The grilled lamb ribs were superb, deeply savory and perfectly tender, the meat sliding off the bone. They came with cucumber and a great chili yogurt. The grilled stripe bass was a nice, meaty piece of fish, served with mushrooms, snow peas, and an addictive kimchi butter, which we asked to get on the side for my picky husband's benefit. The bo ssam bowl was a hefty bibimbap laden with kimchi and other pickled vegetables. Our waiter put the glazed pork shoulder on the side without being asked so that Matt could enjoy it without kimchi--a thoughtful touch. I liked this bibimbap and would recommend it if you don't eat bibimbap often, but it was the one thing we ordered that I could take or leave.  We didn't order dessert (we were full and also had a dinner reservation at Joel Robuchon in five hours), but we'd mentioned it was Andrew's birthday earlier in the meal, and our waiter brought us a plate of birthday cake truffles, one of them stuck with a candle. This was really nice, and the truffles were great--dense balls of cake unapologetically exploding with sugar.  This was one hell of a feast, full of delicious food and blessedly wonderful cocktails. There's no lack of good restaurants in Vegas, but Momofuku is pretty hard to beat.

FHlK0zrQLw_7IP63HD1vSA.text: I. Love. This. Place! As much as I love Milk Bar next door which is saying A LOT :)  We came here for a special dinner and glad we did!  We had the Pork Belly Bun, Brussels Sprouts & Cauliflower, Miso Sea Bass, Sichuan Beef Noodles, Apple Kimchi Salad, Milk Bar birthday cake and coffee. Yes, ALL of it! We were hungry haha! Everything was fantastic! The one thing that caught us by surprise was the Apple Kimchi Salad. You would never think it's THAT good but it is! It's definitely a special occasion dinner but there wasn't a single thing that didn't taste beyond delicious!   Now I must try the other locations :) Way to go David Chang!

G6glv3rCMDTm3IGbw--FNw.text: We enjoyed our dinner at Momofuku.  Daniel was our waiter and was super attentive and friendly. Since we were a larger group, we gave Daniel a budget and he brought food to our table (we did not pick).   They have some really really good shrimp/lobster, brussel sprouts and the duck. Their raw tuna with caviar was not that good (almost all of us were disappointed as it was a very pricey plate but very poor flavor and portion.   The back of the restaurant has a nice view of the Vegas strip and is a nice place for a group.   In addition, they have a good wine selection and very accommodating staff in general.

3k5qqEjzr8gCRSn2Pvs9ZQ.text: I love David Chang, and I was so excited to try this place. We made a reservation and ended up getting seated in the corner overlooking the strip. It was gorgeous. We couldn't get over the view.  Pork Belly Buns -5/5  omg. so good that we had to order more Ginger Scallion Noodles - 3.5/5 good, unique, but not our favorite Truffle Ramen - 4.5/5 the deep mushroom flavor was sooo good and exploding with umami Oysters - 4/5 pricy, but very fresh Bigeye Tuna - 5/5 there was grated foie gras that melted in your mouth. the tuna was really light and tasty, too.  Overall, it was quite pricy for the smaller portions. I would have given this place a 4.5, but the view really made the experience so good.  Note: you can also order anything on the Milk menu for dessert even though they don't have the full menu for you to take a look.

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly buns - SO GOOD and flavorful  Big eye tuna - melt in your mouth delicious

-GhqDeOccrOSXUA4M6cXxg.text: Heard a lot of great things about this place but wasn't sure what to expect. I was delighted! My friend's bachelorette couldn't have been more perfect. Since there were 12 of us, we had a sweet little VIP section in the back with our own private bathroom. Service was top notch. They just kept bringing more and more and more food out!!! By the time we were done, we needed a moment to loosen our belts before we could tackle that delicious dessert sampler.   Everything made my mouth water. It was sooooo good!!! If only I could eat like that every day lol. The duck was divine. So buttery and smooth. It literally melts in your mouth. The Chilean sea bass was cooked perfectly!!! I'm having flashbacks and craving it right now!!! The truffle ramen!!! Ohhh my!!! That truffle ramen!!! I'm sure they rolled those noodles in the back and cooked them fresh!!! Sheesh!!! So savory. Fried duck bones, also a winner!!! Spicy cucumber salad = refreshing!! The spice was a 3 out of 10. The fried peppers are hit and miss on the spicy scale. I got one that was a 4. A friend got one that was about a 9. Left her in tears lol. Overall AMAZING experience. I would go back time and time again so I could try everything on the menu!!!

faOojV2LiESOtUOYkNL1Ew.text: Snack on The Strip (Las Vegas)...  We had just finished watching the Vegas Golden Knights hockey team win at their home turf - T-Mobile Arena. We were hungry and had heard good things about Momofuku. It was nearby; there was no line; and we had caught a ride to The Strip (parking wasn't a concern).  We walked to The Cosmopolitan Hotel and looked forward to a nice meal.  Somehow, I wasn't feeling it...  I asked for a table, but we were given a high top with stools. There were backs on the chairs, but it took some balance to be comfortable. I pointed to the seats by the window, but was told that they weren't available at this time.  (sad face)  Maybe because we arrived in between lunch and dinner, the menu was limited. I felt like we only had a choice of Pork Belly Buns and ramen.  We decided to skip the pricey ramen and just get two orders of the Pork Belly Buns so that each of us could have a $7 bun. Yeah...  I did like my bun!  The taste was good!  The pork belly was a thick, generous slab with an outer sear and a moist, fatty interior!  I treated it as an appetizer and looked forward to dining elsewhere...  I realize that this is the Strip where prices are higher. I think that service should be top notch.  Somehow, I felt disappointed.  I guess we were there at an off time?  Maybe I should come at a different time?

vARW7MHzZoEM8Kwi3hZNVA.text: Came here with my girlfriends to see what the hype is all about.   Me, a ramen fanatic, had to try the only ramen on the menu: black truffle ramen. The black truffle didn't overpower the whole bowl. It gave the broth a unique, buttery flavor. The noodles were a medium sized thickness and the pork was tender. The egg was presented without the egg white; just a soft yolk. The bowl was $50, which is very steep for a standard size bowl of ramen, but I understand that black truffle is an expensive delicacy.   I wish that I had the chance to try a more classic style ramen, so I could truly taste chef David Chang's version of it. But, I'm assuming they rotate the items of the menu often and I just happened to come when they were serving this unique ramen. I would come back to try a different ramen next time.

WT3YxE4UFvOmSvq2c84fwA.text: Amazing food! Kid and adult friendly. Amazing staff. Fun drinks! Lots of shareable delicious and interesting food. They were very gluten free friendly and accommodating. We will definitely return when we are in Vegas. I highly recommend!

MOdLU8adCueM8N5lFWj5mQ.text: Personal Rating: A-OK - 3.5 Stars Location: Cosmopolitan, 2nd Floor  Service: Excellent / Friendly  Food: Average  What I Ordered:  Pork Belly Bun - $7 - Best part of the meal....sadly.  Pork Shoyu Ramen - $17 - Great depth of flavor, the egg was poached to perfection. The pork belly was crispy and the pork shoulder was oh - sooooo tender. HOWEVER, the noodles were too soft. When the bowl first came out, it was room temperature. The bowl had been sitting out for quite awhile. Time Frame: It had been exactly 26 minutes from the time I initially ordered.....to the time I was able to take my first sip. The server took my bowl back and brought a brand new bowl out. They added an extra piece of pork belly this time around, but the noodles were still overcooked - too soft.   Ginger Scallion Noodles - $16 - A mixture of shiitake and cucumber, a little too overdressed. The flavor ruined my entire palette and I was in desperate need of water throughout the meal.   I was torn between my usual Eggslut or if I should try something different, Momofuku. I've been to the New York location and can positively say, the food is better there and the service. Who knows, maybe I'll try it on my next trip to Vegas and it'll change. For the time being, I'm sticking to Eggslut. Sorry David Chang.

_MOjX7EEJ8v-WyoKZ92b2A.text: I have to admit that I've been quite the Momofuku devotee since my initial visit. Our group of friends visits pretty frequently and we always have an outstanding meal.   Service is top notch and I can't think of a bad thing to say about any of the dishes that we've tried. To be honest, I think we've just about tried everything on the menu as well as some off the menu items that have been available when we are there.   The bo ssam is my very favorite dish and I could eat that every day if not for the fact that it would probably kill me to do so.   I can't think of enough good things to say about this place. Don't sleep on a visit and grab a table next to the window if you can for the view of a lifetime.

JK2p4_fnDxs3sTcdmQozTA.text: I was not a fan of this place. We ordered a dozen oysters, pork belly buns, and shoyu ramen. The oysters were fresh, and very interesting. I'm not sure if interesting justifies the oyster's price tag. Anyways, moving on... the pork belly buns were really oily. They were pretty good with the saam sauce (?) but you can see the oil drip out of the bun. After that, our ramen came out. I thought ramen was going to be great hangover food, but omg this was the oiliest. I know ramen was oily, but this has like half an inch of oil in it or something. Everything was coated in oil. I think I pooped oil for a good week after this meal... haha... I would not recommend this restaurant to anyone.  Come here if you like your foods extra oily and oysters overpriced.

RrXqstZ4WvkjAj36YKqI0g.text: AMAZing ramen And service. I have a fish allergy and the waiter totally watched for cross contamination and instructed on food choices!!! Ask for Gregory he is awesome!!!!

XjLeX4jUgPphO2K6Clnk1A.text: This was recommended by a friend and I was looking forward to their ramen and Bo Ssam pork bowl.  However, it was overpriced and the taste was just average.    The chickpea ramen seemed like a good alternative since the base is the same as the black truffle.  They didn't have the black truffle ramen when I went there.  However it came out pretty bland.  Nothing stood out from the dish.  The Bo Ssam pork bowl was not bad. They had some flavors. However the pork wasn't that tender.    The honeycrisp apple salad was a few pieces of apple. It was good apples, but not $16 worth.  It's pretty overpriced for what.
