wFYDve4R37KOtc70IqY-4w.text: On this trip, I looked forward to trying this restaurant the most. The pork belly lived up to all its hype. Everything else was beyond disappointing  Of the three ramen we tried, the pork ramen was the best. Keep in mind, that's relative to our other dishes. We also tried the $58 bowl of black winter truffle. I liked how the truffle added a different layer of flavor to the broth, but the noodle used really ruined the bowl for me. The noodle is not the traditional, curly ramen noodle. Instead, it was bit thicker and the texture was hard, which made it almost resistant to the broth it swam in. The chicken shiitake ramen was the worst of the three ramen. I can't even describe the mushroom sauce that devoured the chicken katsu patty. Why?!? The pork belly buns were very tasty and the only thing that left me wanting more. We ordered a side of the pork belly since the buns were so delicious. We wanted to enjoy it with our ramen bowls. The dish came out at the end of our meal when we were done with our noodles. The food service was very disappointing. The restaurant was more than half empty. The table next to us arrived after but finished their meal before our noodles even arrived. The kitchen seemed disorganized. Our noodles came out at different times. I'm so disappointed. I really wanted to fall in love. The cookies  from Milk Bar sort of made up for some of my disappointment but not enough for me to ever return. The dishes did not blow me away. I don't think I even swayed.   Quick tip: get the pork ramen and pork buns. Skip the rest.

oferEQDvgdoeC7LiBjXCuA.text: Heard about this restaurant from a Cosmopolitan flyer I received in the mail. We love to try new restaurants when we come to Vegas. Momofuku sounds interesting and we love Asian food. We sat at the food bar and were able to watch the chef's hard at work. Manny our server was friendly and attentive and explained the menu well. Chef Jake and his Sous Chef's Spencer, Josiah (looks like Joseph Gordon Levitt) and Alex were so nice and answered all our questions. We are truly amazed how well they worked together!    Food is Five Stars Service Five Stars Atmosphere Five Stars Drinks Five Stars (and strong)  Price was more on the pricey side, but we feel being what you get it was well worth the experience of trying a new restaurant at the Cosmopolitan!

mZ_fjDI9LwaVAk-wESQAsQ.text: Second trip- I came here to give it a second chance and it was dead inside, but the server was good and the food was ok again. But what really made me never want to come back is after my group paid and we were waking out some other waiter who was not my original one come running up to us and yelling "hold up, have you guys paid??" Like I'm some criminal??? And in front of my date? And my group? Insane. How about you guys learn to communicate with each other and don't attack your guests

9Gq3OCNoJB9pS42mzHPEuw.text: I have been wanting to eat at the Momofuku in New York for forever. So when I saw that they opened a restaurant in the Cosmopolitan, I knew I had to come here. Seriously, the pork ramen was the best ramen I have had to date.  The pork bun is delicious and worth the money, even though it is tiny.  We also had a rice dish, Bo Ssam Rice bowl- with pork shoulder, kimchi that was amazing!! The pork was cooked to perfection!! The Ssam sauce was a great addition.  The chilled spicy noodles were good but I didn't expect the sauce to taste so "pesto-y".  Overall we had a great experience eating here and I will definitely come again!!  Service here is great aw well!  I think our servers name was Leah.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork ramen and Bo Ssam rice bowl

pzeM-xsvzVJnkHvCf-VRKQ.text: Very accommodating when I wasn't able to eat directly off the menu. I was in town for a competition and the waitress never skipped a beat. Just ordered accordingly. Jealous of my friends who could eat the amazing food!  Next day I had the leftovers though;) so yummy:)

2Mf5ugC3Jhlv4gOTMj-W6w.text: As a resident in LV, I was super stoked to try the long awaited Momofuku for dinner. David Chang is known for his umami style of cooking, really toning into the harmonious aspects of food/ dish design. Went in with very high expectations & food-wise they were met!  Menu is large, nicely broken into small plates & larger main entrees w/ a la carte side options. There was a salad section (looked underwhelming), a bun section, a raw bar section, small bites section, noodle/ramen section & a main entree section w/ additional side section.  Made a res. for 2 aware of what kinks/shortfalls might occur due to it being opening night. Got seated right away after being 5 mins late, & brought a bottle of our own wine from our collection ($50 corkage per btl, 2 btl max). Cool strip view, & funky interior. Our waitress was so friendly!  The waitress explained that on the noodles/ramen section the Noodles were served room-temperature & drier while the Ramen options was served very hot & in broth.  Decided not to order any salads/small bites, instead focusing on the buns, raw bar, ramen, main entrees & side dishes. Order two pork belly buns, a white fish sashimi (forget name) in a citrus vinaigrette w/ plum, the black truffle ramen, dry aged prime rib, a whole branzino, & the pommes puree.  Pork belly (fatty) buns came out right away & were taco style (I prefer when the buns are shaped as a ball that is filled versus a taco shell that is stuffed). The actual bun was amazing; great texture & flavor. The pork belly came in 3 pieces of pork (vs. shredded) was seared to perfection. My boyfriend had 3 pieces of pork belly that looked well seared & delicious (he finished it), but my bun had 2 pieces of pork that were way overly fatty & under-cooked. I had one delicious piece (truly enough for me) & dish was okay overall.  From the raw bar the sashimi came out. The fish tasted extremely fresh & the flavors from the plums & citrus really highlighted the sashimi. Wanted more plum.  Soon after a food runner came by to present the black truffle Ramen. Food runner presented the ramen & informed us it was the pork belly ramen... We informed the food runner this was not our dish... He proceeded to count out the table numbers out loud, & ask us if we were sure this was not our dish... We informed him we were sure, & that we had ordered the black truffle ramen. He whisked it back into the kitchen, while our waitress came by to present the ramen utensils/bowls. She looked puzzled why the Ramen had not been presented to the table. We informed her of the mix-up & she asked us if we wanted the original dish? (I thought this was a strange question but my boyfriend said she was just being polite due to time delay), which we confirmed we definitely did still want the truffle dish. She said she would rush the ticket & apologized again for the mix-up.  This is when the service started to hit some shortfalls. *I attribute this solely to the fact it was opening night & I truly believe that a kitchen/restaurant deserves a solid month after opening before you can meticulously judge/grade service.*   On both sides of us the couples were either presented with incorrect items, or they were waiting exceptionally long to receive the next course. Guests seemed really on edge, both sides of the close quartering tables were chattering about how terrible the service was. The FOH floor/staff looked calm & so did the BOH open kitchen, but the Managers scurried around tending to guest complaints of time delays & incorrect/missing items.   Whole branzino came out next. Beautiful presentation & was left for us to pick/debone ourselves. No small bones like expected, making it very easy and enjoyable to eat. Fresh fish & citrus notes made for a great dish.   Rib-eye with marrow butter came out & was absolutely phenomenal. Cooked perfectly & not overly fatty the rib-eye was seasoned with onions/mushrooms & blew away the fish (so strange for me to say).   Pommes puree (mashed potatoes) was literally Joel-Robuchon-status good & made me want to lick the bowl clean & ask for another portion(s). This accompanied the rib-eye & truly made me forget we were still waiting for the black truffle ramen dish.  Waitress came back out to apologize once again for wait on black truffle ramen. We asked to see the wine list & were surprised by pricing (not huge mark-up) & a good base selection. (XL wine-cellar promises future advancements to this).  Got a btl of old world Chard ( really great somm.) & the black ramen truffle finally arrived! It was worth the wait!! Truly delicious & interesting (spanish black truffles). Exactly the taste of umami to me. Great ending to meal!  Overall the service was major short-fall due to long wait time, but the food was killer, & staffing was polite, friendly & knowledgeable.. really what more could you ask for on opening night?!  Sadly did not see famous fried chix. on menu.  Large format menu looks like fun place for a group!!   We will be back!!

XQGN20SqpSjOSNEnwiiyvQ.text: Crazy good drinks!!!!!  Ask for josh the bar tender.  He has some awesome drinks.  Never thought bitters could be so sweet!!!! This is the place for unique one of a kind drinks.

SIj6fU-UtYt23mAdaAedqw.text: Not recommending that you go here for lunch. Wish that it were different.  Very limited menu, and of course prepare to throw your money out the window on an $18 bowel of ramen noodles. Ridiculous. Pork bun was the highlight. Would consider another go at their dinner but won't be making any major effort to get there.

ctPTN0YyWAXuQ6EuVd2vIg.text: Love love love the sweet corn cookies.  And the strawberry quake.  So great.  Had it 4 times while in Las Vegas.

sUYV82Tb0eDozcQR62g1rQ.text: Cool place in the Cosmo hotel (2nd floor). I had the pork bowl and thought that it only okay. This place, to me, has the vibe of an upscale chipotle with a bar. Granted I was there for late lunch so I can't comment on the evening crowd. I had a jalapeno beer that was unique and fun. I would go back but with all the good food options in Vegas it would not be my first choice. I would hit Henry's downstairs before I would go back here.

nFFv35_W6Wfr8VEZmg8eXQ.text: Super yummy and fresh fare in a desert of otherwise total indulgence. So good we came back twice. Noodle bowls are a must try!

bGFgu4nLsIfzQFv73C-x3w.text: At the Cosmo. Casual attire excellent service and bar drinks . Best Negronis.  Tasty Asian dishes Pork rolls a must Very noisy Pricey

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

BXWCwdM22n8w5R1WeEIixQ.text: Dinner was good.   It's pretty much family style. They have the large style dining menu that is essentially just a really expensive large entree to share. The large entrees start at $188 per plate. The smallest serving 2-4 people, up to 4-8 person dishes. The most expensive being $1499, fish with caviar, if I remember correctly.    We opted to do 2 "smaller" entrees, to give ourselves more variety. Each of the two were meant to serve 2 people. With 4 adults and 3 kids with us, this seemed the better route.   We got the Salt n Pepper Lobster and Shrimp, which tasted like your typical Salt n Pepper Crab, just with Lobster and Shrimp. A peel and eat dish.  Not a big Lobster fan, but this lobster was sweet and moist. The Shrimp also very tasty. A little kick on the outside but not too much that the kids couldn't have a bite of the inside. Served on a bed of fried jalepenos and hot peppers. $99. Definitely fed 4 adults, we were getting full toward the end.   The Salmon Steak was our second dish, $50. Salmon was pan seared, a little rare on the inside. A really big slice. Pretty good, nothing to write home about. The kids loved it though.   The Pork Belly buns - delicious! So fatty and tasty, melt in your mouth goodness. $7 each. Should have gotten more of these.  Plain pork ramen for the kids. Regular ramen was going to be spicy. This was literally just pork broth and ramen. $15. ($2 less than Regular). If I'm going to pay $15 for my ramen, it's going to have pork belly, soft boiled melty egg, 36 hour stewed broth... This? For the kids? I should have known better.   Service was great. Forgot his name, but he liked us, we liked him. I tipped well, since he doesn't set the prices.  We were full. Almost couldn't finish. We forced ourselves to though, given the price.   All is said and done, $250.   Good experience. A little overpriced for what is was, but then again, it is Vegas. Nice ambiance. The bathrooms have bidets and the toilets are blue.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Salt and Pepper Lobster and Shrimp behind the large slab of Salmon Steak
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Salt and pepper lobster and shrimp

_eeZd9dfHiCnyyfoK_dY4Q.text: 3.5-4. I can only vouch for the bao/buns and the Ramen. They were delicious and quick. Server was really friendly and gave us recommendations. Other stuff on the menu sounded good but was really pricey. We just stopped by for a quick bite, so the bao hit the spot. I got the pork bun and the shrimp bun. The pork bun was a little heavy with the hoisin, but other than that I really enjoyed it. Would go back to try the more expensive stuff when I'm really hungry. Great location, good food, and good service.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ramen &amp; Bao
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Qh3xaALZCDTZ22Pe9FC4SQ.text: The service is excellent and the food is amazing.  Everything we tried was delicious.  The only reason for 4 stars instead of 5 is that the crack pie was a huge disappointment and my husband's coffee was lukewarm.  The slice of pie we received was thin, flat, and hard as a rock.  Go for the food, not the dessert!

RrZSfzzKEda5JCMi1IomHw.text: Food was excellent. More than enough for four. However, don't be fooled by the $$ sign--this place is not inexpensive. The ambience was ok--loud with pulsating music--but it's Las Vegas and everything is loud. Would definitely try again to try the other items on the menu

Kj86UMThGvxjBXwSkgeDqQ.text: Service was great as I would expect from Vegas. The food was decent.... not great. Very average, but love the atmosphere of the place. Relatively new, but not sure I would return

_a6Pdnl8U0AAMm-DnBRZyQ.text: I'd rather choose authentic ethnic food over this kind of over-the-top creative fusion, but Momofuku is something worth trying once. Or twice.   Pork belly bun. Tasty, but loaded with carbs and cholesterol...  As a healthy eater, I wished they had a choice with leaner pork. Some people love melting fat in their mouth, but not me.   I went with a healthy entree - Miso Black cod. It was just too sweet for me.  Japanese style, I guess. Being a fan of authentic Korean spicy cod soup, I wished it was less sweet and had a little red chili or something. It liked it better than Nobu's black cod, but it's not really my style.   And we had this weird smoked pumpkin, which I couldn't even swallow.  The long shaped pumpkin slices were too hard to cut with a knife or to bite into with my teeth. The black sauce coating the pumpkin was strong, too salty, and almost tasted like medicine. I can't imagine how anyone could like it.

7xLVZih9kM1zXgh5L3Yh_Q.text: I kinda feel it's too pricey for what you are getting! And the poached almost raw egg in the ramen is just not right! It makes the entire bowl so eggy, I just don't agree with that!

h3xclzQN-52XIMl7UcHb9A.text: Must try. Will come back again. Very good Asian fusion food which is hard to accomplish. They did a great job! The service was excellent and very tentative. 100% to customer service!! Below are my comments: 1. Tomatoes - must try 2. Pork belly buns - must try  3. Shrimp buns - good 4. Truffle Noodle - must try  5. Chilled spicy noodle - something is missing. But I'm sure they'll try to perfect it.  6. Crispy potatoes - good but a bit too salty.   Overall great experience!!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Truffle noodle at $45. Must try once in a life time.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crispy potatoes. A bit too salty
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chilled spicy noodles

zeGj3OhGYVqw5ICsjLBcmw.text: My friend sent me a birthday cake from Momofuku in New York on my birthday last year and that was the first time I heard of Momofuku. My bf and I were staying at the Cosmo and we came across this spot and had a quick bite. We weren't super hungry so we just shared a few things- most memorable was the rice cakes. MUST TRY!

_W3Oh4fE3D3nQA6abD2Ubg.text: Over priced, salty and they food is poor fusion  David Chang doesn't cook here and just lends his name to this place while other s poorly cook his food  Not worry the price   You want authentic or even great fusion Asian food stick to the OC or LA or vancouver where Asian food and Asian fusion is done right   This place is just below average at best with high prices  There is a reason why there is no Momofuku in OC, LA or Vancouver where Asia food is king   It's because if Momofuku was there the pace would get eaten alive

ty8W36HYI6LRrYhpM77UsQ.text: I feel horrible about giving it 3 stars since it was the NYC location that left me with a lasting enough impression 3 years ago that compelled me to make reservations here.   The restaurant is in the Cosmopolitan Hotel on the 2nd floor behind the huge Chandelier.   The space is huge with great views looking out at the Paris Hotel along the strip.   Our server, Dale, was super fun, attentive and full of positive energy. She told us about the tuna poke special that's mixed with concentrated pluots and shaved freezed foie gras. Umm, hook line and sinker!  I didn't even ask how much it was going to bleed me.  $38 FYI. I took the hit for you so you don't have to awkwardly decline upon knowing the price when there.  It was worth it to me. The shaved freezed foie gras was creamy, slightly salty and rich at the same time and the pluots added the subtle sweetness to the well marinated tuna.  We also got the pork ramen $18, oysters on a half shell ($26), pork belly buns and the shrimp bun($7 & $8 each, respectively).  Although the ramen wasn't on the dinner menu, Dale was sweet to ask the kitchen to whip it up. Unfortunately, I wasn't blown away by it.  The oysters came with melon and lime shaved ice chips on top that had a vodka? tinge to it that IMO was completely unnecessary. It overpowered the delicious sweet oysters underneath.   The pork belly buns, which I saved for last, made my tummy and mouth happy.  Don't bother getting the shrimp bun, pork belly all the way.  Finally, I had to try the famous Milk birthday cake ($14/generous slice). Umm, maybe I was expecting too much, but it just tasted like any cake I could've baked at home. It was a little dry without much surprise or decadence like their crack pie or compost cookie.   Great service from Dale deserves 5 stars, but alas, the misses took it down 2 Stars.  I don't think I'll be craving momofuku in awhile.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. What I&#39;d order if I ever come back. Pork belly bun and the tuna special.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. $14 slice of birthday cake. Pass on this and get 2 more pork belly buns instead.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Yummy, crispy, fatty, tender pork belly goodness $7.

Ix7b_YLhKwlAi81YZ5hTXA.text: We had an absolutely PERFECT meal here.  I am wary of celeb chefs - I've been burned with overpriced, overhyped food.  But this was another level.  We were a party of 12, went without a reservation on a Monday night around 7p, and were seated within minutes.  Our waiter was probably my favorite waiter ever.  HILARIOUS.  We loved him.  (Server on my check says "Mags", I don't remember that being his name.)  Since we had so many people we got to try a lot of things.  Everything was a highlight but the "don't miss" dishes for me were:  Hamachi Shishito Peppers Ham tasting (OMG!)  Grits Asparagus (I know, right?  it was the best asparagus I've ever eaten.) Potatoes (there were 4 sides, we ordered them all, they were all exceptional)  Other things to mention:  The whole Branzino - delicate and beautifully prepared (and they left the head off at our request, thanks!)  Jidori chicken (nothing exciting, it's chicken .. put the Jidori in front of it, it's still chicken.  Order something else.) Dry Aged Ribeye - this sucker was $85.00 it came sliced for easy sharing, and let me tell you, I couldn't have eaten more than a couple of slices.  It was DIVINE, but so so rich.   I'd go back, and I've recommended this place to so many people already (so don't screw up!)   On the "could use improvement side" - Beer selection was weak and they really don't serve dessert, they send you "Milk" which is fine.  They could have gotten us dessert from there.  We ended up not doing dessert at all, so lost opportunity.    We had a blast.

uZIvke5duRp91F9I8HIaNg.text: I was SO disappointed by this place.  The server was super nice and helpful and the 2 stars are really for her.  Came for lunch so can't say about dinner but:  1. Buns - not bad but nothing exceptional. Most were over sauced or salted, the shiitake was recommended but the added flavor really overpowered the mushrooms (nice texture though).  Fish cake one I would actually recommend.  EXPENSIVE considering I can swing by and have chairman bao in the bay  2. Ramen - mediocre.  3. Szechuan noodles - inedible. I love Sichuan food and this was not sichuan in any way!  The green sauce was WAY too spicy and had none of the peppercorn mala flavor signature of Sichuan food.  The sausage was ok but lacked any complex flavor just salty  4. Brussel sprouts - not bad but the ones at rose. rabbit. lie were better.  For how much I paid for this meal I was really expecting something exceptional with complex flavors but this was the worst meal of my Vegas trip.  Save yourself a trip here and just catch an uber/lyft to Monzo and get a bowl of handmade udon.  You'll be much more satisfied.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

D0nO1YjyYHF35RRTLrqllA.text: I went here just last Saturday, on May 20th. Overall, the restaurant has a very modern vibe. There choice selection is on the medium-high range. I got the lamb ribs entree with cucumbers and yogurt. The taste was on point, BUT it was overly salty! Very salty.... I came in with a group of friends, but I could only eat that due to allergies. The rest of them got ramen and buns, which they said was good.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Lamb ribs with cucumbers and yogurt sauce

wu0Jbgf8Xtd0cKoXwVwzyg.text: I thought $17 was a little steep for a bowl of pork ramen... but then it came out with 1.5 servings of noodle and 2 big fat pieces of pork. Really good. Thanks for coming to LA.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

E64mxEhHE7fQt60LI90OQA.text: The menu seems to cater to larger parties and we were only a party of two so I felt a little like there were less options. Good quality food. I want to go back and try the noodles!

JlpDvmgKPSSwVJRmHgeePg.text: Incredible dining experience. Fantastic service and great food. I sat at the bar overlooking the kitchen. It was fun interacting with the kitchen and watching the food being prepared.  The spicy Korean sauce is a must. Every dish exceeded expectations. The cold noodles, pork belly bun and salmon stood out.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

-hkRqIuLK5ev9iuwjeKvxg.text: Got to sit at the bar so we were able to watch the chefs prepare the food. Such a great view :)  Got the ramen and pork belly bun and cucumbers. Loved every dish and would definitley go back to try more!

iglNfreQRm0TI9C7XgMgRA.text: We got the fish for free because it was like 5 minutes delayed and it was the best cod I've ever ate

0nQFmqk_wpwc8c3z6FBy7w.text: Came here late on a Saturday night. We just wanted a "snack" to hold us over.  My girlfriend and I shared a ramen bowl and a mushroom bun. The couple we were with also shared a ramen bowl.  The ramen was fantastic. Very porky broth, the pork shoulder and belly in the ramen was cooked perfectly and was delicious. It was hard for me to share it. The mushroom bun was also good but the star was the ramen.  The ambience is also pretty cool. From the high top we were sitting at if you look towards the back of the restaurant you could see the windows with all the light up signs outside and it really looked like a scene out of blade runner or something. I dunno I got a kick out of that.  I can't go 5 stars because of the price and the drink I had was meh. Had an old fashioned but the bourbon used or something was not that good. At $16 I expected better bourbon. 2 ramen bowls, 1 bun and 4 drinks was over $100.  Would come back just for the ramen.

_gX8k3mgd0ixEI9M8VeH6g.text: Came in for lunch and was seated almost right away. The service here was really good at the beginning and middle of the meal, but when it came time to wrap up we had to flag a different waiter because our server didn't stop by anymore (nbd).  We ordered the duck (smaller portion), pork shout ramen, and two pork buns.  The pork buns were deliciously fatty and rich. Personally, it's worth one but I don't think I could handle another.  The shoyu ramen had a similar pork belly as the pork bun as well as shredded meat (i think pork as well). The soft boiled egg was beautiful and large in the ramen. I really enjoyed the broth as it wasn't too oily and the right amount of flavor for me and the noodles had a good amount of bite to it.  When the duck came it looked beautiful. The amount of meat in each piece was pretty sizable. However, because of the thickness some pieces were a little more rare and led to being too chewy. The skin of the duck was also not crispy. I believe this dish is supposed to be eaten in a lettuce or pancake wrap, but personally the flavors get lost while doing so. I rather eat each component by itself or pair it with the rice it comes with.  Side note- something that threw me off was we were charged for water. Good thing I drank 4 glasses!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Pork Ramen, Pork Belly buns, 5 Spice Rotisserie Duck

gw6B6rg9JOBujyrBDoUjXg.text: All stars are given for area and extraordinary administration and introduction sustenance savvy we had an exceptional cook tasting menu.   All sustenance are incredibly new and great segment. Just criticism was a few dishes were marginally over season. Model: our fish patter with lobster and shrimps accompanied shellfish sauce on top. (Shellfish sauce is amazingly salty, and by and large isn't taken straightforwardly,) else that would be the fifth star.

JkWpkvo5cfNlAdcZdzniMg.text: This is the third time I've dined here and I've never been disappointed! I keep coming back for those warm pork belly buns and the Shoyu Pork Ramen. The big windows with a breathtaking view of the Strip is a great backdrop to any meal. Friendly staff, and it's been easy to just walk in for lunch without having to wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Pork Ramen

GYeFz9c4vHAcZJ0YRdT0-A.text: Slightly disappointed by my experience this time. Came in (just now) and sat at the table in the lounge area. Ordered the pork belly buns and the spicy chicken sandwich. The pork belly buns came out almost immediately and were delicious just like last time. Unfortunately the chicken sandwich was not the same. It was pink in the middle. Didn't really feel like getting food poisoning or salmonella so we didn't eat it. Paid for our pork belly buns and left. I'd only come back to get the pork belly buns.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The Pork Belly Buns
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy chicken sandwich (you can see how it&#39;s cooked on the edges but the center is pink)
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The Spicy Chicken Sandwich

CtYRJXONGL71eRvlpSUAOw.text: In terms of their food, they have really delicious food. The pork bun is the best and I also got the Salt & Pepper Lobster & Shrimp and 5 Spice Roasted Duck. Both are good but I think the pork bun is definitely the best. You need to make reservation to get in here and I went here for dinner. I think this place is kind of overpriced. I was here with 10 people and we spent around $70 per person. I think this is way overpriced for Asian food. This restaurant is located beside Milk Bar and you should definitely try the ice cream there.

bM-FA4nNOLY2zjU_ZlMMdA.text: I'm a huge fan of David Chang but I know I can't use this place for measure. I can definitely say that the service here is great and phenomenal, they know how to take care of you.   I ordered three different items: The Shoyu Pork Ramen $17; Kona Kampachi $26; Brussel Sprouts and Cauliflower $10  1. The Shoyu Pork Ramen: This had some really good elements put together. The pork belly was tender, and it had a nice outer crust that held it's shape together. You can also taste the pork meat itself that they also give and its not tainted with any other flavors. The noodles have a nice bouncy, and chewy texture to them. I would just rather have a soft boiled egg than a poached egg. The poached egg doesn't work. The shoyu broth wasn't very strong it was very light. Hard to tell whether they want the pork to be highlighted but broth is always important in Ramen.   2. Kampachi: I don't think this was really worth 26 dollars. The fish was fresh and clean. However this thick bacon ponzu sauce had such a strong smokey flavor in it; it just overpowered the fish. It would've worked much better if the ponzu and more zest was highlighted but it just doesnt sit well with me.   3. Brussel Sprouts: It's such a common ingredient to be used now in most restaurants but I think this was the one I really liked the most. The fish sauce gives it a nice salty, umami flavor with a good amount of heat.   Momofuku is the place you go to eat, just to say you've been there. Overall its pretty pricey, but then again everything in vegas is pricey.

XPQ-cLzL22b_K2r7sR5HrA.text: Food - 5 stars  What we got: - Shoyu Pork Ramen: omg so so good. Comes with a lot of meat - pork belly + pork shoulder, slow poached egg, nori, bean sprouts. $17 - Pork Belly Bun: also so so tasty - huge piece of melt-in-your-mouth pork belly, hoisin, cucumbers, scallions. $7 - Shrimp Bun: amaaaazing - shrimp with spicy mayo, pickled red onion, lettuce. $7  All the food was delicious and perfectly cooked. I wish I got to try some of the other dishes, but they were out of our price range lol.  Service - 3 stars Got seated quickly at a bar seat. Someone came by quickly to give us fancy water, but after that it took a while to get someone's attention to order. We went on a Monday, but still... pretty slow. On the menu, it says they charge $1 for unlimited water, but we didn't get a charge?  Definitely would come back here.... amazing amazing food, though I didn't see anything peach-related, unless I missed it? I was hoping for a yummy drink lol.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Bun
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fancy water

oca6ZDbxXeppYVGWori_hg.text: If there's one thing on the menu that's worth coming here for it would unequivocally be the pork belly buns! Hands down the beer pork belly buns I've ever tasted and finally glad I've finally had the opportunity to try this place after all of these years!  The pork belly was oh so tender while the cucumber cut right into the richness of the sauce.  Also tried the hamachi sashimi and a wagyu dish and some ham which were also good but the pork belly was definitely the dish that stood out above the rest.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bun

Gusf0L0K8ol2-NXC2YpLlQ.text: Did not disappoint! Had a big group and was accommodated pretty quickly during lunch on a Saturday. We had the pork belly bun for an appetizer and pork shoyu ramen for the main meal. The pork belly on the bun was humongous, cooked perfectly and tasted delicious! Definitely must try it! The pork ramen was really good as well. The broth was very flavorful, but wasn't too strong. The meat servings were super generous! Definitely a plus if you're a meat lover! The noodles were cooked just right for me, not too chewy. The servers get an A+ too, they were very friendly and helpful. We also really enjoyed the artwork inside! Overall a great experience!

Gg_vbjTCpUMqXHxwUPAC_Q.text: Had to try this place after seeing Ugly Delicious on Netflix. I ordered the Bo Ssam bowl and it was so so good. It looks simple, a kimchi rice with a glazed pork shoulder that is tender, flavorful, and sweet. The bowl has lots of pickles with carrots, thin shaved cucumbers, spicy korean white radishes, scallions, a runny egg, and pickled onions. It was such a beautiful and filling bowl, perfect for lunch.  Also had the yuzu lemonade, so refreshing!

gRaem3MZNMPkUnI-NOnR7Q.text: We ordered the sea bass, shoyu ramen and pork belly bun. The sea bass wasn't as good as I anticipated. I've had better ramen and the pork belly was over cooked. Glad I finally tried this place but I don't need to come back.

aSBUG6OqtG2V-dCr5RhmqQ.text: I've finished viewing Ugly Delicious and felt like supporting. Been to his east Village RESTO for his tasting before. It's a completely different thing here: behemoth place with lots of chairs.  Came only to try the ramen and the bao  Solid. Not excellent. Hearty. Noodles could be more "crispy", IMO  Service was very good and friendly. Easy place to dine. Ramen for dinner can be had at the bar area!

bk2EWOPsR_8xT7lOKdz2xQ.text: So it is what it is, eating on the strip you do expect a hefty price tag, especially with Momofuku being a well established restaurant in the realm previously.   I will say their veggie chickpea ramen is by far the best vegetarian ramen i've had. The spicy cucumbers, eh they were ok, I honestly thing for what youre paying for them they could be prepared better, it reminds me of a traditional korean dish but just not mixed, they mix the cucumbers with what I believe is rice vinegar and then garnish it with a little red pepper flake, I would prefer it mixed together but thats me. Crispy potatos were not bad, but i wasn't particularly diggin the sauce they were served with.   I like that you can order milk bar to your table, as there isn't much places to sit down and enjoy your ice cream elsewhere, overall solid restaurant again. I've only tried their lunch but maybe I will swing by for dinner sometime

p5i1pfCwLMpLV4miHqrW4A.text: The food selection is very odd. We had a difficult time creating an meal. Our server didn't help us much and then what we did get was okay, but super expensive. We ended up getting the Kampachi which was fishy and bland. The asparagus which was good, the sweet potatoes which were good, but not amazing. For an "entree" I got the beef noodles. They were filling, but not something I would normally get at a high end restaurant.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Back Bar
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Back seating area.

oyuvuUk1VfjCXIa6Ryb1hA.text: The food and service today were great! Victor, Ryan (the managers) and Cesar (the waiter) did a great job of accommodating us short notice for Christmas eve lunch. The cucumber cooler was refreshing, delicious and creeps up on you! The apple salad, noodle bowl and rice bowls were delicious and just the right portions! We will definitely return on our next trip to Vegas!  PS: Thank you Miko (the bartender)for the  recommendations on the food selections!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

P3HhNMrIaYPZ3-bDvppMNA.text: I ordered the Shoyan Pork Ramen- amazing flavor. You can tell the noodles are fresh and they sear the pork belly to give it a nice crisp. I'll definitely be back for more!   I also ordered the pork bun- melt in your mouth pork. Pair it with the chili sauce they provide and it's a great combo. The touch of cucumber adds the perfect freshness.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

8sAQhxdyH9cRjtK6Lkel9w.text: I am never disappointed when it comes to going to Momofuku. David Chang has done an amazing job with having great quality restaurants all over the USA. Their pork belly buns were amazing and I couldn't get enough of them. Only reason why I did not give a 5 star is because sometimes it was hard to wave down the server or bring over the check. It did take a very long time but luckily the food made up for most of it. They were very quick with refilling water and there was never an empty cup.

lD0EhXUWhIuLdku9iGreJg.text: This is my third time here and I am now completely in love with Momofuku!   Coming in at 12:30pm on a Thursday there was no wait at all and we were promptly seated.  Tried the truffle ramen (don't think this is on the menu anymore) last summer and thought it was good but not something I would come back for. Then in winter I tried the scallion noodles as well as the shishito peppers. I loved the shishito peppers but the scallion noodles weren't really for me (though my boyfriend enjoyed these). But this time around, everything we ordered was absolutely amazing - I'm actually craving all of it as I write this!   Chilled Spicy Noodles (w/ added poached egg): Wow oh wow is this delicious! So nice and refreshing with a very bright and fragrant flavor. The light saltiness of the sausage paired really well with the sweetness from the sauce. On top of that, the noodles were perfectly cooked & had a great chew. Would like to mention that I didn't find this spicy at all so don't be deterred by the name of you can't handle spice. Now onto the famed poach egg, I kind of regret ordering one - I'd rather have ordered 10. The yolk is AMAZING! Teetering on the edge of cooked and runny it was so thick and delicious, I just wanted a whole bowl of eggs... With that said, it worked really well mixed in with the noodles!   Shishito Peppers: We couldn't help but order this again. Simple but so addicting!   Pork Belly Bun: A great appetizer (or meal if you order 2-3 a person depending on how big your appetite is). The pork belly is so nice and succulent and tastes great with the hoisin and scallion. I also really enjoyed the pickled cucumber!   Crispy Potatoes: We ordered this side thinking that we wouldn't be full off the above three (we were wrong and left with a lot of leftovers) & because we thought these might be similar to the raved about butterball potatoes at Majordomo in LA. I honestly have no idea if this side is remotely similar but who cares because this might be my favorite dish. The potatoes are perfectly crisp on the outside and fluffy on the inside with this amazing honey mustard sauce. I don't really remember what else was in it, all I know is that this is so packed with flavor and so delicious!!   As for the space, it's inside Cosmo, is relatively large, and offers a great view of the strip because of its large windows.   Service was friendly and attentive as expected. Great explanations were given of each dish as it was delivered to the table. Waters were refilled for us even though they do leave the bottle at the table for you. We didn't have to wait long for the check. Everything just flowed right!   For pricing, I honestly thought it was really worth it for what we ordered. The portions were all quite large aside from the bun and the flavors were exemplary. We left with leftovers and all of this only costed us $60 after tax and tip which is honestly really good in Vegas for a meal of such good quality.   I will definitely be back the next time I'm in Vegas!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crispy Potatoes
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shishito Peppers
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Bun

scHGa2Qs7xppLSB4kW4MRw.text: Living not far from NYC and spending a lot of time and weekends there (you guessed it, I'm from jersey) I am no stranger to momofuku and been eating at Chang's restaurants since he opened them. I wanted to try this place and it being in the cosmopolitan I knew it was going to be semi swanky. I didn't find it crazy fancy inside which is good and we sat at a table with a revolving top. Server was excellent and everyone enjoyed their food. I got the garlic noodles, spicy cucumbers and pork belly bun. I was so full and honestly could have ate two of those buns they are so delicious  We went for lunch so I assume dinner is different menu a little bit. I am rarely in Vegas but if I find my way back I would go here again. I'll definitely hit the nyc ones as it's been a while

hvB1og_f2WOlWgfD--pCoQ.text: No need to go to NY or wait in line to try the famous Momofuku. It's also right next to Milk ( momofuku's dessert bar) but you will pay significant price for the real estate. The restaurant is located inside the cosmopolitan hotel. Almost everything on the menu is significantly overpriced. The quality control and food quality is good but go win some house money to splurge on the lobster dishes!

QwJI58Gy0KCBBQF2bDw76w.text: We had the pork belly buns and the Pork belly ramen. Husband wanted to try this place. I've ate at Momofuku in New York and for some reason my experience was better in the East Coast.   My ramen was pretty salty (took a star down for the saltyness). Pork belly buns were good. The boiled egg with roe was ok. Crack pie was good, cereal and milk ice cream wasn't anything exciting, cookie was good.  The service was actually pretty bad. As I look around to see other servers attentive to their customers, explaining their meals & menu, ours was gone, eating in back, she took forever filling up our waters, and wasn't really helpful with the menus for my friends who never ate here before. She wasn't really inviting and was prob over her shift. ( took a star down for the service)  Ambience was cool.  Overall, it felt "fusion" to me. If I want some legit ramen, I'll head over to Chinatown, maybe hit up a Japanese restaurant, with legit Japanese cooks, where I know service in Japanese restaurants are always inviting and half the cost.  I am editing the post because the manager Ricalynn kindly reached out to me in regards to our experience and sent a nice care package ( which I really appreciate and did not expect). Like any business, it's great to see someone reach out to a customer who did not enjoy a good experience. Raised the rating for reaching out to us. Thank you for the package & we hope to visit again.

rG-NBmK1oO1p3_ewTXAvzw.text: No wait on a saturday night 10pm for 2 people.  Tried their popular oysters ($30), pork bun ($6), shrimp bun ($8), and the chickpea ramen (about $15). Everything was good but in a very simple flavor way.  If youre looking for something savory, i don't think this will satiate you. Flavors are there but very clean and light.  The pork bun was my favorite.  Would have gotten the pork ramen had i had known how good the pork would be earlier. Oysters were small but i appreciated the sauce on top. Friendly service.

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork and shrimp bun

c8rlBWaEcCfdB0dImAVu5w.text: I heard about the ramen and had to try it for myself. I had the Shoyu Pork Ramen and was not disappointed. It definitely is fusion but you would like the broth which is not salty but flavorful. The guy next to me had the pork belly buns and they looked delicious. He said it was third time he was having that on this trip. The staff are friendly and attentive. Lovely restaurant atmosphere.

rMvSKSHvwlPFkbE6cy8Egw.text: Wow what a huge lets down  Do you like salt? Well there food is full of it from the Katsu chicken sauce to the pork ramen. Everything is super salty.   The only thing that wasn't was the pork bun  I was hoping that this place would be awesome based on the review but I would have to pass the next time I roll in to Vegas

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Zn_zCMsI3Pl-3-xZKPlM7Q.text: I was so excited to try Momofuku in Vegas and will definitely add it to my go-to places for dinner/drinks!  The atmosphere is great -- they have an awesome location in the Cosmopolitan overlooking the strip with great music/vibe.  The food was so fresh, light, and delicious.  We had the bib lettuce salad, cucumbers, pork belly bun, and spicy cold noodles.  Yumm!  Cocktails were great too.    Prices are reasonable by Vegas standards :)

Uh1fpnP3n2ftBZ8ddocFiQ.text: After many years of hearing about this place, I was finally able to try it. Maybe it was overhyped for me, or I didn't order the right things but it was just good. Not amazing but good, but I don't want to spend on a lot of money on "good."   We had the pork buns, shiitake mushroom bun, chicken karage bun and the momofuku oysters. The buns were great but nothing special about them to me. Same with the oysters. Surprisingly loved the fried Brussels sprouts but they are only a side dish, not a main.   Finally, the crack pie. This was my main reason for coming here. This may have been extremely over hyped for me but I thought for how small the dessert was, that it would be unforgettable and packed with flavor,  but I just didn't get that. Nothing I would rave about the way everyone does. Don't get me wrong, all round the food is great.. but I wouldn't say it's worth all the raving reviews. Would definitely try  it again to get different entrees because maybe I'm missing some amazing dish? Customer service excellent. Vibe is casual, trendy and old school hop music throughout dinner. Loved it.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crack pie
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Momofuku oysters
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The pork belly bun, shiitake bun and chicken karage bun, with the fried Brussels sprouts on the left.

hPcdsWAuBFnEFN1kWeNJvQ.text: The ramen wasn't amazing but it was a large serving size! This place is really cute and they were still able to accommodate us even after they stopped seating! The service was good!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

OvdWwfpacfRUnzzS9A6BEA.text: My boyfriend and I were recommended this restaurant and it did not disappoint! First of all, the atmosphere was perfect with windows surrounding the dining area for great lighting all around, music loud and quiet enough to have a good conversation, and an overall simple yet classy feel. The staff were all so welcoming as every person we passed greeted us hello and bye. Our server was informative and friendly and all other staff were just as friendly and attentive!  We initially ordered the pork belly bun, shrimp bun, and the ssam with the five spiced rotisserie duck. The buns were so tender and tasty and the ssam was amazing! The duck provided was well seasonwd, not greasy, and with thick slices of meat! My boyfriend who is Korean said that the kimchee was prepared perfectly regarding the spices and how it was fermented.   We also must have come on a great day because we were also given complimentary brussel sprouts & cauliflower (unexpectedly so flavorful and possibly the best brussel sprouts we have ever had) and the spicy cucumbers (refreshing, light, delicious).  The dessert comes from next door at Milk. They have unique flavors and it was nice end of our meal!

eoN84SYiwYfjHREDMAmc8A.text: I've been wanting to try this place because I've had their delicious sweets in NY! While the Momofuku Resturant was a great late night bite that filled our cravings, it fell a little short of my expectations. Maybe it was the limited late night menu? I wanted to try the Ramen, and it was okay. Good enough for regular Ramen, but not blown out the water Ramen. My boyfriend had the Chicken Katsu rice bowl and he liked it. I felt like the ginger taste in the gravy was a little too strong. I like that it had veggies though! The meatball bahnwhich was too spicy for me, and I put the sauce on the side. (I'm really sensitive when it comes to spicy food). My favorite dish was the Shrimp Bao! Loved that it came in a patty form and the bread was to die for! When I come back, I would get the Bao for sure, maybe in every flavor!   It was nice we could order dessert for the milk bar next door too. I have a big sweet tooth and I would come here just to get the dessert. I love the gluten-Free / Dairy Free Kolosses cookies! The coco was so soft and moist with the maple and coconut! My boyfriend got the Milkshake with the crunchy cereal but said next time we would not get the cereal in it because it was a little too much. Lastly I got some cookies in a cute tin to-go to take to family and friends. The Tin kept it from getting smashed in my luggage. Can't wait to come back!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Ramen was good. Not the best I had, but average.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Late night menu: Chicken Katsu, Pork Ramen, Meatball Bahnwhich and Shrimp Bao. (Spicy mayo on the side)
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 6 cookies in a tin for $17! (Normally $3/cookie)

seIzJaQs6pM1MoM4G3YAWw.text: OMG MOMOFUKU IS IN VEGAS!!! The name is so freakin' cute. This was our first food stop after checking in and dropping off our stuff. By the time we arrived it was late night happy hour and there were two seats at the bar with our names on them! We ordered the drinks right away. The white Cosmo slushie sounded cute and yummy so we ordered that and it was half off. It was so refreshing and delicious. For food, we ordered the shishito peppers, the pork ramen, and the ginger scallion noodles, and the pork belly bun. All the food was tasty. The pork belly bun came out first and it was gooooood. It always is though. The server brought the essential ssam sauce for us to eat it with. The shishito peppers were good too but I think it would've been even better without the powder sprinkled on top of it. Sometimes simple is more. Just a little olive oil and salt! Watch out for those random spicy ones. The ramen was good (but I've had better ramen elsewhere - it's not the best). The ginger scallion noodles were really tasty - it comes with shiitake mushrooms, cucumber and wakame and it's a cold noodle dish. It was simple flavoring but refreshing. I would totally get this again. I also added ssam sauce to it!   We ordered two more rounds of the slushie. Our last one was right at closing time, so our amazing server brought it to us on a to go cup so we didn't have to down it. So thoughtful! Overall good food, yummy drinks, great service, and typical trendy ambience. Perfect addition to Cosmo's dining options!

dHgPtZdVGSC-L3V3d9V2aQ.text: I loved it here, came here for my birthday all the way from Los Angeles. D was our server and went above and beyond to make the night special. Haven't had service that amazing the whole time we were in Vegas and we went to various restaurants. I don't even know where to start because we got almost everything excluding fried chicken and caviar and a few others.  The ramen is a must have and I hate ramen! I'm a believer now. No matter what you get you'll enjoy it and the atmosphere.  OH YEAH THEY HAVE A JAPANESE TOILET

0jzkQSJl8Sf5bdpemyuQ7w.text: Went here for lunch. The service was superb!   Ordered:  Ginger scallion noodle- It was bland. Pork ramen - It was way too salty. Pork belly bun - This was the only thing that's was delicious.   Overall the price was high for what it's worth.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

otr7GogaAuqkoJ4e4tJuZA.text: I visited previously on the second day of the soft open. As one might expect from a venue just two days old, the service, flow, and food timing were shaky, at best.  Fast forward a little over a month: I CAME BACK.   Boom. That, my friends, is really all you need to know. I came back for more. I came back after having tried everything on my "must order" list. Why does this matter? It matters because I very rarely make a return visit to "big name" venues. There are too many other places to experience to make return visits to places where I've seen, tried, and tasted.   So, why did I come back?  ~  ~  ~  ~  ~  ~  FOOD.   I'll be honest. I came in wanting, deep down inside, to walk out hating the food. I wanted my experience to be a living testament to the idea that overrated food is running rampant and that no one's stomach would ever be satisfied by chasing menu items as seen on the gram. That said, even on day two, I had no complaints. The food was all prepared well; good temperature, deep flavors, and balanced textures. The pork ramen, while not the best ramen I've ever had (hey, I have my biases), was still worthy of the notoriety. The broth was clean, clear, and very tasty and the egg was made for yolk porn. On the second visit, I switched up and ordered the chicken noodle soup because it had me at chicken schmaltz. When I was a kid, my family used to drive to Torrance, to a small strip mall to have chicken mami soup (shout out to my fellow pinoys). The Momofuku soup stirred up memories of that soup. Clear, richly chicken-y broth paired with the perfect choice noodle topped with moist chunks of chicken.   Baos are all great. And I typically hate baos. I grew up eating Filipino siopao and was often guilty of digging the filling out of the overly dense bread. The baos are all beautifully steamed and pillowy. All 4 options offer a perfect mix of all flavors and textures in each bite. The pork belly left nothing to be desired, but the shrimp was a surprise treat. I suggest these as top two choices, followed by the karaage and the mushroom.   However, the standout dish, by far, is the chicken katsu. I know the pie at the neighboring Milk Bar bears crack in its name, but the crack is clearly actually in the katsu gravy. On the first visit, we ordered the entree and split it amongst a party of 4. One the second visit, the katsu was also offered in a bowl presentation on a bed of rice with bok choy and thinly sliced pickled cucumber. I was assured that the gravy remained the same. Personally, I preferred the bowl option because adding a bowl of rice for $4 to the entree crosses some moral lines for me (and tempts me to bring a bag of rice in my purse).   ~  ~  ~  ~  ~  ~  SERVICE  The service was spotty on the first visit, but this was to be expected. I am happy to report that none of the hiccups experienced a month ago were even remotely existent this week. In fact, I was continually "freaked out" by how on top of things the staff were. There was one point where I took the last bite of a bao, turned to the right to say something to my husband, looked up and went, "where'd the steamer basket go?!". My water glass was never empty but I never really remember seeing anyone come to fill it. Unspoken service is very apparent here as I don't recall ever having to ask for anything other than for the server to take my credit card while our friends were in the restroom so we could cover the tab.   ~  ~  ~  ~  ~  ~  ATMOSPHERE  Restaurant has a great view, great light (ahem - very instaworthy), and great location.   Oh, be sure to use the restroom. Be sure everyone in your party uses the restroom.  Pricewise - not Chinatown. I have a tendency to under value Asian food because of the "Chinatown pricing" argument but, given the service, atmosphere, and well executed plates, I've been forced to reconsider my usual cheap tendencies regarding this type of food.   What's more: I'll probably be back. That's right, for a third time.   Last bits that I forgot to mention:  - cereal milk ice cream with chocolate chips; you're welcome  - if you order the branzino and the katsu, taste the branzino first (it's delicious but, since it's light, you won't like it after taking a bite of the crack-infused katsu gravy)   - enjoyed the cocktail with calamansi juice (tasted fresh and not bottled)   - you can order most of the milk bar items for dessert served to your table (except cakes and shakes and other things)  - thumbs all the way up for reservations on opentable   - private dining room looks awesome   - large format dinner options are available and tempting    - lunch through 2:30pm (no raw items at lunch)  - limited offering 2:30pm - 5:00pm   - full service dinner at 5:00pm

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp baos
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp cocktail
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cucumber salad

d2ijPDMrTxozNziAwB71fg.text: Some part of me doesn't like like paying so much for Asian food. With Momofuku being in Vegas in a Hotel, you know the price is even more inflated. Somewhere along the price line, I'd rather opt for a really good steak.  That being said, I did not regret my trip to Momofuku. People had told me how the portions were small and they came away hungry. Before you order the server tells you anything you order will fit on the plate in front of you (which was the size of a bread plate).  I went with three others and we ended up getting the Duck. It was amazing and actually quite filling. There was a table side preparation which added to the experience.  This was a great change of pace from the usual steak house, and although expensive, it was very good.

USeHsrTTmMPUnbQRe8yWeg.text: This place was great! The food was so good and impressive. I'm still craving those chilled noodles. They also have an amazing late night menu. Check it out!

SWlVg5XWAj8FSJdMndqopw.text: The Goods 1. Pork ramen: the noodles are what make this dish, they are aldente/chewy and have a light flavor.  For ramen lovers! It also comes with bean sprouts and pork as part of the toppings.  A lot of times they offer a sweet and spicy momofuku ramen sauce, add for extra zing 2. Chicken karaage and pork steamed buns: for someone who doesn't love steamed buns sandwiches I did enjoy these.  I removed the red onions.  I love the crunch and flavor of the karaage!   3. Cocktails: johnnys margarita is tasty and the seven spice sour with shichimi is worth trying for something different  4. Ginger scallion noodles: you gotta love the taste of pickled mushrooms, onions, and wakame seaweed.  Again the ramen noodles make the dish!  Note this is a brothless "ramen" dish  Service 1. Water or bottled, they keep it coming  2. Wait time is long and you usually end up sitting at the bar. 3. Can take a while for food  Ambiance  1. Inside Cosmopolitan Vegas: very upscale like a New York ramen house. 2. Try to sit where there is a window so you can take in the scenery and the strip 3. Fairly pricey for ramen, but worth trying once since there is only this one and the NY location 4. Credit cards accepted  5. Associated with milkbar by Christina Tosi  MoJo 1. It's an experience.  I'd say a combination of trying a concept from NY is what puts it on the map 2. Ramen is what they are known for but they have some high priced items like wagyu beef

xltObNHY5oB4ia_o8szYoA.text: 5 stars for the cereal milk soft serve ice cream! Its not that sweet with a delicately delicious flavor.  Get the pint and ask for extra cups/spoons to share, much better value that way.   Fruit cereal milk tasted like milk in a bowl of fruit loops cereal.

NgoqxG-fugSks5tJnmjYZA.text: Tried the Pork Ramen w Shitake and the Pork Belly bun.   Fair warning - I'm from San Francisco so the bar is high for good ramen and pork belly buns.  Pork Ramen 4 out of 5 stars - comes w shredded pork shoulder, poached egg, slice of pork belly, vegetables, noodle and some tasty broth. Added shitake which I would strongly recommend. Shoulder was a tad dry and I think broth is what makes or breaks ramen. This one was good but I've had better. Also couldn't not adjust spice level - they only offer one level.   Da Belly Bun 2 out of 5 stars - the bun was warm and fluffy. That is where the fun stops :(  Belly wasn't particularly tasty and the sauce was nothing special.   Bottom line - go for the ramen and excellent service. Skip the belly bun.

jfbOYAi_1b4LLjP0ezTJQA.text: Stopped in the bar for a quick drink. The bartender was personable & served us quickly & adequately. Will definitely make this a date night destination

dGFXzlOH9CQHfEuADOtioA.text: I just realized I have not reviewed Momofuku.  This place is the stone cold nutz! Loved everything from the moment I entered this restaurant! Hostesses great! Servers amazing! Food fabulous! Manager present! Do not miss it! Nom Nom!!!

PD_RV6r3Wl6CBV8Dyw0bjA.text: If you are having an intimate wedding in Vegas & are looking for a place to dine afterwards, check out Momofuku!  I was so upset that I had not looked into it before because they have several Family Style set meals that look so delicious!  I was telling my husband we should have went here instead of Delmonico (shade, I know) for our after wedding dinner.  Make sure to make a reservation because it is a popular restaurant!  I had left a note on Open Table stating that we were celebrating our 1st dinner as newlyweds & we were wow'ed by how great the customer service was.  We got complimentary glasses of champagne & had a gorgeous view of The Strip.  We truly felt special, thank you!  Whole Roasted Branzino:  Whoa, they were not kidding when they said their dishes are meant to be split.  Thus Branzino was huge!  It wcould have fed 4 people & still left them full.  Loads of flavor. Ginger Scallion Noodles:  Highly recommend!  Super flavorful! Pork Belly Buns (2):  Tender, juicy pork, mmm.

Mrzo8mrKc0StJgrkuhkxMg.text: Our first stop in Vegas was to grab dinner at Momofuku. I've heard so many good things about their ramen and was so excited to try it! I was a bit thrown off when I saw that they didn't have ramen on the menu. When we asked the waiter, he told us that they do not include the ramen on their dinner menu but you're still able to order it. Which is kind of weird imo because it's one of their popular dishes.   I ordered the pork belly buns and shoyu pork ramen. The pork belly buns were soooo good and juicy! It literally melted in my mouth and the sauce was bomb! The ramen was also very flavorful,  the pork was nice and tender, and the egg was nicely poached and not runny into my soup They have sauce for the ramen that tastes like a mixture of sriracha and hoisin sauce. The food is on the pricier side but it's what you should expect from restaurants located in hotels on the Strip.

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Pork Ramen

7liUdM969gdvzLh8V7q7Dg.text: Got the pork belly buns and a bottle of the sauce to take home with me to Connecticut! I heard of this restaurant from watching, "Ugly Delicious" on Netflix who happens to be the owner.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. So happy to have purchased this!
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Buns 5/5

FIP14RInFaRfvlbOuiuJzQ.text: One of the nicest atmospheres I've ever eaten ramen in.  I had the shoyu pork ramen and there's very few places that can cook the tamago just right and this place nailed it both times I went!  They give you a choice of regular or sparkling water so of course I had to go with the sparkling and was not disappointed.  They have a decent choice of drinks, but they're a little overpriced.  Definitely a place I have to stop and have ramen when I visit Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fanciest water I&#39;ve ever been served

s6QDavN0wAj0lKSgQBTMNA.text: Omg two words: pumpkin ribs.  Are these pumpkin flavored ribs you ask? No. They were pieces of PUMPKIN that taste just like ribs it's like magic (which is funny because ya know, Vegas).  Everything else we had was good too, but these "ribs" were totally the standout.   I also love the cocktails. This is such a great spot to have some snacks and drinks, but also great to sit down and have a feast for dinner.   Service was spot on, super friendly and he obviously really liked his job which made the experience that much better. Definitely a dynamite spot.

tiCVKbhxvbNWxPOF0Ywhzw.text: First timer trying Momofuku. Heard really good things from friends so we decided to give it a try.   For appetizers we ordered the Shishito Peppers and the Pork Belly Buns - they were DELICIOUS, totally recommend   For our Ramen, we both ordered the Shoyu Pork Ramen and a side of Bon Choy. The meat was soooo good.   I typically prefer my ramen to be more on the spicier side, this ramen was not spicy at all. However in this instance, I still really really enjoyed my meal.  If you are looking for good ramen in Vegas, I would totally give this place a t

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Pork Ramen and an old fashion drink

ToQrlAr_MQKnvXuoQy9BUg.text: Momofuku Las Vegas was outstanding during its first two years at the Cosmo.  I regularly visited for the duck, the pork chops, the baos and ramen late night.  As someone who has enjoyed David Chang's restaurants since opening in NYC in 2004, I was excited they opened this beautiful space, covered with David Choe art in Las Vegas.  We celebrated our anniversary here in May and couldn't have been more disappointed.  The same dishes I've been regularly enjoying have all gone down hill quite a bit.  Both the pork baos and pork chop were overcooked and the miso sea bass was underwhelming.  I could only guess this coincided with the departure of executive chef Shaun King (who left to open a restaurant in Portland).  Unfortunately David Chang is not there to supervise his restaurant so we're really dependent on quality chefs that can consistently cook and deliver the menu as it was intended.  I'm hopeful this kitchen gets it together and can bring back the experiences I've enjoyed in the first couple of years.  This downfall happens with too many celebrity owned restaurants that open in Las Vegas only to be corporate run by others without the same passion it began with.     **Additional note**  We were gifted a Momofuku gift card and after we turned it in to the waiter with my credit card for the remaining balance he returned moments later and said they do not accept Momofuku gift cards at this location and went ahead and charged the entire $300+ amount on my credit card!  I suppose it's partially our fault for not checking ahead of time but this was a major disappointment (probably has something to do with being located in a casino) and perhaps we would have tried a new restaurant had we known we were going to be paying the full amount out of pocket.  On the flip side, we were able to use the card at Majordomo in Los Angeles which was 5 stars outstanding!

zhxvCTPpI-yCDx3jK_bkFw.text: *Lunch review  I really wanted to love this place and I dont want to sh** on this restaurant, but it was very overpriced.  It seemed as if the lunch menu was the same price as the dinner menu.    We started out sharing the Pork Belly Buns ($14) and the Pickle Plate ($12).  Both were delicious and they both went together,  yet it seemed like some pickled items to munch on should come with this dish complimentary.  I'm not saying the same as the small plate, but some.    For our entrees we shared the Grilled Striped Bass ($28) and the Bo Ssam Bowl ($17). I started with the Striped Bass and I feel it kinda fell off.  The salt pearls on the greens were good and the mushrooms also.  The kimchi butter I'm assuming was the sauce at the bottom of the dish, this was pretty good.  The fish was good, but not exceptional. This dish fell short of imagination I guess,  not what I expected from what I've seen David Chang cook on his docuseries (Ugly Delicious or Mind of a Chef). The Bo Ssam was tasty, but I thought and I guess I assumed it was gonna come out in a cast iron pot.  Once again, tasty but the cast iron pot, making the rice crispy and burnt, would have put it over the top.   Drinks were good  $14 slice of cake for the birthday cake was deffinately over priced and nothing special.   I wish I could have tried the Salt & Pepper Crab & Shrimp ($289 for 4-6 people).  I just cant pay that much for the wife and I especially for lunch.  They even offered to order a half plate but still $145 for a lunch entree does seem over priced.   It seems like it is assumed that people will pay the high price, therefore they should charge the high price.  I dont mind paying for food but in the context of what I'm eating really makes the difference.

sgLeLcgR5quotnAA_5ZBUA.text: Yumm!   I've always wanted to try David Chang's Momofuku restaurants and you bet I did not pass up the opportunity when coming to Vegas.   The restaurant is located amongst others inside the Cosmopolitan.  I went with a group of friends after EDC weekend and it wasn't too busy. But a reservation is definitely recommended.   The pork belly shoyu ramen was interesting and quite tasty. Although I am not a real big shoyu fan.. I gotta stick with my creamy tonkotsus   However, the Momofuku OYSTERS were out of this world good!! Probably the best rendition of grilled oysters I have ever had. It is life-changing!!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Nk06B9LmRm_fVX7BftZuag.text: Awesome food and awesome service. I can't really pinpoint the style of Momofuku. It's not Asian fusion. Or at least not exactly the underwhelming and cliche Asian fusion restaurants I've come across. Momofuku has its own unique twists to dishes that make it distinct, yet reminiscent of Asian comfort food.   Momofuku is located at the Cosmopolitan close to The Chandelier. We had no trouble getting seating for two people on a Friday night. The two servers were so friendly and every water glass was filled and empty dishes were cleared with efficiency. Almost too well and overly attentive. Lighting is a little dark. Great for a romantic ambiance.  1. Pork Belly Buns (5/5): The first bite and I was in love. Typically this type of dish is made with Peking Duck and served during special occasions. I'm surprised the pork belly worked so well. My friend and I literally looked at each other with joy once we took in the first bite. The meat is so tender, not gamey, with just the right amount of pork belly fat. Worth the $7 each.  2.  Honey crisp Apple Salad (5/5): I do believe this dish is offered year-round, but the ingredients are seasonally changed with slight variations. I was expecting a wimpy salad with little bits of apple. Not the case at all. In an unexpected take, it's actually large pieces of apple coated in spices. Sitting on labne (like thick yogurt) with some sort of citrus oil. With crispy bacon and topped with arugula. Absolutely delicious.  3. Beef noodles (3/5): Probably the most disappointing dish. It's essentially a type of Szechuan-inspired noodle dish. Not worth the price at all. A small serving of thin yellow noodles, bits of ground beef, and a Szechuan chili-based sauce. Wasn't impressed at all.  Overall: This restaurant is an ideal date spot or celebration spot. I probably wouldn't put it on my regular rotation, but I can definitely see how Momofuku has impacted so many diners.

990DLHxgGd05GehXTn-Z8Q.text: Yay! Finally got to try Momofuku! Met up with my girlfriend and her husband for dinner and this is what she wanted.   After making several calls on Saturday, I learned that dinner service starts at 5:30 pm.  Because it is so busy, no walk-ins are accepted, you have to RSVP, like early.  For this past Saturday, the only available time was 9 pm and 10 pm, which was too late in the evening as my husband works super early in the morning. I learned that our option to walk-in for dinner at 5pm is at the bar. It took a few phone calls and different people to understand this.   My husband and I get there and I see that the tables and bars aren't filled. So I grab a corner at the bar so the four of us can still have a conversation since all the tables were taken.  But then the hostess walks a couple over to that very spot.  I ask her since it wasn't busy, could we have this corner spot and they can take the two seats over.  She says no because there is a wait. Hmmm...we were just there, there wasn't anyone there!! Well, just like that, 40-minute wait. Where in the world did these people come from!!!???  I'm not digging the main hostess either, the other hostesses were alright. It may have been her bun that was tightly pulled back, eyeglasses and the emotionless, smileless facade that's bugging me.  So we sit and the service was good. Our server explained the family style dishes and encouraged it since there was four of us.  Short menu, but expeeeeeensiiiiive :o Not a problem, we'll split the bill.  We ordered jidori chicken, lamb ribs and scallion noodles.  Although ramen was not listed on the menu because it is not sharable, it is available to order.  Since the three items we ordered was already $100, we decided that if we were still hungry, we could order the ramen later.  The food was good.  The chicken was piled high. there were 8 ribs where the meat practically fell off the bone and the noodles were really good, which I wish we had more of.  The still water was really good too, filtered 7 times with the special machine they have in the back.   Earlier, when we were waiting for a seat to be available, my girlfriend bought a few items from Milk next door.  When we were done with dinner, the waitress asked if we wanted dessert.  Instead, my girlfriend wanted to share with us what she got from Milk since the dessert menu for Momofuku comes from Milk anyway.  So the server was happy to help us out with providing us plates, a knife and forks.  Turns out, my girlfriend's husband paid for dinner.  It was a thank you for the show tickets we got for them. That was very sweet of them, so I'm glad we were content and didn't order more food.  I don't want to bankrupt my dear friend.  So the rating - Great food service, lighting was a little too dark for me, but nice atmosphere, great food, not pleased with the robotic hostess nor the price.  So although we were here for the food, for that kind of price, I expect fabulous service from the hostess as they set the tone for the entire experience. It isn't the best rating but it isn't the worst either.  3-stars for Momofuku.  I'll be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ginger scallion noodles @ $15
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Family style lamb ribs @ $48.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Family Style Jidori Chicken @ $58

JM6YW0rmRXAaH3JauSIH7w.text: I've heard good things about the Momofuku restaurants in NYC, but never had the chance to go. Happy to have been able to visit the Las Vegas location on a recent family trip. Overall, food was great modern twist on classic Asian flavors, but definitely on the pricier side.  1. Honeycrisp Apple Salad: Was not expecting it to be just apples with a few slices of bacon - but was pleasantly surprised by how good the dish was. The sweetness and crunchiness of the apples were paired well with the spiciness of the kimchi and saltiness of the bacon.  2. Pork Belly Bun: A must try according to all of the reviews and definitely delicious - but at $14 for 2 buns not sure if it's worth.  3. Whole Roasted Branzino: Our waiter recommended this to us as a good dish to share among our family of 4. Soft boneless branzino grilled with kimchi on top resting on a bed of crisp rice was definitely my favorite dish of the night. But again, not sure if it was worth $72.  Great place to try on the Vegas strip if you're willing to shell out the big bucks for a nice meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Whole Roasted Branzino
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Bun

AghF0goh7hu4rvpLBEbs4w.text: Go to spot on the strip. Ramen bar doesn't require reservations, and you can order the amazing ramen and pork belly buns.  Truffle ramen is expensive, but worth it especially if you share it with someone. I would recommend adding pork belly $5 to it instead of duck confit, which was yummy but is $18 extra. Super flavorful broth. Savory and aromatic.  Pork shoyu ramen and pork buns are amazing too.

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Truffle ramen with duck confit

nLxaNAC0Wkg2ggn818ifwA.text: I came here specifically for the Shoyu Pork Ramen.  The ramen was by far one of the tastiest, delicious ramen I've ever had. Surprinsgly very reasonable too.   They are very generous with the pork (lots of it) and the broth is to die for. Very flavorful but not overwhelming.   The noodles were cooked to perfection. I added mushrooms to give the ramen more texture. The runny egg and seaweed made the broth creamy and delightful. Service was really good.

zXIIbJ-D_bx9wyRIX7kLgw.text: Went here for my brother's 21st birthday and they did not disappoint. The pork belly buns are a MUST when visiting. Their Saam sauce is amazing with the buns! It's a bit on the pricier side but I think that it's worth the experience. Some things are more worth trying than others. The pork belly is a must- I think it's one of their most popular dishes, understandably so. The spicy cucumbers are also delicious! They're refreshing and surprisingly delicious- I'm normally not a fan of cucumbers, but they have such an interesting taste. Amazing that something so simple was extremely delicious! The wagyu flat iron steak was amazing! The meat was so tender and the sauce over it was light and sweet. It makes my mouth water just thinking about it. Other dishes I could have done without. The grilled lamb and the wasabi potatoes I could have done without. The wasabi was overpowering and the sweet potato flavors and strong wasabi did not compliment each other. The potatoes were nice and crispy but the flavors did not match up to me- it was my least favorite dish. The lamb was also a bit salty to me as well. It was not as delicious as some of the other dishes. The Hawaiian kampachi is also worth mentioning. It was light and fresh. The fish was super tender and I loved the hint of orange! Overall most of the dishes were really good and I would definitely come back!   Also they gave my brother a cookie from the famous milk stand right next door for his birthday which I though was a very nice touch!

ZuEuJaKoqCXygf0MMkwHMA.text: This place is amazing!!  I have been here several times now and the food has been consistent and so good.  When there is a VGK game and we need dinner afterwards, I always come here!    The drinks are amazing as well. Look at the photos from the several times that I've been here. Noodles, yes yes!!!  If you haven't tried the food here, you are missing out!!!  My favorites are the oysters and the noodles.  The staff is friendly and the place is always busy.  I've sat at the bar and also in the main and private dining areas. Whenever my friends come in town and ask for restaurant recommendations, I always point them to  Momofuku!!
