G3VDP2milhFjwKpCsyVtLQ.text: First, let me give a shout out to our waiter Eric who is the greatest server I have ever encountered in my life.    My three girlfriends and I came here for dinner on a Saturday night and spent a whopping 5+ hours here sitting, eating, drinking, and talking.  I think that's kinda what David Chang would want his guests to experience.    We ordered a variety of buns - vegetarians, there's a shitake mushroom bun that's not on the menu, but our server mentioned that they could make it for me and I HIGHLY recommend - the peach burrata salad, noodles, rice cakes, the brussel sprouts & cauliflower and the shishito peppers, and lamb.  Everything was impeccable.  My favorites were the shitake mushroom bun, garlic and onion noodles, and the shishito peppers.  For dessert, we had the funfetti birthday cake and that my friends was the cherry on top of the perfect dinner.  Once our waiter noticed that we had befriended a nearby bachelor party, he also brought us over some chocolate truffles to go with our wine which was so kind of him.    The four of us had an unforgettable experience here, and even though three glasses of wine were broken and spilled in the process, the staff was so friendly and let us have so much fun well after we were done dining.    100% coming here the next time I'm in Vegas!!!

CvkyKGI7BbCBMK1j1opVlw.text: We got here with a group of 7 and we all really enjoyed the food. We ordered some appetizers. The sweet and sour beans were strictly OK. The spicy cucumber was great, but we really loved the shishito peppers. For our main course, we ordered the duck, family style, the whole Hidori chicken and Ginger Scallion Noodles. The Duck was carved in front of us and it was amazing how our chef cut it perfectly. It was truly a spectacle. The duck was laid on a beautiful bed of rice topped with duck confit. Yum! The chicken was also very well spiced and flavorful and was complimented well by the noodles.  The duck bones were later fried with lots of spices and brought to our table soon after. A little salty for me personally, but definitely a crowd-pleaser. A special shout out to our waitress to whom we made a very odd request (de-boning the chicken). Sorry! We realized that was weird once she started. We just thought it would make it easier to share. For dessert, we got a few crack pies which I personally wasn't a fan of. I would easily skip the next time.  I would definitely recommend getting a reservation before reaching there. Vegas can be extremely busy, especially on holiday weekends.

-Oyrd5nHAGM_g5bLDzzkvw.text: When did Momofuku open up a branch in Vegas? As if the Cosmo wasn't hip enough.  On a Saturday morning, a friend made a reservation for 6 and when we showed up on time we waited maybe 10 minutes to be seated. Our server was quick with water and specials of the day, which included a decadent truffle ramen and a $38/oz wagyu (unlimited ounces if you're interested). However, everyone in our party had one thing in mind: their fabled pork ramen. It did not disappoint. The noodles are thin, soft, and not over cooked, not really the star of the show. The broth is full of flavor but not fatty (this might disappoint tonkotsu ramen fans though). I could have done without the pulled pork but the chunk of solid pork was tender and juicy--just ultimate perfection. Interestingly, instead of an ajitsuke tamago style egg that's hard boiled with a jelly yolk, they went for a poached egg. A little sloppy when you eat but still yummy. Serving sizes are plenty.  Good times overall. Service is friendly and fast. The food may be a bit hyped at $17 per bowl, but it's a painless experience and good for groups.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

UAyLcI5qSiIOvk4INnQMzw.text: Ok, here's a useful tip right out the gate for what is likely to be a rambling, gushing review.    Except for the small plates and buns, everything else here is huge, so plan your dining experience strategically!  I personally would recommend the Bo Ssam.  This is a wedding cake sized hunk of slow-cooked barbecue, a pork shoulder that is barely retaining its corporeal form when it makes its way onto the table.  This arrives with a whole stable of accompaniments, add a side of white steamed rice and you're cooking with gas!  You take the pork shoulder apart, mixing it in the drippings, wrap in lettuce, add Ssam sauce, kimchi, and wait for your eyes to roll back into your head.  They're not kidding about the party that this serves, so don't make any additional allowances for how much you can eat. You can always order more if it turns out that you do have the gastric fundus of a bull elephant.  The menu here is full of the playful, thoughtful food epiphanies that Chef Chang has had and expounded on over the years. It seems to me that the menu is crafted to play on flavor and the food memories associated with those flavors.  Take for example one of my favorite menu items, the cucumber salad.  This is chunks of kyuri tossed in a dressing that usually accompanies sea cucumber or jellyfish on a traditional Chinese restaurant "cold plate".  Usually the opening salvo in a traditional celebratory Chinese restaurant dinner like at a wedding or anniversary. So for me, this was both a little upsetting but also euphoria-inducing when my conscious brain finally wrested control from my reptilian mid-brain and I realized that this was cucumber and not sea cucumber.   An apparently simple dish that hid a wealth of thinking about food, an encyclopedic flavor vocabulary, and mad culinary skills.  I particularly appreciated the restraint in preparing a simple ingredient without going overboard to dress it up.  That same principle of just highlighting what nature has already made very good to eat and perfectly enjoyable permeates the entire menu.  I continue to be in awe of that kind of discipline, thoughtfulness, and love.  I absolutely loved it here and I hope you give Momofuku Las Vegas the time and attention that it deserves to truly understand and appreciate every nuance and suggestion, of which there is an abundance.

1Nzm0FYfGJR4_ArdhG4sqg.text: I'm a big Ramen fan. I've been wanting to go here since I began eating Ramen years ago. I was not disappointed. The Shoyu Ramen and appetizers were outstanding! I'd definately go again! This place does not disappoint.

ldfUkb2TGoYNYGh28kAjeA.text: Lots of fun at this place. David CHANG's kitchen is famous for his cook book, run on Anthony Bourdens show. All can try asian fusion fatty food : pork belly, BBQ sauce, pork shoulder, ramen... all the carbs you need. Beautiful view of the Paris hotel opposite side of the strip, bamboo like modern interior decor and the milk bar (Christina tosi) desserts served (read skip the line!) amazing

46XqFnJvNhwztGKLZmOapw.text: Service. Excellent. Pork Shoyu Ramen. Excellent. Char shu was fall off the bone good. They give you two types of pork in the bowl. Portion is not so much & is pricey but worth it. If you like spice. Make sure to ask for the powder & oil spice. Servers were attentive.

qSNb7IR9zSm6qwfDnEYi9A.text: This was a destination stop, huge David Chang fan. Started with the devilled eggs, these are a definite must if you're stopping here! Moved on to the oysters Momofuku, kimchi version of oysters Rockefeller, which as weird as that sounds it was incredible!  Finished off with the shiitake bun, which was just ok. LU2qpD8GH65_WGCBpez_0Q.text: This place is delicious.  We had the cold noodles with sausage on both visits.  After the first night I was craving it all day so ended up going back.  The steamed buns with pork and the buns with shrimp were amazing.  The lamb ribs were very flavorful.  We loved this place and would drive back just to eat here and then hit the milk bad next door.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

QykVyTIHchRHEo93OgwVNg.text: I strongly recommend the pork belly bun, $7!! It is phenomenal! It consists of a thick slice of pork belly, which was seared to perfection, a nice amount of hoisin sauce and garnish in a perfect steamed bun! I wish I didn't devour it in 2 bites because it was sooooo goooood!!   I also ordered the pork ramen, $18, (I should've ordered something else because I was already having the pork bun, but oh well) it was pretty good! The dish had a good amount of egg noodles topped with a handful of shredded pork, a slice of grilled pork belly, bean sprouts and green onions, and a perfect poached egg. The broth was smoky and flavored well! It is not a creamy type of broth like regular ramen.  I did not get to try the other dishes because I was just passing by, but it would be a really fun experience to come with a group and try their special dishes!   Service was 5/5! Our waiter was funny and welcoming! He also is very informative and explained the whole menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Ramen, $18!
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Bun, $7!

9oC3bkvKzVyJF7Khq8ToUw.text: Momofuku has finally opened it's doors in Las Vegas! Momofuku Noodle Bar is a restaurant that I've been waiting for to open since I've heard about the hype it gets in NYC.   Compared to other ramen places, Momofuku has a more classy atmosphere that illustrates an upscale mood. This classy environment also results in a pricier menu compared to your typical ramen place.   For my meal, I tried the pork belly bun, pork ramen, and bday truffles from Milk Bar. The pork belly bun's bun was quite soft and their pork belly and toppings were very flavorful. The pork ramen consists of a shoyu broth, which I typical don't get at ramen places, but I definitely think that the broth, noodles, and toppings were on point!  Their slow-boiled poached egg was as soft as a pillow and had a melt-in-your-mouth feeling! The bday truffles were quite sweet for me, so I took some of them home.   Since the dishes are quite pricy, this is not a place for those on a budget. For a special occasion or if you just want to try this place out, I definitely recommend this place!

enKbw0qELmYe5fnzy4c1Hw.text: Everybody told me... "You need to check out Momofuku." Uh huh. Not really my thing, I thought. Went here on a business trip and... totally my thing. Cool layout. Zx-3WAzwpkHlFcvBMxkW7A.text: So the Cosmo has gotten really trendy but one of the things we really love about vegas now is that all your favorite food places from around the country are now all in on spot. Now we didn't go and eat here but did stop by to pick up some snacks at the Milkbar.  My wifes favorite thing is the crack pie.  Anyways, if you have a cookie craving, this is the spot.

nFURSf1eWowyeCPAd8BjMA.text: The duck for the table was delicious. The service was a little meh, and we were sat at a table that every waiter and customer walked next to so that was aggravating. Absolutely recommend the 5-spice duck for 4-6! It was unreal good.

qzXWfgqwAY3-9JwZQRQ1lg.text: Brilliant. Completely awesome. You need the pork belly ramen and the various korean meat buns.  When you are gambling and drinking free cocktails and you need food at 10:30 PM at the Cosmopolitan, there is only one thing you do.  Only one.  ONE.  You sit at the counter and eat ramen and fried shishito peppers.  With Tiger beer.  And then you get your butt back to the casino!  Or so I'm told.  I heard that somewhere.  Not that I know anything about that.  It would get 5 stars except it's a little but overpriced, but when you're blowing all your cabbage at craps anyway, who cares if this awesome drunk grub costs a couple bucks more than necessary?  Not me.

8pCspYKp0_I3mMX-nLOylw.text: My husband and I stopped by and ordered ramen. It wasn't bad but the poached egg in both of our soups were still cold. Our server seemed like a nice guy  but so slow and was completely unaware when we tried to flag him down. He didn't even come refill our drinks until we were done with our food. 42vy3RMI53yJfbYmioLVFQ.text: Not a positive dining experience. Reading other reviews we came in with high hopes. However we found the food extremely underwhelming and overpriced for what we received. The only dish we enjoyed was the pork bun and the pork ramen, however not at the price we paid.   We also tried the popular ramen eggs with roe and it  just tasted like boiled eggs with bacon. All this being said, the hot toddy we ordered was delightful.

7kO9MN5sDIBnze_enElZ4g.text: We really enjoyed the food here. but it was extremely salty. The chickpea ramen is vegetarian, not vegan. They use egg noodles and have butter in the broth. The ginger scallion noodles are vegan and delicious. We also got the shishito peppers which I could have passed on. Staff was great. Delicious food. But really feeling the salt bloat!

dv8uQ19w7clCW6VLjZukBQ.text: Wasn't too impressed with the food here.   Customer service was 5/5  Lobster dish was 2/5 - for $240 you get 6 tails and some shrimp. Everything was battered and fried super heavy and salty sweet with oyster sauce drizzle on top   Ramen 1/5 - salty and tasted like just ponzu sauce and water mixed together for the broth.   Cucumber salad 5/5 - very refreshing

UmU-qK0mlZGFt680lVamzA.text: My friend and I just saw Charlie Puth in concert when we arrived upon this high rated spot. We arrived on a concert high, excited & hungry!! We were having the best time that night and we kind of ordered too much food to feed 6 people!! Haha! First up, cocktails! At $15-18 a pop we expected very damn good drinks!! I loved my Peruvian Sour, it was made perfectly! My friend ordered the Cherry Milk Punch, it was a bit strong for her (so I guess very generous with the rum), so then she ordered the Miso Mellow, which tasted better. Both was good, just depends on your taste. Next we had the Pork Belly Buns. OMG!! The BEST thing on the menu in my opinion!! Tender, juicy, fatty, tasty, all rolled up in a soft pancake white bun. So good we ordered 2 more orders. You must eat this, it will not disappoint!! Also try it with their sweet chili Korean Sauce for some added extra flavor!! I also ordered some raw oysters on the half shell topped with smoked trout roe, it was sooo good!! My main course was the Ginger Scallion Noodles with seaweed, mushrooms, scallions, cucumbers, & garlic. My noodles were perfect, and the flavors were great! I forgot to ask if the noodles were made fresh in house because they tasted homemade. Please let me know!! I'd definitely order this again. My friend had the Shoyu Pork Ramen Noodle soup bowl with a poached egg. From what I had sampled, it was flavorful & delicious as well. She finished that bowl clean before me and couldn't stop talking about it. The only thing she complained about was the noodles. She preferred them to be cooked a little longer, to be a little more tender. Maybe if they boiled it a little longer?? The total service was great! We were greeted & seated right away. We had Manny as our server and he was very attentive, nice, and friendly. Over all experience a 4! I'd return again and recommend this place whenever visiting Vegas. Keep up the great work you guys!!

pfAmLuLLdjFuSyKG9_YfcA.text: I have to give this place 5  from our outstanding meal last night.   First off, customer service was top notch. Our waiter was constantly checking on us and our water kept on getting refilled without us asking.   Second, the food was spectacular! We started with the boiled eggs topped with smoke trout eggs and crispy rice; tasty but little overpriced. We had the oysters with melon ice that wasn't needed since oysters were fresh and sweet. The cold spicy noodles were flavorful. The Pork Buns though were amazing! We could have a meal with just those. And then our grand finale of the night was the Bo Ssam pork shoulder wraps with all the condiments... SUPER good!!! We got the small which fed 5 of us.

Jc9rmH2UyTHrkUlK1exlHw.text: I'm a Momofuku superfan so of course I had to try it when coming to Vegas. Living in NYC, Momofuku is right at my doorstep but I had to see what Chang was up to in the desert.  Doesn't disappoint one bit. They've got the Johnnys Marg, the buns, the compost cookies, and of course the noodles. Everything you could want minus the Fuku sandwich!!!  Definitely doesn't stand up to Ko or Ssam bar but this is a great addition to the empire. People that haven't tried any of Chang's restaurants will be dying for more.   If you can plan ahead and have the group, get the Bo Ssam. You'd be a fool not to!

23dSDl2gdEUeHoGeezPajg.text: An absolute must visit when in Las Vegas. David Chang's new outpost in the Cosmopolitan brings several of his NYC menus together under one roof and does not disappoint.  This laid-back approach to high-fashion cuisine is about as good as it gets for the already crowded "Asian fusion" segment.  Set in a gorgeous new space with floor-to-ceiling windows in the main dining room, you'll want to start your meal off with something from the bar.  Innovative cocktails are pricey but boozy and flavourful, and there's an extensive wine and sake menu to choose from should you prefer to steer clear of the hard stuff.  If nothing strikes your fancy, ask Josh to dream something up - you won't be disappointed.  Menu standouts include the flavour packed fried softshell crab bun starter, the spicy rice cakes, mussels, and the whole seabass if you're into large format and dining with a group.  The aforementioned mussels dish really highlights the inventiveness of the menu - a dry roasted preparation with Benton's Bacon. My only lament is that the chilled spicy noodle has been tamed to an almost unrecognisable "mild" compared to Noodle Bar's original.  Dessert options are plentiful from the world-renowned Milk Bar menu.  People seem to love the Crack Pie but it's almost too rich for me.  I'll stick with the powered milk ball... preferably strawberry.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy chilled noodles with sausage and cashews.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Some sort of strawberry milk dust truffle dessert.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Soft shell crab bun (off menu).

BIrgQpCRpJANeDuJFwrCwQ.text: AMAZING * PHENOMENAL * SO DAMN GOOD   I had the shiitake bun and truffle ramen... absolute perfection.   The service, attention to detail, presentation, taste, flavor profiles are all amazing!!   They have a limited vegetarian menu but the items they do have are full of flavor and are filling items.   This is on my forever Vegas must eat at list

r2SH60oSy4YYTArfBMlSVQ.text: So glad my buddy brought me here. I'd heard a lot about the NYC spots and went in excited to try the place.  There was no wait to get a table at 11am on a Saturday. It's pricey, but it's Vegas! What do you expect?  We ordered the Ramen - really good flavor, the egg was super good Ginger and Scallion noodles - I think this was my favorite  Pork belly bun - wasn't that special, but decent Crispy potatoes - this was a surprisingly great dish. Crispy potatoes with some sort of magical dipping sauce.   I would definitely come back and probably order the same exact things minus the pork belly bun.

MYEbBKUwdZAxxuJIpAyKyg.text: I was so excited to eat here and was not disappointed. I had the black truffle noodles and my wife had the toasted noodles. The ambience was urban and the service was great. We got there on the cusp of them changing their dinner menu over to the late night menu, but we were allowed to order from both. Great food, great time!

MC73fBgu0L6pwjHDaYRr0A.text: Ramen is honestly pretty good/decent, but overpriced. But enjoyable. Service was good. It was overhyped. Definitely was at least an experience to have.

s-MiJrxbUaxTXaX-5pFIWQ.text: We had pork belly bun and pork ramen... I have had much better where I came from in Southern California. Also, the hostess at the front didn't greet us and had a look on her face as if she didn't want to be there. (I arrived at 11am Tuesday 9/26/2017).  Our waiter was much more friendlier and was the only reason I would rate this at 3 stars.

v8b5dQz2EwHl8mfo45d1UA.text: I love the environment and staff was friendly. However, I gave it a 4 stars based on the food I ordered ( wanted to give 3.5 stars but not an option) I might have had bigger expectations for this place. We ordered 5 things : oysters , spicy cucumbers , scallion pancakes , chicken bun & smothered Katsu chicken .   The oysters were ok. The spicy cucumbers were EXTREMELY salty and not spicy enough. We had to tell the waiter to take it away . The scallion pancakes were hard and not flakey like how it should be made . The chicken buns were the only thing I enjoyed :) perfectly crisp and delicious . The smothered Katsu chicken was extremely rich and salty . It was good the first few bites but way too heavy and doesn't come w rice or anything to help balance out the flavor. ( I would order the cream sauce on the side). Oh and the yuzu lemonade was delicious but a little too sweet !! I had to water mine down.   Overall, all the flavors were there but just way too rich, heavy or salty .. I would definitely give it another try and order completely different items although disappointing my first time .

ZdRsnsdKn4gg8ownQeOpwQ.text: I've been to the Momofuku saam bar in NY where food and service was excellent so I was expecting to have the same experience here in LV. However, while the food was excellent, service was subpar.  The hostess outside was stone cold when we checked in for our reservation. No smile, nothing. We then got seated and a server checked in with us asking about water and letting us know she will take care of us tonight. So she leaves, we look over the menu and now we're waiting for her to come take our order. We see her right in front of us chatting it up with the table for a good 10 minutes or so. Meanwhile, we're just waiting for her, literally right behind her and she walks away to 2 other tables to check in with them. At this point, it's been about 15 mins since we sat down and no one has taken our order or checked in with us. I had to flag down a manager who grabbed someone to take our order.   The cucumbers and buns came out quickly. My friend and bf ordered the pork ramen, I ordered the summer truffle ramen. They were almost finished with their ramen before mine came out. The server apologized for the longer wait for my food. I wasn't sure if my ramen took longer to prepare, which if the server told me when I ordered, I would've been fine with.   A bit of a disappointing experience considering our experience in NY was way different.

0wvex0v43CkTP12DJMWXWg.text: So Ive been here twice already first time was with my boyfriend and second time was with my son and aunty. I can honestly say there improving with the food but as for the service SERIOUSLY SOMEONE NEEDS TO GET IT MORE ORGANIZED!!! or you can just hire a new manager that can train there employees to provide better service. I say your really killing the stars. Ill get to that later but lets start off with the food.   ----The FAMOUS buns: I tried the pork belly bun. my first time it was bad it was greasy I couldn't really taste anything besides the oil so bad it felt like I should of took my napkin and dabbed it off lol.. but as for the second time I visited it was PERFECT pork cooked real good and the toppings was just enough on the bun.  Chicken Karage first time there was so much spicy mayo I had to take a spoon took some off and it was good. But second time no complaints bun was on point. And love the pickled red onion blended very well with it.  I guess you can say and tell that the cooks who did it some seems like they do a sloppy job just for the money but others that does it so perfectly because they love doing what they do as a chef. And I heard they use to do one bun for $7 but now 2 buns for $7. I got charged wrong I'm guessing the FOH needs to be updated on whats going on.  ---- Oysters on the 1/2 shell (bonji mignonette)  love love love everything lol along with the yellowtail Sashimi (yuzu ponzu, basil, ginger) Cant go wrong with that.  ---- Noodles: Ginger Scallion Noodles && Pork Ramen There both okay I mean you really cant go wrong with ramen I just assume itd be different somehow someway but ramen is ramen.  ---- Smothered Katsu Chicken (Shitake gravy, black pepper) Yummy Yummy Yummy. the price for it sheesh no comment lol bit up there but its okay.  I'm assuming everytime you go and eat here the way the food tastes and is presented all depends on whos cooking it. overall the stars jus goes up and down for me.

YlKfBr7CKCvZ6T2a3xIElA.text: This place really goes to show you shouldn't judge a book by its cover. We've stayed at the Cosmo many times and never considered going until someone suggested going. The front of the restaurant is all you see which is pretty cool and casual the tables have all barstools and there is a bar. We were told there would be a 20 min wait for the main dining room, so when our room was ready we walked to our table and as soon as you walk into the main dining room you see a transformation! It's this hip yet chic very New York feelin room. It's like you're dining right in the center of the strip with huge windows showcasing the strip. Now onto the food we had the pho and the jidori chicken which was served with kimchi and white rice. Everything was super tasty. I would definitely go back. Just keep in mind this restaurant is best for a larger group hence why there is a lazy Susan on every table. The prices reflect the large portions as well, but it's worth it.

QwcMXF6EgKhdKny8-FWigg.text: I've been waiting at the bar to get service for over 20 min. I'm sitting here and there is a check book still here with two dirty glasses and the bartender and bar back have yet to acknowledge me they just keep walking back and forth staring. From a person that works right next door this is utterly disappointing. I finally was able to flag her down to take my order.

rn7AyaIi1Ypz5jsDqJ9WiQ.text: Wow! Top 10 meal I have ever experienced. Our server Max was the best! Truly incredible! We let Max pick the menu and drinks and had the best time of our lives. I would highly recommend this restaurant if you are in Vegas. You will be amazed!!

CNreTZ4YhaDNCDWv6vyMdA.text: This place is way overpriced for what they deliver.  Ramen for $50. And a tiny cup of hamachi for $36?  We ordered the lobster / seafood platter which was waaaaaay too salty.  Would I go here again? No... David Chang, please up our food game

nEq3952APBtdVpD_vxYGRQ.text: Stopped in here for a late dinner the evening we arrived in Vegas. Had some bao buns (chicken and shrimp) and they were decent. The chicken on it was dark meat that was a tad stringy to eat, but the taste was good. The shrimp one was much better for me personally. Had some drinks and the wine was expensive as to be expected but also not that great so disappointing. My husband had the pork ramen - noodles and broth both decent but nothing outstanding. Overall with so many amazing places on the strip, I wouldn't waste time and money on this one again.

TwZkZT2wjz51Kr6BfkkkKA.text: I'm still drooling thinking about our dinner here. We walked in without reservations on a Monday with no problem. When we got there it was definitely before dinner rush because it started to fill up towards the end. The servers are nice and casual. Pay the $1 for the fancy water. We started with the cucumber salad. It's just the right amount of spicy with a light refreshing taste. I could not stop eating it. We also had the pork belly bao & shrimp bao. Theses were so damn tasty! I could drop in for lunch and just eat these. The shrimp is spicy and the pork has a sweet sauce. They compliment each other nicely. We shared the ribeye. I thought this was a strange choice (birthday boy wanted it) for a well known Asian restaurant but STOP THE PRESS this was insane!! It was cooked to perfection with a beautiful salty crust (drooling again.) The fries and the aioli were so good we couldn't stop eating them. We had some red wine with the steak and everything in the world seemed alright. Somehow we still had room for crack pie which was good but nothing exciting. Best meal of our trip.

Z-YNBJsNLzk14IjzaN_xPQ.text: My husband has been dying to try this place; we went for a late night date/early birthday celebration. The Pork buns were amazing, the meat melted in our mouthes, wish We ordered more! The mussels entree were fantastic, portion was perfect for sharing (since we also ordered two noodle bowls!). Chicken soup was ok- honestly, I like the dollar ramen broth from the store better, my meat was a little tough too. My husband loved his pork ramen though! We were too full for dessert and weren't impressed enough w the menu options to overindulge. Overall we  had a really nice time and will prob be back for more pork buns and mussels lol.

XZKxs22g6CfVk2dSvbRqGQ.text: Amazing service and delicious food! Pretty pricey but a nice restaurant for a birthday dinner or any special occasion. The cauliflower and Brussels sprouts appetizer is a must! I ordered the vegetable rice cakes and added shrimp--the curry was mild but very flavorful and the mushrooms were cooked perfectly. Would definitely recommend!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Whole Fried Chicken

OGxYd_WF3w8DUoRWh-MW6Q.text: I had heard a lot of great things about this place, and was excited to try it out.  We had a reservation for a weeknight, but the place wasn't filled and you would've been seated regardless. The menu is pretty limited, which saved us time on deciding what to get. Everything was very pricey though. We opted for shisito peppers, pork belly buns, brussel sprouts & cauliflower, grilled squid, grilled lamb ribs, ginger scallion noodles, and sichuan beef noodles.   My favorite was the pork belly bun. It was very fatty, and the sauce was yummy. The ginger scallion noodles would be my second, but it had a ton of seaweed and not much noodle to go around for a party of 5. I was most disappointed in the sichuan beef noodle. It didn't taste like much of anything to me. I was at least expecting a good peppercorn kick, but didn't get it.   The shisito peppers came with nutritional yeast on top, which I thought was fancy. Nothing else blew me out of the water. And for those prices, I expected as much.  Service was very good though. Our waters would be magically refilled by the attentive staff whenever it ran low.  All in all, I'm glad I came to check this place out for myself and would recommend others to do the same in order to form their own opinion. But there are so many other places to eat within the area that I would not be back.

OpPvOKW2m1fcXtvsfgxTPw.text: This review has been a long time in the making. I have been to Momofuku 5 times now. It has been amazing every single time. I don't write reviews over and that is because I really have to feel passionate about the place I'm writing about. Momofuku and it's sister restaurant Majordomo in Los Angeles are two of my favorites from chef David Chang. Being an Asian American it's not too often we have chefs to look up to in the culinary world so when I learned of Momofuku I had to try it out.   The FOOD at Momofuku is Asian inspired and of the 5 times I have been here now, I have eaten family style 3 times. I can only comment on the dishes I have had here and fortunately for me I have been luck enough to have the 5 Spice Duck 3 times here. Yep...three times!!! That's 15 SPICES! I can't remember the different ways they prepare the duck because I am usually too entranced by the thought of eating it as well as being mesmerized by the carving process. The server will bring the duck out on a giant carving cart and proceed to carve up the duck breast in all its perfect delicious glory. They then take all the juices as well as the carved up meat and place it on top of a bed of crispy delicious rice. Oh my god the rice. Just typing R-I-C-E made me salivate! You are giving lettuce as well as what I like to think of as pancakes to make wraps out of. My personal favorite thing to do is to take a pancake first, remember to put the rice in first so that it sits at the bottom and soaks up the sauces that you put in. Speaking of sauces, you are giving Kimchi(gross...don't at me motherfuckers), ginger scallion sauce(MMMMM) and hoisin. Make sure you get a good scoop of rice, top it with duck confit and a few slices of the duck. Now, a good portion of ginger scallion sauce and hoisin and you got yourself what may be my favorite bite of food...ever...maybe? Seriously, the Duck here at Momofuku is fuku-ing a-MOMO-zing. They recommend 3-4 people to take on the duck challenge and that is about right depending on how hungry everyone is! Please make sure to order the duck if you ever have a larger party because it is SOOOOO GOOD!  I also really love the pork belly puns they have here! The pork is super tender and rich without being overly heavy or fatty. There is ssam sauce provided and I give the bun a good helping of it for every bite.   I've also had the jidori chimkin...I mean, chicken bowl here and it is pretty good but if I were to come back I'd certainly want to try the Ramen which I still haven't had here yet. The first couple of times I was here was for dinner and I didn't know that you can order it any time of day, it is just off menu so please ask your server. The times that I have seen people order the ramen it has looked good but I always think about how heavy ramen broth is and as I get older I realize that I am not always down for a giant bowl of oil and grease...yuck! Although if any place can make me temporarily not dislike ramen, it would be Momofuku!    Anyways, I hope anyone still reading this gathers a few of their favorite friends and comes to Momofuku to get the 5 Spice Duck! It is absolutely worth the price if you're a True lover of food!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Part of the menu on 9/6/2019.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Buns...A MUST ORDER!

bsiZxZcw6FmIlF7SlBfjqQ.text: Love love loves our lunch here!  I'm such a fan thoughtful menus that overwhelm. In the days where menus with multiple pages can be popular it's nice to arrive at a place that knows what they do well and offers a varietal selection without causing choice paralysis.  We opted to start with the spice cucumbers which were so good we quizzed our server on ingredients so we can try to make it at home!  Mains were the pork ramen, excellent, and the little gem salad (sunchokes) with spicy shrimp.  It's expert without trying.  Just delicious.  Attentive staff that sweetly celebrated our special occasion.  Very nice touch.  Pro Tip:  there is an elevated section of the dining room that has slanted windows overlooking the strip win and uninterrupted view.  Ask for a table there if you're looking to kick the experience up a notch.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The star!
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The little gem salad at spicy shrimp and the pork ramen.  Both great.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Delicious:  spicy cucumbers with almond crunch on top.

WTI2oA094h1eCR426TWWDg.text: We love coming here but today's food deserves 3 stars and that is being generous. Every time I come here I order the pork belly buns, spicy chicken sandwich, and the ramen. Today's food was far less than average and far less than a normal experience at Momofuku.  The pork belly buns were dry and the pork belly itself was tough. This never happens but today it did. They also refused to fix this for me or attempt to make another.  The spicy chicken sandwich was below average as well. The chicken was hard and the sauce had 0 flavor. Weak "spicy" sandwich to say the least.  Lastly, the ramen. The ramen had the same issue as the pork bun. Even after being left in the broth for nearly 15 minutes it was still not good.   Today's dinner was below average and below a normal dinner here. If this were my first time I would not come back, but I will give it another shot.

JQGP4GPqNVR-iE-uL2Zzbw.text: Our favorite menu items during the long weekend came from here. The servers were polite and well versed.   Highly recommend the pork buns! We each could have ate six of them! The what the pho cocktail was unlike any I've tasted before, initially I was not a fan but grew to like it as I sipped it more. The ramen was solid, I typically prefer very flavorful ramen with lots of toppings, this was more of a basic ramen. Love Milk bar next door which they serve a limited menu of here in the restaurant which can save a long wait.

9rtL6fcO4UvWZZvpesU4zQ.text: This is THE place to go for your amazing Vegas dinner.  Was in Vegas for work recently and met up with my parents and I decided to treat them for a belated Mother's Day and early Father's Day. We made reservations prior and I recommend you do that as well or you'll be waiting for a while.  The ambiance is very modern, with a lot of wall art that makes the place seem very hip, which it is.  All plates are shared, and though I loved all the dishes we got, my top 3 were definitely the sea bass, the pork buns, and the squid.   Other menu items we ordered: oysters, apple salad, black truffle ramen.  The servers there are very knowledgeable about their dishes as well, which really helped us enjoy the meal even more.   This is a meal I won't forget.

Yq6ocZnwVXOW4V-vIjTtFw.text: My bf and I came to Momofuku again for lunch on Saturday while on a weekend trip to Vegas. When we walked up to the hostess booth, they seated us at the bar where the chefs are, but one of the waiters noticed my bf looking into the dining area and offered to seat us inside, so we got lunch with a view w/o reservations! :)   We, of course, had to order some staples we loved on our first visit: Pork Belly Buns and Milk Bar Pie (formerly Crack Pie). We also ordered the Shoyo Pork Ramen and Bo Ssam Rice Bowl to try this time. The Shoyu Ramen had a very smokey flavor, I loved the pork shoulder, but the pork belly with the ramen is not as good as the pork belly buns, since it got soggy from the broth. The Bo Ssam Rice Bowl was delicious, my bf and I both thought of it as comfort food. If I had to choose which of these 2 dishes to order again next  time, it would be the rice bowl.  FYI - Cosmopolitan has self parking rates: Free within 1 hour, $10 for 1-4 hours, and $15 for the day.

lRCeqCpMK47ryytb5CHZ5g.text: What's better than experiencing an earthquake while eating 36 ounces of American Wagyu beef? Not much really.  My husband & I love Momofuku and have been to other restaurants of David Changs. So while in Vegas we decided to bring my brother and his girlfriend who had never been.  We started with the Pork Buns which were just melt in your mouth good and the Asparagus which they say was delicious.  We decided to share the Snake River Farms Wagyu Bavette. It was 36 ounces of beef, fried corn "ribs" & a kimchi potato salad. What a presentation that was. My husband and I have been to Japan and had the actual Wagyu beef over there and he says this is probably the best he's had (here at least) since Japan. Though it's not like we eat it much so take that with a grain of salt. hah. There was so much food I have no idea how 4 of us finished it.  Also there was an earthquake and that's super interesting watching all the fancy ceiling fixtures move around. As East coasters, we don't ever experience anything like that, so it was nice seeing the servers act super chill about it.  Our server, whos name I wish I remembered, was very attentive, friendly, and just overall great. We even saw the manager talk with the table next to us over a mess up and it really seems like they have their customer service aspect down solid.  Bathrooms were weird because there's only 2 BUT THEY HAVE BIDETS which is always nice so that's a plus in my life.  Can't wait to come back for our next trip to Vegas!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Snake River Farms Wagyu Bavette

MWIOsybvTHeXd4gOX-t3bA.text: oh man! I'm not going to lie... I came here twice on the same day.... please not judge me.    My visits to Momofuku have been superb. Chill, laid back, casual type of lunch or dinner place for any time of the day in Las Vegas. Even though its warm out, this warm bowl of ramen totally hit the spot. I ordered the shoyu pork ramen. The pork is so soft that it almost melts as you pick it up. I also love the fact that it has never been too fatty. The noodles are cooked to perfection. They have the right chewiness along with the incredible flavor that Momofuku has to offer. The broth.. thats where it's at. The broth is flavorful, smokey, and not greasy.  I get that at $18 for a bowl of ramen can be a bit much but the quality of it is so worth it. One day though, when Vegas is being kind to me, I will order the Truffle Ramen Bowl...$50 is a bit hefty for me but I sooo want to try it. Momofuku!! I'll be back. Let's hope the waiters don't recognize me and start calling me the ramen girl.. although that too would be pretty sweet.

R6EYK4G855rkH3ya_BSECw.text: If you're a fan of David Chang and the Momofuku franchise I would say definitely visit the Momofuku location in Las Vegas. The vibe of the restaurant is casual and fun and our server was amazing, her cocktail recommendations were on spot. And if you're not familiar with Momofuku or with various cuisines from Asia, I would say the restaurant has a nice and balanced menu selection for newcomers. It doesn't hurt that their cocktail selections are ! Side note: the Milk Bar is located right next door so you can take your cereal milk soft serve to go.

hP8UlwetqkY14ywkp1isNg.text: Momofuku in the Las Vegas Cosmopolitan, is great for that early morning snack and cocktail! After trying our luck at the slots, we realized after midnight, we were starving! After seeing the amazing Yelp expert, Joyce W, review these delightful little buns! I book marked Momofuku! Glad I did! We ordered up a batch of these little buns, and Yup, she was right on the money! A hearty slab of meaty pork belly, house made pickle, tucked inside a pillow of tender buns! Best bet we made all night!   The Raman is really good as well! We ordered the pork Raman, and the ginger and scallion Raman! The broth was delicious and loaded with noodles!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Buns

URa7jSFKXig82ruMWnH7EA.text: This review is based on service, quality, and cleanliness:  Service: the service is fantastic. Love how they served our drinks and made you feel like royalty. I have no issues with service here.   Quality: this is the main reason why this place gets two stars. You are paying for an atmosphere that isn't real. The food is not worth the price point they set it at. Their appetizers like the pork bun and shishito peppers were very delicious, but that is about it. I HIGHLY DO NOT RECOMMEND eating here for a date or family dinner. It is definitely not worth the money. Our ramen was very basic and nothing special. The chick peas ramen is pretty good but not for its price point. my lamb with their special sauce was kind of rubbery and I only ate one lamb rib. They don't have much spicy flavors, everything is very sweet. Also the portions aren't very large. The bo saam rice was sooo sweet and almost unpleasant. the oysters were also poorly shucked and had shell pieces in it. They also don't have tapatio or tabasco for the oysters. They do have their own sauce, but again it is on the sweet side.  Cleanliness: no issues here. Everything very clean and presentable.  Overall: this is definitely not a place for me. It was nice to try once, but only once. Sadly I will not recommend this to people, just feels like a waste of money, for their small menu options and almost no variations. Pretty upsetting

bf0sGDvRb0fW_WqTZazIvA.text: I was visiting Vegas for a work trip, and while it's not a destination I ever thought I'd find myself (by choice), Momofuku was a highlight of the trip!  Our table shared a few dishes, starting with spicy cucumbers which were so crunchy and had a nice kick. We also had the Brussel sprouts (which had a great char on them) and the country ham (paired with a coffee mayo - such a strangely delicious combo!).   Then came the pork belly buns and beef Sichuan noodles. Both of those were absolutely the star of the evening for me. Get them! The pork belly was perfectly cooked - tender in the middle and crisp around the edges. The beef Sichuan noodles were spicy, and I absolutely loved it. I'll be dreaming of those noodles for many months.

3466d9t2E-CiOOVPD2qPCg.text: Pretty underwhelming.  Maybe I didn't order the right dishes.  We got the Japanese grilled squid, cream corn with truffles, Brussel sprouts and cauliflower, and pork chop.  My husband really enjoyed the pork chop.  I thought the cream corn was good.

Qwj5K4t1i6xTS2O-Nj6RQw.text: Was really impressed in all facets of Momofuku from the staff to the ambience, but the star is where it should be, the food. Every item was well thought out to the details of portion sizes and robust flavor.    A must try for the appetizer are the pork belly buns. The pork is cooked to perfection and melts in your mouth in addition with a perfectly cooked bun with a great balance of hoisin with crunch of pickled cucumber (tsukemono). The crispy potatoes were cooked perfectly and addicting. They look spicy , but it's more sweet with nice crunchy garlic crunch. The shishito peppers were roasted well, but lacking overall, they needed another element to accompany them other than a lime salt topping.    The Black Truffle Ramen is a must try if you don't mind spending $50. It's a bucket list type of food to try. It's on its own level with the richness the truffle  to be broth, which is the perfect balance without  being too overpowering. The aftertaste is pleasing and lasts a while to further savor and enjoy the experience.   The Lamb ribs were tender and juicy and fell off the bone accompanied with the perfect mixture of a cucumber chili yogurt.   Momofuku is a must try and even the bathrooms are nice as they can get and have fancy Japanese toilets!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crispy Potatoes
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Grilled Lamb Ribs
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shishito Peppers

KdONi1tz3SpeC0dUho21bA.text: The Big Eye Tuna with Foie Gras shaving is a must get! I was skeptical in ordering it but the waiter convinced me and it did not disappoint. Shavings melted in your mouth and paired so well with the tuna.   The Pork Belly bun was really good - juicy, and not overly fatty piece of pork belly, hot bun, and fresh, crunchy veggies.   The only thing we didn't care for was the shishito peppers. Were too oily and on the soggy side for us, plus with the seasoning salt on top made it feel so dry when eating.   Overall, loved it, will come back to try more items.

4TZIq95nNG-UPzd-EBHuZA.text: Through the Netflix show Ugly Delicious, I knew Momofuku was going to be a much anticipated dinner in Vegas.  The pork belly ramen is by far, one of the tastiest ramens I've ever had. The fatty broth was delicious, there was tons of scallions, a runny egg and a piece of seaweed to accompany the al dente noodles. I highly recommend that bowl as well as the Ginger Scallion noodles & the infamous Bao buns. The Ginger Scallion noodles had pickled shiitake mushrooms and cucumbers that gave the bowl depth and flavor. As for the buns, there's a good pork belly to bun ratio for the $7 bao. The shrimp bun was very crispy. Im sure everyone is ranting about these dishes and in my opinion they were great choices that filled two of us up for dinner.   I had an amazing experience while dining at Momofuku on Sunday and will be back. While you're at it, pick up the Crack Pie from the nearby Milk Bar. It's to die for!
