Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bun
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Smoked pumpkin

TxZt5rUNu_IRKgs67N1UZA.text: We made our 4th visit to Momofuku LV on 4/2/19 to celebrate our 10th wedding anniversary. Wow! We genuinely feel the restaurant is now getting better and better (and more memorable) with each visit. Our server (I apologize for forgetting her name) was super knowledgeable of the menu and went out of her way to make the nice extra special, including complimentary sake and a desert cookie from Milk Bar! We started with some delicious cocktails (good enough I don't remember the names :), Shrimp Buns, and then had Chickpea Ramen and Roasted Rice Cakes (although I preferred the slightly different variation of this last summer, this curry-centric one is still very delicious, especially with the recommended additional shrimp). Everything was SO fantastic! Needless to say, we'll be making a reservation for our 5th Momofuku visit when we're back in Vegas at the end of August!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

6uR0OWMzoqbcdKW3DeAclg.text: Sexy spot with truly tasty AF dishes... their spicy chicken sandwich is scorching, yet I can't seem to stop stuffing my mouth with it... must try cocktails: bok to the beat + Persephone...

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. *   *

7txPJOYlCmAImMmBxKXz1A.text: What an amazing experience coming to try Momofuku at the strip. It was a very last minute plan from having visitors from Texas on deciding what to eat. We decided to go to Momofuku. At first i was surprised with the price range and what should i order. My friends and I went to go ahead and try the Fried chicken and Caviar. It was almost $400 and we also ordered the ramen and the brussel sprouts.   I think the hype for this place is just a little to much. I think its a once a year experience for me. If i was suggested to go back...? Maybe. I would probably try somewhere else. The food was okay, but it did blow my mind. The service was excellent, the way they served us explaining everything on what to order was on point. You have to try this place for you tourist !

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

EWhs5iJ3R5vz_S6fapPGnA.text: |[ p r e m i u m ]| Expensive but it tastes good. The ramen is definitely delicious and for the premium price that it is, it should be! I would say it's average delicious but I can still name a few places off the top of my head with even better ramen (and for cheaper). The bowl is enough to fill me up though, I couldn't really finish it after drinking a Fat Tuesday prior to coming the last I went. I do wish they had different meat options as not everyone is into the fatty meat that the pork belly has.   |[ g o o d ]| Service is nice and attentive and the restaurant is decorated really fancy. It's a great place to treat yourself because if you're in Vegas you're probably celebrating anyways. I definitely enjoyed eating here both times I've been. Save this place for special occasions or when you're just feeling baller rich and wanna reflect that with the dining choice just to feel baller. The sides are good as well. The food quality are all decent and good here. 4/5. Man, that bank account does hurt a bit though, but YOLO. xD

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ramennnnn

SZxY0XX8kPZt1PdEe53eIw.text: I came here for lunch and the menu is pretty much baos and noodles. I got the pork ramen, which was really good. The broth was salty but nothing too overwhelming. I liked how hey had pork shoulder in the ramen. It was really tender. I wish there was more than one piece of pork belly in the ramen.   We also ordered the spicy cucumbers which came with roasted nuts and this green puree. It was really good and refreshing. I like ordering cucumber appetizers at restaurants because of the clean crisp taste and it isn't heavy so it never ruins the main course.   We also order the pork belly bao, which personally was whatever. I was expecting a thicker cut of pork belly but instead it was two thinly sliced pieces of meat. It was a little disappointing.   Overall the meal was good, but I probably won't be back. If you haven't tried this place I would definitely check it out.   They also have a milk bar outside with cookies and other desserts. I'll definitely go to that again.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy cucumbers
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork ramen
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Drinks for lunch

LeniTprCMf3FiJdWxsvV8A.text: Currently my favorite restaurant in Las Vegas. The dining room is gorgeous with a great view of the strip. Must haves are the pork belly buns, ginger scallion noodles, Bigeye Tuna and the birthday confetti cake for dessert is the bomb. All their cocktails are absolutely delicious, like the Peruvian Sour! Can't wait to try their restaurant, Majordomo in LA!!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Delicious confetti cake &amp; yummy Peruvian Sour!

_xQHNBWKEMzHQB657mlxQg.text: Food was impeccable - I can't say enough about how well the food was prepared and tasted. The miso cod was perfectly cooked with a delicious sweetness to it and a slight grill to the outside. The Brussels Sprouts were complex and crunchy, each bite was fantastic. Don't forget to make your reservation at Momofuku - well worth it!

EEsTaN4XNm_KVsVHLz5k9Q.text: We had our first meal in Vegas at Momofuku.  We ordered: pork ramen- it was good.  The pork belly was amazing, as I expected.  But we didn't get an egg in the ramen for some reason!  We forgot to ask about it until we were done, but on the menu it says it comes with a slow poached egg, so we felt ripped off. :(  pork buns- I prefer the pork belly in the ramen, but these were pretty good as well.  spicy chilled noodles- this was my favorite dish of the meal, actually.  It just really hit the spot with the right amount of spice and nuttiness with the basil flavor.  Would order this again for sure.  Overall, I enjoyed the meal.  I've been to the Momofuku NY for dinner, and this time it was a casual lunch, so the experience was different, but you can tell the chef pays attention to details on every dish.  I actually ordered the Momofuku/David Chang cook book after our meal because I'd love to try and make the pork belly baos at home.  I'd come back here, but I would make sure there is an egg in my ramen next time before I start eating!

zDSkHc_7Aguu_JJaBZ2N8A.text: This place is perfection. My main reason for visiting Vegas this time around was to come to Momofuku. Drove 9 hours and went straight here. I was a bit surprised about how relaxed the restaurant was. I had always expected to walk into a fine dining environment and I'd be the most frumpy person in the room. We made a reservation which I believe is a good idea although it didn't seem like much of a wait if you didn't have one. This had to have been one of the most flavorful ramens I've had thus far. If you are as obsessed with eggs as the rest of us then you should know that the yolk just adds a completely new adventure to the soup. I've been told time and time again that absolutely must get the pork belly buns as well. I was not disappointed as they melted in my mouth. A perfect pork belly is hard to come across. They were not stingy with the servings which was very relieving since I was nervous about spending triple that I would usually pay for a bowl of ramen. I'll never be able to come to Vegas again and NOT come here!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Buns
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Pork Ramen
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

e2naDDYB3iJ5UHC7_EwIyQ.text: I was excited to try another one of David Chang's restaurants, this time on the west side of the country!  Located in the modern Cosmopolitan hotel, the restaurant is classy, spacious, and trendy.  The four of us went for the 5 spice rotisserie duck meal, one of the large format dining options.  I was surprised we didn't have to pre-order the duck since Momofuku Ssam bar in NY requires it.    The waiter brought out the whole rotisserie duck on a wood serving table and carved the different pieces in front of us. First, the breast, then the leg confit, then placed them over a bed of ginger scallion sauce rice.  They took the rest of the duck to the kitchen to deep fry it for us!  There were accompanying sauces and wraps brought out for the duck.  The chinese style accompaniments included chive pancakes, hoisin, ginger scallion sauce.  The korean style accompaniments included kimchi, bibb lettuce, and ssam sauce.  The meal is a fun experience, but the standouts were the leg confit over rice, the chinese style accompaniments, and the deep fried duck pieces.  I'm not a fan of duck breast, but the leg confit over rice was heavenly. Though I'm a Korean who loves kimchi and ssam sauce, I really think the Chinese way of hoisin + duck cannot be beat!!    We also ordered pork belly buns and spicy cucumbers to start.  The duck meal is for 2-3, but it was beyond filling for the 4 of us.  The large format meals are pricey, but it was a good one-time adventure for us!

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Duck saam
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Carving the duck breast

Thuhc6qXYUu0g4FMMx2SIQ.text: The food is still very good. I'm very disappointed they got rid of the duck ssam for lunch.   Lately the service is the problem. Last two times I went there my entire came put before my appetizer.  I prefer to get and finish my appetizer first before my entree

HSbpYp6N3nd14TMds9WOlQ.text: Despite the high prices, this is a great restaurant. We came for lunch which reduces the sticker shock. The cucumber dish is to die for (and really, who ever says that about a cucumber dish?!) the ginger noodles are lively-spicy but not too much and lots of yummy veggies all done in a sauce that makes you want to lick the bowl. My husband had the chick pea noodles-so yummy with a really flavorful broth. Worth the splurge!

6U8YcmD3tQupfcR4ji5Anw.text: One of the most trendy places to eat at in Las Vegas right now, so expectations were very high. Japanese fusion, and that would normally make me not want to go. That fact that it is inside the Cosmopolitan is probably the best reason I went. What is the nicest thing I can say about the Cosmopolitan? ---- The fact that they have never told me or any guest I have ever recommended visit there "No". They bend over backwards to please.  Advanced reservations are required. Unless, like all of Las Vegas, you have friends in Low, High, and in between places. Friday and Saturday nights the place is always fully booked.   The wife and I grabbed two seats at the bar while waiting for a group of friends to meander to the Cosmo-Aria connection. The bartender took excellent car of us and a quick snack rapidly turned into a full meal.  We chose a Daiginjo Dake that was awesome and was recommended by the bartender. Momofuku oysters as appetizer, pork ramen, dry roasted mussels and summer truffle ramen as main course.   Did chef David Chang kick off the ramen boom in Las Vegas? Don't know because I brought my craving for it with me from long, long ago. Momofuku is made of glass, wood, steel and concrete, grabbing a corner of Cosmo's second floor. The deserts come from the Milk Bar next door. Didn't try one, but they looked spectacular.   Momofuku's vast range makes it special in Las Vegas. The Strip might have everything you can think of now, but it doesn't have many restaurants where you can find a perfect $20 bowl of noodles for lunch and come back at night to share edgy large-format presentations like the vaunted fried chicken and caviar. I had the same reaction you are having now when I first heard about Fried Chicken and Waffles in Hollywood California. Why not Fried Chicken and Caviar?  Read somewhere that Chang was excited to play in Las Vegas. Hopefully he's enjoying himself so far. We sure did, and first chance we get we will go back and try the Fried Chicken and Caviar.

iXLng4vVataTvr2U893_1w.text: Thee best ramen I've ever had. I went next door to Milk to get the cookies for dessert!

dynaK3cfVwbylM2U75t65Q.text: Negroni with cucumber and artichoke was amazing. I definitely want to have that again.  Pork ramen was pretty good, big portion with a good price for the Strip.  Service was fantastic.   Inside is a lot nicer than it looks from the front.

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Ramen. It is not on dinner menu now, but they still serve this at the counter .
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Negroni

V4r6XGqDreZGbEOBAMGGwg.text: Start to finish. Great!!!  Sat at the bar. Our bartender Ashley was incredibly knowledgeable about the menu. As well as entertaining. Food was nothing short of spectacular. Spicy cucumbers are definitely the way to go. I've been to a lot of top tier restaurants. And this one stands out.

tkKZdbaneGtHTYmxj7-cjw.text: What a Kool little place!! Old skool music! Nice little snacky foods but good food. Do a lot of shots!! Hahahahaha

m2jFCaXA7t6NrcB_XVe3gA.text: The whole duck was one of the best meals I have had in a very long time! Absolutely top recommendation

MEUT4VqGwRfSUMVgD2xUTw.text: Been following and watching his Netflix show for awhile. I got the lobster and shrimps, Brussels sprouts and pork shoulder with ginger rice... everything was overly salted and I'm the type to love salty food... the pork shoulder was extremely tender and flavor was pretty good. The ginger rice was too sweet. Lobster and shrimp was too salty, I wanted to tell them to take it back, but at $45 I felt bad... I did tell them to take back the Brussels  sprouts which was again was too salty... service was great though!

pYxLu-KdjpGTnKiotg5UTw.text: Hey guys let me start off with this place is a bucketlist accomplishment for me. I love Chef David Chang and coming here lead me to knowing him more. Even tho he not there personally, the Chefs to the bartenders to servers expressed and showed who Chef David is, how he see and expresses food. To the Bigeye tuna which I recommend to his crackpie alamode, just how fun and creative he can be and serious but passion he is about his life. If you have a chance go and explore his world thorough his restaurant Momofuku.

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

pL79Haekr7qFZ_aqvrc6Eg.text: This place is real crap. In fact, if there were a fancier name for crap, they'd probably serve it up to unsuspecting guests. Our server was nice.  Food was actually disgusting. And I love ramen! So disappointed. The food is not "clean."  The shishito peppers have crap dust sprinkled all over them. The cucumber salad is doused in pureed crap and dusted with more crap.  The mussels were cooked alright but just not the delicious style of cleanly-steamed Belgian mussels with white wine sauce. Instead they were roasted and dry and covered with crap dust.  The truffle ramen is a complete waste of money - tastes like Campbell's cream of mushroom soup but for 45 bucks. Dear chef: stop it. Just stop it.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Something called pig pâté came (surprise!) on a pickle plate. The pickles were gross too!

tMT9fi66k_nv6Dq5-M39Pw.text: Yum yum!  Enjoyed their pork buns!  Ramen was fabulous as well, but definitely the pork buns we're the best. Will be back. Service was great!  I always come on off times. So we ate at 2pm on Monday. No wait.

4iqtlY1vZuIt_AZMHntjZA.text: I've tried Momofuku numerous times in NYC and for the first time in Vegas. I was really hoping the Vegas one would be better than NYC. Unfortunately, it is still just as salty. The shishito peppers we ordered were soooo unevenly salted, that some pieces were extremely salty and we had to rinse it in water. The Brussel sprouts and cauliflower were delicious at first bite but then unbearably salty by the second bite.  So if you come here, I would recommend sticking with the buns and the noodles. Everything else I've had has given me a salt headache.  And of course, maybe just skip it all together and just get a cereal milk soft serve at their milk bar next door.

GMArzqcOQvyVMg8Z_46Z-Q.text: Was excited to visit this spot after watching the Ugly Delicious series on Netflix. Our server Danielle helped us navigate through the menu and we chose a smaller size of a family style entree. Food is definitely a 4.5-5. The Salt and Pepper Lobster and Shrimp was the crispiest yet lightest Tempura I've ever had.  A great portion size including peppers and scallions all covered with a very Unami oyster sauce. The Basil sauced Chilled Noodles with Asian Sausage was amazing balanced with peanuts and peppers. The food here was top notch and a great take on the ingredients. The overall atmosphere was typical Vegas in a hotel mall area so noisy and rushed. A great spot for food and especially family style eating. A bit on the pricier side although the quality is better than most.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chilled Spicy Noodles with Salt &amp; Pepper Lobster &amp; Shrimp
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Basil flavored Chilled Spicy Noodles with Sausage
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Perfect plate

Mn8_bGjxFfPzy60EUxBe5A.text: Very good Ramen and soup is very flavorful since it tasted like it was cook for hours.  The Bolsaam roast pork shoulder was so moist and tasty.   It went really well with white rice or wrapped with salad.   The only thing I would say is it didn't go well with Kimchi since Kimchi has a strong flavor and it appeared to be overwhelming with the pork flavor.  I would prefer it to serve with marinated cucumber or plain cucumbers so we can taste and enjoy the pork's flavor more.

4Bu52NMPoW0g9SaI36NsFw.text: First review ever. Ordered off menu ahi poke (server recommended). Better than expected. Also got the pear berrata. Would pass next time but not bad. Meal became memorable when one of the chefs, Matt, caught us lusting over a plate of lemon pepper lobster. He hooked us up with a GENEROUS sample plate with jumbo prawns. Don't think twice. Order it.

xoeExWoPnV8JIgVT1vMfqg.text: Amazing place to hangout and enjoy world class food. We had Tofu Ramen with truffles easily the best soup broth I have ever had. Their grill chicken had the juiciest breast piece ever. All drinks we ordered were really good.

Rwen3kyepphQ7eGVnt4S8w.text: One of the best dining experiences we've ever had! The service we received was impeccable and the food was outstanding. I dream about the pork belly and shrimp patty chashu buns and my girlfriend can't stop thinking about the pesto noodle bowl. We can't wait to come back here.

80LYuw0pqwha8ltGLHPSzQ.text: I LOVED this place!!!   Came here several times on my last few Vegas trips - I've heard the name tossed around a lot and wanted to see what the hype was about.   I thought the ambiance was really nice and all of our servers were super friendly. We always came when the Late Night menu was being served which definitely didn't disappoint. We got the pork buns with hoisin, scallion, cucumber and the  Momofuku Ramen - pork belly, pork shoulder, and poached egg. Everything was AMAZING.  Will definitely come back on my next Vegas trip.

rESRM-zZvnAPep0vqMM9WA.text: I would give this place 10 stars if I could. Definitely one of the top 3 dining experiences of my life!! We asked if they had a tasting menu, and Manny (who was awesome) told us to give him our price point and the types of food we liked. Then, the chef created a custom dining adventure just for us. It was AMAZING!! Steamed buns = yum, but this was only the beginning. Corn = great, but still just getting started. Melon/seafood salad = beautiful, fresh with a little kick every now and then, loved it. Bucatini = I didn't even know what this was before I ate here, but it was perfection. The egg was poached perfectly, and the hollow noodles give the pasta just the right texture. Next came the lamb ribs... OMG...O.M.G!! Fall off the bone tender, so much flavor, yogurt sauce... I've never had better lamb. Finally, Manny brought out the porkchop. It was almost too beautiful to eat, and it tasted even better than it looked (and I don't usually like porkchops). Juicy and salty with hints of sweet. I never wanted it to end. If you are looking for a place to experience food in Las Vegas, you've found it. I can't wait to experience a whole new Momofuku adventure on our next visit!!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Porkchop. Almost too beautiful to eat, but it tasted even better than it looked!
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Lamb ribs... perfection
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Corn salad

VurOIBQJL1slcZSgV4SfGg.text: Everything was so delicious that we talked about it for days afterwards. We had a reservation so we got seated promptly and the view of the Strip was good. The only downside was the staff seemed a little pretentious which was a bummer but maybe they were just having an off day. We will certainly return.

HtYeAVzlUqjyafuSCFqsew.text: Brand new location but a lot of similarities to their other locations. The drinks are good -- Penicillin and their Old Fashioned are my suggestions for cocktails.  Appetizers, definitely the Pork Belly Buns (We got a lot of them to-go but they're not the same! Gotta eat them right after they serve it to you.)  Entree, we got the pork ramen. A little too salty for my taste but still great pork belly and soft boiled egg. We have yet to try the dinner menu.  Additionally, if you have Tao as your waiter, he is A+. Knew the menu well, easy to talk to, and extremely patient with us! Great service -- best I've had in a long time!!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Ramen! $18.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Buns -- two per order but one person can easily finish two. $14!

MmY7swmxzNEcdoRCfp_Bxg.text: Very poor taste and look of dishes , doesn't worth the money or expectation at all. Don't order the entree chicken , very dry. The steak is a joke, cannot chew it, have to have all piece in my mouth and chew hard

Gw85EJF8ccvZOj7ILe5V0A.text: My wife and I tried this place for lunch, I must say it is pretty damn good. The food and drinks were delicious  I both had the pork belly buns and shared the 5 spice rotisserie duck. I would come back just for those items. Definitely a must try if you are contemplating on whether or not to go eat or drink at this place.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. This was the cucumber salad and the pork belly buns paired perfectly with a watermelon cocktail

RZJVKZnsiZJuV8S7xP8P7w.text: I haven't been able to stop thinking about my dinner last night since I took my last bite! I was prepared to splurge, but filled up on a few small plates. My next visit to a Momofuku-family restaurant, I will most definitely splurge. I'm confident it will be worth it!  I ordered the grilled asparagus with miso butter, which was the first dish to come out. I was absolutely blown away. The miso butter had the slightest heat to it, and the asparagus took on a smoky flavor from the grill.  My next dish was the killer: Pork Belly Buns. Never in my life have I enjoyed fatty meat until this day. The fat melted in my mouth, and the leaner parts of the cut were flavorful and tender. I could barely finish one, but did eat the meat out of the second bun. The buns themselves were neither too sweet nor too savory, a perfect complement to the pork inside.  I was seated at the counter overlooking the kitchen, a seat I would highly recommend taking. It is clear how much care goes into the dishes, having seen them as they are prepared. As a nice bonus, one of the chefs gave me a sample of the roasted corn with raclette sauce appetizer! I haven't been able to stop thinking about it. It was so much better than I ever thought roasted corn could be!!  Thanks for the wonderful dining experience, Momofuku LV. I'll definitely be visiting the DC location back at home.

qvjofB-A3I4uGNlrcuPwuw.text: Just received a message from the hostess that they were cancelling my reservation for dinner on my wife's birthday that I had made a month ago since they decided to rent out the whole restaurant to someone else.  When I called the restaurant, the hostess told me the only option was rescheduling and offered no appologies or remorse.  Only after writing a negative review did management reach out and offer a seat at the bar for the same night.  I appreciate management trying to make it right, but at the level of dining momofuku aims to hit, this sort of amateurish service from the staff is unacceptable.  Making someones wife cry really isnt acceptable at any level.  We aren't taking management up on the putzy bar seat offer since there are so many better dining options in Vegas, and will be instead eating elsewhere.

Iy9BvTDaRQPjnax-Cnb2Ig.text: Danny is amazing! I love citrus vodka drinks and my hubby is an old fashioned type guy! Danny recommended the sunflower and green point. Perfectly paired for our taste! So happy we found this place!!!!!

Cgaa5nq7lKRbzMNh080X9g.text: A few things to note before reading this review: 1) I hardly ever leave restaurants reviews because I typically don't care enough to spend the time or energy 2) I am obsessed with food 3) I am extremely picky and have numerous food allergies/restrictions (mostly raw vegan, gluten free, severe lactose intolerance)  Momofoku's food and dining experience is 112% the best I've had in the last year. As a huge fan of David Chang and his food philosophy, I had high expectations--Momofoku exceeded them.   As I mentioned above, I'm vegan with many food allergies. Although the menu isn't necessarily known for being gluten free or vegan, the kitchen was extremely accommodating and even created 2 specialty dishes, one of which is without a shadow of a doubt the best thing I've eaten in a VERY long time.   As someone who's worked as a server, I rarely approach a dining experience with a critical eye when it comes to service, but Momofoku's hospitality is impossible NOT to mention. From the hostess stand to the multiple servers who took care of us throughout the night, I truly felt right at home--a difficult feat in a place as over-the-top and trashy as Vegas.  One server in particular, Mags, was incredible. As I mentioned, I try not to be too critical when I eat out (because I know from experience how challenging it is to be a waiter,) but I also know amazing service when I see it. Mags is definitely top 5 waiters I've ever had the pleasure of dining with.   Thank you all for an incredible experience. You truly made our trip very special and one we'll never forget!

aeOURHD2kTngXiLVT6AMaw.text: I came to Momofuku for the "experience."  It was also my birthday, so I wanted fine dining on this particular day. Who wouldn't, right?  By the way, if you are a kitchen freak as I am, GET A KITCHEN VIEW. If you're just a tourist, get a strip view.  As soon as we sat down, I was in awe of all the action I was witnessing. It was so beautiful to watch everyone working together in sync! Everyone in there was hustling their butts off. And it was really cool to watch as we waited for our food.   Anyway, about the food !!!  I was with my husband this night. We ordered 3 things.  Unfortunately, there weren't much Vegetarian or Vegan options. So our waiter helped with some suggestions and even offered something that was off menu...  1. The Chickpea Ramen w/ Bok Choy & Fermented Shiitake Mushrooms (off menu.) I give this one a 2/5. The chickpeas were on the dry side. I wanted to love this, but overall it tasted bland and seemed to lack some flavor and spice.   2. Shishito Peppers. I give these guys a 5/5! They were cooked or fried perfectly! The seasonings were on point and it was just irresistible!  3. Roasted Potatoes. 4/5. They were great! The potatoes were cooked well but the toppings on top were a bit overpowering and seemed to "hide" the main ingredient, the potato. If I plated this myself, I'd have put the cream as a base, then potatoes, then Parmesan (imo.)   All in all, I'd go back for sure!  I just wish they had more Vegetarian and Vegan options.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shishito Peppers. These had a great texture and good seasoning as well. Fav side! 5/5.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Roasted Potatoes. Nice texture! 4/5
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chickpea Ramen w/ Bok Choy &amp; Fermented Shiitake Mushrooms 2/5.

h17f-1L_-ezH9U71XYImdw.text: We were excited to try Momofuku in Las Vegas, after having visited the one in New York many times. However something much was left to be desired. The service was excellent, but the food somewhat lacking. We ordered the pork belly appetizer,at the suggestion of the waitstaff, which was delicious. But that is where the goodness stopped! The apple salad, meh! Sweet potatoes decent. We also ordered the whole fried chicken. It basically tasted like a grease ridden salt lick. I have never encountered so much salt in my entire life not even in the Dead Sea! It was basically inedible, we wrapped it and took it with us and gave it to a homeless person on the street. I still feel uneasy about the decision to give the food to the homeless man as it might've sent him into a hypertensive crisis!

Mq4qvbvQ71jumoWZwE0eAQ.text: Love the decor.  The service was ok, but not spectacular.  The food was solid. We enjoyed everything we tried but weren't blown away.

x2WZ2mulKA0sLVGKs_Qj4A.text: Great experience! Wasn't aware that the late night menu was only available after 11pm but still made the best of the choices we were given. The Kampachi with the bacon ponzu sauce was OUT OF THIS WORLD. The shoshito peppers were amazing too, the lime drizzled over them gave some kinda kick that was pleasantly tasty! Just wish the ramen had more of a kick to it. Oh and our waitress Sara was a sweetheart and made the experience that much better!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kona Kampachi
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shishito Peppers pictures with summer fling drink that was well balanced, not to sweet but oh so refreshing
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork bun

4iwPYU8PBaSprIx8ObKE6w.text: I tried the Vegas Momofuku back in May for the first time, but after my most recent vacay trip in September, looks like it'll be a definite go-to whenever we're in town. In the nature of this wildly unpredictable city, our dinner experience was much more of an adventure than we'd ever expected - on account of both the delicious food and fantastic service! If you get the opportunity to sit at the chef's counter, I'd highly recommend it. We were lucky enough to have Josh as our bartender/server and you really cannot go wrong handing him the reins. From the drink offerings to food recommendations, everything was completely on point.   The Food: Hamachi v. Bigeye Tuna - The bigeye tuna was my favorite dish from the first Momofuku visit. Shaved foie gras?? Ugh, my heart. Well this time around, Josh also recommended the hamachi appetizer. We were feeling particularly indecisive so we decided to get both to compare. Admittedly, the hamachi was amazing and the two dishes were unique in their own right. No regrets from getting both.  Heirloom Tomatoes - A really fresh in-between dish as we waited for our main. I might not get it again, but it was fun to try such a different twist to some of the ingredients I grew up with.  A5 Hokkaido Wagyu - THIS. First, I need to clarify that this isn't the normal tableside wagyu dish we originally saw on the menu. We were making bets (in Vegas, surprise) on what the MP for the wagyu was and Josh mentioned to us that there was a wagyu special that had been on the menu a couple of days ago. Luckily they gave us the option to order it and we figured this could be worth the splurge. And it really was! The wagyu was prepared with uni shoyu - a melt-in-your-mouth amazing, perfect medium rare. Still dreaming about it months later.  We were able to try a couple of desserts from MilkBar, which is connected to the restaurant. Josh brought us several cookies to try and we shared the soft serve with rainbow sprinkles. It was a simple and sweet end to a fantastic dinner experience. I won't keep rambling, but for tldr; we had quite an adventure, can't wait to be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

1EfKRldWL_OHXDxJ3T7r4Q.text: Once again Momofuku has out done themselves. I emailed the GM Ryan, he was more than accommodating, answered all my questions and made it easy to make reservations. He sold me on the family style chicken and caviar. I have to say Thank you for making our night memorable. The food again exceeded expectations! Our awesome server Manny had great recommendations, he suggested this appetizer that was like poke with strawberries, I ordered it to try it out because, the paring sounds interesting. I was not disappointed, and found a new favorite. We also had the short ribs and the milk bar birthday cake! Thank you again to the staff for making our night there the highlighted our trip. I can't thank you enough. You made my husband's birthday extra special. We will be back again.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

P6915U_Yq4E1jRaaZRJH7A.text: We came here with a big party  (+ kids) and the team (from our head waiter to the back end staff) were all so accommodating!  Our waiter was attentive, polite, helpful and made the suggestion that if we wanted to give him a $/person budget, he could just build a menu for us based on the house favorites.  So we did and it turned out great. We didn't have to make any decisions or try to figure out how many orders of each plate to order for our party size etc.  We had the oysters, burrata and pear salad, shishito peppers, bigeye tUna, spicy cucumbers, pork ramen, grilled asparagus , grilled lamb, and whole 5 spiced duck. Every was fresh and delicious!  Would come again!

aDoBUol9nWe4o7v6c2GCkA.text: TLDR: Doesn't live up to the hype.  Try it if you've never been to Momofuku restaurant. Temper your expectations, $14 for 4oz pour of sake.   With David Chang being a household name amongst foodies the hype around Momofuku may just be too much for the restaurant to uphold.   I was extremely hyped to try Momofuku in Vegas and this was my first experience at a David Chang restaurant.   We had a late lunch at 2:30pm and ordered the pork buns and the pork ramen. Figured these are what they are known for so decided to go with the known good items.   I was prepared to be blown away or at the very least get an understanding of the hype of Momofuku.   The pork buns were close. Not mind blowing but very very good. I expected the pork to be steamed like a bossam since I've seen pics of it but it wasn't. I suppose that's only available in some of his other restaurants.   The ramen while good didn't blow me away either nor sadly did it live up to the hype. The texture of the noodle were great but the broth didn't quite do it for me.   I was really excited and hoping to love Momofuku and embrace the hype but sadly, no.   If you're a Momofuku fan and never tried it, it's worth a try. Just remember to temper your expectations.   Oh and I'd avoid ordering sake. Not sure what I was thinking but I ordered sake and it was $14 for a 4oz pour.  Cheaper options available but keep that in mind when ordering sake.

PYCUPdcEhJPq4IxU3hSAwg.text: I've had Momofuku in Washington DC so wanted to try the Vegas one too since I've only had the pork buns. The pork buns are still just as good but I feel like they were more expensive than DC. We sat in the back nicer restaurant area so that might be why. They don't have ramen on the menu for dinner but it's on the "secret menu". Basically yes you can still order it. They had pork and chickpea ramen. The pork ramen was awesome and I heard the chickpea ramen tasted pretty good too.  The ramen noodles aren't the thin type which I prefer the thicker ones.  Broth wasn't too salty or heavy and it's definitely more of an artisan ramen vs. your package ramen. Overall great tastes, just expensive pricing.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bun
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chickpea ramen
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork ramen

7dB5RHruTNKHtugVMAUXGw.text: This review was actually for December 2016, update below.  I had been reminded to write my review because we kept passing the restaurant:  After all of the hype, we were super excited to try Momofuku.  Unfortunately, nothing was that exciting or better than other places that made the same thing.    Surprisingly, the ramen was disappointing.    Asked a couple of other friends who came separately.  One thought it was good, but could understand our feelingnothing was amazing.  The other agreed that she was underwhelmed.    With all of the great reviews, we have debated on trying it again, but because of the many places in Vegas, haven't been willing to chance the time...  Update:  We just stayed at the Cosmo again, and my wife wanted to try Momofuku because she hadn't tried it before.  We decided to get a quick bite before heading to the airport.  I wasn't too excited, but had to let the boss try it.    Upon looking at the lunch menu, I asked our waiter which of 3 noodle dishes did he recommend.  He told me that I hadn't actually selected his favorite dish, the chickpea ramen.  I gave him a look of disbelief.  Come on dude, a vegetarian ramen???  He promised that it had passed the test for many patrons.  I put my faith in our waiter thinking, here we go again.  My wife ordered the pork belly bun, and we also ordered the spicy cucumbers.  The pork belly bun was a lot better than I remembered it before.  It was very nicely crispy, which we weren't expecting.  The cucumbers were very good as well.  I am into cucumbers right now because I think they remind me of the crunch on kettle chips.  The ramen... well, it was damn good, even though it was a vegetarian ramen.  I cheated and added chicken.  It was very tasty and the noodles were very chewy (nothing like the thin Tokyo noodles).  My wife commented on how good it was too.    Our waiter also gave us a complimentary glass of sake that was very smooth, enough so that my wife said she would drink it.    The only negative comment would be that my wife saw a person in the kitchen drop a towel, pick it up and then put it on the stainless steel working area.  That then got us to thinking how come the guys don't need to wear those hair nets on their beards that look silly, haha.  Anyway, my wife got a little grossed out, but the food didn't disappoint!  P.S. note water isn't free...

VouIFdOoyv4lX68xMSAS9A.text: The pork belly bun is a must to try. The rice cake dish, however, tastes wired.

KzURs8CgsDNDlFIg2F6d8g.text: A bit pricey, but I'd recommend taking the time to go here if you're around the area to check out the hype. They are known for their ramen, but I ordered the Pork Belly bun and Crispy Chicken Burger. The Pork Belly was a great, and I'm happy to have ordered it. The Crispy Chicken was just the right texture and had sauces to complement it. Reservations could be made for this restaurant, but it's also easy to walk in and take a seat at the bar with your order.

Jsomlex8rlyD5vtqKJYhlA.text: My wife and I came here for an early dinner prior to going to see Lady Gaga at Park Theater (~10 minutes walking distance). The seating in the front feels relaxed, but conversely, the main dining area feels very lux. We were quickly seated near an outside facing window in the main dining area and our server was very friendly and efficient. The food was excellent, even though they were smaller portions. We had the pork belly buns, uni hashbrowns, and miso black cod (my favorite), along with several drinks and desserts. The price point is a little steep on certain items, but otherwise I would recommend coming at least once.

TegvhUtmrcuNitLmJOnWJA.text: First timers tonight! Initially came in to try the ramen, but instead we decided to give the other items a try.  Wanted to try their fried chicken & caviar but it was going to take 45min, not an ideal wait time if you're hungry, so we opted for oysters & mussels as the appetizers and the whole steamed branzino, with asparagus and crunchy potatoes as sides.  Oysters were superb, fresh! However, the sauce they gave with the oysters seemed too salty & almost unnecessary, so we asked for tobasco and you know that did the job!  Mussels were amazing, my new fave! Never had mussels prepared with dry garlic, paprika, peppery seasonings but it was delicious!  The whole steamed branzino was cooked to perfection! The meat melted in my mouth but the flavor of the fish was just alright. Seemed to be drowned in some sort of a butter, vinaigrette sauce & pesto stuffed in the middle of the fish. Interesting preparation, but I wish it had more of an asian kick to it.  As far as the sides go it was a little more on the saltier side.   Will be back to give the ramen a try!

Q3z-LxLo74NtZ3XLouIKuQ.text: I've been wanting to eat at their NY location for so long and finally got the chance to try it here in Vegas. It was underwhelming to say the least. We had: Pear and Burrata salad - the best thing we had Miso Asparagus - 2nd best thing  Pork Belly Buns - good A5 Wagyu potatoes - meh Salt and Pepper Lobster - all you can taste was salt The service was exceptional which is why I gave 2 stars but the food was definitely not worth it.

-WY0bnOl3qJrlpa4J4YDyw.text: We came in here on a Saturday night and was able to get a table.  We ordered drinks as well as a dozen half shell oysters (they come as half dozen), pork bun, shrimp bun, and fried chicken bun.    Yes, they were pricey... each pair of buns (that sounds funny) was like $14... the oysters were like $40 something for HALF a dozen... but my, the food... all of it was simply amazing.  I savored every bite of my pork belly bun... the oysters were SO fresh.    Ambiance is nice and our waiter rocked.    I'll definitely come back again while in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

V4zrAl0YBEsYXbSS2nayVQ.text: Bad experience ever. My bf heard this is new "must try" spot for travelers & locals so we decided to try it! After we have seated, our server asked us if its our first time and she recommended us to order their spicy chicken sandwich, and we ordered spicy chicken sandwich, shoyu pork ramen, porkbelly bun, and a shishito pepper as an appetier.   Didnt wait that long, we got our shisito pepper as an appetizer, got porkbelly bun. It was fresh and pretty good. Then ramen came out, was okay but really salty. When they brought sandwich, we stopped for a moment cuz it came with whole bunch of shisito pepper as a side. If our server let us know that it comes with pepper then we wouldnt order plate of shishito pepper. After done eating (we didnt even touched second plate of shisito pepper, seriously it was way toooooo much of peppers for Two people.) When we got the check they wondered if i want the togo box so i asked my server why didnt she tell us it comes with pepper so we could order something else. OmG.... that attitude, Whatever she said was horrible and terrible. Haha. She said "its first time serving it today" WHAT??????  I didnt even expect her to apologize but THAT WAS WHAT YOU TOLD US TO ORDER. food was okay, atmosphere nice and really liked about open kitchen. But most important thing "service" was worst. If youre serving dishes you better know what youre serving..

1FHXXLsN05sGVYhjz4i4Kw.text: Oysters were tiny but deep. It was delicious but too small for the price.   Ramen was delicious. SO GOOD. I say it's a must get here. WORTH every sip.

TPHrSKlYBBSEdiIOvsUl4g.text: This place is BEST I love the lobster bowl and the atmosphere is very elegant staff is great they are very courteous  The fish is great portion are huge  Pricey but highly recommended

8qfBL_pDHFiBR_wgvZnZ9Q.text: The food and service was outstanding! I loved that the food was served sharing style. Every single dish that was ordered was delicious. I am looking forward to coming back again

RNLMXStyrmQemXQ2lIEVMg.text: Hands down one of the best ramen I've ever had. I'm not a big pork fan, but the pork here is literally melt in your mouth. I always look forward to me trips to Vegas and New York City (East village) for some Momofuku ramen!  The service here is also awesome too. I sat at the bar with one of my girlfriends and the bartender (sorry I forgot his name) was waaaay too funny. I like to use a certain spice for my ramen and I had to describe it to him since I didn't know the name. Of course he knew what it was and he brought it out quickly! I love it here!

-JK42mbmqtKqCv4lHeJdsg.text: Pork belly was soft and melts in your mouth.  Spicy cucumber was good but wish the cucumber were in smaller pieces instead of in big chunks.  The Korean rice bowl was okay. A little salty and with shredded pork. It'd be better if the pork wasn't shredded.  Pork ramen was pretty tasteful and light from the little broth I tried since i tried my friends.  I really like the bathroom. They have a bidet toilet. I didn't try the features though since I don't know how to. But overall it was okay for me. Good to try.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy pork ramen
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Korean rice bowl
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy cucumber

IvLsCzAJph0j_cwVvyhO9w.text: UDPATE: A manager did reach out and was apologetic about our experience which I always appreciate when that time is taken. Therefore I've added an extra star for their customer service. I'll have to still stand by my review of the food since the update is just about the outreach, but it is a good sign they want to make things right.  ------  Was excited to come here and have some good ramen. Friends ate at be New York one and raved. Overall would describe as "meh"   Food: pork ramen was bland unfortunately. They do give a good amount of pork and noodles which was nice but ended up dousing my ramen in the sauce supposed to be for the pork bun because it needed flavor.  The pork bun on the other hand was pretty good but for seven dollars not super worth it.  The chilled ginger noodles also underwhelming.  Price: 17 for the ramen, not worth it. 15 for the noodles and it wasn't as much food.   Service: just ok. Was seated quickly which was nice and never had to ask for water refill but had to wait long time to get two other dishes we ordered with the meal to arrive at the end for us to take to go. Shouldn't have had to wait an extra 20 minutes for food we ordered at the beginning.   Sadly no desire to go back. I know when you open multiple locations quality tends to go down so I wouldn't be surprised if that was the case here.

sHUikTN-gRslhReMDti3ng.text: We had the sea bass and steak and both were the best we've ever had. Incredible food. Service was really wonderful too.

5HpN-u8nlbpqyMwmIJ4bRg.text: Trendy restaurant at the Cosmopolitan.   Advanced reservations are required. We got a 5.30pm slot on a Friday as the restaurant was fully booked the rest of the night.   The food is beautifully served and tasty. Their rotisserie chicken is worth getting as are the crispy potatoes side dish.   Our server was friendly and always had a smile on her face.   Dishes are served at the center of the table without serving spoons. I guess you are expected to share or pick at the food with your own cutlery. This didn't work for our table as there were people with allergies and the flu!   High chairs available for toddlers.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ramen
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fish

ngmKn0uYme7OOdQ13rGCsg.text: I've only heard good things about this place, and was bummed when I was not able to try it when I went to visit New York.  Luckily for me, they opened a location in Las Vegas and my friend made us reservations this past weekend.   Momofuku is located on the 2nd floor of the East Tower at the Cosmopolitan (around the corner from Marquee and Egg Slut). Got there at 5:30 and it was a little unorganized. There were groups of people scattered infront of the host table and I wasn't sure if there was an actual line. I was able to get to the front after asking several people if they were waiting to check in. From there it was smooth sailing.  We got seated right away and the staff was really friendly. My friend who made reservations put down it was for a birthday and the staff greeted me happy birthday (it really was my birthday weekend). They were really nice.   Unfortunately for me and a couple of my friends we ate only a couple of hours before coming here so we were still stuffed. We ended up sharing a couple of of the baos (chicken karaage and pork). Both were really good, I actually liked the chicken more though. I ended up ordering the pork ramen. That was really good, and despite being full, I forced myself to finish it because I knew I'd regret it. I did regret not trying the smothered chicken katsu. Per my friend "it's really good." Luckily for us we were also able to try the chive pancake, and that was delish. It's really basic but it was really good.   For dessert, we all ordered a soft serve (all come from Milk Bar next door). I ordered a cereal milk and crack pie swirl with crunch. That was really delicious. It was not overly sweet or anything and the serving was perfect. It was so cute!! I tried my friend's fruity pebble soft serve, and I'm not even a huge fruity pebble fan but that was amazing. I would definitely order that next time! And surprisingly, they brought out a few birthday cake truffles with a candle on it for my birthday. It was really unexpected and sweet of them. I know they probably do it for everyone on their birthday but I thought it was really nice. The birthday truffles were heaven and even better when you mix it with your soft serve.   Depending what you order this place can be pricey but you're in Vegas! Splurge a little and definitely try out Momofuku. If not, at least hit up Milk Bar next door!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crack pie and cereal milk swirl soft serve with crunch
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chive pancake

GrIiNlZpVOn1EUVCBeAXdQ.text: We wanted to try this after reading many great reviews about this Momofuku. We made reservations and were seated promptly.   The waiter was friendly, informative and made excellent recommendations on what to order.   We ordered the pork belly buns (sooo good), the deviled eggs (a little odd but good), smoked pork chops (juicy and cooked perfectly) and the pork belly ramen (excellent).   We had a great time and highly recommend this place!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Smoked pork chop

m2ZUGQ72q3qDB8fjPB-R4A.text: Faaantastic. Located on the 2nd floor of The Cosmo, right off the escalators.   Decor, ambiance, and service top notch for the price range. Not crowded at all for a Saturday at 12pm.   The shiitake mushroom buns were so tasty, but a tad expensive at $6 for each.   Potatoes crisps with tofu sauce were also phenomenal. Got it sans Parmesan for it to be vegan.   Pork ramen was very good. The bit of pork shoulder had great flavor. Add ons for the ramen do get spendy though. The fiance was pleased with the chickpea ramen as her vegan choice.   Would definitely come back!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shiitake mushroom buns
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crispy Potatoes sans parmesan

kLv5MUEzhXA3xntLJEyTMA.text: Wanted to try this place because of all the documentaries I saw. I was very disappointed because the food was nothing special. I ordered the pork bun, and it seemed like they cut a lot of corners in the proper garnishing in it. Then it was the truffle ramen. Although I can smell it, I don't taste it. The soup was decent but the ramen itself wasn't good at all.

5IlVHUfegT1QpyCNtAQ-2w.text: VERY VERY close to 4 stars.  I am super psyched that Momofuku has finally reached the west!  Really a great looking space inside the Cosmopolitan hotel. Has a nice view of the strip, especially from the Private/large group dining area.  A lot of the previous reviews mentioned problems with service. If my experience was any indication, it looks like those have been addressed. We had very solid service all the way from the Hostess to the wait staff and bartender. Service was friendly, fast and courteous.  On the menu for us this evening  Pork Belly Bun, and Chicken Karaage Bun - Both of these are exactly as amazing as you think they are. If I ate nothing else here, these would do.  Beet Salad with Citrus, rye XO sauce - This has the potential to be very very good. Tonight it was just alright. Desperately needed some nice large flake salt.  Ginger Scallion Noodles with pickled shiitake, cucumber, and wakame - This is a really simple and really good dish. I am not sure anything that would make anyone lose their mind but there is nothing you will ever say bad about it either! Satisfying is a great word!  Rotisserie Chicken & Fried Bones - The chicken was quite delicious! They use Jidori which is my absolute favorite. Super flavorful! The bones were a bit of a miss for me, just didn't work as well as I had hoped.  Back to staff, special kudos to the bartender. He stopped by to grab a couple of our plates and noticed my drink was low. Asked if I needed another and suggested an off menu option he had been playing with. It was great and well appreciated.  Couple of minor misses - plates could have been refreshed better between courses and there was a miss with getting utensils back to us at one point.   Keep working! I think everything is falling in place!!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. @momofukulasvegas thank you so much for the swag and the kind note! Look forward to continued success and to seeing you again soon!
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

NV9K1BKYVkxvZOt5ve4fDg.text: I been lunch time, great food except the lamb which was little to many herbs in my opinion. Service also almost on point! Definitely I will be back soon.

pIMRhkU7QDz21L36GeyfcA.text: I am very skeptical about high Yelp ratings for Vegas restaurants. Usually the food isn't well executed and you pay a very high price for mediocrity.  Not so much the case here. Our food was delicious and it didn't seem ridiculously priced to us (all depends on your expectations).  What we had:  Bun: Shiitake - hoisin, scallion, cucumber (LOVED!) Bun: Pork Belly - hoisin, scallion, cucumber (DECENT!) Side: Crispy Potatoes - truffle tofu, parmesan (PASS... Everything that's fried can taste 'good'. Not very flavorful either.) Noodles: Chilled Spicy Noodles - Sichuan sausage, Thai basil, candied cashew (LOVED!!!!! My boyfriend and I like to share main courses, and both agreed that this was our favorite.)  Service was pretty good. We ate dinner around 7pm on a week night and it wasn't busy and no wait to be seated.

6uZN0uhZrjMAwgRITn9cHQ.text: I walked in on a Sunday right after they opened and because I didn't have a reservation they seated me at one of the high top tables near the bar even though the dining room was pretty much empty.   Pork Ramen - pork belly & shoulder, slow poached egg- the ramen was average at best. The broth lacked depth in flavor and the noodles were also just meh. I expected more from the ramen just because I know Momofuku has a ramen/noodle restaurant in New York.   Hamachi sashimi- The Hamachi tasted fresh and combined with the sauce it was a pretty good dish.   Pork belly bun- comes with hoisin, scallion, cucumber. The pork belly was tender and had good flavor to it. 1 order only comes with 1.   Shrimp bun- comes with spicy mayo, pickled red onion, iceberg. I actually liked this one more than the pork belly. The shrimp was fried perfectly.

C-kA7WI6Sgth6nHWg5OjtA.text: Really tasty ramen noodles and pork buns! And if you get here early, there's really no wait. It's so much easier to get seated than the one in NYC.   The service was great and the waiter explained all the dishes and ingredients with careful precision.   Also tried the yuzu lemonade, which was delicious and not overly sweet.

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp bun
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Open kitchen with a cook hard at work

ogyETuOEN0Dne63P0lGieQ.text: Make your reservations, this place can get packed at later hours despite the ginormous amount of tables. If you're in Vegas, you have to try this notable restaurant!   After entering the restaurant, the extremely beautiful decor will catch your eye. With amazing decor comes equally amazing food. Their donuts were delightful and the wagyu carpaccio just melts in your mouth! I wish I was able to try one of each plate or have enough money to get more sushi from the menu, but my hot stones bowl will do for now.   The waiters were extremely attentive. Me and my friends has a running joke going on that they were like hawks waiting to grab peoples plates the minute they finished eating their food!   It's a pretty pricey place, but I would highly recommend!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Donuts  beautiful presentation and tasty

FQ836oj5QUjJEL0WTwv6ng.text: Creative take on Asian dishes in a fun upscale setting. Been there twice now. Here's what to get and what to avoid:  Spicy cucumber starter (5/5) - delicious and light. Almond adds a good bite  Pork belly bun (4/5) - still solid execution with a good cut  Ssam Pork Bowl (5/5) - this is so addictive! I was impressed how it can taste light, filling, and flavorful at the same time for a rice dish.  Wakame Noodles (5/5) - very light and relatively healthy option. Add a poached egg!  Tuna with Foie Gras (3/5) - the tuna gets overpowered by the foie gras which does taste light for such a heavy dish but it does get heavy and one night after a few bites. This could be great for a large group to share but for 2 people, it's a lot to eat.  Truffle ramen (2/5) - Disappointing. Pricey as truffle is but this was very much the sum of its parts and not elevated  Would come back. They seem to really do well with their simpler dishes that feature less expensive ingredients. The more expensive ones could be to your taste but I haven't had as much luck with them.

91yy1dYLEcAvTHfe8ho4vA.text: I came pretty excited about their ramen, but we were told we couldn't get them after getting seated at the table.  The hostess even said there were ramen today. Total disappointment and a feeling of deceived, especially at a reputable place like this.  We ended up getting their buns with different filling in them. They were just ok.  The bun was just mouthful of flour with 2/3 of it being the bun while 1/3 stuffing... The veggie one was terrible. I only found the pork belly one edible.  Everything felt very pretentious here.  I am not here if I'd visit another Momofoku restaurant again.  Definitely would not recommend this particular one in Las Vegas.

9ylFXv2FuoYQWP9lgGDHCA.text: For a variety of reasons, I've been a fan of David Chang for quite a while now. Not the least of which, quite simply...his restaurants/eateries are just good. Granted, this is based entirely on the two spots of his in NY that I've been to (Ssam Bar and Milkbar), but there wasn't much about either experience I didn't like. So, clearly, after seeing that one of my favorite restaurateurs had taken up shop in one of my favorite hotels in Vegas, it was only a question as to WHEN I'd stop in to check them out! While I've yet to visit most of their sister locations, I imagine that this Momofuku outpost is on the trendier side. Which makes sense, give their home (Cosmopolitan). The front "bar" area has a more of a casual look, but the main dining room in the back is nicer, with large windows to take advantage of its perch overlooking The Strip. More importantly, the (lunch) menu, though not extensive, looked just as good - starters, buns, noodles, sides...just about everything looked delicious! **Note: besides how the menu is different for lunch/dinner/afternoon/late night, the range of offerings changes often/daily, so it's very likely that what I had won't be on the menu when you come here. -- GINGER SCALLION NOODLES with Pickled Shiitake, Cucumber, and Wakame...$15 Unmixed: (yelp.com/biz_photos/momo...) Mixed: (yelp.com/biz_photos/momo...) It may not have sounded very interesting, but this was great! The fact it was served cold was unexpected, but it made sense given the flavors - slightly salty, earthy, and acidic. The cucumbers added a nice crispness and the noodles had just the right bite to them! Delicious! -- CRISPY POTATOES with Truffle Tofu and Parmesan...$12 (yelp.com/biz_photos/momo...) I was actually pretty hopeful for this one, but it missed the mark. While I liked the truffle flavor and the Parmesan (who wouldn't?), the potatoes didn't do it for me - kind of bland on their own and not the least bit crispy. -- PORK BELLY BUNS with Hoisin Sauce, Scallion, Cucumber...$7 (yelp.com/biz_photos/momo...) Though not quite as good as the one at Ssam Bar, this was still pretty solid. It was a little dry as a whole, as there wasn't much sauce and part of the pork was dry (surprising, since it's pork belly), but everything else was good - the pork wasn't super fatty, the bun was decently soft, and the overall taste was good. -- SHOYU PORK RAMEN with Pork Belly & Shoulder and Slow Poached Egg...$17 (yelp.com/biz_photos/momo...) I wanted this as soon as I read it on the menu, but I got even more stoked when I saw this come out! The pork belly (so thick!), the pork shoulder, the egg, the noodles, the broth (so rich!)...everything was perfect. Even the sprouts were good! I would totally come back just for this. Beyond the food, I'd be remiss not to mention the service here - from the hostess to the variety of servers that stopped by our table, everyone here was super friendly and accommodating. At the end of the day though, it's all about the food and Momofuku was straight up delicious. As bummed as I was to miss out on their noodle spot when I was in NY, I was just as elated to have corrected that here...and that it was so good! Given how their dinner menu offers an entirely different slate of things to try (including a lot of large/family-style dishes), I'll undoubtedly come back to try that. But even if it's just for lunch, afternoon snack, or late night eats, or even for just a ramen craving though, you can bet I'd come back just for that shoyu pork ramen!

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Buns with Hoisin Sauce, Scallions, and Cucumbers
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crispy Potatoes with Truffle Tofu and Parmesan

9W1wWyI3uIG84Maofdx-GQ.text: It's your staple food prepared so sophisticatedly it'll still leave you mind blown. Based on reviews I ordered sea bass and pork buns. Both were absolutely freaking brilliant.   The broth in the sea bass blended such a robust taste and supported that flaky fish beautifully. I recommend pairing with rice to balance the dish and fill you up.   The pork belly buns leave you in this tension of wanting to scarf it in one bite and wanting to eat it slow to savor. So conflicted. Comes with two, worth every bit.   Sorry too excited and ate too fast to take pics

xfxP3gGyzKCszB4zkOejog.text: Literally the best food I've ever had. We had the pork belly buns, creamed corn and spicy cucumbers. Nothing disappointed. Even the rose we ordered was delicious. If you can only afford one high end place to eat in Vegas this should be at the top of your list.

Oi1NgtacyvORkJtFm8emfA.text: Having "free time" jumped at the chance to try this little gem!   The action and comfort from the restaurant as I made my way to the bar to sit was so inviting. Even before ordering here the collective of employees are like family and it transfers immediately and fills others around them with glee.   After pulling out the stool at the bar and placing my handbag in one of those lovely hook for excess clutter it was time to view the menu. The cocktails and wine offering are some of the best here at the Cosmopolitan. I decided to dabble with beer from abroad today; since my selection of food was on the spicy and saucy side!  I enjoyed the service of three different bartenders; whom were all an extension of the next. They were attentive to all the customers at the bar. Very outgoing and friendly. Their radiance was shining light that spread out in vibes of positivity. So some of the best and happiest bartenders in Vegas! Have to respect those that absolutely love what they do?  My beer selection took me all the way to Singapore where I decided to embrace the tiger and had a Lager Tiger. It was really smooth; plus the bartender recommended it too me. It was an excellent choice with stunning taste. You might compare it to Budweiser in America but smoother.  Beer selected check! Wanting to explore something saucy I decided on Shishito Peppers and the Grilled Asparagus. These two plates come separately and make a wonderful pairing together. They are extremely healthy and delicious. The Asparagus was amazing and properly streamed too.  Let's move to talk more in depth about the Shishito Peppers. Perfection on a plate; but let's explore more! So being the kind of girl that invites hot stuff to dinner these peppers make a perfect pairing. The Shishito pepper is of the Asian cuisine and they are flavored well when roasted all by there lonesome. They are spicy but not like American peppers. The hints of smoke are more apparent in the taste and a sweeter flavor. It is worth trying if you enjoy the heat of good peppers. I ended up enjoying all the peppers and asparagus paired with a tiger to rinse it all down!  The restaurant and bar of Momofuku are so delightful and worth a peak! Try the peppers and beer from somewhere new. I did and will explore other regions of the globe when I return.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shishito Peppers $11
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Grilled Asparagus $10
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Singapore Tiger Lager $14

w3MYCk6ZEdhuWcoWv2T3Mw.text: This was my first time at a Momofuku and I have to say it doesn't live up to the hype. Personally, I would've given this place three stars but my mom hated it.  I had the pork ramen, which was overly salty but not the worst ramen I've ever had. The noodles were cooked well, the portion size was small, but they give you a lot of meat. Wish the pork belly was sliced into two thinner pieces, the large chunk they give you is hard to eat. The broth doesn't quite have that deep rich flavor you'd expect from good ramen.  My mom got the ginger scallion noodles and I tried some, I will have to agree it wasn't great. There were too many competing flavors and it was very overseasoned and over salted.  The service was great though, never had my water glass less than 1/3 full, which is a big accomplishment given how thirsty we were from all the sodium.

-EWZHc0EeGIN55H8Z_SExQ.text: Momofuku Las Vegas. One step for David Chang. One giant disappointment for mankind.   I have been a fan of David Chang's television series for years as I find him as interesting as articulate yet I have not had a chance to try his cuisine up until my last visit to Sin City. Momofuku was founded in 2004 with the opening of Momofuku Noodle Bar in New York City and has since become an empire thanks to Chang's ascent  into culinary superstardom. The Vegas outpost is similar to the rest of the Momofuku locations with neon, glass, white oak, raw oiled steel, and concrete as the focal points but the Las Vegas Strip's dominating skyline reminds you exactly where you are at all times.   I arrived in a group of four at 8:00 pm with reservations and was seated immediately  and took in the interior over a craft IPA and noticed at once that the service was near Michelin star level. Our waitress knew everything about each dish and was happy to answer any question as in-depth as our party cared to go. There is no questioning Momofuku's service game.   The menu is split up into Appetizers, Small Plates, Large Plates, and Noodles & Buns which encourages your party to share in order to sample as many flavors as possible; this is the only way to go if you aren't going to opt in for the family style meals that start at $200.00 (yes, ouch).  If you are going to only get one thing at Momofuku (and that might not be such a bad idea) let it be the Pork Belly Bun. This is perhaps the best Bao I have ever had sporting a generous, thick slice of perfectly charred Pork Belly with a smear of Hoisin along with Scallion & Cucumber as garnish. Thanks to the texture of the Bao Bun, everything comes together in perfect harmony bit for bit and there is a nice salty note in the close only made possible by Pork infused with Hoisin. At $7.00 each, this is the most inexpensive gourmet experience you will have in Vegas without In N Out or Shake Shack being mentioned.   Sadly, this is about where things start to slide downhill quickly.   Next to arrive at the table was the A5 Kagoshima Wagyu Potatoes and as incredible as the presentation really was, the use of the A5 Wagyu is a dismal failure. You see, they pound or slice the meat razor thin and then melt it over the Potatoes - so much so you cannot decern any Waygu flavor whatsoever. In fact, we actually called the waitress over and insisted the Beef was forgotten altogether until she pointed out that the thin, almost transparent cheesecloth looking top was, in fact, our A5. This dish is $42.00 worth of Potatoes with Honey Mustard, crunchy Garlic, and Almonds. Absurd.   We also shared the dubious Spicy Cucumbers tossed with Togarashi & toasted Almonds which did not excite in any capacity along with the equally insipid Hozon Rice Cakes (another lackluster $28.00 Tapas). After those four courses, we decided we were simply burning money and wasting valuable stomach real estate on a dud in Vegas and that my friend is heresy.   I cannot express the level of depression I had as I left... David Chang was a long time hero of mine but some things are better left for televisionfantasies.   Momofuku is a hard pass. Well, beside that Pork Bun, that is.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Buns.

Dqwu4eRwOofvlJGxPduHzA.text: AMAZING. a big fan of David Chang and Ugly Delicious on Netflix. The Pork Shoyu Ramen was amazing and so delicious. The chef hooked it up with a side of fries that usually only come with special and they were the best fries I've ever had. They are fried and then tossed in the meat drippings from the special. I would recommend getting a seat at the chefs table to see all the happenings in the kitchen. It's an experience to see it all go down behind the scenes. Danielle, our server was great and attentive

y28zQLr5omPIWg3HMUR7xw.text: The service and food were both amazing. Definitely set a standard for other restaurants that we try in Vegas.   We will definitely be back!

0SDx5uT_O_7mKjLTS79KCA.text: We got the star treatment on a Friday night, the day after seeing Lady Gaga in concert.  The hostess led us to a round table of five, in a corner overlooking the Eiffel Tower and the Dancing Fountains of the Bellagio.  A round table that our waiter found scary because it juts out past the building - seeming to have no foundation (but there is a view of the Momofuku's manager's office on the floor below).  The waiter said "I'm a fan of scary movies, but this table scares me more!"  The sensation of floating over Vegas with a dancing fountain view was totally spectacular.  The lazy Susan made sharing way, as the waiter demonstrated with a scratchy DJ move.   When one of us mentioned a nut allergy, the waiter said, "No worries.  I know mouth-to-mouth."  Nothing wrong with a flirty waiter, even if he did promise to throw a peanut into a dish . . . His favorite dishes are the branzino, duck and lamb.  We started with a group of small plates and worked our way to share two large plates - cod and branzino.  Shishito peppers with smoked salt and lime.  Mostly mild with the smoked salt providing a perfect counterpoint to the acidic lime.    Sweet and sour long beans with ginger, garlic and black vinegar.  Excellent, crunchy bite with complimentary sauce.  Spicy cucumber with togarashi and toasted almond.  The togarashi is a sweet roasting spice mix.  The cucumbers tasted fresh, green and herbal with the spice mix providing layers of nuttiness that did not overwhelm.  Smoked pumpkin with carrot barbecue, orange and cilantro.  The pumpkin had a crunchy outer shell with a soft, perfectly cooked mushy center - a great balance of texture and taste in each bite.  Ginger scallion noodles with pickled shiitake, spicy cucumber and wakami (a brown seaweed).  A favorite of the group and the only dish we ordered two of.  The mushrooms offered a good acidic counterpoint to the noodles.  Miso black cod with crab butter, mushroom and roasted vegetable broth.  One of us is married to a fisherman and explained that cod, with its rich, buttery flavor once once not well regarded in restaurants.  Once regarded as a trash fish, something g that was caught while searching for more popular fish, but this dish was a favorite of the fishmonger's wife.  Fun fact from the fishmonger's wife "Black cod was popularized by Nobu and is also called sablefish or butterfish."  Whole branzino with bonji, bonji ponzu and crispy rice.   Bonji is like a soy sauce, but it does not contain soybeans, rather it is made from fermented hearty grains.  Ponzu is a citrus based sauce common in Japanese cuisine.  The branzino was delicate and perfectly accompanied by the crispy sticky rice, hidden underneath.

zW5D_cus2xGBCCJhJIfv0Q.text: We liked it so much we came here twice.   Full disclosure: I'm extremely biased. Momofuku brings me back to my NYC days, one of my first tastes of fine dining and definitely my first taste of good ramen.  It was the Momofuku ramen back then, and it's the Shoyu Pork Ramen here. Shoyu broth is never my favorite, but this broth is rich and savory, and that thick, dissolving chunk of pork belly and shredded pork shoulder will never get old. You can't go to Momofuku without ordering a Pork Belly Bun. That brick of pork belly is everything. There's a Spicy Fried Chicken Sandwich on the late night menu. Crispy with a sweet, sweet burn. Lunch includes Ssam, and the Jidori Chicken is surprisingly good. The chicken is perfect, so tender and juicy, great if you're craving something on the lighter side. Be sure to share - it's still a lot of food.   I still love Momofuku. Everything on the menu is good, and they deliver quality every time. If only they would bring back that kimchee stew...my life would be complete!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

dX-aNPXraxdTA6N7Yd-AwA.text: It has been two years since I've been to Momofuku and I must say it is even better than when it first opened. The entire restaurant was poppin and full at every table. The drink selection was vast with many unique options. The Violet Femme and the Penicillin were awesome. Staff were very attentive and knew exactly what we needed. Some of our favorite dishes were: Chick Pea Ramen (Sounds crazy, but it is outstanding), Heirloom Tomatoes (Fresh Plumes, Thai Basil, Sesame oil), brussels sprouts (yummy Japanese twist that will explode in your mouth). Lastly the Creamed corn stole the show. Famers market purchased, cooked corn husks, with a added pesto and topped with crispy chicken skin and truffle oil! We even added some to our ramen to make for the perfect ramen. They also have a truffle ramen which I would try next time. To end our experience, we enjoyed a milk chocolate explosion. I'm actually not impressed with anything at Milk except for the what was once "crack pie".  Anyway, check out Momofuku! I assure a great dinning experience!!!
