Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Violet femme

xz-rz44E56IwriJujasmDQ.text: Don't miss out on Momofuku while you're in Vegas!   I've had the chance to dine in for lunch and dinner, and both experiences were excellent.   On our first visit, we celebrated my boyfriend's birthday with 3 friends. Since it was a special occasion, we decided to get the family style bo ssam pork shoulder. The price tag for the item alone was hefty, but well worth the money. The menu says that it feeds 3-4 people, but we had plenty leftover, and brought it home with us. All the drinks and side dishes we ordered were delicious, including a few of the special items for the evening.   This past Saturday, we came in for lunch at 11am before our flight back home. My family and I all ordered individually, but took bites of each other's dish - how could we not! To start, we had the pork belly buns and spicy cucumbers, and half order of oysters. An order of the shishito peppers came out, compliments of the chef, as it took a while to get our cocktails and a few of the items from the menu were unavailable at the time. For entrees, we had the 5 spice duck ssam, bo ssam rice plate,  and the ginger scallion noodles with chicken, which was one of my favorites.  If you're not too full after the meal, order some of the famous cereal milk soft serve or hop on over to Milk Bar next door for corn cookies and crack pie!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ginger Scallion Noodles w chicken
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Grilled Lamb Ribs
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bo ssam rice plate

0Of9NICbssiG_2XQsg_JQA.text: What a burst of flavor this place is! So thankful they had it in the cosmopolitan where we happened to be staying in, so location was definitely a convenience for us! Majority of us ordered the shoyu ramen. Wow, do not be fooled by the size of the bowl. The noodles were never ending and the pork was crispy on the skin and soft and tender to the meat.  Not to mention the flavorful broth and perfectly poached egg that complimented the ingredients so well! We also ordered the pork buns which were also delicious and meatful, along with the crunchy sweat potato fries.  We had absolutely no issue getting a seat during the peak of lunch hour on a Saturday and the service was beyond satisfactory!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Shoyu Pork Ramen

tV05fNvP-lxDKKvGrxXbGQ.text: On a family trip to Vegas and I took today for myself. Decided to goto Momofuku solo before hitting the strip. Had a good server, but slow service. The crispy sweet potatoes were the highlight of my lunch. Great textures, perfect balance of sweet and hot. The ramen left a bit to be desired,  it no complaints. Pass on the whiskey highball- to much club soda to taste the whiskey and not enough apricot to be meaningful, this cocktail could be best described as tv static in your mouth.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ah oyu Pork Ramen
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crispy Sweet Potatoes

dSP164QqbUjjLePHp8SUzw.text: I'd say our dinner was good. Nothing about it was bad, but for as much money as the dinner was, I'd expect more than just solid food.   We ordered the crudo, long beans, squid and ginger scallion noodles.   The crudo was AMAZING.  The long beans were fine.   The squid was well cooked but the seasoning wasn't very good. it was hot, which was fine, but it was just hot without any other real flavor, which I didn't like.  The noodles were average at best. The pickled mushrooms were great but the rest was kinda flavorless.   Service was great, very friendly and attentive.

vu3635-wDx7v_Paq5u3JBQ.text: The place is really nice, service is great.  The shisito pepper and salads are delicious with interesting twist.  Forgot to take pic of the ramen, maybe because it's not my favorite dish here.   The ramen soup is on the salty side and most ramen soups are usually saltier than Chinese soup noodles.  Personally I like a more concentrated pork broth, the soup here is not as greasy or thick as the ones I have in Japan.    The price is reasonable considering the location.  Beautiful place.  Did I mention the service is amazing?  Haha

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

uQYeirPHMr7pCz7z-GGj7A.text: This place is a regret meal waiting to happen. Flavors are mild and one dimensional, ingredients are average quality, and the prices are too high for the quality.  The one redeeming part might be the pork buns, but they certainly needed their additional sweet and sour sauce to save it.  I ordered the bonji old fashion and it was just boring. No complexity to the flavor, just a glass of bourbon with a orange expressed over it. For my entree I got the shoyu ramen and it was bland, it was a rich dish but it wasnt rich in flavor.  $100 later I wish I went anywhere else. I have heard good things about this place but I guess I need to reevaluate where I get my advice from.

YBiXkUz8XU0leAnUpY6xEQ.text: Smoked salt could be more evenly distributed on the Shishito pepper. The color on the chicken karaage could be more golden brown, but taste and texture is on point. Scallion noodle is ok. Would like to try the ramen, pork belly bun and yellowtail sashimi next time.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

kN9_SnIOspB05iAh0paCCg.text: Always a great experience. Food and service always up to it's standards. The duck is by far the best I've had. Bring plenty of friends so you'll be able to taste everything.

HT-q9IYmIp5-acIZAzHleQ.text: I walked into Momofuku uknowing if they had any food options for me and my husband. We are vegan/vegetarian medical reasons and its been hard. But they very much surprised me with so many delicious vegetables plates. By far my favorite dishes in the Cosmo came from here. Carrot BBq Pumkin and the Long Beans were the best plates I had. I even mixed them together and it was heaven...The cocktails were just right. Now I cant stay in any other casino, they dont have Momofuku. Please give me more vegan dishes! Your food is amazing and I need more of it in my life. And I also read a review a few before mine that dogged David Chang and is food at this restaurant, I feel that was unfair. And I also read in the same review that the Pumkin tasted like 'a bunch of five spice' I didnt get only five spice, I got the aromatic, the smoke, the carrot and the crispy outside with soft melty inside. Thats hard to do with pumkin, I cook them a lot. Thanks David

eWwO5sy8uxZYAdUzELNUUQ.text: I think this place is overhyped. I tried the popular pork belly buns and the pork belly didn't have much flavor.  It also didn't have a good ratio between meat and fat. I also tried the ginger scallion noodles and the noodles had great texture and were flavorful, but a little too salty.  However the service here is awesome. The wait staff is very friendly, fast, and attentive; and it's only because of the exceptional service that I'm debating on going back to give their food another try with some other dishes.  If I do,  I'll update my post.

YS_hoAB4UINTcEe1dPB0CQ.text: We were twice in 4 days! Tried every thing  that  met our dietary restriction ( no red meat)  and loved it all.. the food was great , unique flavors! Service was great! will be back and order some shrimp buns and the chilled noodles. SO SO SO BOMB!

yqQ4_5spvt9uVAj2Egx2DQ.text: I was really excited to try this place after how much my friends loved the New York version. The service was good but the food left a lot to be desired. The pork belly bun was decent but the bread was pretty flat. The truffle ramen was okay, the broth was delicious but it was served with extra thick noodles that were tough and difficult to chew and did not absorb any of the broth flavoring. There were no actual truffles in the broth either, just shavings. The worst part was it was $50!!!! Also, the $50 was a surprise as it was only listed at market price on the menu. Given the other ramen noodles were $14-17, you wouldn't expect the other ramen to be dramatically different, lesson learned, MomoF***edMe. For a bowel of chewy ramen noodles....this place didn't live up to the hype and the prices were ridiculous.

NVG7KrUXBREl6bJdR1mA7w.text: Really great Chickpea Ramen and Chicken buns. Yuzu lemonade is terrific and original. Tasty. Pickle plate was large and had wide variety. We had the limited menu since we came during the day and the waitress was very helpful in letting us know the ingredients in the dishes.   Service was terrific. Definitely worth a try! Everything we got was good.

aaF2wuNMYF1Cf572MeDuTg.text: I was really excited to come across this place while in Vegas because I had visited New York a couple weeks before and hadn't had the chance to try Momofuku in NY!  I'm usually partial to creamy tonkotsu-esque ramen but the darker, clear broth ramen they serve at Momofuku was incredibly flavorful! Noodles are thin but very chewy. It's funny, because Momofuku is the antithesis of everything I love in ramen: fatty broth, thick noodles, generous slices of pork, but I still really enjoyed my meal!  Portions aren't huge considering the high price, but it's definitely worth trying out!

6kViB-Dp9qj2fydQRqgC7Q.text: Pretty darn good! First time at the Las Vegas location. Sat at the bar/food counter. One of the bar tenders Charles was so friendly, attentive, and really awesome. Got the pork belly buns and tuna foie Gras small plate that was delish!!

-6anl-7SvX0Vv_VWlsCVGw.text: First time at this location. We came on a Sunday evening, so there wasn't a wait. Had to try the pork ramen which did not disappoint. Broth was fantastic, the poached egg done perfectly, noodles not too soft... but all of this was expected considering the popularity of the restaurant. I'd say the surprising part was the sides and appetizers. The mushroom and walnut side dish was savory. We finished the side dish before our ramen. It complimented the flavorful ramen well. Our appetizer was the cucumber and roasted almond dish. It was a great entry plate as it was light, had a little bit of heat with the chili but some opposing flavors with the cucumber and the heavy helping of almonds. This did well with the cocktails that we ordered.  We got out of there with a bill under $100 for two... pretty good considering how full we were when we left.  No room for Milk.

ePSNi3CFu4t_eZkbHX-EoQ.text: What started out as a potential disaster at Momofuku turned into a pleasant meal with friends.  Mr. Booth, Bloewen, Buxton and myself arrived a couple minutes early for an 8pm reservation.  We were told that it would be at least a 30 minute wait from that point.  We stood there asking for an update about every 10 minutes and the hostess simply said that the tables were still full.  We saw other people being seated, but for us, the table still wasn't ready.  No offers for a drink or appetizer, we were just told to wait  After I finally got angry enough to talk the manager, we were quickly seated, given a nice table, and a great server.  Things were much better from that point on.  Dishes that we had were the following: -  Raman (5 stars),  - Spicy Raman (4 stars) - Thinly sliced pork (4 stars),  - Pork chops (2 stars since it was too fatty),  - a few buns(3.5 stars),  - soft boiled eggs (2 stars - served cold which was weird)  In general, the food was very good, and i'm glad that we ended up eating at Momofuku.  And thank you for the manager for quickly resolving our problem and finding us a table.  However, it was unfortunate that the long delay occurred and the hostess team handled it so poorly.

axRN2mujovMAkqyWgh4PyA.text: Celebrated Valentine's (plus hubby's new job) the weekend before and had an amazing time! We made reservations via yelp and Rica was awesome setting it up. They seated us lovebirds at a more private location with the best view (ask for this seat if you get the chance). As expected food was delicious (fusion flavors and exotic dishes)! The service was top notch (server knew every detail about every dish! For you foodies out there this is a treat!). Our favorite dishes were the black truffle ramen, bone marrow, and the cauliflower + Brussels sprouts... and dessert was absolutely devour-worthy--cereal milk soft serve with corn flakes and a slice of crack pie!    Momofuku Las Vegas is befittingly located inside the Cosmopolitan hotel    Thank you so much to the Momofuku team for making our celebration so memorable with your hospitality and delicious food!

_4PvJgicsJfXiU_tEH1pBA.text: My ramen bowl was served with a broken poached egg. The noode texture is not tender and feels very "processed". The broth was so salty that I felt tired after eating.

TxgwUJlW4OifG09DeijhKw.text: Best meal I've ever had in Vegas.  The duck was the most amazing things I've ever had.  My group shared a few things and they were ALL Amazing.  In love with this place.  I love places where you don't know what to expect and it seems strange from the description but then you eat it and you are like I LOVE THIS.  That was what it was like for me.

iYbp-wFaEcnprz-xl2uHlA.text: The food was great, but the service was even better. Thank you to, Omar who brought me a complementary birthday treat, even though we didn't tell him it was my birthday! (It was on my ID, the Madam Jeanette is really good btw)   Would definitely come back

jiAylEOqN3VQn264vbSSEw.text: Momofuku in Las Vegas has good ambience and a great view; tables by the wall-to-wall windows are overlooking the strip and Miracle Mile shops.  Overall the food was spot on and staff were very attentive.   I tried the pork belly bun and the chicken karaage bun, both were quite tasty, but if I were to pick one to try again, I would go with the pork belly.  Pork is melt in your mouth tender and the pickled cucumbers accompanies it perfectly.  The pork ramen was the highlight of the meal.  A tasty and not too heavy broth, toothsome noodles and delicious toppings, everything one can ask of a bowl of ramen.   I also tried the chilled spicy noodles, which was also really good.  A good balance of generously sauced cold noodles under a bed of  warm crispy sichuan sausage and herbaceous fresh basil.   Finished the meal with the signature "Crack Pie" and it was really good! Dense and moist and lightly dusted with powdered sugar.  The great thing about everything on the dessert menu was that it was the same price inside the restaurant as the Milk Bar dessert stand right next door! No up charge for the table service! So try the cereal milk soft serve and crack pie desserts and feel at ease knowing you are paying the same price as everyone outside at the much more casual Milk Bar.   Will come back with a larger group to try the family style "Large Format menu" on the backside of the menu!  Momofuku meets all expectations in both food and service; a great addition to the Las Vegas dining scene.

iHjWAoRFaP7qhmrThDRg8w.text: Expensive and poor quality food. Japanese foods are cooked by no Asian chef there. Ramen ia salty and luke warm.I have tummy ache 30 min after eating. 2 star for the good service.  Expensive and poor quality food. Japanese foods are cooked by no Asian chef there. Ramen ia salty and luke warm.I have tummy ache 30 min after eating. 2 star for the good service.

DRvQtkExjI2Gyn_JO4Ifuw.text: Finally got a chance to eat at Momofuku during a work trip and had to try all the buns. They were perfect and so delicious. Tried the rice cake dish and potatoes as well which were amazing. We didn't want to fill up too much since we wanted room for Milk Bar! Looking forward to trying other things next time.

4XSWew24KwyPjW961k-9XQ.text: May have missed something here but on the website and Yelp photos showed lots of noodle and ramen dishes. Our menu was made up mostly of meats and farm to table type food. I couldn't find one noodle or ramen dish. May be a summer thing. What we ate was pretty good but I was thrilled to finally try some of Changs traditional Asian dishes--unfortunately that didn't happen. Might have to try the location in DC. Ambiance and staff did a good job just disappointed in food selection

11VSDWMKpKTaMTSoEzOXSQ.text: Ramen is comfort food for me and after a late night or long convention week in Vegas, Momofuku hits the spot. The ramen is delicious- not the best authentic ramen, but still good flavor. The cucumbers are also a nice side to break up the fattyness of the meat in the ramen. What makes this place Four stars is the added bonus of delicious desserts after a nice bowl of ramen. The crack pie and cereal milk ice cream is the perfect ending to your meal.

jQzvnJqk8V101srjgzbI8Q.text: Got the Bossam bowl & shoyu ramen. YESSS TO THE BOSSAM. VERY GOOD. The meat was oh so so well seasoned and cooked softly. The contrast of pickled ginger, kimchi and cucumber slices balanced out the fattiness  of the pork belly really well too. And importantly that the meat was not dry!! As for the shoyu ramen,  seems like its lacking some flavor, the broth doesn't have much of a porky flavor and was a little bland. The noodles and meat however were perfectly cooked .  Great interior decorations and staffs service! At certain side of the restaurant, you get to see part of the strip, really neat!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Ramen
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bossam Bowl. YESS, I approved this so much.

YWKGvmx31hcXQYQDR_lnPQ.text: _________________________ \                                                / /   -:: OVERALL RATING ::-     \ \                                                / /   4.5/5.0    ::    Venue/Decor   \ \   4.5/5.0    ::    Service            / /   4.5/5.0    ::    Ambiance        \ \   5.0/5.0    ::    Food                / /________________________\  I was super excited to dine at another restaurant of the infamous Chef David Chang, since I am such a huge fan of his. Unfortunately, we didn't make it to either the lunch or dinner time frame but smack right in the middle of the afternoon. We didn't make a reservation. But guess what?? Momofuku even had a menu for the odd dinning time! It's a limited menu items but still good enough to try out whatever they had to offer.  -:::- VENUE / AMBIANCE -:::-   Love the Cosmopolitan hotel & all the good dining spots within. There really isn't a lack of good restaurants here. Momofuku is on the 2nd level within Cosmo. A pretty darn good prime & hip spot being in the middle of the Vegas strip. Due to the arrival of our time we were seated near the front of the entrance. So I never got to see the inside of the restaurant.  Ambiance was nice and the noise level was a bit loud. It was an enjoyable & relaxing atmosphere.  -:::- SERVICE  -:::-   Hostess was approachable. Our server was courteous. Service overall was fair given it was an odd time to dine but not OMG impressive. Food was served in a timely manner and our questions were answered.   -:::- FOOD  -:::-   For the 3 of us we ordered more than we should have but it was well worth it.   Whiskey Highball             [2.0/5.0]  -- Doesn't even taste like suntory toki whiskey & definitely no hint of apricot  Shoyu Pork Ramen         [4.0/5.0]  -- Overall not bad but not the best. But the pork belly was pretty damn good. This ramen is better shared. Pork Belly Buns               [5.0/5.0]      -- All 3 of us agreed that these are the best buns we've yet had   Salt & Pepper Shrimp      [5.0/5.0]   -- Perfectly & lightly tempura battered veggies & shrimp Shishito Peppers             [4.5/5.0]   -- I learned a new item called the Nooch (nutritional yeast)! I know it sounds strange but it is a game changer. Nooch's cheesy, nutty flavor is densely packed into tiny yellowish powder/flakes (like a cornmeal), making it the perfect ingredient to sprinkle over veggies for a healthy side dish.   Next time we visit Vegas, we definitely are coming back to try out their lunch or dinner items!

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 6/23/19 (sun): Pork Belly Buns!! Sooooo goood!

TTys4E3mWS_gJwWx4kKi6Q.text: The truffle ramen is amazeballs. That's what I ordered and I am so happy I did. My only caveat is that you must love truffles. Otherwise, you'll hate it because it is loaded with oodles of shaved truffles.  The big eye Tuna was suggested by our fabulous waitress, Ashley. It's so unique. It has shaved fois gras mixed with strawberries and tuna. The rich fatty texture of the fois gras combined with the sweet but somehow also tart strawberries and the fresh tuna was a taste explosion. You would never think these three ingredients go together but it works!   The beef Sichuan noodles were a treat because the dish is savory and it has some spiciness to it. It balanced eating the tuna and the truffle ramen well, because we can all use a bit more spicy in our lives right??  The pork buns were just okay that particular evening. They were a little on the tougher side even though flavorful. They didn't stand out as much from all the other stuff we ate there and are on par with other pork buns we've had at other places.   Our bartender, Adam, was awesome at dealing with my hubby because he could tell he was a bit grumpy from our trip and was probably hangry at that point. He stopped at nothing to appease his cocktail tastes and whipped up some unique concoctions not even on the menu!   Momofuku was great overall and the service really impressed us! It's a bit on the spendier side but that's to be expected in Vegas and it's worth it when you get sooooo much truffle in that ramen (wink wink)!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Black Truffle Ramen
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Grilled Japanese Squid
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Our dessert that was addicting like crack

820l8FPM8FMvk1UDCCUe1g.text: Nom!!!!   Best dining experience in Vegas this week. Solo dining!!   Vegas is all fun and games with 107 plus degrees heat right now. Pool parties, night parties! Just parties and non stop hyper adrenaline pumping everything when you're here. In the crazy heat, it can be exhausting!!   Dining here was quite the opposite of all. And I love it! Even the Cosmo is quite hot and busy but super mellow and zen inside this expansive beautiful spot! Open kitchen, gorgeous dark wood/ wood interior. Non glitter but with the strip views!   Food: snacks, ramen, noodles and main dishes. And their milk bar for dessert is right outside too but you can just order it here and beat the lines! Sugar cake, sure!  My ramen was rich, light and tasty! Super rich pork belly, light broth and tasty noodles! They bring you extra brother too! Simply delish! Spicy cucumber was their popular item and it can be a dish itself. It's rich and dense. The only thing missing was their amazing salt and pepper lobster! But that's no feat for one person! Gotta share!! With a group! Or their five spice duck!!   Add a few more baos, coffee and drinks: you have an afternoon chill spot. The staff was so nice here! So nice that I spent a couple of hours here: unplanned! Just a combination of classical music, open kitchens movement and super relaxing atmosphere ( even though it was fully packed)  and food! And spicy peppers! Thanks to my awesome waiter! Portions are massive too.I couldn't finish any of my food. But I left very full and happy!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Got peppers?? Yes yes I do! Thanks to my awesome server for bringing 3 bowls of this!
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Latte all day!
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The leftover cake!

XW5GLzhbmBgHoMWi6BwbDw.text: Came here for dinner with my coworkers and the food is great! Definitely recommend the large plate duck dish. You get to eat the skin with crepe/ lettuce (kinda like peking duck), and they cook the meat with rice. The beef sichuan noodle was savory and delicious as well, although there was definitely a spice kick.   Service was really good, and food was definitely "Vegas/ strip-priced".

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

7EzPNZcnwZroXZqdLQRv4A.text: I have to be honest I felt a little silly suggesting ramen when it was 100 degrees outside but after my experience here I regret nothing!!  From start to finish we had a spectacular experience. We were a group of 6 and had a nice circular table in the center of the restaurant complete with a lazy Susan on top that allowed us to easily share conversation and food. You'd be surprised how hard it is to find an adequate seating arrangement in Vegas for larger groups. Our waiter came right over to get us started with waters and drinks. he was great at answering questions we had about the menu and making recommendations.   I ordered the Shoyu Pork Ramen for myself and shared an order of Pork Belly Buns and Garlic Green beans. Everything was to.die.fooorrrr. The Pork belly in the buns just melted in your mouth and ws so full of flavor. The green beans were some of the best I ever had and probably filled up on too much because I couldn't finish my ramen hahaha. The ramen I loved as well. I asked if they had some spicy chili sauce to add because I love my ramen with a kick and the waiter said they didn't have that exactly but brought me two types of oil. Neither was super hot but together they added the little UMPH that I needed.  After my visit I learned they will be opening a location in my home town of LA and I can't wait to check that one out as well.

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Pork Ramen

mZR-VuVUICC1ZAOf6pRVzQ.text: I was really excited to try Momofuku because I'm such a fan of David Chang from Mind of a Chef and Ugly Delicious. The food did not disappoint. My shoyu pork ramen was really flavorful and you definitely get more meat than you normally would from other ramen shops. The noodles had a nice chew which is how I like my noodles.   Because of its location on the Strip, however, you definitely pay Strip prices. Did my $17 ramen taste 70% better than a $10 bowl of ramen? I don't know, but I did enjoy my food and the service was really good. You also get plenty of food. I was barely able to finish my ramen after the pork bun appetizer. The bo ssam bowl was also very tasty with delicious pickled red onions.   The server will ask if you want still or carbonated water. It only costs $1, so it's not a big deal. You need to ask explicitly for tap if you don't want to pay for water, lol.

iY9JsO6__Pp0lZoEm1H9XQ.text: It really pains me to write this because I was so blown away by this place on my first visit. So much so that I came back 3 days in a row on this most recent trip. None of them were as amazing as the first time. First of all, they do not have the slow roasted pork shoulder wraps anymore, and that was my favorite item. Don't confuse this with the Bo Saam Rice Bowl that is currently in the menu: I tried it and it was pretty ordinary. The picked vegetables didn't really complement well with the rice. I also came for dessert and we tried the salt and pepper lobster and shrimps and lots of desserts. The shrimps and lobsters were good but not worth the exorbitant price. And I would recommend skipping the desserts too, some were too sweet, some not enough. Would probably only come back for the pork belly buns in the future.

b_ZW3_gTDNaNTEXRQYlcEA.text: Momofuku is a fun restaurant - they play with unique flavors and ingredients, making it a memorable dining experience. It's a hip urban place that mixes the new and the old Asian (more distinctively Korean) palates.  I tried a couple dishes there with friends - I enjoyed them all, but everyone unanimously agreed that the pork belly bun was absolutely AMAZING. It was so good that we ordered another one after having a bite. The pork is grilled and charred to perfection, the cucumber adds a nice crunch, and the bun adds a pillowy soft bun bed to your bite. The waiter gave us this sweet and spicy sauce which paired very nicely with the buns.  I'm giving 4/5 just because it is a little too expensive... The Szechuan beef noodle dish was good, but I don't think it was worth $32! I'd much rather get more pork belly buns with that :)

9xGA08yuHuqe2_ELtUMgSg.text: Did the tasting menu after coming here and not being sure how to navigate the menu, and we were SO glad we did.   Big eye tuna with strawberries and shaved foil gras - never would've ordered and SO glad we did. The best thing we are. Don't be scared of the foie if you don't like it in its traditional way.  Miso sea bass - Fantastic.  Pork belly buns - Also, fantastic. Got to get these.  Hawaiian kanpachi - Fresh, great fish.   Creamed corn with truffle, and the shishito peppers were Le flame.    But, the only things we didn't like food-wise, we really didn't like: Chilled spicy buckwheat noodles Lamb - probably my least favorite. It was a little fatty and soft, but the vegetables served with it were perfectly done.   A little bummed about the dinner menu not having the ramen available, we and didn't like our drinks too much (Violet Femme was okay, the Garden Gnome tasted way too much like seltzer/tonic). Also, I'm a foodie. I pay a lot of money to eat well and DAYUMN, Momo be expensive.

i-jMX2xxZxOi9UM7c34UZg.text: First I'd like to say our service was amazing!! Shout out to Max, he was super funny and provided exceptional service! Now let's get to the good stuff... the whole fried chicken was SO delicious! Not only can you tell that the chicken was brined, but it was sous vide and then fried to a very crispy perfection with a sauce that will light up your life.  The miso sea bass was my next favorite.  The it was so flavorful and the whole dish was tasty throughout.  To be honest, if our service wasn't so great, I would have given this place 4-stars just because every dish wasn't a 5... like the shishito peppers were just eh and not all of them were thoroughly cooked.  The noodles were good, but I wouldn't say anything close to 5-stars.    Overall, I'd say please go try this place and ask for Max!

IVr21FBO-6Q_Qs8nq-mJHQ.text: Went here with a large group for dinner with reservations. We were seated right away and the wait staff was so friendly and courteous throughout.   I started off with the Pork Belly Buns. They are DIVINE. Honestly I've had them so many times across the country but this was by far the best one. The bun is a soft pillow with the perfect balance of chew and fluffiness, the pork is slightly crispy on the outside but just melts in your mouth as soon as you chew in. Every bite is an explosion of flavors in your mouth. Do yourself a favor and get these.   The Ginger Scallion Noodles are so delicious. They are a perfect portion size and really excite the palate. They are rich and chewy, perfectly spiced and so very aromatic. Absolutely loved these.   I also requested my server to see if she could ask the kitchen to whip me up a ramen for dinner. It's typically on their lunch menu and not served for dinner but I really wanted to try it. She made it happen. I'm usually a die hard Tonkotsu Ramen guy because I love the deep rich porky broth; but was excited to try this Pork Shoyu Ramen. OMG it was incredible. I have no idea how they managed to fit that much flavor into a single bowl. The broth was so smokey and porky and rich and light all at the same time. The noodles were firm and chewy with a fantastic mouth feel as I slurped them up. The pork belly and the shredded roast pork were both other-worldly, so perfectly tender and delicious. Together with a poached egg and some simple toppings, every bite was a symphony of flavors, textures and aromas that would put even the most elite operas to shame.   I absolutely loved every single thing about this meal. The food was amazing, the service was impeccable, the prices were reasonable, the portions were huge and the ambiance was just so warm and welcoming. I'd very strongly recommend this place to everyone and I can't wait to go back.  p.s. Some of my friends ordered a bunch of other large plates to share family style and they really loved every single thing they had ordered too.

RA1sjjsCj7hkHRXZya0vkQ.text: Momofuku is a 5-star experience from start to finish. To begin with, the staff is extremely professional, well-trained, and personable. While they are experts at what they do, the service refrains from feeling stuffy. The decor is gorgeous, exactly what you would expect from Vegas standards. The atmosphere is bustling and lively, with views of the open kitchen.   We came with a bachelorette party of 9 and the option was given to us for them to select our menu. All we had to do was let them know how much we wanted to spend per person and they would bring out a variety of dishes. We went with $50/pp which ended up being $90/pp once we added in drinks, tax, and tip. At that price point we were stuffed and even had leftovers, so I suppose we could have gone with a bit less.   Shishito Peppers: Blistered to perfection, these were a nice light bite that were able to make their way around the table a few times.   Pork Belly Bun: This might have been my favorite dish. The meat was beyond tender and bursting with juicy flavor and the bun was light and fluffy.  Brussels Sprouts and Cauliflower: You really can't go wrong with a brussels sprouts dish, especially when they are expertly prepared with katsu sauce, Japanese mayo and bonito.   Miso Sea Bass: Made with crab butter, mushroom and roasted vegetable broth this dish was light but packed a punch. It was another of my favorites.   Ginger Scallion Noodles: The noodles may have been ramen noodles, nice and light and curly with a flavorful sauce. I definitely recommend selecting a noodle dish because the Sichuan Beef Noodles were delicious as well.   Whole Fried Chicken: I didn't try this because I was already so full, but it was a favorite of the table. At $78 though, I wish they would have left it out in favor of more small dishes. I don't think any fried chicken can truly be worth $78.   Salt & Pepper Lobster & Shrimp: This was an add-on by one of the people in our group. The 3-4 person serving is $289 and comes with 6 lobster tails and 18 shrimp. I believe she got a smaller portion for around $150 with 2 lobster tails and less shrimp. The seafood is tempura battered then fried with garlic and chilies and finished with yuzu mayonnaise and soy glaze. There was a lot of filler in this dish. I thought the flavor was tasty but the seafood was a bit overcooked. And again, I think the price is steep.   As you can tell there is plenty to explore in the menu by way of meat, seafood and veggies all with an Asian flavor profile. Seeing as this is a David Chang restaurant, that is to be expected. I have to admit I didn't like Momofuku Noodle Bar in NY (tooooo salty) but Chang really hit it out of the park with this one. It's perfect for an extra special indulgent celebration.

5fiFEZktTeCuEGfq3HeCQQ.text: The pork belly bun and shrimp bun were good, juicy, and milky, but as expected from a Momofuku restaurant, they were hella expensive. Dock 1 star due to the price.

yIHCjSVOWa5jp377Kf-ILw.text: OK, I've been dreaming about coming here for years and I finally got the chance on my most recent trip!  What the pho cocktail drink: 5/5 Shoyu Pork shoulder Ramen: 4/5 Bo ssam Rice bowl: 5/5  The "What The Pho" cocktail is something I can say I have never ever tried before. It tastes exactly like pho broth! I don't know how they did it but I love it. It has a hint of sour and alcohol flavor but other than that, just like broth. I'm realizing the way I'm describing it might make it sound gross, but I promise, it's not. Try it. Worth it.  Pork shoulder Ramen: this is the dish I was most excited for but if I'm being honest, I was disappointed in the broth flavor and consistency. when it comes to Ramen or pho, I am a broth gal over noodles. Always have been. The flavor is very good but it was very watery and not as rich as I imagined. The noodles were cooked perfectly, and everything paired well. At the end of the day, it was a good bowl of Ramen but nothing mind blowing or fantastic, which I expected from such a prestigious restaurant like Momofuku. I would prefer the Ramen from my local Ramen shop back home.  Bo Ssam Rice bowl: THIS. Was good. Packed with flavor, the rice was crispy and fluffy, the meat paired it perfectly. It was a great dish with a lot of balance. It had the crunch of the veggies but the softness of the rice, and the chewy texture of the meats. The sauce brought everything together and I would definitely recommend this dish.

wxg-cTCETwuzJoh6ep6CBg.text: I'm a huge fan of David Chang so I was really looking forward to trying this place. We came for lunch on a Tuesday and the place was pretty empty. It's located inside the Cosmopolitan hotel on the 2nd floor. Staff was friendly and sat us quickly. Our waitress, Tasha was wonderful! She allowed us to have sample tasting of our sake before we order. I really do love the set up and decor. The restaurant has a huge wine wall. Place is hip and modern with a classy twist. The artwork painted on the wall by David Choe gives the place it's own retro charm.   Ugh....Really hard to give it a three star, but this is solely based on the dishes we had there. I was so unimpressed by the lunch menu! I was hoping to try a couple of dishes, but there wasn't many to choose from. It was disappointedly small and limited. We end up ordering sea bass for entree and Bo Ssam rice bowl. We were delightfully welcomed with a free cold appetizer of spicy cucumber. Food was mediocre. The sea bass was tasty, but the sauce it came with was not necessary. I felt the fish was already seasoned well and adding the sauce just add too much salt to the dish. It was definitely portion for one person so if you're hungry order a side of rice or salad with it. Whyyyy....the Bo Ssam rice bowl looked so good! I was really hoping this was the dish that would steal the show, but unfortunately it felt short compared to the sea bass. The rice bowl was just overwhelming! There was just too many flavors competing against each other. You have the pickled vegetables mix with the salty/sweet braised short rib, and the seasoned rice. Each items came on top of the seasoned rice and must be mixed together. I felt the dish was just too salty and sweet. There was just too much sauce in the rice that it was hard to eat the rice itself. The spicy cucumber was ok. It was sour and salty, but was topped in a peanut sauce and peanut crumbs. I would prefer just having the cucumber the traditional Korean way...pickle. They do have some pretty good sake. We ordered the house Akita sake and it was delicious. Sadly to say not any of the three dishes we tried made me want to come back. I am glad I tried it though, but I wouldn't revisit again whenever in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy cucumber

jzXETsp6eQOh-N9PYdtpCA.text: Ordered pork belly buns & shoyu pork ramen for dinner. Glad I found this place in Cosmopolitan Hotel. This place ROCKS!!!

Tk1h-Y5KTm5k8d8C4AnmRQ.text: After binging David Chang's Ugly Delicious (and bonus Christina Tosi/Milkbar from Chef's Table) on Netflix, I was very excited to have the chance to eat at one of these restaurants!   We came here for our 5 year anniversary (made the reservation online and just put a little note of the special occasion). They sat us next to the window, which we loved! We also got to have a complimentary toast of champagne or sparkling wine (I forgot what our server said lol) because of our anniversary, which I thought was a nice touch to the night.   We ordered the grilled Japanese squid and the heritage pork chop, as well as the pork belly buns to start. They know how to do pork! The pork chop was the best -- each piece was the right amount of fatty and full of flavor.  The squid was also good but I think I was so obsessed with the pork chop I didn't pay much attention to it lol.   My only issue with the food was that for the price, I would've wanted it the squid to come with a starch/side as well as the entrees. I know that's normal for a lot of places to have to order it separately, but just eating squid and mayo with no veggies wasn't cutting it for me.  In the end though, it was good food and a good experience, will definitely want to come back and try one of their large format dinners... I'm eyeing out that duck dish!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Buns duhhhh
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beautiful view! Would&#39;ve been better if it was at night!

bodmU9PxTcgtTnjCcl8aFA.text: It was an important occasion and we were pleased that our guests enjoyed themselves.  We ordered the Large Format Plate and several other dishes for the group.  Without a doubt, everyone at the table agreed that it was the best wagyu beef we had.  The dishes were impeccable. Full of robust flavor but simmered and balanced well.  Our side favorite was the Brussels and Cauliflower and the grilled corn.  Place is energetic and hard to hear.  Dress attire is casual from posh casual to street fashion.  It is hopping and lively at night.    Service can be spotty.  No fresh cutlery when switching to the small plates to the large format.  We had to ask for refill on non alcoholic beverages though they did ask for for refill on alcoholic beverages....I think they were only looking out for the drinkers. HMMM

Z_84fP2KERiYgx4j_iK0fg.text: This is a late post. However, the food and service were both amazing, so I feel like this review is better late than never. I dined I'm on a weekday and made a reservation for 1130am, hoping to beat the lunch rush. When I arrived I was seated immediately   I ordered the shishito peppers (a little spicy and way too much in my opinion) and pork buns (yum!!) for entrees I ordered a duck bowl dish - Their menu has changed since I visited and I don't see it any longer. It was too fatty for my preference, but that is how duck is, so I should consider not ordering any kind of duck dish in the future. It did have a ton of flavor though.

6FuhiOhMIbyjycd4yeOToA.text: This place is AWESOME!!! Food and service were really great!! Came for a mid-afternoon snack and ordered the pork ramen (melts in your mouth pork belly), spicy shishito peppers and watermelon beer.  Sat at the bar area and our server was very attentive. The chefs were really friendly too. They gave us a free beer cuz they couldn't figure out an issue with their beer tap at first. Also, one of the chefs gave us a free appetizer - baked fingerling potatoes with truffle cream, Parmesan cheese and chives - soooooo yummies!! Definitely recommend the pork ramen, spicy shishito peppers (really good with beer), potato appetizer, and local watermelon beer (limited batch - summer only). Great experience!! ^_^

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy shishito peppers - simple yet so good with beer!! Not skimpy on the peppers at all.....

BE9PAkzw_INDktyJnLgGUQ.text: Ate at the bar and it was a great experience. Bar staff is fun and helpful with pointing out local favorites. Sometimes I hate making up my mind as to what to try and my husband is the same way. We were both undecided with what we actually wanted. We provided our great bartenders our particular flavor likes/dislikes he made great choices for us. Food was great and drinks were as well. It is a popular place and easy to find on the Cosmopolitan.

dUJ_Jil1qrZKl1Yeab11uQ.text: Best thing here is pork belly bun.  The pork belly is the size of a 1.5 kit kat bars and at least 3 kit kats thick.    Also had the pork chops, shrimp bun, and chilled spicy noodles which were good if I only picked one I'd eat pork belly buns for the whole meal!

oneHSE6pbkXS7oc0YMzVjA.text: We didn't seek this place out but we were returning a rental car to the Cosmopolitan and had passed by it earlier in the day. Our friends really wanted to visit here because the New York versions had always been so crowded, and this one was empty on a Friday at 5:30-- too good to pass up. We learned this incarnation combines the menus from their other locations into one restaurant, if anything because they have the space to-- it's huge!  We mentioned we were in a bit of a time crunch to make an evening show and our waitress made sure our food came out as soon as it was ready-- in some cases the mains made it out before the appetizers.   We had pork ramen, kimchi stew, the ham small plate, shishito peppers and a slice of crack pie to share (which, even though it looked small for the 5 of us, was plenty). If I had to dig for a minor complaint it's that the ramen broth was so rich and with so much sodium I was quite thirsty for hours after our meal even while drinking several glasses of water with dinner.   We left full and in about an hour, which left us plenty of time for the rest of our evening. By the time we left the rest of the restaurant was starting to fill up.   Yes, it was expensive (for ramen), but this restaurant executed on all cylinders- service, food, etc were all top notch.

w7CZ5ZkchbPxkB_CB6LL_w.text: I'm not sure what people are raving about. There's more great ramen shops on Spring Mountain Rd. for cheaper. The broth was SUPER salty. And this is coming from a Viet girl who likes fish sauce. I had to down 3 glasses of water.  Service was impeccable. Drinks were tasty. Tried the mojito slushy and another drink with tequila and spice (forgot the name).

uTGdIyKhWOY96Z0QmW_Ovw.text: If you are like me, you probably heard of David Chang after watching him on "The Mind of A Chef" and his dorky quality was endearing and on some level you kind of related to his off the cuff nonchalant way he presented himself. Kind of disheveled, potentially high and lover of salty food. LOVE IT.   So you would not believe my surprise when I was staying at the Cosmopolitan Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas when I heard there was a Momofuku and Milk Bar... I practically hightailed it there the second I could.   We kept it simple and ordered the Scallion Ginger Noodles, the Benton Ham Mussels and the Pork Belly and Chicken Karaage bun.   In most to least liked: Bun(s), Mussels, and the Ginger Scallion Noodles. And here is why:   The buns were ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS. They serve it with the ssam sauce, the pork belly was cooked to perfection. Low and slow and then lightly crisped, served with some hoisin and cucumbers it's perfection in a bun. The chicken one was equally delicious and if I had to write about it, it would go like this- "Get the chicken Karaage you (insert expletive)!"   The Mussels are dry roasted meaning they are put on a hot griddle and cooked like that until they open. Then they are tossed with benton ham bits that seems to have been reduced with onions. It's equally salty, sweet and fully of flavor. I just wished they served it with some buns or bread so you could soak up the liquid at the bottom, but that's only a small slight.   Then the Ginger / Scallion noodles.... this I was the most disappointed in. I would have asked for salt from the staff, but my mother taught me never to say anything if I only had bad things to say. The flavor was ultra subtle and lacked some depth aside from the ginger/scallion oil tossed with the noodles. The shitake's and cucumbers that accompanied the dish were good, but didn't add much in my opinion.   Overall- I would come back. I liked the food I ordered and would come back to try the other things on the menu. Specifically the $60 bowl of truffle ramen.... the only reason I didn't order it was I didn't want to seem boujee in front of the person I was with...you know who you are.   Anyways, for sure check this place out if you have a chance, it's worth a stop anytime.

UupZ_sYndV7ywW4fypAmWg.text: Super excited to finally get a chance to try this place. We truly enjoyed our meal..we had shishito peppers,pork belly buns,salt and pepper lobster and truffle ramen. It was definitely a feast. I'd give this place a 5 but the hostess was kinda clueless about her job..like you should know if have you full occupancy for dinner or not...so I'd take one star off for service.i understand this is the newest hot spot restaurant at cosmo so you would think as a hostess you have an ideas where you can sit you guess or not..this is a pet peeve of mine when they hire punk ass kids in a trendy spot and they have no common sense.

sD6NDohVJyoBoc7Wt2mOsg.text: Beautiful restaurant and great staff. Great addition to Cosmo and Las Vegas. Eggs were delicious. Pork bun was solid. Truffle Ramen was very pleasing. New York was a nice cut. Rica one of the managers made some great recommendations. Will go back and often.

nyTWGkqMK_9xpzGcwOQVzQ.text: FYI: This place has Pork Ramen (off menu) for dinner available. I'm very surprised it's not on the menu. Despite that, the Ramen is very good an the pork is cooked perfectly. I would also recommend making reservations as weekends, this place is very very busy. There are also good views out towards the strip so try requesting window seating.

uZuj5BcSvBT2Ktm3cWUUjQ.text: PRO: our best experience in LV during our weekend. Saw Chef Dave Chang working behind the counter! Food comes out fast. Looks simple but taste amazing! Probably the most beautifulest hostess I have seen! The eye candy alone is worth the experience. Reasonably priced food items. Did I mention the food  taste amazing!  CON: not sure why the hostess pushes you to sit near bar as oppose to their dining area? Bar menu is limited in comparison to their dining menu.

UlE9xqO0GqZ1VaHBbR71cA.text: Best service EVERRRRR! And duh food was amazing! We sat at the bar with Arrion and Matt was our server. They made the experience awesome. We ordered pork ramen and a shitake mushroom banh mi (chef made it on the fly). Even though it wasn't your typical Vietnamese style banh mi (on a hamburger bun not French baguette) it was well done and surprisingly delicious! The shitake mushrooms were perfectly sauteed and banh mi was topped off with perfectly pickled daikon and carrots. Also, Arrion whipped up some delicious brussel sprouts as a surprise for us and also had us try the chef's hot sauce. Omg both were to die for. I highly recommend trying out this place even though it's not exactly like the one in New York.

nlKjNrXgWTZM2fmQwla3Hw.text: Great service from all staff including the hosts. Didn't try the ramen because I heard the chilled spicy noodles were not to be missed. They didn't disappoint. Definitely, recommend them as well as a sampling of the buns.   I got the pork and chicken karaage. The pork was incredible and my favorite but the chicken bun had flavors resembling a fancy hot-n-spicy chicken sandwich from McDonald's...which, in my opinion, was a great offering. Got dessert next door at milk bar and will write my review for there after I try these cookies I brought home.

5wz1u9iFfkTPYqbF868-QA.text: I didn't want to believe it when people said this place was overrated, but it really is. The price point is way too high for what you get. The fare is much more appropriate as fast food than in the lovely setting they have here.

hqBad4LXi2TwpLwM_b0xhg.text: I met a lovely, professional gentleman at the Cosmopolitan Las Vegas (who approached me and worked there and asked me how my visit was A+ to you sir), he suggested I try Momofuku for a nice little snack. Originally thought this was a sushi restaurant. I approached the hostesses and asked what kind of food it was and they responded with "do you want to see the menu" which, I definitely did, but would have been delighted if they gave me a few words on their style of dining. They sat me immediately at the bar, and the bartender was super engaging. He asked me what kind of food I was interested in getting and I said vegetarian. He provided me with options, and was very detailed in his descriptions. I had a mushroom bun, a bizarre but tasty spicy almond cucumber appetizer (that he suggested) and the chick pea ramen. All of which were wonderful. The bartender accidentally gave me a bun instead of the cucumber appetizer but was very quick to correct his mistake. Apologized, and comped it. I was impressed and plan to come back very soon !

cnx1EghPQ41u889fMnDOYg.text: Enjoyed my lunch so much I had to come back the next day for dinner. Loved the almond in the spicy cucumber dish. Ramen was good as was the pork belly Bao. Had the lobster and shrimp but batter was much too thick and black sauce was too sweet for my taste but everything else we tried tasted yummy.

Lf41h0ifvfiWoga8UprbUA.text: What happened here?  Momofuku came to Vegas and left behind everything that makes the NY versions great - ambiance, mystery, energy, and good food.  I came in with high expectations and was really disappointed.  Pricing, while in line for a strip restaurant, is too high.  We started at the bar, which was wet and dirty, with a bar staff that scowls at you.  This team feels like angry hipster bartenders straight out of central casting.  The cocktails were not well executed and quite frankly they were overly sweet.  Table service is jumbled and weird, putting a smooth dining experience out of reach.  Not a single manager could be seen on the floor.  If they had been there, they would have had a chance to check on the bathrooms which were filthy.  Water and paper was everywhere.  Maybe the person before me decided to use the bidet feature on the Japanese toilet to do their own version of the Bellagio fountain show - who knows.    Food was not up to par, and certainly not at the level delivered in NY.  Soft Boiled Eggs lacked any seasoning - it was just plain missed.  Pork Belly Buns lacked pork.  Kimchi Stew was good, but it was so spicy that I had to keep going back to the buns to cool off.  Ginger Scallion Noodles featured the mushiest noodles you've ever tried.  The only dish worth trying again was the Citrus Cured Fluke which was outstanding.  It was Monday night and the place empty, yet we were rushed through our meal.  The only saving grace of the meal was selections from Milk Bar next door.  The crack pie was it's usual good self, and the cake truffles were outstanding.  But after a $300 meal for three people we still left hungry.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

NEZdQR5-VD-ErgSaxw2yvw.text: If you're going for quality over quantity, this is the place! I walked away a little hungry, but my taste buds were very happy! Only reason I was honestly disappointed was because I thought this was a ramen house--it's really not! But the food is great! The apple kimchi salad was super delicious, and the noodle dish I did get was delectable. The ambiance of the restaurant was cool, we sat at the bar where you can watch them make some of the dishes. Which was fun until we saw a guy forget to use his gloves. Let's hope he washes regularly!

yXuIBRA-kVqX--jzno42MQ.text: Two words. Pork Ramen. Get it. It was perfect for my Las Vegas hangover. I'm not sure how they make that broth but its amazing. I also added the chili oil for some spice.

OlxIU1ErDYBy5YM_Ugp6qg.text: I was very excited to eat here for Easter lunch but little did I know how horrible the ramen soup was. Maybe it was an off day for them but my ramen bowl was very salty. Actually it was EXTREMELY salty. At first I thought it was just my bowl but my mom's bowl and bf bowl was also very salty. To be specific, the level of saltiness in each bowl was different. Mine wasn't the saltiest but my mom's bowl was so bad, she had already asked for four cups of water. Not to mention, we also asked for lemon wedges and room temp water to help lighten the soup... that didn't work either. Very disappointing meal because it was recommended by so many of my friends. On the bright side, the pork belly bun was good. Service was okay and thank you to our bust boy who came with filling our water cup consistently. I'd love to give this place another try but probably try something different.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bun is good!
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Extremely salty, taste broth before you take your first bite!

TGDa7K66JWZSEnZXRtLVpg.text: It's exciting to see Momofuku slowly making their way over from New York all the way to LA, with their pitstop here at the Cosmopolitan. This fancy Asian-fusion restaurant seems to be "known" for their ramen, but I would have to disagree and say that the real fortunes come in their main entrees which looked pretty damn good.  Given that it's a higher-end restaurant, a reservation on a busy Saturday evening is absolutely necessary. Our party of nine was able to get our own long table with a great view of the Strip. At night, it lights up the area where you don't need to have lights on inside the restaurant to give you a great dining atmosphere.  Our waiter was quick to serve us still or sparkling water- whatever your choice! We kicked things off with their oysters ($12 for half a dozen), which were a tasty treat. The freshness quality was certainly up there.  Being on a bit of a budget crunch, I ended up choosing their Chilled Spicy Noodles with Sichuan sausage ($14). At first glance, the portions seemed fairly small. However, once you mixed everything together, it became a spicy, delectable medley of flavors. Absolutely loved all the ingredients and kick the noodles had. No broth needed.  While my noodles were good, my friends meals didn't seem to live up to the hype. The Ginger Scallion Noodles were way too salty, which prompted them to comp the two bowls our table ordered. My other friend ordered a chicken dish that was fairly dry. So good and bad, there seemed to be some inconsistency in the kitchen offerings from that evening. Hopefully they can fix that for future customers.  Momofuku is definitely worth a try if you're feeling classy Asian. Give it a whirl before you head out to your late night adventures.

7TNqVdD-7XUbZM9U5Txurg.text: The food is 5 stars, hands down.  However, we ordered wayyyyy too much food and weren't told that was a crazy amount.  Additionally the wine selection from the Sommelier we completely disagreed with - we felt that one of the people we were with had more knowledge of the wine than he did.  Those 2 things slightly reduced the experience, but overall the service was fantastic otherwise, and the food as good as it is still gives it a 4-star.

gPXN0H9_VlWzWWPFoWjqmA.text: The food is overpriced and just average. We had the fried chicken that was just a little better than your everyday Korean fried chicken. We also had the lamb ribs which were good but not worth the price. Service was so so.

IpqL9tkgPqo57MzBLELUuw.text: We were seated immediately! The service was awesome & attentive. The food was equally magnificent and the staff so kind and made us feel welcomed.

bZXB34uW39XfGuH7zJDvTQ.text: Momofuku, wow. First off, Momofuku is a great name for a restaurant, roll off the tongue. Apparently, it means "lucky peach," no relation to actual peaches, it seems.  We went here for a team dinner, with plans to potentially go out for a night on the town alter. Unsure of what to order, we just told them to bring out enough food for the 9 (or 10) of us.  Honestly, everything was sooo delicious. We started off with some shishito peppers and pork belly buns, always good. The other large dishes that came out were the Bo Ssam, 5 Spice Rotisserie Duck, and the Salt & Pepper Lobster and Shrimp. So these dishes were all really good and we were too full to even finish it all, but for me, the Salt & Pepper Lobster and Shrimp really stood. Seems like a simple dish to make, but that fried Lobster was top notch. I would normally think that frying lobster would cheapen the flavor, but it definitely added to it. And there was plenty of lobster for everyone to have, which isn't an easy thing to do.  You visit Vegas, this is a place you MUST try. Definitely coming here the next time I'm here.

NdtgV5BNigPQb-yJyfGnxg.text: My family and I came here for lunch right after Christmas Day, hoping this very establishment from David Chang's restaurant empire would put a highlight on our winter road trip.   The decor was modern and minimalist. The host was friendly and led us to a table with a view of the Eiffel Tower duplicate. The menu design was clean. Our waiter was funny, knowledgeable, and attentive.   We ordered:  kampachi - fresh, but the sauce was salty Pork belly bun - alright  Shishito pepper with nutritional yeast - tasty and/because greasy  Kimchi fried rice - not enough kimchi, not enough rice  Veggie ramen - handmade noodle with fresh and flavorful veggies, again, tapa size  The food quality is likely higher than your average Vegas restaurant. The restaurant's target client group is clearly people who do not wish to be labeled "picky eater" or "non-adventurous eater"; even though they might well qualify either. this group looks for something "exotic" but not authentic. This restaurant approach, including elevated decor and the Asian fusion label, attracts and/or even educates people who are scared to step out of their food comfort zone.   However, if you grew up with immigrant parents, if you brought homemade lunch to school and got laughed at, if the entirety of your identity was evil-spiritedly equated to a dish, if you frequent hole-in-the-wall, mom-and-pop restaurants or food stands in LA's Koreatown or San Gabriel Valley, this is not the high light of your Vegas trip. This will disappoint.

WiwuKE0D3gq1B3WBYWkP8w.text: Worth the hype worth the hype worth the HYPE  Pork belly bun - $7 - juicy and fatty ugh - they threw in another one for us for free   Hamachi tuna - $24 - a really sharp and interesting flavor that only intensified as the fish melted in your mouth - it's not the fish's fault but it looks like raw chicken :')  Spicy rice cake - $15ish I can't remember  - this is my favorite dish. Crunchy on the outside, chewy on the inside, the rice cakes are like shorter dukbokki doused in Sichuan sauce.  - not that spicy  - you might wanna order something blander and carby to balance this out  Scallion noodle - $15 - honestly just okay. Skippable.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bun

ff1ss35zXmJsRnkQs5ZoWg.text: Came here for dinner the other night with my husband and our roommates. I've never been here myself and love that their name means lucky peach!   From the moment we checked in to the end of our meal the service was exceptional. It's hard to find great service at restaurants so I am so happy that we actually were able to get this kind of service.   The place is a good size with art decor on the wall. We sat near a window which gave us a nice view of the planet Hollywood. When we were sat we were greeted right away and our our server was nice enough to give us his opinion on our many questions.   We went with his suggestion of the half portion of the Bo Ssam since it was on the large portion side of the menu. We also got oysters, dry roasted mussels, a spicy cucumber appetizer, pork belly buns, unagi buns, truffle potatoes, Brussels sprouts and cauliflower, and pork ramen(which isn't on the dinner menu but we asked for it). Everything was really great and I love how our plates and utensils were changed with pretty much every dish we ate.   I highly recommend the pork belly buns! Also, we were celebrating our friends birthday so our server brought out a crack pie dessert for him, which was so good !   Overall, I would come here again to try other things on their menu. Their service is great and their food that I tried was really great!

UIte2YMFdOE-g0ch5NVY5Q.text: Excited to try we had big eye tuna with strawberries and shaved truffles very unusual combo truffle shavings reminded me of pharm cheese it was different not sure if I liked it but My gf loved it.  The pork belly buns were delicious could have used more pickles for crunch but buns soft and tender one of my favs,  the Japanese squid with mayo and fish eggs was smoked and tender but I wouldn't order again, the long beans were the best with sweet and sour taste and I'd like to make those at home.  The service was spot on and our server even  brought us a Cesar we didn't order cuz we wanted a salad I like the radicchio and croutons. Being Vegas it is pricey but I'm glad I tried!

jwaY9UBPY3qyi_Zv1US06w.text: This was the highlight of my quick trip to Vegas!  I wanted to celebrate my husband's belated birthday so we did a quick lunch here. The lunch menu is also a great way to try their food at affordable prices.   My hubby and i ordered the pork ramen and chickpea ramen as well as the shrimp bun and pork bun. For a drink, i has the Yuzu lemonade.  The yuzu lemonade was $9 bucks, a little pricey, but really refreshing. It has more hints of sourness from The yuzu but i found it to be a nice complement to the lemonade.  The buns came out next and i just want to say, those little buns are made of clouds and are as soft as Charmin! The pork bun was just divine with its crispy pork belly! The shrimp bun, which really had a shrimp patty on it turned out to be very flavorful as well.   But to me, the highlight of the meal was the pork ramen. The way they get their pork belly so crispy is amazing and perfectly complements the texture and flavor of the ramen. The soft boiled egg, the noodles, the broth..just all so good! My mouth is watering from it! My husband had the chickpea ramen and really liked it as well. I tried one of his chickpeas and it was super crispy and freshly made! You could tell!  The ambiance during lunch is chill. The staff are super nice and helpful. We made our reservation for 11:30am and by the time it was noon, most of the tables were filled.   I cant stress how important it is to make a pit stop here while in Vegas! I cant wait to go again and try more!

iJow1Rz02sOMYbQl_0gH4Q.text: Compared to their NYC location, I found the LV spot to edge out ahead by a small margin   The broth felt less greasy and more depth in flavor. Noodles were similar and the pork, as usual, was a standout   Had a chance to try the potatoes, 100% home run and worth getting again and again   Service was friendly and accommodating   Overall Thoughts  While NYC didn't win me over, the LV location certainly changed my point of view

C_rDF8LxB-nJZx5hwcRBrg.text: Overall good service and food! I got the shrimp bun, spicy noodles and I tried the ramen. Shrimp bun was pretty good but I don't know if I would order it again for $7. The crispy fried shrimp patty was probably the best thing I tried though.  The spicy cold noodles were surprising. I wouldn't get this if you're looking for something actually spicy but the Thai basil pesto sauce was very good and paired well with the slightly sour peppers.   My friend got the pork ramen and I tried some of it. Glad I didn't get it because it was very average but the pork belly itself was decent.  Overall slightly overpriced for the quality of food but a decent meal nonetheless.

V3_ARedRA_4lx38g7SrdzQ.text: Visited for lunch with 5 other first-timers. We chose Momofuku because it is in our hotel (Cosmopolitan) & Japanese food sounded good. Well, Momofuku is not strictly a Japanese restaurant, it draws from Japanese, Chinese, Thai, Korean (& other) cuisines. Also, initially, I didn't know what kind of restaurant It was because the decor is neutral & modern, with lots of wood & metal, not "Asian". Our food was very good, though generally pretty spicy. I had the Chilled Spicy Noodles - Sichuan sausage, Thai basil, candied cashews, jalapenos & red cayenne peppers on top of a pesto pasta - highly recommended by another Yelper, and it was terrific!   The dish didn't taste chilled ... more warm/room temperature, and that was fine. Even though I removed all the peppers, the dish was delicious and hella spicy, though not excessively or painfully so. Very delicious, though be forewarned, when they say "Spicy" they ain't kiddin' ! ;)  I'd read that the Confetti Cake was good, so I ordered it, realized my sister's birthday was the next day, asked our server Chris was if he'd put a candle in the cake, and he brought it out along with candle, dessert plates & forks! We were all happy with Chris' attentiveness & efficiency!  Others in our group ordered the Pork Ramen, which they are famous for and which about half their customers seemed to order while we were there, Bo Saam Rice Bowl, a Pork Belly Bun, and a Shrimp Bun. Everyone loved the food!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

IPK-yXBVsYQLhrtsHJqecA.text: I was a little apprehensive getting the pork shoyu ramen but honestly not sure why the other reviewers had complained. I got a steaming hot bowl of delicious savory ramen with generous thick chunks of pork belly and slices of pork shoulder. The pork belly was not fatty which impressed me since oftentimes restaurants just give you pure lard which I hate. The noodles were chewy and so filling. It was a generous portion and I don't know why the other reviewers had said it was too little food. I could not finish my noodles and not for lack of trying. I  had the pork belly buns as well. Also very yummy. Love it! The bartender was also amazing!

SeBtsppZWqeQBjiP0DCHeg.text: Momofuku is a nice gateway restaurant to those who never had authentic Korean food or maybe cannot stand authentic flavor.    My party ordered shoyu pork ramen, Bo Ssam bowl, Denver steak, and a pork belly bun.    As a Korean who grew up with Korean food, food was interesting but I can see why a lot of Korean people especially elderlies will be disappointed.  David Chang is very popular in Korean community and even in Korea due to media exposure, which is why you'll see many Korean tourist from Korea in the store.    The flavor for ramen, bossam, and pork belly bun had interesting flavor coming from American/Western cuisine perspective.  I get hint of authentic Korean dish and flavor that David Chang was going for.  And it is for definitely more for those coming from American/Western cuisine who are not ready for authentic Korean flavor/ want their familiarity with hint of something bit exotic than from Asian who wants fusion of western.  David Chang, born and raised in the States who caters toward the US crowd definitely hit his target demographic.    I do have my preference of ramen, my preference of bossam and pork belly.  It was interesting to taste a different interpretation of Korean food and ramen, but I suppose it's not really for me.  And it is not for me.  I'm not the target demography.  Neither are tourists from Korea (especially elderly) who insist on having daily Korean meals included in their tour in foreign countries.  I'm glad David Chang is making ways to showcase to demography who may not otherwise have chance to come across Korean food.    Maybe recommendation would be to bring little bit of Korea to the States.   Many people who's been to Korea have said that they love the ding dong man (little buzzer at the table in every Korean restaurant) and would love to bring it back to their country.  Maybe David Chang can implement that to the restaurant to show little piece of Korean convenience.

YgcYtgHm4XtaQ66WtWKzng.text: They recently just readded the black truffle ramen back on their menu and it's absolutely delicious. If you're a truffle lover, this is a must! I added chicken, bok choy, and mushrooms to my bowl of ramen and that one bowl came out to $50+.. not sure how I feel about a small bowl of ramen coming out to $50, but definitely had to give it a try.  The shrimp buns were amazing!! I'd come back just for those tbh.

abkXI6xF7e8vBsZUN3wwIA.text: Yes! Yes! Yes!  To be honest, I was super nervous for suggesting this restaurant for dinner with my extended family. Knowing my family and my mom, they are super picky and hard to please.  Luckily, momofuku did not let me down! We were a party of 7 adults and 1 kid and we ordered the following "large format dining" items from their menu.  Salt and Pepper Lobster an Shrimp: super yummy! Lightly fried and crunchy! Nice as an appetizer for the table Five spice duck: pretty traditional flavors for Asian duck! The duck fat drizzled on to the rice is perfect!  Bo Saam: huge huge portions of meat and super tender! This item was totally worth it  All dishes were amazing and worth it. Loved the experience and can't wait for my next excuse to dine here.

oeUDtqIexDVLirHTsfiy8Q.text: What a great experience!! Yager, Ruston, and Kevin really made our experience exceptional with great service and suggestions. Tasty food! Everything that came out was my favorite.... till the next dish came out... lol and fun atmosphere, can't wait to come back!  Try a Peruvian Sour!!

v4nTgqmkkyOYVhWYttXC9A.text: Truffle burrata - didn't know this was a salad, but it was quite delicious.  Burrata is rich in its own, so I have to say having it in a salad helped cut the full fatness of it down a bit.   Shoyan pork ramen - this set the bar WAY up high for future ramen. I already knew it would be amazing before I had the first bite. Just the aroma of the broth - makes my mouth water.  And they actually sear up the pork belly, so that it has a nice crispy texture.  So amazing.     This just made it onto my "have to eat every time I'm in Vegas" list.

5udfGzgx6PhKK_2WjrCICw.text: I have David Chang's bio/cookbook also titled Momofuku and always wanted to go to one in NYC.  I was excited to see one open up in the Cosmo in LV recently.  The restaurant is huge and is well staffed.  Pop music playing in the background and nice manga-style art adorning the walls.  We came here for lunch and frankly, the results were mixed.  My wife's pork ramen was incredibly oily and the pork belly had gobs of fat.  The noodles were chewy, and they did use a slow-poached egg, just like in the Momofuku book.  The oiliness was a major turnoff (2 stars).  The dishes I ordered were much better:  Cucumber Salad - I loved how each cucumber chunk had a thin layer of avocado, and was topped with nuts for crunch and seasoned with spicy pepper. (4 stars)  Pork Belly Bao with home-made Ssam sauce was excellent, and was decent sized. Pork belly here looked better than in my wife's ramen (4 stars)  Fried Chicken - This was half a chicken with four pieces.  Very good seasoning on the crispy skin, and most of the chicken meat was juicy.  It reminds me a bit of that golden crispy chicken that's popular in Chinese banquets, only the Momofuku version had a slight spicy kick which I liked. (4 stars)  Probably not our favorite place for noodle craving in Las Vegas (Shang Artisan Noodles and Bellagio Noodles seem better).  Still, good non-ramen dishes and very friendly and attentive service.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Ramen - broth was extremely oily and pork belly parts very fatty.  Decent chewy noodles. (2 stars)

is-MPGD7U9_8yaP5mM9YFw.text: Disappointed. After watching the Netflix special about Momofuku, this did not measure up to the hype. The broth was oily and salty and the noodles was thin and I swear undercooked/stuck to each other. This was also $$$ for noodles. $18/bowl of ramen. If you want ramen that tastes amazing and half the cost, definitely take a Lyft to Monta Ramen on spring mountain. Only reason this review is getting a three star is the service was good for 1am and the peppers were really good.
