Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Order up!
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Boring ramen, I&#39;d pass on this.

s04V7Mn63notPST4UsIsXA.text: I tried the pork belly ramen. It was pretty good but just had a single piece of pork belly, just one bite which was pretty disappointing. The broth flavor was pretty good though. It was pretty pricey -- $17.

EGFNAG8lPcUSHeVIuql2qw.text: Absolutely try Momofuku while in Las Vegas! Yes, several dishes are substantially overpriced, but the quality of the meat and flavor of the dishes makes it worth a stop. The pork belly bao is a must - the pork melts in your mouth. I also recommend the ground shrimp bao, it has great flavor. The spicy cucumber starter is lovely, not too large, and the kimchi tastes great. My favorite noodle is the spicy noodles - the pork sausage was very flavorful, the spinach pesto tasted great, and the spice level is perfect! I know in the past people have complained about the dish being too spicy, so Momofuku lowered the heat a few notches to cater to more guests pallets. If you have the time, I recommend popping out and ordering from Milk as well. Unless you know what you want while still in the restaurant, its worth sampling the soft serve flavors and checking out all the baked good options in person! So yummy and a classic!

CZ3Y_kM--279fJu1nbzwVQ.text: Momofuku hit all the money during a team dinner this week when we needed a fun (but not insanely expensive place) post conference. What can I say- other than worth the hype! The service was actually the best part of the meal, our server was super friendly and knowledgeable, and the other staff member gave us some incredible dessert recs. We ordered family style with the karaage bao (must try), the fried crab bao, ramen, and a bunch of other things. My least favorite main was the ramen- pretty meh in my book. And favorite was the scallop poke- small portion but mind blowingly good. Dessert we tried all the things but the crack cake and cereal milk ice cream were on point. Seven spice slushie was ok- but was jealous of my friends elderflower selection :) One star off for some strangely high priced dishes and disproportionate portions.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cereal milk with sprinkles

O084EP86rH2qtndEYcE-JA.text: A friend/ colleague and I ventured from our review course over here for dinner, and we were not disappointed. I ordered the shiitake buns and scallion noodles, which were comfort food after our rigorous review course. The service was prompt and friendly despite being seated at the bar. The atmosphere was inviting as the vibe of the restaurant was topped off by the music choices. I enjoyed sports of personal karaoke when old Kanye came on, even. My friend orders the Crack Pie as Momofuku is associated with the adjacent Milk ice creamery and dessert bar. She enjoyed the dessert while I continued to pretend to be vegan. This was my second visit. I can't wait to come back when I return to my non-vegan ways...

wVrxeAM_b4l7-uEc_DCvOg.text: So much more than Rarmen, Would definitely go back.  Stayed at the Cosmo and decided that we (8 people) would try Momofuku. We got sat very quickly. Server came over and began to tell us about specials, and took drink orders. He promptly came back with drinks and reinforcements. He had a great personality that made the whole experience that much better. We got two of the family style specials, see picture.   Everything was absolutely fantastic from the get go. Had the Shishito Peppers & Pork meatballs to start. For the main course we shared the Bo Ssam and the Korean Braised Short Ribs.   To our waiter Manny - YOU ROCK! Thanks guys for an amazing meal!

F2B8Z4l8Q766kZH76la60w.text: Hype, hype, hype.  It all adds up to expectations not being met.  David Chang is one of my personal food heroes and having an opportunity to eat at Momofuku while in Las Vegas was one I wasn't going to miss.  The place is handsome, glitzy and very Asian in that there are lots of Asians around, eating, serving, bartending, cooking.  The bar has a very casual vibe and the drinks have Asian touches.  Nice.  The kitchen is open and in view from the bar and restaurant area.  The menu is expansive.  There are are small plates, medium plates, and monster plates made for sharing.  Our group was large enough to try a number of plates of all sizes.   We asked for recommendations from our server and added a few things of our own.  It all added up to waaay too much food!  And because the large format items come at the end, we were faced with a huge amount of additional food when we were already full!  I think our server should have been more cautionary with us in our ordering because at the end it was not very enjoyable.  Shrimp buns: Fried shrimp cake on steamed buns with Asian accoutrements.  Tasty but the steamed buns were not the softest.  Ginger scallion noodles: This is a David Chang staple and I have to admit it was disappointing.  The noodles were soft and the the ginger scallion sauce was lost in an overdose of the sweet pickled shiitakes.  Shisito peppers: Can't go wrong with these and they were appropriately delicious.  Rotisserie chicken and fried bones: This is a roast chicken with crispy skin, served with chicken parts that are fried until crispy.  Dry and dry.  Not good.  Bo Ssam: Another of chef's famous dishes, it's a large format, whole or 1/2 pork shoulder, braised and roasted until fork tender, and served with raw oysters, sauces, and lettuce leaves for wrapping.  We ordered the 1/2 shoulder and it was still an intimidating amount of food.  Delicious!  5 spice roasted duck:  This AWESOME version of roast duck is also served as a large format, and can easily feed 8+ people.  The legs and thighs are removed and the bone-in breast is spit roasted until the skin is golden brown and beautifully crispy.  Meanwhile a confit is made from the legs and thighs which is then shredded and brought to the table and served over a large serving bowl of rice.  The whole roasted duck breast is then brought to the table, taken off the bone and carved table side; the perfectly cooked breast slices are then placed atop the confit/rice.  Wow, so delicious!  Oh, and then the duck carcass is taken back to the kitchen, chopped up and fried until crisp, and then brought back out to the table for some additional snacking.   Soooo good.  Like a lot of Las Vegas outposts, Momofuku does not meet the hype however if you come for the duck you will not be disappointed!

GSRIoenDaN1qDJk7e_PWPw.text: Momofuku is located on the second floor of The Cosmopolitan Hotel on The Strip. I made an 8:30 pm reservation for dinner on a Saturday. Our table was ready by 8:35 pm. I was very impressed with the venue. The restaurant was much bigger than I expected and I was seated in a quieter back room with a beautiful view of the 'Eiffel Tower' and Paris Tower. I found the service to be excellent. There was a server specifically assigned to remove dishes and fill water glasses. I don't think I ever had a water glass that was less than half full. The only issue was when bringing out our main dishes a server accidentally placed them on a neighboring table. Realizing the mistake he immediately took the dishes back to the kitchen and put in a rushed reorder. So it took a little longer than average to get the food. However, the servers explained and genuinely apologized for their mistake. They also comped us their crispy potatoes and market greens small plates without us having to ask!! Overall, environment was excellent, service was outstanding, and food was great. Five stars earned without contest.   Food Reviews:  Small plates:  'Market Greens': this item was complimentary due to the situation described above. It included cauliflower and Brussels sprouts roasted in an Asian-inspired marinade, topped with apples. It was great for being a plate of vegetables, but it didn't stand apart as unique. I wouldn't order this myself.   'Crispy Potatoes': this item was also complimentary. It included 'bite-sized' potatoes, ham, and seasoning, topped upon delivery by server with a unique Momofuku cheese sauce. This dish was heavy, but extremely good. If you're super hungry, I'd recommend getting this appetizer. I would order this small plate again.   'Sichuan Lamb Ribs': this was actually my first time eating both Ribs and Lamb so I don't have much to compare this dish to. But the ribs were melt in your mouth quality and very well marinated. Excellent dish, but very fatty. This is also a very filling plate. I personally wouldn't describe it as a small plate. Would be filling as an entree.   'Black Truffle Ramen': I ordered this dish first and foremost to try truffles. Again, it was my first time eating truffles so I don't have much to compare to. But this dish was excellent. The Ramen broth heavily over-shined the noodles. Truffles and egg yolk gave the ramen a powerful and satisfying flavor. If you like truffles, you'll like this dish.   'Crispy Unagi': I saved this for last as it was actually my favorite dish. The Momofuku 'buns' lived up to their hype. They taste like bread, but have a marshmallow-like consistency. Also, the bacon mayo was awesome. My only regret here was that I didn't order a second bun. They are pretty small.   If I ever return to Momofuku, I would order a bit different. I ate a lot of heavy foods which made me uncomfortably full. I would most likely order more of their vegetable starters opposed to meat-based and then order two buns and split a Ramen.

5NTCbd6UCdMrarNanrQnew.text: We did end up going back this past Saturday. My wife was a little apprehensive due to the last experience. She would've given this place a 3 star. We had guests in town and this time our 11 year old son, who loves Ramen, was coming with us too.   The experience this time was great for my wife! We didn't get the Brussel sprouts and we tried the Shrimp Bao this time and my wife found a new fav. We had the chicken Katsu with Shitake gravy, that was beyond incredible! That gravy can go with anything!   My son and I had the pork Ramen, that was very delicious! Our guests had the ChickPea Ramen which was incredibly flavorful.   For desert, I had the crack pie, which is signature and always delicious, IMO.  Wife had the cornflake marshmallow cookie. Her favorite.  My son had a cereal milk with chocolate chips and hot fudge. He killed it. I managed to sneak a taste and it was very good. Its as people have said...you know the milk left over from the cereal you just ate...? Well they made it into an ice cream flavor... So good..!  I like this place a lot and do look forward to returning with guests that come into town.  I'm glad that my  wife had a better culinary experience so that means she too will return.    Whomever reads this, I hope that you have a good time there and great experience.

svvBDr8PZWiGId6CTLM7tw.text: As a native in Las Vegas, I don't go to the strip. It's hot, it's crowded and people forget how to drive. That said, I heard that Milkbar was here in Las Vegas and they have Cereal Milk, so I had to make a pilgrimage to it.   When something lives up to the Hype, you are forced to acknowledge the awesomeness of that thing.   Momofuku is legit. It's a real spot, something that, while expensive, is a necessary spot to visit and pay homage. Get there while you can, get some of the cereal milk. If I could buy a gallon, I would.

oXnziZHG7rPWrBbpjQY2QA.text: I had a really great time here tonite. First of all i loved the music they had there. Great playlist. Kudos to the person who picked it. I got to drink basically a asian gatoraide. It was like grapefruit flavored water. Really good. Where can u go wrong with asian gatoraide? You cannot! Then for dinner i got the pork bun.  I love how they put the cute little flags on top like the bun is they moon and they a declaring that momofuku has been there by putting their flag on top. Very cute. Another great idea. I gotta say that whoever made the prok bun was a hell of a good chef. The pork bun was perfect.

Nnj58sBLUMKOUZ848xU9hA.text: My overall review for Momofuku was just okay. I really wanted to like this place and have a great time but I was disappointed. I sat at the bar and in front of the service bar. Bartenders seemed weeded and unorganized. Drink garnishes were nice and organized at the service bar but the two containers which had the herbs inside had a lot of fruit fly's. No apologies or care was given to that... I ordered the kanpachi which was okay... fish seemed a bit lost with the herbs and smelled a bit fishy. I then proceeded to order the pork ramen and was again disappointed. Bitter flavor to the broth and just lacked flavor and fat. I opted to pass on dessert. I'll probably give this place one more try but I was certainly disappointed

mSet6zjhnWDbh_EZKNM6xg.text: Let's just say the potent flavors of everything from the chicken katsu with shiitake gravy to the chickpea ramen with hozon made me question everything. But, unfortunately, so did the prices.

BomDyYlw-R6upFHLAvgeJQ.text: Tried this the first time today during lunchtime. No waiting time so thats a plus. The service was amazing. Our server was so attentive and so fast in giving out the dishes. We tried several dishes that was recommended by the people on Yelp.   1. Kimchi Rice Bowl I think you can pass on this. It doesnt have any special taste to it so yeah just so so. But the portion is quite big.   2. Pork Ramen Kinda expecting something more than just that. Ive tasted something better than this. But its still better than the Kimchi Rice Bowl  3. Shiitake Bun This. Is. So. Good! Would definitely be back for some snacking time only for this!   4. Shiishite (?) Peppers I might be wrong about the name but it is listed on the appetizer side. Suprisingly this doesnt taste spicy at all! It is in a decent size and perfect for appetizer.   5. Mussels This. Is. So. Good. Too! Im not a seafood lover but Im lovingggg this! It has a perfect blend of caramelized garlic and bacon. It is sauteed together perfectly even you can lick the seasoning off of the shells. Portion is really good for the money too.   Over all I will be back just for the Buns and Mussels only!

Dy2ST-RjjubCoGdwYNwfRg.text: Right out of the gate this restaurant will impress you to no end. Our server Bronson was so knowledgeable about all the dishes and recommendations. He guided us and explained everything and made sure that we did not want for anything. We had different types of Ramen and salads. The pork buns were outragoeous and the thinly cut ham reminded me of the ham from Barcelona ( Jamon de Iberico Bellota ). The duck that they prepared tableside was the star of the show. Everybody in the dining room was watching the show. All of the different components cooked differently but came together in a symphony of taste and texture has me ready to go back next week for some more ( and it can feed an army! ) I cannot forget the chicken Katsu smothered in love and mushrooms. They also took the carcass of the duck, chopped it up, fried it, and brought it back to us !The final notes of the meal was the lamb and the truffle Ramen! We finished off with some crack pie and ice cream. They were nice enough to have wheelbarrows to take us to our cars. To Ryan and Neil, thank you so much for your generosity and care. We are amped to work with you and send our clients your way for sure!

NTP08LPvoPMd3sEA3L9V_A.text: I now understand the hype. I have been following David Chang for a while, so I was super excited when a Momofuku opened in Las Vegas. It is on the pricier side, but I promise, you are getting your money's worth.  My party and I ordered quite a few dishes to share. I got to try Spicy Cucumbers, a Pork Belly Bun, the Hamachi, Chilled Spicy Noodles, Brussel Sprouts and Cauliflower, and the Salt & Pepper Lobster and Shrimp.  The most underwhelming thing we ordered were the Spicy Cucumbers, they were good, but at the same time pretty standard compared to everything else. The Hamachi, however, was absolutely unbelievable. Even the Uni (sea urchin) that came with it was unlike any other seafood I have tried. I have lived in Japan, so I can be a snob when it comes to raw seafood, but both of those are high on my list when it comes to the best I have ever tried. The Salt & Pepper Lobster and Shrimp was an incredible dish and decently portioned, perfect for a small group to share, you really are getting that much food.  I am looking forward to the next special occasion I have so I have an excuse to come back. The service, the food, and the overall ambiance does not compare to so many other restaurants. This was truly one of the best meals of my life.

mICPFrMxrLOKsxa6x84wjQ.text: Awesome vibe. 90s music playing and a great view of the strip!   Bao $7 per bun Ramen $18 per bowl  The ramen is great, but I think you're paying for the ambience and the David Chang name   Although I'd definitely come here again!

ZQWB2j0n7JQ8hEVUiFZzNg.text: Review is just for the ramen, which is terrible! The broth tastes like soysuace with water and is super salty. Not to mention it's very pricey as well. Avoid the ramen here.

lnjla7UHBk4jDB9IMLyMlg.text: I was Sooo excited to eat here but it did not live up to my expectations. This has been on my must eat list every time I visit NY but I never get around to eating it when I go. So I was excited to see there was one in Vegas.   I thought the food was decently good but overpriced. It wasn't bad food but nothing to write home about. The hot tea is $25. Yes, $25 for a cup of green tea! That's insane. It doesn't even come with refils.  We ordered: Soft boiled Eggs with salmon roe- I didn't like these just because it tastes really fishy to me. No one at the table really liked these.  Pork belly bun-these were really good. The best buns out of the 3 we ordered  Chicken karaage bun-this was decent. Didn't have a lot of flavor but how can you not like a piece of fried chicken on a soft bun?  Shrimp bun-this was the least favorite bun. It didn't have much texture or flavor.  Pork belly ramen-this was good but again, nothing special. I've had much better ramen at other places.   Momofuku oysters- these were good. They had a nice smokey flavor and I really liked the crunchy topping  Chicken katsu with gravy-this was my favorite. I can't describe the flavor but it was really good   Spicy rice cakes- this was so spicy I could only have a few bites. No one at the table liked this but I liked it. I would have ate more but I couldn't handle the heat  Brussel sprouts- these are just too deep fried. They were so black and tasted burnt  Overall I'm glad I tried it but I don't see the need to go back. Nothing outstanding.

qChWKAjqJbsICZh1APanqA.text: We came in for a quick bite and a drink. The server was jovial as we opted for the much lauded pork belly buns and pork ramen, pork on pork, if you will.   The real star of the pork belly buns is the balance between the beautifully rendered pork belly and the Persian cucumber pickles that were well matched with the house hot sauce.   The ramen featured a perfectly cooked noodle- not too soft and just chewy enough. The broth was an amazing balance between salty and rich.   100% would return.

U3otUVw65k_KS9d1DUhKqw.text: Wow, amazing! Best place I've eaten at in Vegas thus far! Also, the bathroom is a fun experience (once you go you'll know what I mean )

4vO-x3ZBr8pzpnsl86goLA.text: Awesome time here. The servers were very friendly and even let us order ramen which they do not have on the late night menu. thanks!  pork buns. end of story.

4TM9sOpOzgkD_BRXDvqWdw.text: Upon visiting the shops and restaurants at the Cosmopolitan, one stumbles upon Momofuku by David Chang.  The ambiance is inviting and you can smell the food from right outside.  They're open pretty late on the weekends, which is really helpful when you're craving a late night snack.  Ordered the soft boiled eggs for appetizers, which were so delicious!  They were filled with salmon, which made them both unique but tasty.  Also had the chicken noodle soup, which hit the spot on a cold Vegas day.  Overall, I would recommend Momofuku if you're looking for a tasty noodle spot whilst wandering the many avenues in Vegas

Ba3YAFasB2ujUYEdgjZnEA.text: Didnt go for the hype. Went because we happened to be at the hotel and were gonna go to the buffet there (wicked spoon--took a look at food before paying and decided against it. Similiar items to Wynn buffet but didnt look as good).  So we changed plans and went here instead.  If youre looking for something more interesting rather than copious and wanna get away from the excess of LV, this place is perfect. Its good, its inventive, its sane and its refreshingly thoughtful in its decor (minimal compared to the rest of vegas).  Loved it. Perfect for first meal after doing a buffet.  Ramen wouldnt be my favorite and i like ramen.  My favorite was the burrata salad.

3B7eC03ZVzc9spnhdVS0zQ.text: Worst ramen I ever had. Broth lacks flavour and the meat was cooked terribly. Would not recommend the late night menu if you are in Vegas. Many other spots right next door that are way better.

6w2QJ-xMoIORk1taLpidXQ.text: I have been wanting to try this place in NEW YORK buuuuuuuuuuuuuut luckily they now have it in Las Vegas! Yay they got everything in vegas. So I came here during the summer and try their ramen noodles. I thought the ramen was good, a little salty but good! The service at this place is really good. Also this is located at the COSMO which is nice location. After some ramen you can walk right next door and have some dessert at milk. Great leathal combination!

wf5Fr1YLoSc5BYjqmFDzJg.text: I really don't like the ramen and noodles there.....but the pork bun and shrimp bun tasted good. However the ramens are disastrous :(

tXZ6gUqsTZ8iRq5OUQy-YQ.text: Don't pass this up! Simple menu high quality  Start w pork Bun Erick the bartender is creative and very professional

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

K8_xBXEX3cqG_7BVP64-pw.text: I wanted to eat hot noodles, there were only 2 types of noodles on the menu~ Only the cold Sichuan Spicy noodle and something else, neither of which are ramen. My Sichuan Spicy Noodle was nothing to write home about, which costs $17 when I think I can get something similar at home for $7 in the bay area. I accept this is Vegas and $10-15 would have been reasonable.  What got me was the "hidden" ramen that is not on the menu. Apparently it's one of the most popular items, why not list it on the menu? why didn't the hostess mention it? Why make it so secretive, why have me walk on the way from Luxor to Cosmopolitan back to Luxor only to find out there's a "hidden" ramen option.  I feel deceived. And for that I gave it 3 stars.

o95En2n6OOkblrkRS74UrQ.text: 1) "What do you want to drink?" That was the first thing the waiter said to our table. I wanted to respond with, "oh hello, my name is --, I'll be your customer today..." But since I know they recently opened, I didn't want to say anything up front.  2) It took about 10 min, no joke, to get waters and ice teas. We also thought we'd make it easy and have 1 person order for the table...that still seemed to be too overwhelming for our server. I work in the industry too, and I know it can get pretty hectic, but communication is key.  3) Had to ask for a refill on ice tea 3 times before we actually got it.  4) One of the bussers reset our table with plates, a butter knife, and chopsticks after ordering ice cream and cake truffles for dessert....but WHY??   5) Had to ask for the check twice.  It was a really awkward experience for all of us. There was always a different Busser at our table trying to clear it, but was actually quite disruptive when they're there every 2 minutes. It would be a great spot to go if they would just get it together. This place is a bit pricey, so it was aggravating to pay for the bill and still tip over 20% (due to karma) for a really bad experience. Sucks cuz I really wanted to like this place.   Overall: The service was absolutely HORRIBLE! The food was not my favorite, but everyone else in my party loved it.

mVx9jgjJiVQZdJdmc5o95g.text: Momofuku is a nice change-up in atmosphere, service, and tasty ramen from the typical ramen joints you'll find in China Town. It is definitely more pricey, but I think I got my money's worth at lunch today.  I suggested this place to my colleague who was looking to have a power lunch before a meeting. It was her first time here, and I talked it up from my Momofuku experience in Washington DC. We were not disappointed! The 2 hostesses greeted us warmly and sat us right away. On a Thursday at 12pm, the place wasn't busy.  The lunch menu seems limited, mostly the options rest with the small plates and appetizers. We ordered the pork bun, mushroom bun, pork ramen and ginger noodles. The buns were springy and mouth watering, the noodles were cooked to perfection and not clumpy. I found the food to be very delicious and flavorful, the taste was rich without being cloying or overpowering.  I was impressed with the superb service. I saw other yelpers didn't get the same quality service which makes me sad, because everyone we witnessed at lunch today was on point. Chris and Jueen were our servers (they changed shifts in the middle of our meal) and they took great care of us. They did try to upsell cocktail drinks, but were discreet and never pushy which I appreciate. The bussers and food runners were attentive and gracious, our water glasses were never empty. What I like the best: everyone was keeping busy, staying attentive or being more engaging with the guests, even though the place wasn't busy. Nothing worse than seeing staff being lazy or ignoring people when business is slow. Thank you to everyone for the outstanding service!  Would I go out of my way to visit Momofuku? Probably not, but it is a nice option if you're already at the Cosmopolitan or want to experience a more upscale noodle experience for lunch.

ygEoWePuD6WBhtx-R-Q8dQ.text: Amazing service and food. If you seat at the bar, there is a good chance that you will get some samples for free.

nz58EOmHz4eJIe8sFXjeLA.text: WORST SERVICE EVER!!!!  Yes yes, we all know it just opened and there are always kinks and training that need to be worked out but SHAME ON DAVID CHANG for NOT being at the restaurant opening week and working the f*cking line and making sure everything is perfect.   Starting with the horrible hostesses that are more interested in chatting with each other than helping patiently waiting clients in line to the head chef walking around the restaurant chitchatting away, it was really a horrible experience.   I work in the industry and have been to every DC restaurant from NYC to friggin Australia and this was by far the lamest and worst of his restaurant.   There were 3 hostesses on duty and clearly they were hired for the length of their skirts vs making clients feel welcome and comfortable during the time of waiting for tables to clear. The worst part was that we waited over 30 minutes and there were a multitude of tables open in the restaurant.   The ineptness and lack of communication between the wait staff and kitchen was so embarrassing and such a train wreck that you could clearly see the breakdown. There were so many hapless employees just standing around doing nothing while every single table in my vicinity had NO food on their tables.   The "managers" and underlings were so basic in their attempts to appease customers that you would think this was an opening of a local deli down the street from your house.  All they did was make lame ass excuses for the delays instead of being honest and telling people that there were problems. You know what helps when those situation arise!?! You comp our drinks and food...you apologize and grovel at the customers. You don't lie and say the same damn thing over and over again.   The head chef (bearded and tattooed...and so affected) was barely in the kitchen. All the chefs I know are sweating balls during service. This guy was so casual and just chilling by the bathrooms and walking around like he didn't have anything to do.  If there is a breakdown of food and/or service, it starts with the head chef. They control the tempo and put the damn beat to the music. Without that, you have already failed.   Okay...for the food. Clearly they are catering to the customers that haven't been to another DC restaurant. It's not the best of the best by any means, but it's the stuff that they can do with their eyes closed.    Buns were good as expected. Ramen was whatever and broth was lacking density and porky saltiness. The clams lisboa and Bo Ssam were great. Pickle dish was good but any K-town place as better banchan. The spicy noodles and cold sesame noodles were stoner dormitory dishes that didn't add much.  The duck and Bo Ssam are not difficult dishes but take a lot of time and care. In NY, you have to order way in advance to get. They said the same thing for LV, but no one is ordering bc we ordered extra and they already had them in the kitchen. Btw...they made a point to tell us how long the cooking time was, but it's already a cooked dish and all the sides are prepped. We asking knowing this, why did it take 2+ hours to get to a damn table. What a joke!  Again with the service...not sure if they just expect every person to walk into the Las Vegas restaurant as hapless and ignorant, but the usual question for any multi chain restaurant is asking if you have dined with us before. It sets the pace, makes everyone feel special and also let's the server aware that yes, in fact you are familiar with the food and vibe.  That didn't happen..what happened is that everyone employee made you feel like you won a lottery ticket to gain entry and they were smug as sh*t about it.   The ONLY and most important thing in today's restaurant world are repeat customers. That's the only thing that will sustain the business. Yes, Las Vegas is 99% tourist and one off customers but word will get out that the service and food are mediocre.   It's 2017 and dozens of restaurants close down every day in every city. Don't ever get comfortable and let down the customers that are loyal, have gone to sister restaurants and intended to come back. David Chang seems not to care about that anymore and seems to have gone to the dark side of being a sell out and just another chef that just makes appearances on Top Chef.    This isn't a fancy restaurant. It's not meant to be a 3 hour service with 45 min waits between courses. They won't make any money if they don't turn tables and they won't have repeat customers if everyone gets scared to come in because they don't have enough time to eat.    I love the food but the service was so horribly disturbing that I wish I could give it ZERO stars.   Still blows my mind that he wasn't there overseeing everything and how bad the service was...Breaks my foodie heart.

nWq6YW3AFFIMlUTtvES2Iw.text: Arrived 15 minutes before their dinner started, so we decided to get drinks next door while we waited. Were told that we were not allowed to enter with our drinks once we returned and dinner was avaliable. We contemplated going somewhere else, while we tried to hurry our expensive drinks down. After a bit of frustration I decided to ask if we could at least place our order and at that time they reluctantly let us in with the drinks.   Highly frustrated and in a rush to make our show we agreed to dine there. Service was good after that, food was ok, but not worth the price. I've had much better ramen in Sacramento for half the price.

xA5DP70reANBUWr0TEEslg.text: Got the salt and pepper shrimp and lobster for 2 people. It was just okay.  Not worth the price and it was a little too salty. The shishito peppers were super good, tho.  The service was great.

PjQOT_qYH0vpekTIV0AO6g.text: Ashkhen was the most wonderful and AMAZING person who graciously invited us into the restaurant. It was because of her, our experience at Momofuku was elevated to the next level. This was our 'day before the wedding' dinner and she made it extra special. It had to be because it was the last night and the last dinner before my fiance and I became husband and wife.  She sat our large party down in the private dining room with a nice table set up overlooking the strip. It was definitely beautiful and amazing to see the Vegas lights while eating dinner. I won't talk about the food because the food of course was simply amazing as it should be (just read the other reviews). This is solely for the experience.   After dinner, she kept on reassuring us that if there was anything we needed, even beyond the restaurant, even for future visits, she would gladly help us out. That is what sealed the deal for us. Extending her service and graciousness for future and repeat visits was definitely a humble gesture we appreciated. We will definitely be back!   Forgot to mention that we are also big David Chang fans and love his style.

GtEnNG39Z57oTMkas7lAqw.text: Came here with a friend of mine that was familiar with the Momofuku in New York. He had raved about the pork ramen and the pork buns, so my expectations were pretty high.   We sat at the bar and had great service from both the waiter, and one of the chefs that spoke to us all about their menu. We had the:  Pork Buns - these were really delicious, and I could have order more and filled myself up just on those.  Oysters on the half shell - They were good, maybe not the best, but definitely fresh. Would probably go with something else next time.  Pork Ramen - Don't let them fool you, as they don't put it on the dinner menu, but you can order it any time. This was an incredible ramen, and likely the best I've ever had. My only pet peeve is that they don't put it on the menu because they try to push people to the higher priced dishes.  Definitely give it a try, it's well worth your time and $$.

rnyrVwYOSxUQuvjYBuybcQ.text: I just had the most amazing foodgasm experience of my life!!! I'm currently here for my bachelorette weekend and we came to Momofuku. From the beginning of the meal right until the end, we had the best curated meal of my life. Starting with the cucumbers, sashimi peppers, oysters, shrimp, and king crab legs. Caviar to top everything off and finishing with a five spice fried duck!!! It was the most amazing culinary experience to date.

fGM59_H81tTZsRGBGIiL8w.text: Amazing service and very good food. We came with a group of 6 people and everyone enjoyed what was ordered. A bit on the pricy side but typical for a good restaurant on the strip.  Everyone loved the chicken, recommend doing a family style order so you can try different types of items.

PcLaHu6HQ0TinblQd2fncg.text: First of all, we have so many ramen places here in Vegas (thankfully) but this place is has the best ramen in town. I've been to momofoku 3 times, I appreciate the consistency and the service. I always get the pork belly ramen, and I normally hate getting the same dish over and over, but that's how good it is! The broth alone is so rich and flavorful, and the pork is cooked to perfection. They have great bartenders and I recommend their penicillin! I love sitting at the bar and watching the chefs make the magic happen. Great service and solid food. I just wish the prices would be more reasonable. Be ready to spend when you go!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Best pork belly ramen ever!

-9GX2Z_V4ecTrbjMPhKvqQ.text: My overall dining experience here was just wonderful. The staff were very friendly and helpful. Our waiter was very attentive, Basically my glass was never empty. We were seated at the bar where our chef Nick was preparing food. Nick was such a joy to chat with and he even gave us complimentary ginger garlic string beans. The dish was very flavorful!  We ordered the cold chili noodles and the shoyu ramen. Both were really good and flavorful, the ramen broth was okay, a bit salty. For dessert, we had the crack pie with the soft serve. Awesome! Definitely recommend trying it. It's so good and addicting. Definitely coming back to try the other items on the menu!

qyfoQ83EFmAtxnz0myM6BA.text: Excellent food. We started with the spicy cucumbers which were really addictive!   The kona kampachi was next, and was good,but left something to be desired. The fish was fresh and delicious, however 1)The temperature it was served at was a bit on the warm side and 2)the ponzu was missing something.  I got the black cod as my Entree, served with delicious veggies. I highly recommend that dish ..the cod is not overdone and totally melts in your mouth.   Ramen is available upon request during dinner although it's not listed on the menu .

G_K9jj00yZjtln2KxS0XMg.text: I had to try out Momofuku while I was in Las Vegas and check out my main man, David Chiang's local edition of his iconic restaurant brand after watching his excellent TV series Ugly Delicious.  So, AFTER having eaten a steak for a business dinner, I had a few drinks at the Cosmo to digest and pace myself before walking into Momofuku to eat a second dinner.  (I never do this, I'm not normally a glutton).   So from the moment of walking up to the restaurant unannounced to the moment I left, service was impeccable, friendly and attentive.  They have trained their staff well!  I proceeded to sit and the bar and ordered a pork belly bun ($14 for 2) and then a pork belly ramen ($17).  Normally that's too much pork belly for one day but I know those are two well known dishes so had to do it.  In both cases, the pork belly serving sizes were pretty big and generous which was good.  I enjoyed David Chiang's take on the pork belly bun.  It was pretty good.  I also enjoyed the ramen.  The noodle serving size again was good, broth was good, the soft boiled egg was cooked to oozy perfection and the pork belly was nicely seared.  By the time I was done, I was ready to exploded but it was worth the visit.  Again, my server was excellent and I enjoyed my time at Momofuku.  David Chiang, represent!

RPnwOeX0j_l9OXyw-0-SkA.text: The best! Simply the best! This place is 5+ stars.  The food was so delicious that I easily consider the restaurant one of the best we have ever been! Besides the food big thank you for the EXCELLENT EXCEPTIONAL SERVICE. We appreciate what you have done very much!   Definitely recommend it!

S9Pzpd0R7SD_l2AUlcxcPQ.text: I had a fantastic experience at Momofuku. I solo dined here my last night before flying home. It's always a difficult task for me to order when I dine alone because I want to try multiple dishes from the menu. The waiter was attentive and a huge help when I asked him multiple questions. I was also concerned in finding a small vegetable side dish that wasn't too greasy. He recommended the Spicy Cucumbers and offered that the kitchen could add less chili oil. It was the perfect addition to the delectable Bigeye Tuna that I ordered. I saw so many other tasty dishes at tables nearby while I was eating. I can't wait to make the trip back out here again.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bigeye Tuna &amp; Spicy Cucumbers

63Q7HR1Y4KLuNundFmdHVw.text: This has easily been one of the best meals of my life!   This is Vegas so I won't bother talking about decor and atmosphere- of course, it's up to snuff to all other trendy restaurants on the strip.  But I just wanna dive right into the FOOD! It portrays itself as an American/Asian fusion restaurant, but they seemed pretty Asian to me... raw bar, baos, noodles, ramen... my chopsticks were ready!!   One of our servers was Cooper- he was super friendly and gave us spot on recommendations.   We started off with surf n turf baos- one Pork, one shrimp.  The Pork Belly bun had hoisin sauce, scallions, and cucumber. The bun was perfectly steamed and the flavors were balanced nicely- a little sweet, tangy, crunchy, fatty... I didn't think it needed anything else but our server handed us the signature Ssam Sauce and suggested we add that to our buns. And it was so good! The full flavor came through, even over the hoisin sauce as I delightfully detected a boozy kick to it. Turns out it's an umami-rich Korean chili paste with miso, sake, soy sauce, and rice vinegar.   The shrimp bao was like a perfect morsel from the sea. It was more like a shrimp patty with spicy mayo, pickled red onion, and iceberg.   Now... this came as a surprise to me... but the Truffle & Burrata salad was life changing! There were thick juicy slices of lightly salted heirloom tomato, fresh, crunchy greens in a lemony dressing, and big chunks of sourdough that were perfect for lathering on the creamy burrata at the bottom. I could not get enough of it!!   The Spicy Shrimp & Avocado were served over rice. The shrimp were pretty big and meaty with a nice chili garlic spice. (I transferred my avocado to my salad.)  Last, but not least, we had the Chilled Spicy Noodles- I was a little apprehensive about cold noodles at first, since cold food doesn't sound as appetizing to me... but these were so refreshingly creamy, spicy, crunchy, and delicious! They were a beautiful shade of green and spiced with pickled chilies, thai basil, and candied cashews. I think my eyes rolled back with each bite.   Dominic came by our table to make sure we were doing well and chatted with us a bit about the restaurant's roots and history... (that mysterious bullet hole!)   This was, needless to say, but I'm gonna say it anyway... an AMAZING dining experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

nci4xWWiv0hqcLwFceE6Ag.text: Everything we tried here was great.  Definitely at the top of our meals in Vegas.    You've never had brussel sprouts and cauliflower that tasted this good.  Must try it to believe it!    Also enjoyed the pork belly buns, lamb ribs, and beef noodles.

--qvqpp_sQssdHJ6PqeImQ.text: We went to Momofuku on a friend's recommendation and had quite the enjoyable experience. The restaurant has good views of the strip and a lively atmosphere. The wait staff was friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable. We began with the Bigeye Tuna with shaved foie gras and strawberry, which was a unique and wonderful treat. The pork belly buns were scrumptious. We also had the grilled scallion noodles and miso sea bass. Altogether, a nice variety of food that was enough for two.

Ool2Y60O-S9GPhIf1aSx8Q.text: I've been wanting to try the Momofuku in NYC...so when we discovered one in Vegas, we just had to try it. Momofuku is located inside the Cosmopolitan casino, which is filled with other trendy restaurants. I would recommend making a reservation.  The menu is filled with many items, with the most enticing being the family style selections, which serve 3-4 or 4-6. Being that we were only a party of 2, we opted for a large plate and a few small plates to share. Needless to say, the portions were still generous!  Pork Belly Buns - This is pretty much standard at trendy Asian restaurants these days, but these pork buns were really good. The pork belly was very tender and melted in my mouth.  Spicy Cucumbers - Such a simple dish with pickled cucumbers, but the spices and toasted almonds complemented it so well.   Chilled Spicy Noodles - I typically don't like cold noodles, but these were so good! The chiles brought the kick, the thai basil added that unique flavor, and the candied cashews brought everything together.  Whole Jidori Chicken - This was literally a whole chicken. The chicken was so juicy and flavorful. We asked for extra limes which made it even better. The side of kimchi was a nice touch as well.   Alright, we ordered a little too much food for 2 people and had tons of leftovers...but the delicious variety was well worth the night of overeating. Everything here is done with so much care - from the quality of food, to the outstanding service, to the ambiance.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Whole jidori chicken
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy cucumbers
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bun

kBgrE4J35QqDhF8eNVZP4w.text: My husband and I had the good fortune of eating at Momofuku AND getting Mags as our server! Just like most people who visit Vegas we were hoping for a delicious meal and an experience that made us feel like VIPs. After weeding through an overwhelming amount of restaurants and reviews on Yelp we selected Momofuku and are so glad we did!   We devoured the Salt and Pepper Lobster and Shrimp, along with the oysters, and spicy cucumbers. The food was divine (some of the best lobster I've ever had!). The timing of our food and drinks was on point, not a single beat of the experience was missed. This was all tied together by the real star of the show, our server MAGS! He was genuine, attentive, and helped us choose the perfect beverage pairings. It's not every day you leave a restaurant feeling like you joined a new family and are inviting your server to Christmas dinner (the offer still stands Mags) but that is exactly the experience we had.   We are still smiling when we recount our experience at Momofuku and will definitely be back. If you are looking for outstanding and unique food, a wonderful atmosphere, and incredible service Momofuku is the place!

5rKVbMOdRyFFLSpnuYxRUA.text: Two words: lamb ribs. Oh. My. God. These were the best lamb ribs I have ever had in my life - super juicy and tender and literally fell right off the bone. Paired with a creamy cucumber yogurt sauce, this was hands down my favorite part of my dining experience here at Momofuku. However, I can't neglect to mention the two apps that were also mouth watering delicious - the pork belly buns and their cheesy chive bread roll that came with a sriracha/coffee/mayo aioli. Everything came out perfectly cooked and you could really taste the quality of the ingredients coming through. Our waitress was super friendly and made some recommendations for our table of 9 on some of her favorite drinks and made sure that all of our food came out at approximately the same time (note that the lamb does take a little longer, but it's so worth it). I can't wait until I can come visit Momofuku again - the lamb ribs will live in my dreams until then.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Lamb ribs

hl1LIJeoxwv4iQ9_en6S4w.text: MOMOFUKU is where I celebrated my birthday lunch.   Located at the Cosmopolitan Hotel on the 2nd floor.  Go early as they tend to fill up quickly.  If you order anything at all...order the pork belly buns!  The buns are housemade, they were so soft and pillowy. Inside was a slice of crispy yet succulent, fall apart pork belly that was accompanied with thinly crispy cucumber slices and a delicious signature sauce.  One word...AMAZING!    We also ordered their pork ramen.  Yummy chewy noodles and a tasty broth.  The pork was fall apart and flavored nicely.  But strangely was not served hot, it was more on the warm side?  We ordered the crispy potatoes which were also delicious, perfectly soft and fluffy inside while maintaining a crispy exterior.    Lastly, because it was my birthday, I had to order a slice of the signature Momofuku Birthday cake.  It's a huge slice so get ready to share.    Ok so the only reason why I knocked off a stars was because when reservations were made, my husband mentioned it was my birthday.  When we arrived to check in, they asked who's birthday it was and I cheerfully told them it was me. We sat down and the waiter acknowledged my birthday and I told him I was excited to choose Momofuku as my birthday choice, especially for the famous Birthday cake.    Finally after our meal, I was excited to get the slice of birthday cake.  We were a little confused why they handed us a menu for dessert but went with it and chose a slice of birthday cake.    The birthday cake came to our table with a candle!  I was so excited!  What I was NOT excited about and was shocked to discover, was the slice of birthday cake on our bill for $14!!!  We paid it and didn't question of course.  But my question is, why go through all that trouble to acknowledge a birthday yet charge for the birthday dessert?!!    Even at the most finest of restaurants to the moderate restaurants are birthday desserts usually given for free.  So beware of this assumption when dining here on your birthday.  Not going to lie that left a bad taste and disappointment as we left the restaurant.  And unfortunately that is what I will remember most about Momofuku.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork ramen
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crispy potatoes
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Delicious pork baos

tRuFNj5cKHc4Qlaf6xoOtw.text: I don't even know where to start with this review. Momofuku is absolutely amazing. We had a few small plates and a shareable dish. A lot of their menu items for main dishes are family style and priced fo 3-4 people so we didn't get to experience those as it was just Gary and I. We enjoyed the raw cucumber with spicy mayo, burrata, cold spicy noodles, and the lamb rack with a yogurt drizzle. Everything had so much flavor and only got better with each bite.  I'm not a lamb eater but I really was amazed by this dish. The meat just fell off the bone and the sauce gave it such a unique flavor. It melted in your mouth. The chilled noodles were definitely spicy! But the flavor was so complex and continued to get more amazing with each bite I couldn't stop eating them. Gary definitely took to the truffle and burrata. I love burrata so it was good, but it had a lot of lettuce which I didn't expect.   We definitely will be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

BuRrgVljQ9BSwcMK4Y-7Bg.text: Concept of how they make and present the food is definitely unique!  Have you heard of fried chicken with caviar combined as complimenting? I haven't until I watched a YouTube video on it from this place!    Momofuku is a renowned chain and is known for their different takes making it into extraordinarily complimenting in a complex way!    Generous proportions so come with an empty stomach.   Shishito peppers went well as an appetizer.  Pickled cucumbers were a must in the hot heat of Vegas and refreshing!  Salad with the burrata sufficed for the veggies that was needed to support the meaty dish on the large entree ordered.  Their roasted duck was a nice savory dish.  They could have lightened up on the salt, but it was doable.  It can feed a good 5-7 people on serving size.  I looked over the next table and they ordered up the beef entree that looked like a grand feast and it looked like thanksgiving!   Great meal for sharing!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Roasted duck
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Presentation

TP9ZVbbA2CkGGfpPuVQwHw.text: I am nerd for David Chang like most of us here! Went to try the Ramen during dinner and the only one available was $50 black truffle ramen. Ehhh...  so glad we read Yelp reviews and asked if other ramens were available!  They gave us two choices, either a vegetarian or pork ramen. FYI more choices are available in their late night menu at 11pm.  We got the pork one and then also ordered the pork belly bun. The bun order comes with 2 and it was DELICIOUS. Ramen was really good, lots of pork. They have you 2 big chunks of pork belly and a heaping of what looks like pork brisket. I wish there was some veggies. I mean it was a lot of meat, almost too much for me. I ended up giving my husband more of it. Noodles were really good. Broth was okay and overall we give it 7.5/10.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bun order
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork ramen!

_MD6hkBDuaZUPYNDQ-u2Gw.text: We came here because we read they had won many awards, plus they had some vegan options.   I was let down by the food. The dishes seemed simple and they were not flavorful. They had some spice, but not much else. We got two appetizers and a noodle dish. The picked cucumbers were not even picked they just had a vinegary sauce on top. The pepper app was a mound of peppers with too much salt and nutritional yeast on top. The noodles had some greens, sparse veggies, and a bland sauce. For the price and all the praise I expected more.  The host staff was very friendly. In fact she made sure to not sit us in front of the kitchen to avoid seeing meat cooked ... which we didn't really care about but it was a nice thoughtful gesture. The waiter was nice at first but then kind of ignored us. There is another Momofuku in NYC which may be better. I would not consider this Japanese food, but a weird American take on Asian cuisine.

fIUq9zgCyXWj8IqnINcv9A.text: Solid 4.5 stars to Dave Chang's outpost in Vegas. Have wanted to try one of his restaurants ever since I saw ugly delicious and i totally missed out when I went to LA and didn't go to majordomo.  We started off with the truffle and burrata (which is a salad technically, though I don't think it would win any healthy food awards). Haven't had such good cheese in a while. And the sourdough croutons were amazing!   Next were the pork buns which were amazing. Juicy pork with a sprinkling of their spicy sauce was delicious!   Also had the ginger scallion noodles which were balanced but ursting with flavors.   Service was impeccable, we also got 2 cocktails, Toki Thyme and Herb-A-Peel, both of which were excellent as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork buns
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ginger Scallion Noodles

9PPZgIw4h9Rmll48AgPYaw.text: I was all really excited to try this place as I'm a fan of David Chang. We made the reservations months in advance and we're glad we did because it was packed when we went.   Before we were seated I asked the bartender if he could make a cocktail with caffeine. He made me a cold brew martini which is one of the best I've ever had. He also very conversational and made some suggestions for dinner.   We went seated within 5 minutes of arriving.the service was great.   We ordered the Salt & Pepper Lobster & Shrimp with a hefty price tag of $238. It says it served between 3-4 people but it big enough to serve 5 people. The presentation was great but the tempura coating was extremely salty. We ended up removing the tempura coating otherwise we would not have been able to eat it.  We also got the Hozon Rice Cakes. These were my favorite. My friends thought it had a weird gummy texture but we all enjoyed it. It was something different but a good different.   Will definitely return to try something else next time.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Salt &amp; Pepper Lobster &amp; Shrimp

uqEaQAzt7QBPiKAYZkVkLQ.text: "Simplicity is the Ultimate Sophistication" ~Leonardo da Vinci  Dear Chef Chang:  I am so confused.  Did you invent the pork belly? No. Did you invent the Bao? No. Yet you have built an empire on taking the simplest of ingredients, creating and banging out honest to goodness amazing food! What the Momofuku is next? A Fried Chicken dish with Caviar or something?  Oh wait?!... Cherished and loved is the food you've rendered for us to consume viciously but with sophistication. Thank you!   Ever Faithfully yours, Jon H.  Momofuku, pronounced MoMoFuku, is a definite must go-to place when in Vegas. Don't walk, Run! But do it in grand style with panache like our friends Joyce W. and Michael W. They were so accommodating in joining us last minute as my meeting got cancelled. Thank you both!  The night was young as the sun was still out. We knew drink-wise, driving was out of the question especially since we didn't have cars. So we all Uber'ed in to Momofuku and rolled out gracefully a few hours later.  Here's the skinny on the Pork Fat we devoured:  ~Pork Belly Bao; A Bao bun so fluffy and soft as a pillow, tucked with the best Pork Belly this side of the Milky Way Galaxy. It's truly outta this World! Comes with Cucumber, Hoisin, and Scallion and I added extra sauce which sent ripples thru my mouth! A MUST have. (Please see photo) My theory of the cute little flag with a peach placed on each Belly Bao, is Chef Chang's explanation that Momofuku means "Lucky Peach". Just a guess.  ~Bo Ssam; Tender? What's beyond tender? The most succulent slow roasted pork shoulder you can imagine, then take that thought to the power of 10! So beautiful, it glistened. No kidding! Also, It came with a symphony of Kimchi, Lettuce, Oysters!, Rice and 3 extraordinary sauces. It was pure poetry in motion.   ~Chilled Spicy Noodles; Insane marriage of great Sausage, candied cashews, and Thai basil topped with jalapeno peppers for a good kick in the pants! The noodles were perfectly cooked adding to the delightful texture of the dish (Please See Photo)  Man/Woman that was delicious! Next time I'm ordering one just for myself. (Only child syndrome)   We plowed it all down with wonderful alcohol and had such a beautiful dinner experience. The service was ever-present without being obtrusive. Difficult to accomplish but enjoyable and admirable when achieved.  From the moment we entered until our sad departure, Momofuku was a culinary dream. Can't wait to go back!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Our checkin!
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Inside view!
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Oyster&#39;s with the Pork shoulder order

Cxbz8T3TvDPfAltKNwMW_A.text: I've been a fan of David Chang ever since I lived in NYC, so when I found out we were going to Las Vegas, I immediately knew this was my chance to try his Las Vegas restaurant - a wonderful lavish experience that was memorable!   We ordered two small plates (pear and burrata, brussel sprouts and cauliflower) and one family style meal - the five spice duck that comes with ginger scallion pancakes, kimchi, lettuce and a variety of sauces.   Pear and Burrata - the creaminess of the burrata with the sweet crunch of the pears - beautiful pairing and a nice way to start off the meal  Brussel Sprouts and Cauliflower - this was delicious - probably my favorite brussel sprouts dish by far - there was a tanginess that paired so well with the crisp texture of the fried brussel sprouts and cauliflower with an all-encompassing savory note in the sauce that made this addictive to eat. (We ordered two plates because we devoured the first one so quickly)   THe main star - the five spice duck - as a Korean American, the presentation and dish was new with the tableside carving of a protein that's more common in Chinese cooking, the duck, yet simultaneously reminiscent of growing up in a Korean household with the kimchi and the ceramic pot with rice inside. THe duck had the crisp exterior, rich umami taste, and tender with a slight chew. Paired with the ginger scallion pancakes and the hoisin sauce - great allusion to a peking duck preparation. But I also liked how we could almost go like a Korean ssam style with the lettuce, rice, kimchi, and duck - a more refreshing and bright take on the duck. I liked how we could pick and choose the experience we wanted -it's a really interactive dish that forces you to combine different toppings and sauces.   As with most things on the strip in Las Vegas, it's not a cheap meal, but I think it's worth going to if you're going to completely indulge in the Las Vegas nightlife.

qS_zx33igyJ-6zxs-oi7hA.text: Coming from a Vegas regular amazing food! Had Brussels sprouts/wagyu trip tip/pork belly and shrimp buns/ pear & burrata/ chilled spicy noodles... literally all of these had no complaints. Out of all Vegas restaurants this is the place to go hands down!

0IFM6qORwCPiDGGo4NAfAg.text: Had the Pork Belly Bun with whole slice of tender pork belly. Very tasty but only second to a pork belly bun I had from an old lady from a street stall in Taiwan last year. Two young ladies next to our table gave us their review of their entrees and told us the pork belly ramen they had was not on the menu but it was Momofuku's original signature dish and it was very good. I ordered it on their recommendation but the broth was a bit too salty for me. The heart of palm and avocado dish was disappointing with very thin slices of each with "mayonnaise" in the middle of the dish. Now, two days later writing this review, I don't remember what my other two entrees were. Personally, food was "so so" but the service was very good. I will give it another chance later in the year while I am in New York

F9cJMV3GjvzyGJrC7Jzstg.text: Momofuku in NYC is one of my favorite restaurants. Sadly this place doesn't compare in any way. Average service (forgot items more than once). But the most disappointing was the food, ramen broth lacked salt and was bland nothing like what you would get in NYC.

TE9VCx7YKQ0LhY3tLVo5Kg.text: Am I the only one that was extremely disappointed with this place? Maybe it's because I've been dreaming about this place ever since I heard about the New York location. But I went into this restaurant craving ramen, and I left EXTREMELY disappointed.  I'll leave this short since I do not want to talk too badly about this place. High prices(which  are yes expected since its Vegas and it's so well known) but the flavor was SERIOUSLY lacking. Let's just say I ALWAYS finish my ramen bowls. Yes I know that makes me sound like a plump. But when I tried this bowl of ramen, I left with over half the bowl still there. Smh.

5Fex7cAPFiGdGgK32kmGtQ.text: I'm a huge fan of David Chang, but this place is a scam. I gotta admit that the pork buns were transplenent--everything was good for that matter, but c'mon...the prices!  And I'm not cheap either. I really had to take issue with the roasted corn. Fourteen bucks. It was about a cup of corn, roasted...with a tasty cream sauce. It was like, "think of the most ridiculous price you can imagine. Now double it."  I felt like a real sucka.  I still love David Chang. In fact, I admire him even more now. What an empire he has built for himself!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Get the pork buns.

CHIaGxe34jf3FlxDCMS4PA.text: Phenomenal food and fantastic service! Presentation of the dishes was brilliant! What a fun evening.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

4adp9huKBsmNcPOHc8RcZA.text: We went for my birthday dinner. Our waiter Cooper gave us complimentary sparkling rose to start for my birthday. The big eye tuna appetizer was incredible. The foie gras and strawberry make for an interesting flavor combo. The wagyu short rib stew was also amazing - great flavor combo. Good wine list, too. Expensive but worth it for a special occasion!

LcOrwPPHglIJVoy8No_GZQ.text: I've been to a few Momofukus but this one has the best service. Our waiter was good but the gentlemen helping him were the True stars. We had the pork buns, pork ramen, crispy fish ssam, and the crispy potatoes. The fish ssam was my favorite. You must try it at least once! It was so crispy and paired so well with the rice, kimchi, and lettuce. The ramen was also very good; I've just had better and for a lot cheaper. The pork buns were awesome and the pork was crispy and tender. The potatoes have this sauce on top -I liked it and it has a creaminess that I wasn't excepting. I wish the potatoes were a little bit more crispy. Overall, I'd recommend to try this place at least once.

GtXGmf-Juam3CecK2BXLuA.text: We finally got to tried this place after becoming amused with its name a couple of years ago.  We saw the fried chicken on buzz feed and ordered the same dish.  The chicken was good but I just didn't think it was worth the price we paid for - it's Vegas. Overall, we had a solid experience and we are glad we tried this place.  Thanks, Momofuku.

4KE9ZqKAMtVr1yYqunvqMQ.text: Pork buns are very good   Complex, traditional, and not too greasy. Skins are crisp and meats are juicy. Noodles are noodles, nothing special to speak of.  Move on.

ARC5Sd_x3doiKpOzuJzxpQ.text: Ate here just tonight and everything was todie for. The entrees were all soft and baked in garlicky sauce, even the scallions. We got the Wagyu potatoes, the ramen and also the pork buns which was really a pork taco. The ambiance was bumpin', with 90's music like Nas and Maxwell

5sWN7Z8GoXl7UaQbKDi_kA.text: Super fun menu with some great flavors.  Loved that we were able to order desserts from Milk next store.   Our servers were outstanding: friendly, informative, present, but not overbearing.   It felt formal enough for the price point, but was very friendly.

a5rbb_Jys-y29htdoj9twA.text: Reading reviews - this is a place to be. Well - reality is much worse. Starting from service, all the way through most of the food - extremely sub-par experience.   The only good thing in this place - pork belly buns. Water - still water - disgusting. Crispy potatoes - extremely spicy, without warning. Ramen - bland.   Hostess and wait staff - trying to be friendly, but incompetent.   Do your self a favor - go to the Mexican/Chinese place next door - you will get a lot more flavor, even though with a very slow service.   Yeah. What a waste of , well, money - but, more importantly, culinary opportunity.

sgxg95ZfuTIKIFZeEh7Z5w.text: I almost want to give a 4 star rating.  The food here was great and the service was super friendly.  The only reason for the 4 star rating thought is that for the price i feel like i could get similar foods in chinatown for a much much cheaper price. If the price was similar then sure i would say momofuku deserves the 5 star rating. but when the price seems like 2-5 times more... then i guess i'm paying for the "las vegas strip" price tag.

SW3NwpUJxzUz7WKnpIXfig.text: I love Momofuku! Been to the DC location, now the Vegas one! We went for lunch which was a trimmed down menu but consisted of the essentials.  If you have never been: get the spicy cucumber, get a bun, get the Pork Ramen or Chilled Spicy Noodles. To me, that's Momofuku. Also get a Crack Pie A La Mode with Cereal Milk Ice Cream from Milk Bar (can order at Momofuku), and some Cookies to go to eat later.   If you like what was maybe the best cocktail I had in my entire trip to Vegas: Toki Thyme. Thank me later.  Just overall this place is perfect: sleek space, their own bathrooms that were SPOTLESS, fun servers, great buns, great noodles, and amazing drinks. Also compared to a lot of places on the Strip this is one of the best values!

pto-6hBq5eyrYLciNuehdw.text: For starters, I had no idea what type of restaurant this was since I was going with a group of people from work.  And all I knew was the name, which I thought would have at least one item on the menu with a peach in it. (Momo is peach)  I would have to say that the overall experience, and restaurant, was amazing.  I really liked the ambiance (granted, we were seated away from the main dining area, overlooking the strip). The service was great too! Everyone, accept maybe our main server, who serviced our table was very attentive and accommodating.    Everything was a bit pricey so we opted to order a few random dishes and shared with everyone so that we could get a taste of multiple dishes rather than just a few. But, each dish was delicious! The chicken, while it was mostly white meat, was very juicy, tender and flavorful!  The drink menu was amazing! The selection of alcohol, from top, top shelf to everyday "regular" items were available.  So I definitely liked that.    I kind of got the impression that our server didn't care so much that we wanted to order a bunch of smaller plates despite his attempts to hide it.  (Hence the -1 star) I mean, he did recommend other items on the menu which were much more expensive.   I might go back if I were going for an intimate dinner/date, but I'm not in a rush to go back either.

XWHFO0SCjbz8sQQUgl9DtQ.text: Great place, as usual. I have been almost every time I come into town, the grilled squid is a fav.

DMzlLPCYBzly8KKywD9hAA.text: I was a little disappointed. The food and vibes were decent but the best part with the dessert from Milk next door. I wouldn't come back.

UIj3mqiv3-Hs973TrdYrBg.text: Great view upstairs restaurant. If your craving for noodles this is it. We loved the noodle soup. Full of flavor and filling. Lemonade is delicious with a tangerine taste to it. Attentive and good service.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

dtZa1ADIBqcf_6gn2R4nRA.text: I suggest calling and making reservations if you plan on eating here, because there is usually a long wait if otherwise. The ambiance at this place is very romantic and great for dates!  We came to this place because we heard they have really good ramen, so we had to come give it a try. They only have the pork ramen ($17) and vegetarian ramen that is not on the menu.  The pork broth was light in flavor, not too heavy. The pork was so juicy and tender that it almost melts in your mouth! It also comes with an egg, bean sprouts, green onions and dried seaweed. If you want to add spicy, they charge $1 for a small thing of chili oil, which isn't worth it in my opinion. Most places give it for free and the chili oil wasn't even spicy!  OH and we also tried their pork buns, also delicious! It comes with their homemade ssam sauce, which is almost a twist between Korean red pepper paste and hoisin sauce, kind of tangy, sweet, and spicy (spicier than the chili oil for sure).   Ramen is only a small part of this restaurant and it was good, but the price was just not worth it for me.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork ramen
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The menu
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork buns

ZUAxyOUg1FQ_2-JUjrD1bg.text: We had the spicy cucumbers that were fantastic and the pickle plate that had a couple great items and a few ok (kimchi pears and mushrooms were awesome).   Then we moved on to the pork belly and shrimp buns that were both great (shrimp were better for me), you should add the ssam sauce to the pork belly one.   For entrees we ordered the spicy chillled noodles.

Gd-eFQ2N0fe-nps46oVrew.text: Loved everything I had here:  * Pork belly bun ($7 each) - maybe the best that I have ever had...cucumber, sauce, crispiness, fatty piece of pork belly...all on point * Chilled spicy noodle ($17) - the Sichuan sausage is ground meat, loved the candied cashew and Thai basil flavor. Looks like pesto but tastes phenomenal with all the flavors combined. It is not as spicy as it sounds. * Korean braised short ribs ($188 for 3-4 people) - the meat came right off the bone and must have been slow-cooked with a lot of love...I may or may not have been eating the leftovers after the meal.  Not used to these prices coming from out of town...but I would recommend everything I tried!

fmYiP158MaT1jJaUCJu3TQ.text: EXCELLENT place to grab noodles while on The  Strip. I typically prefer pho while partaking in Las Vegas shenanigans but I have yet to find one really worthy. This restaurant definitely will do.  Stopped by late, maybe around 11pm and took a seat at the bar with a friend. There was no wait. We were greeted by friendly staff who had their own comical banter behind the counter. I ordered the pork ramen and oh my goodness did it hit the spot after a few hours of drinking. The soup wasn't as thick as I am used to but that made it easier to down in my opinion. It felt "cleaner" and the pork was super tender.  Will definitely come back every time I go to Vegas. Thanks so much Isidra!!!

LAMxL93rKrVrVMRz-8J8Og.text: OKAY. Not mind blowing and not worth the hype. I came in for Tuesday lunch and there was about 2 other tables in there since we came around opening time. I ordered a yuzu lemonade, pork bao and the pork ramen.  My yuzu lemonade came and the waiter took off before I can ask for a straw. It was IMPOSSIBLE to wave down a single staff when there was many of them and 3 tables. My cup of lemonade had white rings all over the top like it wasn't washed or dried properly. DISGUSTING -1 star. I tried making eye contact with the staff and gave up. I ended having to WALK to the front where the servers were standing just to get a new cup. No one said sorry or anything. WHATEVER.   Pork Baos: I've read some reviews on how people said it was "tender" but why on earth was mine so chewy and hard to eat? I had to put it down and wrapped it home for my dog to eat because it was sooooo CHEWY. I really wanted to like it. :(  Pork Ramen: GOOD. For that price tag I expected a little more.   Overall, my experience SUCKED. Not coming back... as much as I wanted to like the place. I planned my trip there and was alll excited but everything from the service to the food was extremely disappointing.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Momofuku Las Vegas
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Momofuku Las Vegas

jDua2CoytGU3MjJlsexFBQ.text: Recently watched some episodes of Ugly Delicious with my mom so I thought we could check out Momofuku while in Las Vegas together. I had memories of momofuku in NYC being okay but nothing spectacular but really wanted to take my mom to show her one of David Chang's restaurants and his style.  It was a nice space, decked out with David Choe art on the walls, and the service was great. We felt very mixed about the food..  The spicy cucumbers and the pork belly/shrimp buns started off our meal on a high note. Then we had the rotisserie chicken ssam and shared a ramen. The chicken and kimchi were too salty. And the shoyu ramen was not as good as we had hoped.   The meal wasn't awful but it wasn't outstanding. I definitely see where the ssam dish and ssam sauce were going conceptually.. I kind of wish it was more traditional Korean ssam sauce or that the chicken were less salty and had a deeper flavor. Good overall meal but could have been better. Maybe our expectations were too high?

Q6k1ZIDS7wOxNXS251unHw.text: I had the ginger scallion noodle and pork belly rolls.  They were both fantastic and I could barely finish them.  This is a great place with pleasant atmosphere and great view of the strip.   However I do have one complaint.  This is NOT a "two dollar-sign" restaurant.  It probably should be 4.  All Main dishes are over $50. There are some "family style dishes" for 3-4 people for over $250!!  The dishes I chose were both under $20 but they were by far the cheapest things on the menu.

LjCqfsgeTZwsM1PHcQ5Ntg.text: Food was good, and service was good. Some of the items felt a little busy and over thought in a way that confused my taste buds a little . I'm not quite sure if this menu is for me, but food was decent. Nothing really "wowed" me, though.

64nrDNHFcAyYCp_keuMk6w.text: It was OK.  Went with my partner and sat at the bar, one bartender was lovely, the other was a putz, talking all night about how he was opening a bar. Ugh. The food was unremarkable. I guess my expectations were really high. We ordered the shishito peppers  those were the best of what we had a nice lemon flavour - but the jidori chicken was dry and off-putting. The ginger scallion noodles were average but a bit oily for my taste - The pork shoulder was nice, but again 'forgettable. We didn't finish anything and won't be back with all the offerings in Vegas now.     I won't even go into the sommelier on duty - he was WAY too 'hipster' and that was disappointing, he was really sort of one note.  I feel like I know more about nice wine and pairing them together.  He didn't even ask what we were planning on having - before launching into his "Under $100' picks.  Rude. This place is supposed to feel like good approachable food with the same sort of vibe for the staff but instead it falls very short.

VWJIfUKdm-jozge6GmM1xQ.text: very oilly and salty, not even better than a food cart. do not recommned it for anyone who have ever had a meal more than 5 dollars

mF2ECrkM5Po8aqsDX7GNzA.text: Yaaaaass! Time to feast! The smaller plates came first: the shrimp bun was warm and fluffy, the chilled spicy noodle was as delicious spin off of a traditional SzeChuan style cold noodle (as a native SzeChuanese, I approve!!), and the grilledlamb ribs were so tender the meat just fell off the bone (the bone literally fell out of the meat, ricocheted off my hand when I attempted to catch it, and landed on my friend's plate!!). . And then they wheeled out the star of the show: the 5 Spice RotisserieDuck. They wheel it out on a cart because the chef combines all the 5 spices into the dish right at your table. Then he skillfully carved the duck into delicious slices and laid them on top the rice. The juices from the duck meat slowly seeped out and began covering the rice. Omg. Instructions: take a lettuce/scallion pancake as your base, spread on some sauce (there's 3 to choose from, or you can combine them like I do ), layer on some rice, then add in the duck meat, and enjoy. So moist, much flavor, wooooooow. Must doge because words are hard when the food is this good... Read the full post, see more pictures, and view the map on my blog!thegrandappetit.wordpres...

UEN8F8RoeQbYNgjkU22vNg.text: Finally went to Momofuku to see what all the hype was about. For someone who's watched every video on David Chang known to man (and Christina Tosi too) it was time for me to see what this place was all about.   Overall, I'd say I had a good meal. As someone who spends a lot of time in Asia, many of the flavors were familiar to me. The fusion of American and Asian was fun on the whole. If you've never been, never plan on going or rarely go to Asia then this place is a treat.   The bao (ordered the pork and the shrimp) were good. The pork bao is a classic dish, but is amped up with smoky pork and richer sauces. The shrimp bao is a really good fusion of Chinese and Thai as the shrimp in the middle is very similar to a Thai shrimp cake while the wrap is still large.   The lamb ribs were a surprise - sweet, salty, spicy, tangy Korean style ribs paired with yogurt and dill from the Mediterranean. I never expected that these would go so well.   The spicy cold noodles we had were like a cold pesto with meatballs. It's discombobulating in its flavor combinations but if you like cold noodles this should be fun for you. The pesto is made with Thai basil so that in itself will be a nice surprise.   We kept this meal simple as we planned to head to Milkbar for dessert.   If I had any one of those dishes alone (except the bao), I would say that the it would be overwhelmingly eat dishes with so many complicated flavors. However, if you are a group of 2 (or better yet, 4 or more) order to share. You will enjoy your meal much more that way.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
