6YeKNLEV2trNj0R1BCT1Fw.text: Came for lunch and was surprised that the menu was not more extensive -- was hoping we could find a replacement for Yong Kang Street when we want a noodle fix in this area but Momofuku is not it.  We tried:  - Pork belly Bao:  simple but super tender and flavorful.  5/5 - chicken karaage Bao:  nice breading, but not as memorable as the pork belly 4/5 - pork ramen:  good thing we read the Yelp reviews to expect a lighter broth than what we prefer for ramen.  The egg helped give some richness to the broth and set off the strong shio flavor.  There's nothing wrong with this ramen but I wouldn't order it again 3.5/5  Service was professional, and we would be open to visiting again for dinner.  I've been to three of the NY Momofuku restaurants and hope they add more to the lunch options here.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork ramen.  Decent but not crabe-worthy
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken karaage bao and the pork belly bao.  Get the pork belly

2k4I5YWNjRiQziYQEYfe2w.text: I only can give 2 stars for the buns. I ordered the pork belly and the shiitake mushrooms buns. They are just ok. The buns are rather dry and at room temperature. I expected warm and moist buns as I usually get when I order buns at other places. Both the pork belly and the mushrooms had too much sauce which is  overpowering. I can only taste the hoisin sauce and can't barely taste of the pork and the mushrooms.  I will give 5 stars for the service.  The waitress are nice and attentive. When she asked about my food, I mentioned the overpowering taste of the sauce. She offered to make me another one with less sauce and the manager came to apologize and didn't change for my food. I'll give it another try by ordering other food beside the buns.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly and shiitake mushroom buns

BMzG6hGAXQ8uYNCjqVuzfw.text: Momofuku has the level of service expected of restaurants on strip, so I need not discuss that in detail. The food was, however, subpar. I had the pork ramen, soft-boiled eggs with arugula and ikura roe, shrimp cocktail, and the pork belly bun.  The pork ramen was certainly disappointing. The alkaline noodles were a touch soft, and the broth lacked depth of flavor. Only the pulled pork shoulder and pork belly imparted a modicum of flavor into this dish.  The soft-boiled eggs were even more disappointing. They came lukewarm, and the ikura roe completely overpowered the dish with its saltiness.   The shrimp cocktail was uneventful, with 6 tiger prawns and a fusion-inspired cocktail sauce that was sweet rather than spicy.  The pork belly bun was the only item I enjoyed eating. The bun was fluffly and the pork belly had a melt-in-your-mouth texture and was not overly seasoned.  Such mediocre dishes tarnish David Chang's name and bring into question his ability to expand the Momofuku chain while preserving his culinary vision. If this establishment is a portent of further efforts, he should re-evaluate his plans.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork ramen (pulled pork shoulder and pork belly)

kGPfmQmUFOydQNa4HjGPPw.text: What a wonderful experience at Momofuku. After two days at a conference this was a great place to relax and enjoy a delicious meal.  Meal: 1 Pork Bun 1 Shiitake Bun           - Chilled Spicy Noodles           - Lamb Ribs           - I think I'm missing something else...  Definitely get the buns and try out some of it before you use their ssam sauce! The flavor is amazing and I don't know if it's the price or the actual flavor, but it tastes more expensive and tasty (very springy bun and tender meat(pork)) Be sure to use their ssam sauce as it adds a whole other side!  The chilled spicy noodles was all right, but growing up in a taiwanese household, I've had better.  Lamb ribs just fall off the bone and are incredibly delicious, especially as someone who has lamb pretty often it was a treat (:  Cheers Momofuku, I'll see you again soon.

cJD_OC0KJWMOdhwFoPv5TQ.text: So the Assistant GM, Victor R, reached out to me shortly after my review and was very genuine in wanting to make things right. He promised to share my review with the chef and offered to refund my meal.   I appreciate it when management gets involved to ensure their establishment takes feedback seriously and works to improve their food or services. Just for that I can't wait to give Momofuku LV another shot!  Bumping up to a 3 star until then!

HTTurMjZpiWJOWCGUumbng.text: Finally able to try this place out. I wasn't impressed with the pork ramen. I was wrong to assume that the ramen would be tonkatsu based so I was disappointed when it came to the table. The ramen also costs $18, which is absolutely ridiculous for some noodles and soup. The pork belly buns were amazing - full of flavor. The oysters were also a plus but considering the price, I won't order them again. Our waitress was friendly and explained everything.    Overall, I don't think I'll return unless someone pays for some pork belly buns.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork ramen
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Oysters
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly buns

BMkY80klu-M03cWNDVExDQ.text: Dined alone and was seated in front of the kitchen, which was great, as I had a chance to speak with the kitchen staff as they prepped the food, and i also chatted with other people sitting nearby who were also dining on their own. It's a great spot for solo diners.  I came to Momofuku because I craved ramen. But after seeing their pork belly bao sandwich on the menu , I had to order both the ramen and the pork belly sandwich. Wow. That sandwich is so good, crispy, tasty, and delightful. Ramen is as good as other ramen I've had (there's one ramen shop in my hometown that does it extremely well, and I go there on a regular basis. I'm pleased to taste a similar dish of equal quality).   To finish the meal off, I had a tiny cup with salted / caramel chocolate ice cream with caramel cereal flakes. Highly recommended.   Delicious, overall, and the service was wonderful.

wcpkXMFRoIMkpky67B-CwQ.text: The service here is great! All of the staff was really friendly and accommodating. Ask for the daily specials if they don't already introduce them to you. The lunch menu becomes buns and ramen only after 2:30pm, so plan accordingly. Also, the menu changes, so the pics you see on yelp may not be available to order. Overall, I would give this place 3.5*, service was great but the food is not worth the price you pay.  SOFTSHELL CRAB BUN 4* $24- This was a special the day we went. It was $24 for 2 buns which I thought was bit steep (what'd I expect really though) but it was really tasty! There was a whole softshell crab in each bun, batter was fluffy but crispy. The star of the bun was the avocado sauce and pickled peppers. The combo of the creamy avo with the freshly pickled peppers was perfect!  CHICKEN KATSU 3* $34- They recently did a "revamp" of this dish and it's no longer the shiitake mushroom gravy. Instead, the chicken katsu comes with a side of pickled shiitake mushrooms and a mediocre sauce with Japanese mayo. This is more of a "traditional" Japanese preparation of the chicken katsu. The chicken itself was prepared to perfection, meat was super juicy, outside was very flaky and crispy, but I wasn't impressed by the dish overall. I would have preferred the old katsu because it was more unique and had their own "take" on a katsu. For $34, I wouldn't order this again.  PORK RAMEN 3.5* $18- Solid bowl of ramen. Broth was flavorful but not creamy or oily which was nice. There's 2 types of pork - pulled shoulder and belly. Both were good, but of course that belly was bomb. That egg though ;)

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork ramen
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Soft shell crab buns (daily special) $24
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The &#34;revamped&#34; chicken katsu. No longer has the shiitake mushroom gravy :(

6mTziXdkXWPMQC5ketxA_A.text: Tried the Shoyo Pork ramen and the duck confetti friend rice. Ramen was amazing. The taste and flavor was out of this world.

V_rhv-URPTf2tTK0l2-xkA.text: I only stopped by for a quick lunch on my way out of town, but this was quite possibly the best meal of my life. I was seated at the end of bar, near the entrance to the kitchen and across from the grill, and I'm sure the smell of the grill and broths certainly helped. This was my first time at one of David's restaurants but I'm a big fan of his, and had high hopes.  This was just a quick lunch before my flight, so I ordered a shrimp bun and a Bo Ssam Bowl. The ensuing experience was like a religious epiphany for me, a meal that I'll remember for the rest of my life. In both dishes, the combination flavor, aroma and texture was so perfect, utterly sublime. Every bite brought something subtly different in the interplay between flavor and texture. Just an incredibly delicious, incredibly memorable experience.

_ogpdYSzhnbaNr2xuIp2Aw.text: So was in vegas to search for lady luck at the gambling games before reigning in the new year. Unfortunately I was not as lucky as I had hoped but fortunately I had the opportunity to go on a "cheat week" for my diet and ended up eating at a bunch of spots which brings us to momofuku located in the cosmo. I had been hankering lately for momofuku in NYC so this seemed like a good spot to make the first dinner night while in Sin City. I made a reservation and got seated right on time. The server was extremely friendly and took the time to explain the full menu and provided her own favorites with detail which certainly helped. The joint itself is a classy affair with nice tables and nice decor adorning the walls on the second floor of the cosmo.   The menu consists of a raw bar, small plates, buns, country ham, noodles, sides, meat & seafood, and the large format dining things. My party was not large enough to order the large format dining items but the table next to us had enough people for the fried chicken  and caviar and our mouths were watering the entire time we saw them eating. Make sure to order these in advance and call the restaurant as it is not prepared on the fly and takes some advance notice it seems. It seems like 3 - 4 dishes is probably good for two people depending on what you order of course but my table went with the Big eye tuna with foie shavings, black truffle ramen, the Sichuan lamb ribs, and a side order of Brussel sprouts which ended up being more than enough for two. They also have a solid Japanese whiskey menu so of course I went with my whiskey ways and ordered a few of these bad boys. The big eye tuna was first and it was delicious. The tuna was quite fresh and oh man.. those foie shavings were on point. It took me a lot of restraint to not lick the foie right off the plate. The truffle ramen (priced at $50) was really solid. It is not your standard ramen to expect from a place like ippudo but a True fusion blend. The truffle was faint but it was well balanced into the ramen itself. It was definitely a unique experience and definitely worth a try at least once if you are searching for a fusion ramen. The noodles were slightly overcooked vs what I normally like but still solid. The Brussel sprouts were good but it was a bit too salty after a few bites.  The Uni sauce on top made it tasty for the first few bites but the salt started overpowering half way through the side dish making it hard to eat in large helpings. The star and surprise of the night was certainly the Sichuan lamb ribs. I was hopeful for this dish but did not know what to expect. The ribs came out with great presentation adorned with jalapenos. The meat was cooked perfectly and absolutely tender and the chili yogurt was the perfect complement to the heat that was brought by the spices. The cucumbers on the bottom also provided a nice texture balance to the overall tenderness of the meat. It really was delicious and is perfect for those searching for some heat.  All in all, a solid experience at momofuku. It is not truly Asian but offers that nice Asian fusion blend that I am sure people could be searching for especially after all those  buffets and heavy American food options around. Definitely will be back when in Sin City. Also make sure to get your Identify points with the hotel rewards program!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Brussell
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Black truffle ramen
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sichuan lamb ribs

A0rTCnqjJBo9aMTgffyO0w.text: I had high hopes for Momofuku, in fact: it was one of the places I really wanted to go when we decided to book a weekend stay in the Cosmopolitan.  Unfortunately it didn't deliver: the ramen were just average, I wouldn't call them bad but I've had much much better ramen in some other places  (don't even get me started about the ramen in Japan).  Also the appetizers were nothing special, actually, I had to consult my pics on my phone to remember what they were... meh!  Also, the service was also on the slower side, I like to drink a lot with my ramen as most ramen broth is quite salty and the waiter never bothered to top up my glass. We had to waive him down every time we wanted something and often we had to wait long-ish to get him down to our table. Knowing that we were there off-peak and the restaurant want only half full makes me fear the worst for when it gets more busy.  Sorry David but I expected more from you... so, with the variation of food options in Vegas I will think twice before I go again.

XO2aa2n14ddbzEXlm6K9Eg.text: Came here on a Saturday night in lieu of going out because certain people are weaklings nowadays. We got there at around 9pm and there was a 45 minute wait for 2 people so we waited at the sportsbook nearby. Once we got the text we went back up.  Overall the place looks nice. Very modern, it fits the look of the Cosmopolitan. We were seated at the bar area and all the servers were very friendly and accommodating.  We ordered one bao to share, and a ramen. We initially ordered something else but had to cancel mid-dinner as someone had a problem holding in the food. The servers at this point could see her struggle and was offering sprite and other things to calm the stomach which I thought was very helpful.  YES get the bao. It is delicious and you will not regret it.  The Ssam sauce goes with everything.  The ramen, while delicious and full of meat, I think I would not order it again because I would like to try the more sophisticated dishes on their menu.  Maybe some day we can order the fried chicken with caviar (starts at $300+) but you may need 4-6 people for that. Maybe if we were with a group we could try that.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Rt3DaDd7CLJ9JDLuakenlg.text: Momofuku was our last stop before leaving Vegas. We did lunch. We were extremely tired from the night before, and exhausted from the previous few days, but Momofuku delivered!  We shared the crispy potatoes (amazing), as well getting the pork belly pinch buns (drool) and the very best ramen I've ever had.  I'll skip to the ramen and tell you why you should at least get one for the table to try. Beautifully soft-boiled egg on top sitting on a healthy portion of noodles, and both pork belly AND some shredded pork. I've had my fair share of ramen, and just have never had one with both pork belly AND shredded the pork. Both were cooked perfectly and just made the whole dish taste delicious.  The restaurant itself was also beautiful. We sat in the back part that big windows to look out and get nice light in, and a really interesting mural that was the length of a long wall.  Don't forget to stop by Milk Bar next door. Birthday cake truffles to go? Yes please.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ramen
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Pinch  Buns

dTLm0-vS65KIQit3pKDvSg.text: I really enjoy David Chang's docuseries "Mind of a chef" and felt coming here would pay my respects and finally let me try all the rage from foodies and millenials in my life.   I arrived with the full understanding Momofuku has executed a twist on classic asian dishes. The twist however, just wasn't something that wow'ed me.   Growing up in China, I had already been accustomed to tastes of what a bao should be so trying an over-complicated version of something the nice lil old lady used to sell for 50 cents around the corner of my block on Shanghai felt wrong. I wanted the moment where I'm transported back to my childhood and instead I got and overpriced pork belly bao with sauce.   Surprised also that they couldn't make me an affogato especially when they have Milkbar connected.   Definitely hyped.

yBy86BjfKhw3d2304_kbcg.text: I had an amazing experience dining at Momofuku with my son. We started out with the Big Eye Tuna with shaved foie gras and strawberry and Pork Belly Buns.  Both were delicious. Our main course was the kimchi stew with wagyu short rib stew. The stew was rich and tasty.  We realized we could had order rice after we ate the stew. The richness of the stew need rice. We cap our dinner off with Milk Bar Pie al la mode or otherwise known as crack pie. The dessert is a must eat! Super yummy and fucking delicious. The deserts and the pork buns were the best overall.  The service was amazing and everyone was attentive. Plus, the manager was adorable. She came up to our table and checked in on us twice.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Milk bar pie ala mode
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wagyu Short Rib Stew

h7HP_6oqYjmEsmaWtHnSAg.text: Came here shortly after landing because they were famished.  During non normal dining hours, there is a pretty limited menu and we were seated in the bar stool area close to the open kitchen.  We got the ginger noodles, shoyu ramen and the pork belly buns to share. The ginger noodles dish was a good mix of an assortment of vegetables, some of which was a bit spicy.  I was a little bit disappointed with the ramen dish.  The pork belly and shoulder was a huge chunk of dry pork with lot of fat (not the good pork belly kind) that made it almost inedible.  The pork belly was decent, it could have used more flavor and the pork belly was not that tender.  Perhaps I would give it another shot with the formal dining menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

6R-e8eR-8uXU_AsO6Zp36g.text: I was excited to try Momofuku. Sadly it wasn't that exciting. I had the pork ramen & pork belly buns. I've had both better at ramen restaurants in So Cal, Honolulu & NYC. The service was good but the food was just ok - I'm glad I tried it but it's unlikely I'd go again.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

1ks2ZaH8FuOPETNBOqWoyQ.text: David Chang amazing baos did it again!!! We ordered the truffle ramen, pork belly baos and fried chicken. All meals were delicious and prepared perfectly. The truffle ramen was divine, the truffle oh my gosh the truffle hit every spot! The noodles on the ramen were al dente and had a delicious chicken broth. I would definitely come back and have more baos and ramen. Don't forget to try MILK, their soft serve and milk cereal were divine!!!

vuScqkwebuLhOqzCVu310A.text: This place offers up some fantastic Asian flavored comfort food... for lack of a better term.  The bar up front is really fun, although they offer seating right at the kitchen so you can watch the chefs work while you enjoy your meal.    You can go for any noodle dish the Al Dente noodles and the smoky flavor the broth will win you over instantly.  The only other must do are the lamb ribs... do not miss that opportunity!  They are easily one of the best things you will ever put in your mouth.

eTZFZVSlRdwuP9g9290gPQ.text: I could not RAVE about this place ENOUGH. I'm a huge foodie, and this is one of my favorite restaurants & dinging experiences of ALL TIME. My group (of girls in their 20s) was skeptical coming in because the menu seemed to have either cheap eats or expensive af eats. BUT our waiter offered a custom tasting menu, all we had to do was pick a price between $50-100 per person. $50 sounds a little pricer for a bunch of college girls, but we got WAY more than we ever expected, and personally I think way more values worth than $50. and the food is OUT OF THIS WORLD DELICIOUS. They threw dish after dish full of unique, carefully designed plates such as pork belly bao buns, cold cucumber salad (which I didn't think would be good, and a whole fish with kimchi and fried rice. All of us were amazed!! The staff is so kind & the somelier there even gave my friend a free glass of wine.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. pork belly bao buns
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. fish with kimchi
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Rice gnocchi

s_dVxwFWp_myh9-81_Dvdg.text: OKAY OKAY! Some might tell you that Momofuku is overrated.  Those authentic asian food people might steer you away.  BUT I do not judge a book until I've experienced it.  Boy did I experience!  Luckily my friend and I were deciding on where to go last minute in Vegas (apparently these days you need reservations to get into the good spots).  Thank you Momofuku for having a reservation time available for us!  I never go too try it in NYC so Vegas you deliver.  We had a smoke salmon dish which was really flavorful.  We actually loved love loved whatever they did to the sides for the dish.  Couldn't even tell what it was but it had some roe, corn, and sunflower seeds.    The Winner of the night for me was the Truffle ramen!!!! Taste buds tickled. I love the punch of truffle flavor in the soup.  It's perfect to share between two people.  This wasn't on the menu so make sure to ask because they will make it!

Z-ZFyCxuVq1JbFFC_pzB8A.text: I was so looking forward to trying this restaurant! The spicy cucumbers are a must try. So fresh and delicious! I would pass on the black miso cod. It was very well cooked but didn't have as much flavor as I was expecting for the price. My friends all enjoyed the ginger scallion noodles and also the wagyu. Another favorite was the black truffle ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

SwyLI3xAuVrwCKciW_oe_w.text: Fuku yeah to those spicy cucumbers!!!  The Mister and I stopped for a late lunch - he was starving and I wanted something light. Momofuku handled both well! The space is spare and modern - expect a fun menu of fusion delights made for sharing.   I opted for spicy cucumbers ($9) which were fresh, light and wonderfully spicy. This would be an amazing start to dinner or a tasty choice for veggie lovers. The Mister opted for a pork bun ($7) which was good but kind of a rip for the price. His shoyu ramen ($17) was really good though - full of nice al dente noodles, a smoky broth and topped with a perfectly poached egg.   If you still have room, they'll charge you $14 for a piece of cake. Vegas, baby.   Who the fuck spends $14 for a slice of cake? Y'all need Jesus.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bun and spicy cucumbers

hdx4vKG5K7D9ACaXmqUpfA.text: Spicy chicken is very good. Large piece of Karaage chicken with a homemade chipotle sauce. Spicier than sriracha sauce. The sauce and the juicy Chicken is really what stands out. Chicken is not dry (was afraid of that)  Didn't get the shoYu pork ramen bc I typically prefer tonkotsu broth. I did get to sample the shoYu broth and it was bombbb. Super duper good just not my broth. Flavorful. I felt like they added something to the broth where it wasn't just shoyu which made me feel like it stands out a bit more than your typical shoyu ramen. Maybe it was umami...."shrugs"  Pork belly bun was cooked perfectly. The fat melts in your mouth. It was a nice thick cut and the ratio of bun to meat was just right. Sometimes I feel that there's not enough meat and momofuku did it just right.  I also had their Kalbi beef dish which was also very good. I expected the beef dish to be overpowered by sauces but this dish, you can actually taste the meat. Cooked medium rare, not too chewy. It came with a side of what tasted like pickled mushrooms. I do have to say that I felt that this dish was particularly overpriced for how much you get. You don't get very much for $48. Overall, good dish.  Note to patrons who want to also get dessert here. You can order from the milk bar menu at momofuku, which is nice and convenient.   Servers were attentive and great. They know they menu well and don't just try to up sell you.   Worth visiting! Just a few dishes just feel a little overpriced for what you get (kalbi dish and the shoyu pork ramen).

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

YVXvUnV_L5COEufIoFKFWw.text: Wow! So delicious!! I was so excited to try Momofuku and happy that it lived up to the hype.  We ordered the Pork Belly Buns ($14), Tasting of Country Hams ($28), Jidori Chicken Rice bowl ($17), and the Bo Ssam Rice Bowl ($17).   The pork belly was super thick. It was very crispy and melted in your mouth. Buns were fluffy and delicious. The biscuits were perfectly seasoned and the hams were so flavorful. The mustard added a balance of sweetness to the salty ham. The frozen grapes were a wonderful surprise. They tasted like grape popsicles. The jidori chicken bowl was our least favorite dish of the day. The massive amount of pickled ginger overwhelmed the bowl. It was better when we removed the majority of the ginger. To Bo Ssam pork shoulder was sooooo good. My mouth is watering as I write this review. It was sweet and savory. The kimchee rice, picked cucumbers and onions made this bowl perfect.  Next time We will order the Bo Ssam sharing plate!  My only disappointment was that they were completely full for dinner and we could only enjoy lunch.   We will definitely be back on our next trip or just wish that David Chang would open a restaurant in Honolulu!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Jidori and Bo Ssam rice bowls. We ate the pork belly Bao so quickly that I forgot to take a pic!
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tasting of Country Hams

j9ot14eLzq5rVbBIa4by7A.text: I came with no expectations, and the food blew me away. Me and my fiance ordered 1 pork bun, spicy noodle, and lamb rack to share, and we thought it was just enough food for us. The pork bun was tasty but fatty, and we were happy to only share one. The spicy noodle was pesto based, which I did not expect, but it somehow worked well with the candied pecans. The lamb rack was most delicious..we were sooo happy with our choice. The lamb was frenched perfectly and the meat was so tender it fell off the bone. The yogurt sauce complimented the lamb well.  My friends ordered the Bo Saam ($138 to feed 3-4 people) so I got to try it as well. We were very impressed with the Cook of the pork shoulder. Super tender and flavorful!!! The order also came with 6 oysters, which you are supposed to eat in the lettuce wrap with the pork. The portion was huge and we felt like could have fed more than 4 people. Of course my friends had to get the rest of the shoulder to go. The waitress was nice enough to pack up a set of new sauces and lettuce wraps for us.   Great service and great food. We thought what added a nice touch was when the chef came out and discussed the menu with us! I would want to come back to try other items on the menu, and maybe for lunch as well!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Grilled Lamb Ribs
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bo saam with Slow Roasted Pork Shoulder
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Oysters that came with bo saam

V53KnYZDWtsBUPH7MpSB-g.text: I finally got the chance to try Momofuku in Vegas! We had a large group, so we made a reservation on OpenTable ahead of time. Once we arrived, we were lead to a private room for our party. It was a beautiful room which made our dinner here an excellent dining experience. The staff were also friendly and displayed great customer service. They explained to us the menu options and how they can even create a menu for us at whatever price point we pick. We decided to order individually, but that's a nice option that I wouldn't mind trying next time!  Food that I got include:  Pork Belly Bun (hoisin, scallion, cucumber) - This was an excellent appetizer before my meal. It was delicious and each bite had me wanting more! If you're deciding between this or the shrimp bun, pick the pork belly bun.  Shrimp Bun (spicy mayo, pickled red onion, iceberg) - I had to get another bun after tasting how delicious the pork belly bun was, so I decided to give this a try as well. It was also good, but the pork belly bun is definitely the better of the two.  Chilled Spicy Noodles (sichuan sausage, candied cashew, thai basil) - Noodles with sausage and nuts. The spice level isn't too high, very bearable for people who can't handle that much spicy. Overall, the noodles were great!  Overall, my experience at Momofuku was great. I especially liked the noodles here, they were perfect quality and had plenty of flavors. The staff mentioned that the menu changes routinely, so be open-minded with the menu when coming here. However, the staff were also understanding and after speaking with the chef, we were able to order some items not on the menu, such as the pork ramen. Dinner time at Momofuku is definitely more on the fancy side, so come here for lunch if you want a more casual food experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chilled Spicy Noodles
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp Bun
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Found the noodles!

ZdZQd4iyhvV6LHCB-RUGBQ.text: Absolutely incredible meal. As I am waiting in a ridiculously long rental car line ( Budget) at the airport in Florida, I am tempted to write a negative review but my stomach is hangry and all I can think about suddenly is this delicious meal I had last month. My favorite was a tie between the salmon and the pork belly and shrimp buns! The bf really enjoyed the lamb dish. The wagyu tri tip was not cooked right, it was way too thick and chewy still and it ended up being the only dish that we didn't finish.   The table next to us was kind enough to share their $300+ fried chicken. Holy chicken, it was amazing. Thank you generous strangers for sharing that dish with us!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp and pork belly buns
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kalbi Wagyu Tri-Tip, Brussels Sprouts &amp; Cauliflower, Pork Belly &amp; shrimp buns, Grilled Lamb Ribs  Not pictured: oysters and 3 happy guests

DPURqcl15UdhTZMbFO5VtQ.text: For our annual Vegas trip this year, we decided to revisit Momofuku to try the Bossam that we did not get to try on our first trip and it did not disappoint. At $168 dollars and a suggested serving of 4 people, we couldn't believe our eyes when it got to the table. The serving size should probably be more like 6 to 8 people. It's a really good value for money, as well as an amazing take on Bossam.   Bossam is traditionally a boiled pork belly dish that is served with bean paste, pickled veggies (kimichi, etc.) wrapped in lettuce.   David Chang's Bossam is Bossam level 100. The shoulder is marinated in brown/white sugar and salt overnight, and slow roasted in an oven. The result is a pork shoulder that's fork tender, with a lightly salty and sweet crispy skin covering the gelatinous fat and tender, juicy pork. It's truly a gleeful, gluttonous, melt in your mouth burst of flavor. Accompanied by a garlic scallion sauce, rice, butter leaf lettuce, kimchi, hoisin and ssam sauce, and you've got a party of flavor in your mouth. We had four people at our table devouring the shoulder for over two hours. While our appetites are decent (or more on the eyes bigger than stomach side), we were defeated by how much there was. If you have to order one thing, and you've got a large party of 4 or more, order the Bossam. It will not disappoint and is truly a great experience, especially if you are a fan of pork. Oysters were also served on the side of this - which are great if you like oysters.   We also had the opportunity to try a couple of sides on our visit as well.   Shishito Peppers - these were a nice side to break up the fattiness of our meal. They're served covered in a lime salt, which was nice. The spiciness was not consistent throughout the peppers so it was a bit of a spicy roulette. If you enjoy peppers, this dish is decent.   Hearts of Palm and Avocado - this was also a nice salad to pair with the Bossam. It had a light dressing and was a great way to cleanse our palettes and balance out the richness of our meal.   When we came, we also had the opportunity to try an off-menu spicy chicken ramen as well. As I mentioned in my previous review, I was not a fan of the Momofuku pork ramen because of the shoyu-tare broth. However, all my table mates agreed, this ramen was much better than the pork ramen. The ramen had a chicken broth base, with shredded chicken, carrots, green onions and shitake mushrooms. It came with a somewhat spicy sauce, which mixed into the broth made the soup slightly spicy, but also a tad sweet at the same time. The flavors were very balanced and clean. The shitake mushrooms were also well done. The noodles were curly ramen (my fave) and perfectly al dente. This ramen is a great cold weather item to eat or eat even if you're feeling a bit sick. If you come in, do ask for it. They can also make chicken meatballs as an added item for it as well.   Lastly, no meal is complete without dessert right? We tried both the Birthday Cake dessert and cereal milk. While I wasn't wowed by the cereal milk (perhaps because I'm used to the Asian flavored milk soft serves), the Birthday Cake is truly a nostalgic and delicious take on birthday cakes you may have had as a kid. It's light, fluffy with a bit of cake crunch bits. It's sweet, without being overly sweet and frosting is just the right consistency of not being too airy, or too heavy. I highly recommend it.   Shout out to the wait staff who put up with us eating for hours on end. You're the True MVP's.   If you find yourself at Momofuku, don't be afraid to ask your waitstaff for their recommendations. They're highly knowledgeable and will make the effort to make your dining experience at Momofuku a memorable and delicious one.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shishito Peppers with lime salt - Photo by J. Fong
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Hearts of Palm, Avocado, Endive, Sunflower Seeds. Photo by J. Fong
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Off-Menu Chicken Ramen. Photo by J. Fong

MB3bWKR82MI6_IONo8HU3g.text: The pork buns and duck are SUPER good. One interesting thing that they do with the duck is that they cut it up in front of you after it is fried, then they take the bones and fry them again with some seasoning and bring it back to your table. The double friend bones with a little bit of meat on it was delicious.   Our server was really nice, and service was awesome overall!

jLeETlBToSofrKGMUX3uKw.text: Asian fusion food. Busy on a Friday. The fried chicken was good, but not good enough for its eight five dollars price tag. The schezuan beef noodles? Well if you like oversauced spaghetti, you may want to order this. It's a very confused dish, not Asian, not Italian. Just a bad hybrid. The pork buns were good. The best dish would be the pork chop. Overall, MMFK is overpriced for what you ger. It did not meet out expectations - 5 people in our party. Good for people watching, but not my choice for food!

rMh4ty3XnJ-2UpAdHNBvWA.text: So amazing and so yummy.  Came here for a birthday dinner with a party of 11 girls. Our waiter was very patient with us and suggested to us that he could make us a tasting menu for $50 per person and the table ended up going with this option. The waiter catered to all the diet restrictions we had at the table (pescetarian and lactose intolerant) to make sure that everyone was satisfied with the meal.  We were served several different dishes ranging from veggies to buns to two whoole fish. My favorite dish of them all was the pork belly bao buns, just wow. Everything we were served was super yummy and everyone was happy with the entire experience. The birthday girl even got a special birthday cookie that came from Milk Bar right next door!  I wish I could remember our waiters name, but he was very deserving of a 5-star review.

7IUdfS5UUM9dK0BHJBitRw.text: Dear David Chang/or manager of Momofuku Las Vegas:  Korean-AMERICAN to Korean-AMERICAN here. Thank you for a delicious family meal at Momofuku tonight.  I had a bowl of ramen many years ago at your NYC location that was not notable, so this was a pleasant surprise.  Kimchi was legit.  Thank you for providing a bottom-less bowl of lettuce and proper accoutrements to go with the bossam.  Thank you for providing kid size portions of ramen even though Yelp says that it's not a kid friendly restaurant.  The Momofuku labeled sake was respectable and our server Sarah was wonderful.  You're doing a great job at feeding the masses in Las Vegas!  I'm happy for your success even if it means my pocket is $500 lighter after eating at your restaurant.  All the Best!

5gG-V4TNyhYCJzME4JLxuw.text: Came here with a large group.  The decor is nice, a lot of David Choe graffiti art on the walls.  The lazy Susan in the middle of the table was a nice touch and was very useful for family style dining.  We ordered:  1. Truffle and burrata salad - pleasantly surprised how good it was.  The portion was large.    2. Tuna with foie - I would highly recommend this dish.  It was definitely one of our favorites of the night.  The combo of the tuna with the frozen shaved foie on top was excellent.  3. Kampachi - I heard it was good.  I didn't try it, but no complaints from the others.  A small serving.  4. Long beans - Not good.  Overcooked, oily and salty.  We sent it back.    5. Ramen - Even though it's not on the dinner menu, we asked for 2 orders to share.  The consensus was...it was ok.  Nothing special, nothing horrendous.  It was a nice sized bowl.  6. Foie buns - Our server sent us Foie buns, which was off menu and an experimental item.  It was pretty good.  I was scared of the lack of texture of serving foie in a bun, but thankfully they added nuts for a nice crunch.  The seared foie was cut generously and was very rich.   7. Branzino - came whole roasted.  The fish was nicely cooked, and the crisped rice underneath was delicious, however the fish was killed by the over dressed sauce as well as the slathering of kimchi.  The combination of the sauce and kimchi created a salty, spicy mess; you couldn't taste the fish.  I think they should get rid of the sauce, or use less of it.    8. Lamb Ribs - Excellent!  The best dish of the night.  The ribs were cooked perfectly and the yogurt sauce was superb.  A definite hit all around.  9. Lobster thermidor - another off menu item.  Traditional thermidor preparation, but with a generous helping of noodles in the center.  The lobster was huge, and tasty.  I would recommend the dish, but it's quite large.  10.  5 spice duck - Eh.  I think it's difficult to serve duck to basically a table of all Asians who are very used to eating it.  It wasn't a popular dish, and I would find it difficult to recommend.  Although we were quite full by this time, I doubt we even ate a third of it.    Overall, it was a great dining experience.  The service was excellent.

lq2mq9xfmK6XqarsiECksQ.text: I believe the food here is good and it's a must try unique eats if that's what you are looking for. It's an Asian fusion cuisine and I think if you order their couple few hundred dollars for 4 to 6 ppl it's good for a small family so we ordered two from that menu hoping to feed 8 people which for the most part it did and overall it was satisfying due to protein and rice. Our waiter was cool he demonstrated how to shred meat and put everything together on butter lettuce etc.  With all that said, don't be surprised with the bill though as the tab will set you back a lot for what you think is some fancy sauce with bbq and rice. Pricey AF!

0SlVqTvWMvFpBagB138PTg.text: Yum! A little expensive but good! 3 people no drinks but water and the bill was $200. It's Vegas so why not! We had the whole bass, honey crisp salad, pork chop, pork belly bun and oysters. Everything was so yummy! Service was good and loved the music playing in the background but it's my kinda music so yeah. Everything had great taste. Not everything came out at once which I liked. Once we were almost done with one another would come out which gave us time to enjoy one thing at a time.

1-D6ZK26VQg1zO9XwK-edA.text: This food was amazing and the service was excellent. We ordered quite a spread and enjoyed it all. The pork belly buns and the chicken with crispy rice were DELISH. There was also plenty of food for our vegetarian friends. Order the violet fem cocktail and you will be a happier person :)  Only notes would be to pass on the little gem salad (it was only ok). Gluten free noodles or an option would have definitely been the 5th star on this review.   We will definitely eat here again and recommend to friends.

c7oPfs3SUjHVmceCIo-w3g.text: Tried this place with my two friends on a recent trip to Vegas. Made reservations, showed up and ate our souls out :)  Somehow the 3 of us spent $466 there just ordering random nonsense off the menu...it adds up quick!......The food was very fusion-y and ambience was nice. Great for groups and drinking.  We ordered basically a bit of everything from: oh so fresh oysters on the half shell $24, King crab cocktail with the gigantic juicy legs $48...mmmm, crispy and a bit charred Shishito peppers $12, Hearts of Palm & Avocado-basically a salad $19, tender & juicy Miso Black Cod in roasted vegetable broth $52, medium rare Dry Aged Ribeye sliced into thin tender slices $98, fluffy Pork Belly Buns with a huge honkin' thick slice of melt-in-your-mouth pork belly $14, and lastly, Ginger Scallion Noodles $15.  Everything was good but nothing truly stood out among the others aside from those crab legs. Ugh..they were so good...  Then we had Milk Bar's crack pie for dessert and that stuff was THE PERFECT ENDING.  Would not mind eating here again :)

f0wWYtequZbkxX0tXNn8KQ.text: Stop by this place just to have their wagyu steak!  Hand down was the best steak I've ever had!! Would come back to just to have the steak again!

enIKVQAFmB-rnugPmrR0NQ.text: We came for a lunch menu. Pork belly ramen and pork belly buns were incredible. We had a cucumber App too that I loved! Service here is amazing as well. Our server Hadley had the best customer service and he was so much fun. I would come back here anytime I'm in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Buns. These were perfection... A must try.

CF66fPwL8gEIODjs57lrZg.text: Who finds time in Vegas to eat? Ummm definitely me!   Cosmopolitan Hotel...one of my favorite hotels in Las Vegas. I have so many bookmarks in Vegas it's hard to decide what to eat. I have a ton of bookmarks just in the Cosmopolitan. So when my friend wanted ramen we came here. I think it was a win, win situation since there was a donut shop across the way and Milk Bar ice cream next-door.   Momofuku was a pleasant surprise. I was expecting to get a quick bite to eat but this restaurant was fancy. My only disappointment was many of the pictures of the dishes on yelp weren't available anymore. Their menu continuously changes so make sure you look at the menu not the pictures online. They can confirm if they have those items still available.  My friend ordered the Ramen and said it was ok but not worth $17, but she's pretty picky. I ordered the crispy potatoes and the Pear & Burrata salad. They were both outstanding. My vote is in and the food is quite delicious. I wasn't very hungry or I would have ordered more. I'm excited to try more of their menu items.   The majority of the service here is outstanding and the restaurant itself is beautiful. Even the bathrooms are fancy with heated toilet seats. If you're at the Cosmopolitan, Momofuku is an excellent option. The only thing you need to keep in mind is it's not going to be cheap. Our bill was $75 and that was with two small appetizers, Ramen and a drink. If that sounds pricey go gambling before dinner so this fancy dinner won't burn your pocketbook.   Drunk or sober Momofuku will still taste good!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crispy Potatoes
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crispy Potatoes

foicrW2iPtHLsJHrTi2z-Q.text: One of the best dining experiences of my life.  We were in town for the weekend of April 26 and sat at the chef's bar for 2 lunches in a row (totally unplanned) because we had such a wonderful time and mouthwatering food.    Over the 2 days, we had the pork belly buns, the shishito peppers, the spicy cucumbers, the sweet and sour long beans, the crispy sweet potatoes, the honeycrisp apple salad, the bo ssam bowl, the duck confit fried rice, and the grilled lamb ribs.  Almost everything was superb, the flavors piquant and bright and thrilling and memorable.  I would kill to eat the lamb and pork belly again, and the long beans were surprisingly wonderful. The only dish we were disappointed in was the sweet potatoes, which were a little dry.  And I thought the fried rice, though the tastes were wonderful, was a little heavy in texture; I would've liked the rice grains to be a little fluffier and more separated. But honestly that's just nitpicking; again this was definitely top 10 (and this includes French Laundry, Alinea, Bestia, Bavel, Momofuku New York, Balthazar, Maude, Trois Mec/Petit Trois, Pizzeria Mozza, Chez Panisse (cafe), Alan Wong, Michael Mina, Patina, Redbird - disappointing, Baco Mercat, etc).    Nick the chef was fun to watch and chat with; he answered my questions about the food he was preparing, gave us a little insight into the restaurant, and slipped us a couple of amuse bouches on the side.  I can't wait to go back!!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. View from the bar at the chef&#39;s area
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Inside dining

eB-qUxM-j62b814mvcxF_A.text: Momofuku was an experience like no other. It's one that I'll not soon forget and wish I could have regularly. Price wise, it's not a cheap experience, but it's Vegas and it's worth every single penny (dollars) you're going to spend.  So we decided to come here for my birthday. I scoured Yelp for places to go and I kept coming back to this place, something about it just made me feel like I had to experience the food. It looked almost too good to be True. Located on the second floor of the Cosmopolitan Hotel next to Milk, we approached the hostess table. Of course they asked us if we had a reservation, sadly we didn't, but they told us it wouldn't be more than 15 minutes- phew! Eventually we were taken to our seat, which happened to be at their bar area. Now typically I would have asked for a table, even if it meant a longer wait, but I was feeling like gambling (and a little drunk at the time) so I was relaxed, and figured I'd just go with it. And thank goodness I did.  Our waiter at the bar was phenomenal. He walked through the menu with us and explained everything in such detail. They either train their employees extremely well or this guy is an encyclopedia of all things food and Momofuku because he was like Rain Man with his knowledge of ingredients and flavors. It was perfect.  Beverage:  I only had one drink here (because I had so many others earlier in the day). I opted for their Bok to the Beet. For $17, you'll receive probably the most refreshing alcoholic beverage of your life. If you're a gin-lover, get this now. It's gin, beet, blood orange, and bok choy. None of them I'd mix together normally, but it was absolutely delicious.  Appetizers:  We had two appetizers before dinner: 1. The spicy cucumbers. Never have $9 cucumbers tasted so good. And never did I think spending $9 on cucumbers seem worth-while until I tried these. Featuring this togarashi spice, toasted almonds and an avocado-like paste/sauce, these cucumbers were the perfect blend of spicy and salt. You literally want to lick the bowl clean. We didn't, but that doesn't mean we didn't want to. 2. The pork belly bun. Wow. Wow. Wow. $14 gets you two of the tastiest pork belly buns out there. I loved the hoisin sauce; it was the perfect amount and of course, you could get more if you needed it. The bun is also topped with scallion and cucumber- more cucumber!!!!  Dinner:  Now the real treat was dinner. And that's saying something because everything prior was outstanding. We ordered the Salt and pepper lobster & shrimp. Menu price is $268 and feeds three to four people, but you can do a half order for, you guessed it, half of the cost! So our order came with three lobster tails, 9 shrimp ( these beautiful jumbo shrimp), all battered in this amazing tempura then fried with copious amounts of garlic and chilies. Oh, and that's not all, it's finished with oyster sauce and condensed milk. My photos don't do it justice. It was amazing. If you're any type of seafood lover, this is truly a treat. I felt so badly leaving any remnants of the meal because I wanted every bite to be gone. The chilies were amazing and not spicy like I would have imagined. The lobster tails were delicious as well. Nothing bad at all. Everything we tasted was truly out of this world.  Overall this was an amazing experience on so many levels. I couldn't imagine it getting any better than this. This experience at Momofuku really helps you understand the phrase, "you get what you pay for" because the food isn't cheap, but you will not regret it one bit.  Also- they partner with Milk Bar next to it so you can get a little sweet treat from Milk brought over to you at Momofuku. As if you needed yet another reason to love this place.  A+ dining experience and I really can't wait to come back here and explore more items on their menu. I hope you love it as much as I did.

V_Eolpg7Qv0Ld0S-noSFSA.text: Great rib stew and miso bass! The waitstaff is pretty awesome if you sit at the bar! The drinks a killer too

BK34NlghlFbaYO1N5PPL5g.text: It's not the "best" ramen I've ever had so I can't give it 5 stars but I was very pleased by the chickpea ramen. It was delicious! The chickpeas were perfectly roasted, the noodles tasted very fresh and the miso broth was so good! I'd be happy to have that again.   The spicy cucumber appetizer left some to be desired. The powdered spice (togarashi) drenched on top was too much.   The bartender made one of the best French 75 drinks (sparkling wine, gin and lemon) I've ever had!  And the staff were very friendly and attentive.

jdZejjWgSiiJxoUqDjVaew.text: A must stop in Las Vegas! This review might be a tad biased since my best friends friend was a chef and we got to try a bunch of the dishes but this was one of the best restaurants I've ever been to.  The crack pie dessert was amazing.

mAbkqsJOmD2D3N3_-tGARQ.text: I was here tonight with a group of friends from my college days and Mags (our waiter) made our night! Not only did he help us choose the best food on the menu, but he also brought it with a smile and so much positive energy! Thank you!

HX7kmNMBzSeN7mba9hgOeg.text: Soo this place is just amazing. Keep in mind that although it is listed as $$ it should probably still be $$$..lol but soo worth it! APPETIZER: Just get the spicy cucumbers. Enough said. But seriously though, the crunch that the toasted almond added, the depth of flavor.. I couldn't get enough and I didn't know I needed these cucumbers in my life. ENTREE: The schezuan spicy beef noodles were ABSOLUTELY AMAZING!! Definitely not your typical ramen, imagine a spaghetti bolognese with schezuan spice and better noodles! Each noodle was coated perfectly in the thick sauce with red oil, I almost licked the plate clean I kid you not. We also had the ginger noodles with chicken that was grilled.to.perfection. The sauce was thick and flavorful with a pretty strong ginger taste (without the kick) that builds as you continue to eat so be wary if you're not a fan of ginger, I loved it! *Certain foods may not be available depending on the time of day. There are family style meals for around $250 but it seems like a lot of food..now that I've eaten there, if I came back with a group I'd definitely splurge. ATMOSPHERE: Located on the 2nd floor of the cosmopolitan near egg slut. It's modern, sleek, with an open kitchen..filled with talented chefs. Will save all my coins and be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy beef noodle, absolutely delicious!

hT4sUh3UHimqia2jgKER-Q.text: Ok.......  so we came back (I know a little dramatic since there is no doubt we are coming back it is Amazing read my other review and pay attention).....  .....  so we came back, and it was literally better than we remembered it. We had the apple app that has been soaked with kimchi and has the perfect amount of crispy bacon that complements the peppery hints that the arugula adds....  man you thought that was it right?  NOOOO. Now as you grab the apple slice you will smear the edge of your apple into the maple labne (soft rich and creamy think Greek yogurt texture) and it cools the heat of the kimchi.....  Oh man the sea bass with miso is just stupid it is simply perfect the very very lightly sweet and salty pairing in the miso is on a different level...  The other dish....  oh I mean the "other dish".....  was just a noodle with beef.  Oh...   oh man.....  the heat of the beef complements the noodles is every way.....

21S4YLB85H3bFEOe4R86AA.text: Oh Momofuku. Let me count the way I love you.   Always a favorite of mine in NY and DC I couldn't pass up the chance to try the Vegas outpost. It didn't disappoint.   Good craft beer to start. Then pork buns eith a think piece of pork belly and buns that met in your mouth.   Then of course ramen. More noodles than I can slurp but a great broth. I added some bok choy to make things a little greener. But the egg was sublime. Runny without being gross, it was just perfect.   Service was helpful and friendly and enjoyed sitting at the food bar to see the food being prepared. Great place.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

bH0wctwkC4B40c_ScZg8Qg.text: I don't get the hype.  At all.   This was our first meal in Vegas this week and I was really expecting to have a great dinner.  With all these positive reviews, I assumed it would be good.   We ordered the pork buns, cold garlic noodles, an octopus appetizer, and spicy rice cakes (last two not on their menu, it was their special of the day)  Every dish, except the pork buns, was spicy.  And even that came with a side of very vinegary spicy sauce.   I liked the pork buns, never have I tasted such well seasoned, well cooked slab of thick pork belly.  Everything else was..... bad.   The texture of the octopus was great.  The burnt flavor was strong, but the consistency of the legs were really soft and chewy.  The flavor..... not so much.  Think butter mixed with Tabasco and sour burnt flavor.  The texture of the cold garlic noodles were good, but the flavor.. eh.  Think mint/cilantro mixed with peanuts and spicy chili peppers.  The rice cake was cooked deliciously, they were semi fried it or something where it was crispy and chewy (very different from the original, nonetheless delicious) the flavor.... blah.  Think vinegar with spicy sauce and butter  I was scraping the sauce and seasonings off the main ingredient of all the dishes except the pork buns.  It's like someone went into an Asian American home and just started mixing all the seasonings in the cupboard onto a dish.   You can't exactly pinpoint what the flavors are because there is sooo much going on, it's salty, sour, spicy, and buttery all at once but not the same flavor for each dish.    I recommend the pork buns.  Maybe the family style dishes are better, there were many large parties when we went.   But I don't think I'll go with just my bf again.

2t2ZUFacQkIIMdbCS6M70A.text: Thrilled that Momofuku has finally come to Las Vegas! Perfect location on the 2nd floor at The Cosmopolitan! Great that Milk Bar is next door. The food at Momofuku is delicious! The menu is large, and there is something that everyone will enjoy at all price points. Highly recommend the original pork ramen, the chicken Karaage buns, chicken katsu, steak, rotisserie chicken, mashed potatoes, foie gras with tuna. I had 3 dinners and 2 lunches, and everything was delicious! Service is friendly and attentive. Space looks great too! Great view of the Las Vegas Strip. Enjoy!
