F-P8nexHfaLd6wepjtePQA.text: Bo Ssam rice bowl is amazing!  One of the best things to eat in Vegas.  Also recommend the spicy cucumbers and chilled noodles. Thank you Momofuku!

rFHPID1Ax3DinNp54jDTuQ.text: Went here for dinner on a Wednesday night around 9pm. Place was fairly happening. I would suggest a reservation. Overall a good experience. I would go again to try different things.  Ambiance: typical hype vibe you would expect from Cosmo. People were dressed up as well as casual. There appeared to be an area for a big group if you need one.  Service: really good. Server came right out and explained the menu. Even gave me some sample sake to try out. Her recommendations were pretty good. Food. Some out in a timely fashion. Waters were refilled throughout.  Food: I was excited to try David Chang's food. The menu was pretty simple. The server mentioned that some of the items were not his classic things (i.e. Ramen) and he was trying to make it more "west coast". I felt that some of the items did not live up to the hype. We had the soft boiled egg. Not really a deviled egg and kinda salty with the salmon roe. Next we tried the scallop poke. It was interesting indeed. Kinda creamy/salty. I probably wouldn't get it again and prefer the more basic poke. The yellowtail sashimi was pretty good. Not fishy at all and very flavorful. We opted to try the cold chili noodle. This was one of the highlights. The amount of heat was just right. Tons of sausage. It was also a good portion. Great flavor. Finically, I had the pork bun. The pork was nice and fatty. Cooked perfectly. The bun was light and soft. Just the right amount of hoisin sauce. I would love to try the other buns. Overall, food was great but not outstanding. I would return to try some of the other items

zBsa1H7rIkpa8ssZtNPNGQ.text: The shiitake mushroom bun and the pork belly ramen were insanely good.

B4tpSWDxE1yp6GEOCow76w.text: We saw that this place had ramen so we came in for ramen. On the menu there was only a truffle ramen for about $40. We had to haggle to get the regular ramen menu which ended up being ok ramen. If the menu exists, why do I have to ask for it?? Also...Nothing as good as a hole in the wall place in L.A. Totally disappointed in our expensive and bland meal. Service was also subpar.

4MaPgn5CtmSTeafQMwoQNA.text: Great environment and food. One less star due to my confused waiter. Definitely try the pork belly bun.

S2aT4cPA2pd-7k7uZaRaJw.text: Our party of 4 came for dinner with reservations from open table and we were seated close to the windows. I appreciated the Vegas strip views and attentive wait staff.   Love: Chicken karaage Pork belly bun Pork chop  Crab deviled eggs   Like:  Spicy Cucumber   Dislike: NY steak

DwS2XNhXcLhoat3lK4FkBQ.text: I'm posting for the the criminally priced and portioned pork bun. It was incredibly small and flavorless. Such a overrated menu item.

W1eQSmKKSLf8tXracbNJpg.text: My Favorite Place For Japanese Snack  Takoyaki Is Good And I Recommended for coming here and try it

-RM2aTsjnMh6HSBNNvva7w.text: Fantastic, just like its NYC counterpart.  Mindblowing pork belly buns and scallop cerviche.  Order several things and share so you can try more for your money.  (Vegas isn't cheap people.) The ramen was enough for two of us to share, as well as the shrimp cocktail.

R0a8Q9ALLmi8m92q3yyGIA.text: Momofuku Las Vegas is the joint.  There's not a lot of bargains to be found on the strip, and even fewer in the Cosmo where this restaurant is located, but you can get a great meal at a reasonable price for Vegas.  It's Ramen, so it shouldn't be outrageous.  The shishito peppers are absolutely the best I've ever had, and I order them basically any time there on a menu in front of me.  This menu doesn't mention their secret ingredient, only saying "smoke salt and lime."  Chang's are tossed with nutritional yeast and while I could never picture how that would work with the pepper flavor, it's a stroke of genius.  Having been here before, I had to go twice in the 5 nights I was here recently, dragging as many coworkers with me as I could round up.  None of them was let down by any part of their meal.    The Pork Ramen does not appear on the dinner menu, only on the lunch and late night menus.  They dress it up with black truffle on the dinner menu and sling it for $50 or so.  No thanks.  I'm sure it's lovely, but for $50 I'm not eating ramen.  If you ask for the Pork ramen they'll still serve it at dinner time, and it's just outstanding.  I'm not sure how they get the egg to that consistency, it must be magic.  When you slice into it with your chopstick it's like an egg-asm in your bowl. The Dashi is every bit as good as you'd expect if you know who David Chang is.  The buns are great too, and if you have a few friends ready to share the menu offers family style meals like Bo Saam , an incredible roast pork dish for about $140, or fried chicken with caviar that you can spend $1500 on if you're a high roller or too drunk to read the prices.  This extravagance is offset by the Miller High Life that was the beer special a few months back.  Overall I love the vibe here, the food is outstanding, and it's a beacon of comfort food in a hot shot hotel that was a welcome surprise for me.  Enjoy!

MBChJfI0PhmeZkNlvZdv2w.text: The pork belly buns are amazing. They have really good buns, but the ramen is average. You are in Vegas so it's not like there's a lot of Ramen shops to compete with. The pork buns are definitely worth trying even though it's seven dollars for one of them. I personally don't think it's worth getting the Ramen here. But I have to say my review is up because I'm craving the pork belly bun with the special sauce. There are a lot of places to eat within Vegas but if you really need some pork bun then it's worth a try other than that you can get really good food for a better price.

lUGIEQiJ99Ae0JeXXcTALQ.text: Came here on a Sunday for early dinner at 6pm not really expecting to eat much but once we got here, it was on!  We got seated at the bar right away which I didn't expect since I thought we needed reservations.  We had really good service and the waiter took time to explain everything and was really nice about suggesting a few items for us.    Sitting at the bar was fun since we got to see them manning the deep fry section which makes things like the long beans and shishito peppers.   Sadly I don't remember the waiters name but I do know that the line cook, Aaron, Aron?, was also really good about checking up on us.  We even got a free sample after the expediter saw us pointing at something and he had them give us a sample.    Really good: Brussel sprouts - fried till crispy and mixed with like 10 things; its definitely a flavorful dish. Mussels Crack pie - its pretty tiny for the price and its overly sweet but its good. Good: Rotisserie chicken - the waiter made it sound better than it was but it was still a solid dish.  We asked for more kim chi but they only give it if you buy more.  Meatballs with beans - the bacon is very prominent.  This is a hardy dish, no wonder it cost $18.   Pork Buns - but nothing that normal chinese places serve and charge less for cereal milk ice cream - lighter than what I expected from a soft serve.   Skip: spicy rice cakes - maybe its because I don't like rice cakes so I didn't care for this dish

CaFbEr-Zk3EuDR8i0-hypw.text: Great drinks a and food. On the pricey side but worth it. Don't get the duck. Over priced for what you get.

Frz_Cl59jCgNi2KB-pElMg.text: Amazing. The whole experience was GREAT! I came to celebrate my birthday and quickly chose to eat at momofuku. Bring from SF, there's no momofuku so thankfully they brought one close by in LV! from the host, to the servers, and everything was amazing. Our server was great, we didn't get his name but he was so nice, funny, and really informative. He explained everything for use and the whole purpose of the restaurant. We got the shrimp bah mi, pork belly bah mi, beet salad, pork ramen and the chicken. Evrything was to die for. As simple as the bah mi is, it's packed with flavor. The pork ramen was so so so good, broth was very flavorful and the pork belly, don't get me started  . The chicken was so good too!! Overall the whole atmosphere is great, they treat you like family and welcomed. Definitely recommend it.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly ramen, to die for.
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp and pork belly bah mi. So good, the presentation was cute too.

8kSM740PHh4WcrVaF1tHtA.text: food was great.   1.00 for tap water is probably the douchiest move ive ever seen. i'll pay for whatever but. 1.00, tap water

0cRO1d5IuvA5cQ6MpE7ggA.text: Amazing meal from start to finish! Fun, family style dishes that everyone in our group loved. Service was spectacular as well! We also had delicious cocktails that were fun and interesting concoctions! I tried for a week to get a reservation on open table, but was unable to get the time our party of 4 needed. Luckily, we walked up and we're able to put our name in and only had to wait 25 minutes on busy Saturday night!

XNdelVz6CPfMYYKI3lhjvw.text: We sat at the bar and had a fantastic lunch -- seated right away. We ordered the Brussels sprouts with cauliflower, shiitake bun, lamb ribs, and chickpea ramen. Brussels sprouts had a fantastic crispiness but still soft, flavors were bright and savory. Lamb ribs were a 10/10 would order again -- crunch on the outside really tender on the inside, right amt of fat, super tasty yogurt and cucumber to contrast the lamb. Shiitake bun had an awesome texture and flavor mushrooms were unfortunately wayyyyyy to salty as was the chickpea ramen. The ramen had an amazing flavor with great texture to the noodles the issue was the broth was so salty it was unenjoyable and we left most of it behind. Price was on point for the quality of food -- i get that you can get ramen and buns for a lot cheaper elsewhere but you're obviously paying a premium for a unique spin.

JmYTl9vY6Ue5R90d2MW4aw.text: Daniel Gabai made our night 5 stars apart from the fact the food and ambiance is spectacular. Will come back again and again. Love this place !

eERyXICXcBPBQO6EsIkIsA.text: Food I got was the Karage chicken, the tuna with fois gras, and ramen.   Honestly this place is over hyped. The food was good don't get me wrong, but the price that it was at didn't match up.   Service was kind of lagging. My friends and I were sitting around long after our dinner was done waiting for the check. A lot of waiters standing around but I'm assuming they were getting ready for the dinner rush that happened.   I would definitely try Momofuku again but on the East Coast

tdYmd0W1rIg4_VVhQg1MwA.text: Maybe I'm being a little harsh giving three stars but dropping $700 on a dinner for 6 and having to ask for our drinks twice and having our starters mixed up is not up to speed for this venue.having said that the food was amazing and I would still go back.

_O7RY7XyaKxkAsVP1cxH4Q.text: Loved our experience here! We had the bigeye tuna, branzino, and the wagyu tri-tip. Our server recommended all these dishes so we went with his suggestion. Great combinations that paired well with wine they recommended. We ended with crack pie from the milk bar + coffee. Great overall experience! Total was around $325 FYI

UP4v0vFAgDps_8aofXFTtA.text: very appropriately located in the super hip cosmopolitan. i had a bowl of their namesake pork ramen and a pork belly bao, which hit the spot for my asian food cravings in vegas.

A34SihOadnu6SvlprCxpZA.text: I went there for 2nd time in this year for lunch with family. Just love all the dishes.

vmNAhq-mISFEjcHv8n6oBQ.text: If you are on the strip, this is a good option. As with everything else on the strip, Momofuku is busy, and despite having a reservation we still waited 20 minutes to be seated.  The food was overall good... the service subpar. Almost felt similar to more airport restaurants in regards to service.  We lucked out and had some nice table Neighbors who liked sharing some food with us. The Pork Shoulder was good, the Pork Belly Buns were even great (serious, these were awesome), but the Chilled Sichuan Sausage Ramen was not the best. It was far more heavy than any other Ramen I've had, and I ended up only finishing half of it at best.  Drink prices as you'd suspect, were exorbitantly high. We're talking $9 Coors Banquet bottle. And no, that wasn't what I was drinking.

u8Q5mX45_hzzx2On40CCCQ.text: The food and the services don't worth the money. We waited for a long time to get our food. And the food is overpriced. The bun is $8 per piece with only 1 small piece of meat and a little vegetables inside! The noodles are too dry and tasteless. The chicken costs $29 but it's just a half roasted chicken with nothing on the side. I don't recommend this place.

P7Q0VK-YfBKiatHzc6zDow.text: Had a really great experience here. We ordered the spicy cucumber salad (creamy, fresh, a little spice), pork bun (perfection), mushroom bun (seriously, texture on the mushrooms was divine), lamb (how is it so perfect, not a spice out of line and all flavors working together delightfully), and mushroom noodles (starchy, hearty, yummy). Oh, absolutely get the "flask" it's like 4 drinks in one and you get to keep the flask - aromatic, well-balanced, a very nice drink. Had to deduct a star after trying our two neighboring tables' food. The branzino was past it's "best by" date and a little fishy, its sauce wasn't as balanced as the flavors on our table. The pesto with the sausage noodles wasn't an expected combination, but it was fine. The flank steak, I couldn't even finish the small bite shared with me it was so tough and flavorless. No joy in that dish. Salt+pepper seafood was salty as expected. I saw a table send back the shishito peppers for being far too salty, but I didn't try them. I could visually see the salt-dusting on top was excessive. If I hadn't tried the other tables' food, this would be a 5-star food+experience review. I was surprised to find disappointment in the other dishes, since what we ordered was so delightful. Since the fun dishes are all for 4-6 people, we'll have to bring some friends back with us next time to try them out. Wish they had some portion sizes geared toward parties of two. Hopefully they'll consider adding that option to the menu in the future.

h2qHufRVKvnw9JYHmzpQ-A.text: It was a really amazing meal. All of the food was outstanding and the service was great. The only dish that we didn't love was the roasted corn but everything else was phenomenal! It was pricey but worth it.

4PyiLEmTx9f9-gfgwvuRpw.text: I went here twice during my stay in Las Vegas. I am very familiar with the restaurant in many locations. The food was consistently great but the service at this location was off the charts. My group sat at the bar and lost track of time and the staff never nudged us or gave us dirty looks but rather were totally welcoming. It was exceptional service and I am totally impressed.  Go here for a meal and service you will remember!

xrjYSsKsWxmil8TBxjVSuQ.text: Ahi and foie gras was amazing. The rest of it was good, but not so fabulous. Not a kid-friendly menu. And, the damn menu changes, so what you think is a staple that you see on Yelp is not available when you get there, i.e., truffle ramen and ramen eggs. Boo. Awesome wait staff. So-so hostesses out front. Probably wouldn't return, even though I love watching Chef David Chang on Netflix. Haven't given up on him, yet. Will try Ko before deciding whether or not to give up altogether.

XVjYfr_PqXVmd5Kv2t1IPg.text: The service is excellent. However, price is so expensive although the food isnot tasty after all. It costs you more than $100 for 5 people with 1 burn for each, 1 noodle and a dozen of oyster. It's small and you can eat 5 pieces of burn. Then you can pay around $300.

ZD0MiUsQnvVcIsyD2XWv8Q.text: Great healthy meal with the best ingredients. I had the ginger scallion noodle dish and pork belly bun. I've been to the NY and D.C. Ones before and Las Vegas did not disappoint as well. I would highly recommend. I love watching them make the food, very clean kitchen. I would recommend the come chai with me drink. Don't leave without the cereal flavored milk ice cream or the birthday cake milkshake/ regular cake from Milk!

BwG0-6_QZIR4pTpTJqwYIg.text: Wow! We just wandered in for a late lunch- blown away at how tasty and inventive the dishes were.  This is now a "must eat" for any of my Las Vegas trips.

ZwtkhgrY4mXN0tY0p7-L2g.text: Went at Monday afternoon. Got that modern vibe. Had the Chilled Spicy Noodle. It was pretty good.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

_FoFza9hc8fdTVbsxLbqEg.text: Our waiter Josh was da bomb. So friendly and put us at ease for my wife's nut allergy. Food & drink he recommended were delish. Best meal in Vegas so far.

qjUURWw2723yTKOoXgmLkQ.text: The vibes are modern. Service is alright. When asking the  serving size of the dish we were looking to order our serves said 5-6 ounces or 4-5 bites. Not a huge deal but would have been nice to know ahead of time how big they actually were. The sliders were amazing though. The shrimp one is the best one  service was quick and the food was tasty

mJjch_-WV0DnFEYoSyY4tg.text: The service was awesome. The ambiance was just right-modern- busy- but not crazy busy.  Good vibes. The drinks were phenomenal. We ordered s drink made with mezcal and it was delicious. The food was the best we had in Vegas that weekend. The short ribs literally melted in your mouth they were so tender. The Bronzino wa sour of this world. Overall a great experience.

HLs0JWB6v9E3H18kehqlKA.text: You must order lamb! Best dish! Five spice duck is also delicious. It is not americans, is more asian fusion cusine.

U2liJO1ixWgooPEoydXifw.text: Really disappointing, especially for such high prices. Don't understand all the hype. The jidori chicken was tough and gristly.  Made one of our party sick to his stomach. The rice cakes and pork belly bao were good, but no better than what I've had elsewhere at a fraction of the cost.  We abandoned most of the food on the table uneaten and went upstairs to Secret Pizza. Nice decor and music, and attentive service, though.

irrOPshBbJ2i0Rl85qOdjg.text: Shiitake steambuns, delicious Ramen, and a frozen mojito that you can take poolside.....are just a few of my favorite things. Amazing.

Vu5WCGA9ES_2w7yau0rEqQ.text: Appalling service. Our party of 6 had a reservation weeks in advance and 30 minutes post reservation time we were still not seated. The three hostesses were completely incompetent and were just plain ignoring us. We were first told that our table was being set up and ten minutes later the same response. Each of the three hostesses would go back to "check on the table" only to return a minute later and whisper to their co-hostess. After another 10 minutes a party that arrived after us with no reservation was seated; at this point we had had enough and left. I would not return to this establishment, the service was absolutely disgusting.

d6iM0UlcuBSAffDf5MWhIQ.text: Pork Belly Buns. Chicken Noodle Soup. Black Winter Truffle Ramen.  Quite Tasty.

YD0rA2-CbP3k3xBcRpn-eQ.text: Came here for dinner with a reservation from Open Table. We arrived in Las Vegas one hour earlier and they were gracious enough to bump up our reservation and seat us immediately. That was just the beginning of great service. Our server and other people serving in the dining area were all friendly and pleasant. Water glasses are always filled, your napkin is folded when you leave the table, they ask if you have questions. The place does get loud but the decor is beautiful. I love the view of the strip from our table. They have a seating area that you climb some steps to get too and there is a sliding sort of wooden window that they can close for privacy if you have a private party or open for just casual dining.  We ordered (1) chicken karaage buns - the burst of flavors in this bun is wonderful. The bun itself is soft and sweet which contrast perfectly against the crispiness and  savory flavor of the chicken. This is a must! (2) Spicy Sichuan Rice Cakes - pork sausage, broccoli, crispy onions. We had no idea what to expect with this dish and it surprised us in a great way. The mix of textures and flavors are amazing. A winner. (3) Pork Ramen - pork belly & shoulder, slow poached egg. This is not the ramen I am accustomed to. It is not as fatty and flavorful as the tonkotsu ramen that I prefer but it was also good. I love how al dente the noodle is.  If you are from the West Coast and have been waiting to try chef David Chang's creation, you must visit Momofuku at Cosmopolitan. Don't forget to make a reservation.

8mU1QurXSKDuKpE5Yt80pg.text: Had high expectations for this place.  Food was okay, service was all over the place.  It wasn't the same server who served us through the dinner.  Different servers keep asking us same thing over and over.  "How's everything?" Us-"well we are missing such and such" server-"let me check on that".  THAN another server comes asking same thing and we repeat.  Happened 3 times.  1 wrong food order.  2 missing drinks, (there were 9 of us and only ordered 3 drinks, 1 came out) 1 food never came out.  And part of the group did chef's choice and we told them diet restrictions and told them one of our friend was pregnant.  First thing they served, RAW oysters.  Then some sort of raw fish....we are like come on.....not worth of the price or the hype!

8Ljc6maJ7caUaV0mcneyVQ.text: OMG, the food is amazing ! And the Service is top notch. This place could give lessons to Sage at Aria on how to treat diners.  I highly recommend this restaurant. There was nothing on the menu, that we orders, that was not incredible. And I can't say enough about the service, totally incredible.

Rll6XHSjuxmhXhhjby4k_A.text: Ordered pork belly ramen and karaage bao.  I loved the bao, chicken was crispy, sauce tasty, and the slaw good. My friend ordered the pork belly bao and she likes it as well. I was hoping to try the spicy chicken sandwich but got full quickly.  The pork belly ramen is okay. To me, it was salty. The other components in the ramen was good tho. I hope to try their full menu for lunch or dinner next time.

6WkQ9Scyjw85wE9FQN9Zkg.text: Warm and polite staff. Food was unreal. Thought the Country Ham plate would be a boring dish, but it was delicious. And I would eat the Lamb Ribs all day every day.

_WNsVV3coEbbX2-hRLlc2w.text: I went with two friends and we all ordered different items. The waitress helped me decide between two and I went with the Chilled Spicy Noodles. Great choice! Very salty but I love salt. One friend got the chicken katsu and the other got the pork ramen. The noodles are definitely the right amount of spicy. We were not impressed with with Ramen but few places can compare to Ramen Sora. The hostesses don't seem very friendly but our waitress was incredible. They also own Milk which is next door so we ordered our dessert from there. Everything was very rich and delicious!

The pork belly bao was also delicious but I would not order it again.  I don't really understand the concept of upscaling foods that are supposed to be cheap and affordable and tastes just as delicious as the normal ones.  They do have other items on the menu that seem unique for those with unlimited budget.

MCV1nvsEyM04apvauXC7Xw.text: CHECK YOUR CHARGES. I was charged an extra $50.00 that they are claiming I tipped when I clearly did not write that on the receipt. I am currently going through disputing the charge which they keep disputing back. Why would I tip $60.00 on a $50.00 and mediocre service?

IHhYwZmPRfT5nNpXM0bwkA.text: 1st things 1st, if you're debating to eat here make a reservation! Not sure why this place is popular and gets booked but I suppose you should experience it yourself and determine that. My party was lucky enough to be seated with a great view of the strip including the Paris Eiffel Tower which was a nice touch.   Service: attentive and always refills water. But they didn't serve water with ice or offer it--odd.   Food: Pork Ramen - get if you love the taste of pork with a smokey tasting broth which could be due to the addition of pulled pork.   Spicy Sichuan Rice - it says it comes with pork sausage and broccoli with onions but you won't find sausage that looks like whole sausage. The sausage is cut in small pieces which for me gets drowned with the vision of onions. Broccoli also seems non existent as you don't see whole broccoli or even florets of it. Must've been cut into really small pieces. Tho, the rice is crispy which is nice.   Pork Bao bun - 1 bun is pretty filling on its own. Pretty good. Would recommend at least trying it.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

BIzEGK3lrVAycdSvsxbBmg.text: Momofuku is a great addition to the Cosmopolitan and definitely fits in with its' cool, lively vibe.  Easily got reservations for lunch on a Sunday the day of.  The restaurant space looks a lot smaller than it actually is from the outside.  Once you enter and make a right, there's a larger, bright space with more tables and a view of that side of the strip.  Service was really great from everyone, our waiter was really nice, helpful and attentive.  The whole experience was superb.  My husband got the pork bun and LOVED it.  I got the roasted mussels and fried brussels sprouts.  The roasted mussels were tasty, sprinkled with their special furikake.  The fried brussels spouts were packed with flavor but were definitely on the oily side.  But overall, the dishes were really good.  I definitely would recommend you to try it out. Dessert is all from Milk next door so that was a little disappointing.  I've never been to the other Momofuku but if it's like this location I'm sure I would love it.  I would definitely come back the next trip to Vegas.

SK4YcXJVw5-pTFwVxg9fmA.text: My husband and I were seated at Momofuku at 4:30 on a Thursday when this restaurant was pretty slow. In 10 minutes no one so much as acknowledged us after we were seated while servers and bartenders talked with each other behind the bar. Needless to say we left and went over to China Poblano where they took our order right away:)

0qWweQZWiQ0GyvPMBLnGWg.text: Disappointing. 5 stars for the amazing pork belly but everything other than the pork belly was so disappointing.  The ramen was decent, the only thing special about the ramen was the ridiculously good pork belly.   Shishito peppers didn't taste much like anything.  The chicken katsu with shiitake mushroom gravy was sour. It could have been great. The katsu was good and the gravy tastes good initially, but then the sour vinegar taste sets in and it's all you taste.  There are so many other places much more deserving of your time and money. Come for the best pork belly you've ever had but don't expect anything else here to be good.

-RiF-9zJzsXwfFt1GdCcgQ.text: Update:::: the manager messaged me to apologize and offer us drinks. I thought this was very nice of him. We couldn't take him up in his offer since we were busy and leaving town but I'm happy they have the good sense to know when they may have made a mistake. It's worth coming back  . . . Review before update-   Yummy noodles but a bit annoyed because we came for lunch and it wasn't crowded but our drinks took forever to get our drinks. Pretty much when we were done eating.  UPDATE: the manager is awesome and reached out to me immediately. He offered to make it right. We never had time to go back and take him up on it. But the concern was heard and so I'm bumping up to 4 stars thanks again!

4IIR8OHkMDmIR2_YOfl-LA.text: Amazing tasting food. We except for a day later when 3/5 of our dinner party gets severe diarrhea and stomach cramps. You guys need to clean up your act in the kitchen. We're thinking it was one of the chicken buns that got us. And it's probably from the meat, because of the delayed onset.   Tasted great, but we're still paying the price for eating at your restaurant.

Q-ndiiY9jIMAtjcEdo0W1g.text: Had a wonderful experience here with my boyfriend a few weeks ago. Our server Josh really made it an incredible and memorable experience, he was personable, funny, on point, and surprised us with a few dishes we absolutely loved. The food was awesome too, we got the crab for two and it was both delicious and decadent. We will definitely come back to this place at the Cosmopolitan next time we're in town, which is pretty often since we live in Los Angeles.

puJL_5OtIxwpoFSeswUn_g.text: The duck is amazing. Wish I had a bigger stomach. I'll try other things if we come to Vegas.

afHfHvSzLolbx6To6rCQSA.text: What an amazing meal. Started with big eye tuna (my favorite menu item), roasted mussels, salt & pepper lobster, amazing salad and ended with crack pie. Sat at the grill area and it's the best seat in the house. Chef Steve was great and I quickly made friends with other food enthusiasts at the grill. Ended up sharing plates with a videographer from CNN....totally cool and fun night!

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Must end with a little crack pie...just pure sugar and butter with some cereal milk ice cream of course. Life is good!

QI-2p_Dy-6nz6DL2bjqssg.text: My first experience with Momofuku was trying their Cereal milk soft serve in NYC which I loved. Here, my husband & I shared the shrimp buns, the shishito peppers & the ginger scallion noodles with chili oil. We really enjoyed the buns but the peppers & noodles were okay at best. The peppers were not worth $9. The ginger flavor in the noodles doesn't stand out & the chili oil has zero spiciness to it. I don't know if it was the time of day we came (3:30pm) or the fact that were very busy but I've had better noodles elsewhere. I would honestly try the other locations in NYC if you can but don't recommend this one.

X5we_z_Xjf8XRFNZTBkIjA.text: It was a nice surprise to see Momofuku and Milk as new additions to the cosmopolitan. I think these are great restaurants and its much closer than NYC! I went to Momofuku in NYC a couple of years ago and FELL IN LOVEEEE with their pork belly bun. probably the best I've had in life (so far)!!    I have visited this Las Vegas location twice now and had the pork buns both times. the first time the pork belly melted in my mouth and was soft and tender, reminding me of my experience in NYC. The second time here, the pork was not as tender but still good and great flavor. The server recommended the Chicken bun saying it was their top seller, so I tried one of those too. I feel the chicken had a bit too much batter but a good Asian flavor ( I think it had a hint of ginger in there). Overall.... Pork Bun Over Chicken and everything else I will probably always make a stop here anytime I'm in Vegas for a pork bun or 2.

Arhuws9pSDarBGfC5PvS4Q.text: I have been to the momofuku in NYC and I had to try the ramen here. The service is excellent, the atmosphhere is great, the hours (10am-2am) are awesome.   The ramen I was not happy with. The pork belly was amazing, and the noodles were very good, but the broth was very thin like a clear chicken soup or udon broth, not very tonkotsu like at all. I get that his ramen is different, but I was hoping for the rich almost creamy tonkotsu broth with this ramen. That being said, it was tasty, but not what I wanted or expected. I did not get a chance to try the pork belly buns, but given how awesome the pork belly was in the ramen, I will be back to try that. I will not be back for ramen, did not satisfy my craving. Some of the best ramen in the country is just up the road at Monta Ramen in Vegas... it beats all the best places in LA and NYC in my opinion.

BVVTxXezml0uAqRHgVhK7g.text: Momofuku is located on the 2nd floor by the Chandelier Bar in the Cosmo. Walk-in tables and bar seating in the front. No outdoor seating. Open for dinner only during the first couple of weeks.  *~Our Order on 1/22/2017~* Pork Belly Bun: ($14) hoisin, scallion, cucumber Chicken Karaage Bun: ($14) spicy mayo, pickled red onion, iceberg Shiitake Bun: ($12) hoisin, scallion, cucumber Pommes Puree: ($8) Kimchi Stew: ($24) pork shoulder, rice cakes, roasted onion Ginger Scallion: ($17) pickled shiitake, cucumber, wakame Pork Ramen: ($18) pork belly & shoulder, slow poached egg Black Winter Truffle Ramen: ($58) perigord truffles, egg yolk  The pork belly in the bun is fairly thick and not too crispy (which I like but one person in our prefers it to be crispy). Some people in the group actually preferred the Chicken Karaage bun over the Pork Belly. Wouldn't order the Shiitake Bun again (even though I love mushrooms). Same goes for the Truffle Ramen. Even though it was very fragrant, the broth completely overpowered and you could barely taste the truffles. The mashed potatoes were very light & airy, and actually pretty good. BF regretted ordering the Ginger Scallion ramen. Everyone else said their dishes were "ok" but wouldn't go out of their way to eat again. We did like the QQ (or "bite") of the noodles tho. If we HAD to come back we would only order the buns, but for about $7/bun, we didn't feel it was worth it.  Getting seated was an absolute nightmare (and why the 1 star)! I came at 5:15PM since they open the doors at 5:30PM and saw that no one was in line yet. I had a flight to catch and wanted to see if our group of 9 would be able to get seated earlier than our 6PM reservation time (only 30min earlier).  I was told no as they were "setting up the table." I was debating if we should just sit at the bar for walk-ins (they didn't have any tables for larger than a group of 4 in the front end) but as I told the hostess of the time restraint, I thought we would get seated in time. We even gave the hostess all of our orders so that the food would be ready by the time we would get seated.   BIG MISTAKE. We should've just sat at the bar. Only after many inquires about when we were going to be seated, we got seated 25min AFTER our reservation time. Our table was in the very back of the restaurant and we saw that ALL the tables were already setup and not even 1/4 of the restaurant was full. Our entire group was baffled as to why we couldn't be seated earlier. THEN, when the waitress asked for our order and we informed her that we already submitted it with the hostess, our waitress found out it was never entered. By now, everyone was starving and fed up with the experience and was on the verge of leaving. Our waitress said that luckily the items we would like to order would not take long so we were convinced to stay. One of our friends (who used to be a manager of a high-end hotel) insisted on speaking to a manager tho and the only response we got from the manager was, "I'm sorry but I don't know what to tell you." Service right there folks! The chef did send out a pickle plate as an "apology" but after a taste, no one really cared for any of the pickled items (even my BF who LOVES pickles!).  NO ONE in our group said they would return. Not sure how service can be so poor when one of their restaurants was able to get two Michelin stars. Shame since we're in Vegas many times in a year.

hPLg969_TVTRv6PnRSmpTg.text: What can you say about this place the service the food and the atmosphere everything is unbelievable

u0t0ODvxjr-a3ahKIUCKRQ.text: Very big fan of David Chang but never got a chance to eat at his restaurants. Really enjoyed his show on Netflix ugly delicious and I really wanted to try out Momofuku when I had a trip scheduled to Vegas. This location is in he Cosmopolitan and is right next to Milk bar. Very awesome environment and really good music playing in the restaurant. Nothing is better to eat noodles while Wu Tang is playing  When we got there, it was a lunch menu which was very limited but had want I wanted to try out. We ordered the shishito peppers, pork belly buns, ginger scallion noodles and the spicy fried chicken sandwich. Lots of items but each could be shared.  Starting with the shishito peppers, they're good but nothing too special about them. Kind of a standard pepper with an added taste of salt and lime. Probably won't be something I would order next time  The pork belly buns are a super thick cut of pork belly with a hoisin sauce and super delicious spicy cucumbers wrapped in a nice soft bun. Really awe dish and pretty filling in my opinion. Order these!  I really came here to try out the ginger scallion noodles and they are really good. They have a nice mix of mushrooms, scallions, wakame with a really delicious ginger garlic sauce. The noodles tasted great but I think I ate the noodles incorrectly at first. I felt like it needed a little more sauce on the entire dish but I found out you should of mixed the entire dish to really get that delicious sauce on everything. Maybe there should of been so instructions on how to make them but I figured it out eventually. Once the who dish was mixed with the sauce, it was delicious! Great dish for sure  The Spicy Fried Chicken sandwich sounded super good and to be honest It was so good! The size of the sandwich isn't too big, but the taste was for sure excellent! It has this pepper sauce that reminds me of gochujang sauce with a nice bite from the cucumbers. Perfectly fried chicken with a nice bun. All around a good dish!  All in all, good restaurant and looking forward to try out some dishes next time with the full menu. Also don't forget to try out Milk bar after

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ginger Scallion Noodles. Good amount of noodles and really good. Mix everything together to get the sauce all throughout the dish

cx5z-yP0GUW9xjuCpN6ssw.text: Thank you again, David Chang! I usually frequent his noodle bar whenever I am in New York City to order the pork belly buns. This Las Vegas of Momofuku is like a mixture of Ssam bar and his noodle bar. There are many Momofuku staples on the menu such as the pork buns and truffle ramen.   The restaurant is large and has a lot of room for open kitchen bar seating. I personally ordered the pork buns and they did not disappoint at all, really tasty! For my entree, I ordered the tomahawk pork chop that was accompanied with yams. The pork chop Tasted like a steak and was grilled to perfection.  The prices are reasonable and the same as the NYC locations. For dessert, they are located right next to milk bar (Christina Tosi's baby). Milk bar serves the milk bar staples like cereal milk, crack pie, and the layered confetti cake. It's like a Momofuku family in cosmo

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

L6kwzXvyk8IyUNVh6n1Ldw.text: Pork belly buns were legit!  I could've eaten a whole meal of just those and left happy, especially with the ssam sauce.  The truffle ramen was delicious, but I love truffle and not everyone does so unless you love truffle flavor I wouldn't get it because it's very forward on the truffles.    We also got the short rib stew and the burrata in the stew was a nice touch, but with my wife being Korean and making a similar type stew (without the burrata) it wasn't as impressive a dish to me.  Everything tasted great and service was excellent!

pSH70bD07V-1ADEOYv8oQg.text: I originally had Momofuku in New York and I remember it was delicious but my experience at the Vegas location was not that great.   We ordered the pork ramen, pork buns, ginger scallion noodles, and the honeycrisp apple salad.   The pork ramen was alright. I wish it could've been warmer and the soup was pretty salty. It wasn't bad but it wasn't that great either.   The worst part of my experience was the ginger scallion noodles. This is seriously the worst dish so PLEASSSEEE DO NOT ORDER!!!!! This dish was so salty. It was miserable to eat and bite into the dish. We ended up eating not even half of the dish because it tasted so bad. Every bite was so salty and I couldn't understand why they would choose to put this dish out on the menu from a restaurant by David Chang.   Another reason why I was so disappointed by this restaurant was the honeycrisp apple salad. This dish was literally sliced apples with marinated kimchi on the apples. It was literally sliced apples and they charged $16 for it. Are you kidding me?!?!  The only reason I gave this place two stars was for the pork buns and the service. It's a bummer that most of the food we ordered were so salty.  I honestly don't think this place is worth the money.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ginger Scallion Noodles
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Honeycrisp Apple Salad
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Ramen and Pork Buns

vgMBl0JhYixQ1QN1ZENqjg.text: We had a great time at Momofuku, from the service to the dishes...it was pretty amazing!  We got there 15 mins early and were seated right away. Our server Danielle (D) was great. She had great suggestions on the menu and was even able to get us a half order of the salt and pepper lobster and shrimp. This dish usually serves 3-4, so being a party of 2, it would have been too much food. The place wasn't as busy so we were able to enjoy the half portion thanks to D and the kitchen.  We started off with the pork belly buns, which was a perfect starter. The pork belly was perfectly cooked and the pickled cucumbers couple perfectly with the fatty meat. We also ordered the cold chili garlic noodles, which had an amazing flavor but were SPICY! The spice goes away as you move on to other parts of the meal, but if you can't handle spice...this isn't the dish for you. We enjoyed all the food and chased it with the Yuzu lemonade and a wicked garden drink. Both were tart and tasty. Lastly, we ended the night with the crack pie a la mode from the mill bar. The thin delicious pie and the cereal milk ice cream wrapped up a perfect meal.  This has definitely been one of our favorite dining experiences in Las Vegas. It really makes a difference when not only the food is good. But the service is immaculate and curated for each guest! Highly recommended!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cold chili garlic noodle. Spicy and yummy!
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crack pie a la mode! Sooo good!
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Salt and pepper lobster/shrimp...half order with peppers. Soooo yummy.

LvOBjryKMwdUjuFfDB00Wg.text: Needs more noodles on the menu.                     Everything is good here. If you don't like noodles there are a lot of options. My other favorite is the shosito peppers.

UKAmt8cDiDfgZXtOAkBYww.text: Second Time here always with large group.  Up front - they are pricey, so not for the faint of wallet. As for the quality, let's start from the top.  Service: They are always busy, but they have a lot of people on the floor, so it's not hard to get the attention of anyone. However, since they are busy, our actual waitress only occasionally checked in on us.  4/5  Drinks: Quite delicious - they have a large selection, but we stuck with mixed drinks A few looked quite interesting and unique, but we stuck to some classics - whiskey and thyme & honey ginger gin. Overall, great drinks and served quickly.  They did not have any beer, it was a bit odd to hear - they said it would take AN HOUR to get a keg open, so taking a point off for that  4/5  Food: We got a large selection of food, so I'll list them out: Shishito peppers Green beans Special rice cake Scallion noodles Rack of lamb Pork shoulder  The appetizers came pretty quickly - great service and the quality of the peppers was great actually. Always get these. The green beans were cooked in sweet and sour sauce and MAN did they have a strong flavor. Great to start with!  The scallion noodles hit the spot - they added shiitake mushrooms, so there was a good amount of meatiness to them.  The lamb came after - a bit small for a full rack in my opinion. We asked for the sauce on the side. Lamb itself tasted great, but I'm glad the sauce was separate since the lamb tasted better without.  We had some rice cakes, super spicy!  The pork shoulder came last. Comes with oysters and MAN is this guy huge and good tasting. MUST HAVE. 5/5 for food  Overall I rate the place a 4.5/5 But since I can't give partial reviews on Yelp, it is getting a 4/5 total.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

NF8G475VUCDc-spuZ_ORMQ.text: I don't think I can even write them a proper review!  I've been hearing so many good things about this place and seeing all the delicious looking food in photos on social media.  I came here only one time and it was with a large group.  We didn't order very many items though because we weren't ready to splurge on so little.  (Eg, prime rib was $100, so we'd be paying $10 for a tiny tiny piece of meat.)  PORK BELLY BUN.  The menu says an order includes two buns, but our waitress let us order single ones for the same price ($7 each).  Everyone in my group got one - some even ordered two.  EVERYONE loved this.  I would say it's a must try!  They offered a special sauce with gochujang as the base, but I didn't like it very much.  I would have preferred normal gochujang to eat with the bun for that spicy kick.  MISO BLACK COD.  This one was like $50-some, but came out to like four pieces.  I only got to try a tiny bit, but it was soo salty.  The mushrooms and greens were ok but salty as well.  I never drink water (it makes me full), and I actually finished my glass.  COLD CHILI GARLIC NOODLES.  $16 for a bowl.  The fried garlic toppings and chopped chilies made the dish.  I loved the flavor.  I forgot that you have to ask for the ramen because it's on a secret menu... I'll have to try it again on my next Vegas trip!  Service was really good.  We had two people waiting on us, which may have been extra, but soo helpful!

pFc6kBKf0zYnNV-LVsxlfQ.text: We dined here for a snack before getting ready and heading to dinner. It was the perfect amount of food to hold us over and all of the dishes were delightful. My boyfriend started out with the pork belly buns, which he LOVED. I ordered the spicy cucumbers small plate. I have had plenty of cucumber salads at Japanese and Asian restaurants and these were quite different but very good! I loved the crunch of the toasted almonds on top. Lastly we ordered the ham sampler, which was very, very thin slices of two types of ham. That came with delicious biscuits and like a mustard like sauce. I am usually not a fan at all of ham in any forms but these slices were similar to carpaccio and were AMAZING!   Overall great food and service! Wished we had more time to try other items on their menu!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Biscuits with ham- so good!
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tasting of county hams
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Cucumber salad

q3lGuREy24rilC9BQiSH8g.text: Given how many reviews are praising the pork belly buns, I got a little hyped up and now I gotta be critical about them.  Is the flavor good? Yes I'm not going to deny that. However, the Pork to everything else ratio is so terrible that I think it brings it down! Its a HUGE serving of pork belly (which helps justify its price), but many does it feel unbalanced as a dish.  You have to HOPE that your pork's meat to fat ratio and distribution is good, otherwise, you're bites consist of a really fatty, delicate bites, or really lean meat bites.  For some, that is a draw, for me, it feels like they are not harmonizing with each other and giving me the best of both worlds (or, I have to inhale the whole thing in one bite, which is a choking hazard :) )  Related to that, I don't feel like there is enough, or strong enough pickles that help cut through the fattiness and really brighten it up.  Anecdotally, when I make Pork belly buns, I make quick pickled red onions which can cut right through the fattiness if you need to refresh your palette. The bun itself is barely large enough to contain the pork belly as well.  If I had the choice, I would make it half as thick; more opportunity to increase the char to meaty/fatty ratio, and a couple more pickles.  Again, that's just my taste.   Especially if y'all are leading into the the ramen which itself is can be very rich.  I had the Bo Ssam bowl which is excellent and I highly recommend btw.  Great variety of flavors and textures!

gzqS9a3w7-s8XqWvWKaLIg.text: I've heard about Momofuku in NY but never went so I'm glad I got the chance to visit in Vegas! I got a reservation very easily at opentable so hopefully you can do the same as well.  The prices are a little high but it's Vegas so what do you expect. It's about $20+ per person not including drinks.  The shishito peppers were tasty. they were very soft (not crispy at all) and showered with some dried lime seasoning. My parents usually don't like eating peppers straight but they liked these. Also note that about 10% of shishito peppers are spicy so it's like playing roulette!  I got the cold garlic noodles and thought they were decent. It got spicy the more you eat it! I thought the sauce was a pinch too sweet but other than that it was good. The chicken was an extra $6 but I liked how flavorful the chicken was. It was a pinch too dry in some cases but flavor was good.  The jidori chicken bowl had similar chicken and it was tasty.  The ramen bowl seemed to be under seasoned according to 3 people who got ramen at my table.  If you get water for the table they use Vero water which tastes really good. It tastes so pure!

aKiU1hVi0aHMrlfMAFzp9Q.text: Bosam bowl, shoyu pork bowl, 1 pork belly bun $7. $2 shitake mushroom extra. Pork belly buns were good just like most places I had elsewhere so can't say I need to come back to Vegas for pork belly buns at momofuku.   I didn't really like shoyu pork bowl. The flavor was a bit off/bland. The slab of pork belly was sad, not much. And I hate the idea of having to pay extra for vegetables or whatever that's needed to make the entree taste right. If it needs certain ingredients to make it taste better it should be included and bring up the price instead of making it look cheap then after all the add ons it costs more.   Bosam bowl was interesting, sticky rice colored with kimchi sauce, can't say I didn't like it but it was nothing out of this world where I can say I want to come back for more!   This location is on the same floor and right next to Eggslut. It was not as busy when we were here compared to eggslut so that was a plus.  Service was fast and friendly but that alone may not bring me back.

Z7D2QNAHBUNiBH8uyi8XKQ.text: My son introduced me to David Chang via Netflix.  Told me we HAD to go this place while in Vegas.  Glad I listened to him.  Tremendous flavors here, people.  Check it out.

-pwLI4oJiRYgHyS65rrC0Q.text: Dropped bank here and was totally worth it.  We started with the pork belly buns  - mouth watering. Then we had three of the large format dishes (to serve 9)including the duck, the shrimp & lobster and the waygu. We   In all everything was sublime and the service was spot on. Perfect Vegas spot.  P.s. order the Negroni for drinks

41URGC7mHunvBe79KIwwNw.text: I love everything Momofuku and eat at their restaurant any chance I get.  The Las Vegas location reminds me of a grander version of the original location in New York. The open kitchen concept is still a main focus and the food is just as amazing.  My only suggestion would be to add more single person dishes to the menu as most of the entrees offered are for winter large groups or for two and up.   My ramen and pork buns were delicious and the Crack Pie is truly a wonderful sensory experience.

aCb072BV2NnrF-Jxzdn2qg.text: One of the main reasons for my visit to Vegas was to try Momofuku and it did not disappoint.  I'm a fan!    Ordered:   1) Miso Black Cod ($52): Delicious!  It was melt in your mouth tender.  It came with 2 pieces served with mushrooms, roasted carrots and baby bok choy in a vegetable broth.  The carrots were a little hard though :(       2) Pork Belly Buns (2 pcs-$14): Mmm, one of the best pork belly buns I've ever had.    3) Shoyu Pork Ramen ($17): it was good but not amazing.  The ramen isn't listed in the dinner menu but can be requested.

EzS8wl49OySkbjvNY1XiWw.text: I have eaten a lot of ramen over the years all around the world. By far this was the best I have had in the US. I wasn't completely sold because a lot of Vegas hot spots don't live up to its hype. Well this place definitely was worth the long wait and price.    Location is in an odd corner of the cosmopolitan and the decor is basic but I liked it because it allows focus on the open kitchen. The staff immediately were very friendly and recommended several items.   First the bartender recommended the Spicy cucumbers and those were amazing. Also suggested a mixed drink which I think of was gin and beet juice but whatever it was i was impressed and could have had several...I didn't at 17 bucks. I went in because I have because David Chang always talks about ramen on his show. Well he didn't do it wrong. I choose the pork ramen and the roasted pork was to die for and add pork belly it can't get any better. The whole bowl was perfect and one of the most flavorful and rich broth I have had.   Honestly the ramen was something i could eat everyday. Definitely worth the stop to check it out. But make reservations.  If you have a large group there are larger dishes to enjoy as a group.   Definitely put this in your list.

0Aks9Hlf_XIKMHHA3xvusA.text: Came back to Las Vegas and wanted something really good to snack on. I was going to take the Pork Belly Bun to go and have my friend try the most delicious Pork Belly Bun I've ever tried in my life!!!!  While, I was ordering, I saw a couple who ordered a Rack of Short Ribs. It looked good and I asked them how it tasted. They suggested I order it. So, my friend and I decided to order that and Pork Belly. Boy oh boy, the Rack of Short Ribs melts in your mouth!! It's super tender and juicy. The meat just falls right off the bone. It's so good!! Next time I'm back, I'll be ordering that again!!

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Lamb

8sSfXUK19p_D7Zdqyfqwhw.text: This is a tough review for me to write. I will start by saying that I stan for all things David Chang. I've been reading about him since he started the first Momofuku in New York. I watched the Mind of a Chef and Ugly Delicious. I listen to the podcast (it got much better!).   So when we rounded the corner in the Cosmopolitan in Vegas, and saw Momofuku, I was in awe. We didn't have reservations, we weren't dressed for the experience (I was wearing flip flops from driving all day), but somehow we were seated.   You have to start a review of this place with the food, because that's what it's all about, right? Well, we ordered the pork belly buns (appetizer), the Sichuan beef noodles, and the half order of the Salt & Pepper Lobster & Shrimp.   So let's start with the sublime. The pork belly buns were exactly what I dreamed of; perfect. I could have just eaten those all night. Given what came next, I probably should have. Seriously, though- they were amazing.  Next, the decent. When I tasted the Sichuan beef noodles, I got it. I was like, "Oh yeah, it's spaghetti in meat sauce! That's clever!" And then ... that was it. This was a clever concept, a bite, turned into a larger meal.   Finally, the Salt & Pepper Lobster & Shrimp. First, the "half portion" is massive. Huge. Too much for us. And even though it says it is tempura (fried) I guess I didn't internalize just how much fried stuff was coming. But while the old rules of food (a. everything tastes better fried; b. everything tastes better on a stick) might be True, this was ... eh, I wasn't a huge fan. There was no real variety. I would definitely not order this one again, or recommend it.  The cocktails, by the way, are worth getting. Inventive and delicious. The Don Collins was really good, but the What the Pho was amazing.   So, all that said, in terms of the food quality for the money I would rate Momofuku three stars, as much as it pain me. Had we ordered something else, maybe it would be different. So ... why four stars?  Because of the six-star service. It was impeccable. Despite our attire from traveling, the hostesses seated us at a bar table. The commis waiter silently glided by filling our water and dealing with our dishes. Our server was perfectly poised, friendly, and helpful, coming by enough to give us attention but not too much in order to give us space to talk and enjoy the meal. And the bartender, who brought over a drink, stopped and cracked some jokes and made us feel welcome.  In short, it was perfect service. I just wish we had ordered different dishes.

eoxI5iaS8LN4XKGQCLajzw.text: I have never met a Momofuku I didn't love. David Chang, can we just hang out already? I'll tell you long-winded stories about Canada and you can teach me how to make ramen? Please?  Popped in here for a late lunch and sat in a booth in the window over-looking the strip. As expected being a few floors up, the view was very quintessential Vegas, and perfect for a tourist like me.  I didn't stray from my usual pork ramen order, but I did also enjoy a spicy ceviche, avocado salad and green beans in sesame. I am the worst with menu names, but hopefully these descriptions help you out... because honestly you should just copy this exact order.

GZfm72VKqUufzI4Ak7x_5g.text: Momofuku is not just about the food. David Chang's vision for a restaurant experience is embodied from the moment you walk into the elegant, modern dining room and from every interaction with the amazingly attentive servers. Our water glasses were never left unfilled for more than a couple minutes at a time, and our servers were all so friendly and helpful with recommendations as well. Of course, the food did not disappoint!  We started our dinner with the shrimp buns, which consisted of a chunky, hot shrimp patty along with spicy mayo, pickled red onion, and iceberg lettuce on a soft white bao--what a flavor combination! Our server even brought over a tiny squeeze bottle of ssam sauce for the shrimp buns, and the sauce added the perfect touch of sweet and spicy flavor!  Even though the ramens technically aren't on the dinner menu, our server allowed us to order it anyway; the shoyu pork ramen, which came with a rather light broth, pork belly, pork shoulder, and a poached egg was executed perfectly, though I didn't find it all that memorable. But by far my favorite dish was the mind-blowingly delicious chilled spicy noodles. These green noodles were flavored with a thai basil pesto dressing, along with pickled jalapenos, lean Sichuan sausage, and candied cashews. Oh my goodness.. I savored every last bite and drop of sauce of this dish that combined spicy, salty, acidic, meaty, umami, and herbal flavors, along with an awesome crunchiness and nutiness that were simply unparalleled! Amazing!!  Come, come, come for the amazing food and amazing service. Momofuku is wonderful for a reason--the chef really cares about each aspect of the restaurant experience, and the dishes are prepared with the utmost creativity and finesse!

e3r55_sXEgKjyxLWl7UTlQ.text: Came here with a large group; we had a reservation and were immediately seated in the back. The room was darkkk, apparently it was in between sunset and lights on, so they couldn't turn on the lights... we ended up al getting the tasting menu which starts with 100$/person and up. We ended up getting the 130$/person option. The main courses were pork belly bao, lobster, brisket wrap, cauliflower and a accessory of side things. It also came with several desserts. They were good portions and we were full at the end. Overall was a peasants experience, but the food was not as good as expected; probably could have the same at a regular restaurant at much cheaper price. Service with good +1 star, other wise food is average(3 stars).

WDSF7ExuZy3eaBHZqoBlcw.text: Good ramen, great service.  That's really all I can say here, Yelp; if I had more to say, I would.

o6-sjDZF2tDTAvQGvo3GaA.text: So, I've been a fan of Momofuku for a long time. Especially Milk Bar, but I've also been a fan of their other concepts (Ko, Noodle Bar, etc.) So on my trip to Vegas, when I heard Momofuku was opening a Vegas output in the Cosmopolitan Las Vegas-- my BF and I decided to make a reservation (which we found at the last minute!) and ended up being pleasantly surprised with the quality of food. Vegas Momofuku is much larger than its counterparts and has a larger menu. It comes large format dining menus from several concepts and offers about 5 choices. Since there were only two of us and I'm allergic to crustaceans, we opted out of the large format dining.  We dined for around $100 per person and got: - Pork belly buns: Always a classic. Large pieces of pork.  - Ginger-Scallion Noodles: Add the ssam (spicy) sauce to this. The noodles themselves don't have much of a taste, but the cucumbers add salt, the seaweed adds umami and the mushrooms are pickled so they add a nice acidity. Adding the ssam flavours the noodles and elevates the flavours further. The cucumber and acidity cut the spiciness. Huge recommend. - New York Strip: AMAZING. The bone marrow is subtle but there is this beautiful brown butter... almost dashi like sauce? You only get it in doses but it's perfect. One of my faves. This is the cheaper version of the Wagyu they offer for $115 lol. This was only $60ish excl. tip -Chicken katsu: Like a mashup of American country fried steak smothered in gravy, but with chicken katsu and also partially German food? Huge portion, so share.

rUhVFTF3BgEv2q7_OehYTw.text: This place is gustatory heaven if you can ignore the menu prices.  Uni hashbrown - Smooth and crispy mesh of savoury goodness. Small dish for $42, but the amount of flavour in this dish forces you to forgive that.  A5 Wagyu potatoes - This dish was bigger and heartier. I loved the double fried potatoes mixed with the crispy garlic and grainy mustard. The Wagyu beef was not quite what I expected. They were thinly shaved pieces of Wagyu beef sprinkled over the potatoes.  Pork belly - I could eat a few of these in one sitting if I let myself. Everything from the thick juicy slice of pork belly to the pillowy soft bun was perfect.  Chilled spicy noodles - The cool temperature of the noodles combined with the heat of the peppers makes for a party in your mouth. It's a combo of distinct flavours and textures - sichuan sausage, Thai basil, and candied cashews - that magically work together.  Shoyu pork ramen (available in the afternoon) - This is a winning bowl of ramen. I respect ramen that has a good proportion of meat, greens, and noodles. Not only is there a thick slab of their infamous pork belly, they give you shredded pork shoulder, as well. The noodles are perfectly chewy, and soak up the tasty broth as it should.  Worth it.

efjcUsp3dKMy4H5L6pDBQw.text: This was an amazing experience. The cosmopolitan is one of the newest casinos on the strip with a hip-haut couture vibe and Momofuku serves Ramen bowls one of the newest trends to hit the foodie scene. What could a Vegas trip need after these two experiences?? First let me say, We love love love truffles and what better way to indulge than in ramen? I'm including photos of black truffle ramen bowl. Super yumm! The heat of the broth dissolved the truffle like butter! It was divine! Every earthy umami thought you have ever had made into a dish, We also had truffles over our wagu beef carpaccio ( it was sliced so thin you could read a paper through it! ) and to finish the meal---yep even truffled icecream! OMG! Did I say Yum! A friend had the unagi which I've included a photo of but neigh I wouldn't mess up my truffles fantasy with that.

Cne-CgPulNjJ8i-qBbISmw.text: Our reservation was at 930 pm here on NYE and we couldn't have been happier with Momofuku! Actually that's a lie, I'll get out my only complaints about this restaurant from the start: the place is incredibly loud! I'm not just talking about people, but the music they play is crazy loud too, or at least it was on NYE. So not the most romantic dinner location if that's what you're after. Second complaint: we didn't know who our server was for about 15 minutes because no one stopped at our table for that long. We were expecting top-notch service and we were starting to get a bit grumpy when our waiter finally arrived. And guess what? He was awesome (you know, once he arrived)! So overall we had great food and great service though the entrees here are a bit on the expensive side, I will admit. Everything else though seemed reasonable to us.  They do charge for water but it's only $1 for still and $2 for sparkling water! So not a big deal at all and I feel like many restaurants charge way more than that for sparkling so I cannot complain (fyi the water charge is NOT by the bottle, it's a flat charge). For appetizer we had the spicy cucumbers, for salad we had the honeycrisp apple salad, for entree we shared wagyu beef (on the day we had it the MP was $48 per ounce. Ouch. That hurt. But since Japan ruined my experience of beef forever already, and because we really weren't too hungry, we thought sharing a small amount of wagyu would be plenty and we have no regrets!), and even though we were full already we got 2 desserts to share after noticing they're from the NYC milk bar!  The spicy cucumbers were absolutely delicious! It's a simple dish with a lot of flavor, relatively large portion size for an appetizer, and only $9 so I'd highly recommend it as long as you're OK with spicy. The honeycrisp apple salad was also delicious, the apples were perfect and the labne cheese went perfectly with all the ingredients, but the apple slices were just way too big. We asked for a knife to be able to cut ours into bite sized pieces and I'd recommend that the restaurant considers doing this in the future. While the presentation looks more impressive with larger slices, it's not practical at all when it comes to eating the thing with chopsticks.   A5 Wagyu... It's insanely expensive, but it's worth it if you've never tried it or if you miss it. The downside is that you don't really see the cut that you are getting because it's already precut into bite size pieces and comes on a sizzling hot plate. At first I was disappointed to see the wagyu was rare, but then we realized why they did that and appreciated it a lot. You're supposed to use the hot plate the beef is sitting on to cook it! This way you can cook it perfectly and it is still hot when you're eating it. The one downside to perfectly cooked wagyu is it gets cold as you eat it, so this strategy eliminates that issue! So if you're wondering why your dish arrived completely rare, that's why! The wagyu plate also had peppers and a few other items on it that were all delicious. Was it as good as what we had in Japan? No. But it was heck of a lot better than just regular beef, so it was totally worth it.  For dessert we had the crack pie and birthday cake. Both from the milk bar (fyi Netflix chefs table desserts episodes, they have one about the chef that owns the milk bar where they talk about both of these desserts!) The crack pie is just butter in essence, it's delicious, and I'd recommend you get it a la mode if you're getting it. I really enjoyed the birthday cake but my husband thought it was too dry (I disagree). One thing we agreed on though is the slice is way too big for one person, we couldn't finish it between the two of us.  Overall would highly recommend Momofuku. The tables around us who had gotten family sized dishes or regular entrees all seemed very happy and the reviews on Yelp are mostly super positive as well! So give it a try unless you're looking for a quiet romantic dinner spot. It's too loud in there for that!

s46HFidy5492nO45VNm5mw.text: This is probably the best meal I ever had.  We had the chef's choice tasting menus for $180 per person (10 people total).  I've had other chef's choice tasting menu in San Francisco for $450 per person but it did not wow me as Momofuku had.  Our dishes included a spicy cucumber dish.  It reminded me of the Chinese Cucumber cold dish mixed with sesame and chili oil.  We also had some sort of roasted green chili.  Oyster with Cavier (supposedly MP of $2k). Serrano Jason with big flakes of black truffle.  Salt and pepper lobster, shrimp, and veggies.  Roast duck with crepe or lettuce wraps, fried duck bones, steak, and some veggies.  And some very tasty sake was included.  I don't remember all the food that came last night but I do being wowed with the ones I've listed.  Oh and don't bother checking the menu.  You will not find any of these items on the menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Salt and pepper lobster, shrimp, and veggies.

mirFW7FyL56JTM17_MRVTw.text: Great place to bring clients/ guests whom you would like to impress.   Came here with a group of friends and restaurant itself was lovely with a awesome decor and service was great on my last visit.  But as far as the price for what you get, HELL TO THE NO.  Come here for the so you can say you've experienced dining at a David Chang establishment and thr convenience of not having to leave the Cosmo hotel but be prepared to pay for the convenience and for the sub stellar food. Would i return back? Highly doubt it, really dont see anything special here. Maybe we had just ordered some of the lackluster dishes... but then again majority of our dishes was recommended by our waiter.. so yup.  Insider tip, you can order ramen but you need to ask for that menu because they will not be given to your automatically when they seat you.

Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Save your money and make your way to Chinatown instead

dG8P-gGwQa5R0dCkdPlUUA.text: Fun fact: David Chang is one of my chef crushes. He's always smiling or laughing on camera, he absolutely loves what he does, and he's not pretentious about it.   I first heard about Momofuku on No Reservations (Anthony Bordain is another chef crush), and I made a mental note to visit one of the locations some day. My first opportunity to do this was last summer during my Vegas trip.  First and foremost, you know something will be spectacular if it's housed in the Cosmopolitan. Momofuku's location makes it a hot spot for atypical visitors, so when you're not looking at the gorgeous view of the strip (pictured), you can sneak some peaks of the quirky people around you. Don't like those loud cowboys lookin' for a big juicy burger and letting everyone around them know? You probably won't find any of those here.  We had a reservation, so I'm not sure what the typical wait time is. The restaurant was packed, though.   After being seated, my eyes shot to the drink menu. Almost immediately they land on the spiced slush drink. When in Vegas, gotta try something different! It tasted like a spicy frozen margarita, for those who like those.  We started off with the crab stuffed deviled eggs, because why the heck wouldn't I try David Chang's seafood deviled eggs? Those are three of my favorite things! They were definitely the strangest deviled eggs I've ever had, and also pretty darn tasty.   We also ordered the ahi tuna with tomatoes and cheese, because this was a night of fusion food! I'm also always craving poke, so it was bound to be ordered. I'm not sure if it was actually listed as a fusion poke, but pretending that it was, this was also the strangest form of the dish I've ever had. I would have never thought to pair raw fish with tomatoes and cheese, but it was oddly delicious. Sometimes I wonder if David Chang thinks of dishes while he's really high...maybe that's what most chefs do though?  We ended with the smoked pork chops. Though well cooked and seasoned, this item was easily forgettable, compared to the other items we ordered. I'd say order it only if you want something safe.  Would I visit Momofuku again? Hell yes, and you should, too.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Views
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Views
Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Last Night in Vegas

iOHbHpL-HQZJO_E4C-jFTQ.text: First of all, let me start by saying the customer service is great and this rating is purely from the food.  Everything on this menu was overpriced for buffet quality nonsense.  The only delicious item on there were the pork belly buns, which are slightly expensive and can be found in a lot of other restaurants.  The wagyu short rib kimchi stew was not tasty, got overpowered by the perilla leaf flavor and going the "modern" route on a classic Korean dish ruined everything (trust me I know this... Now I sound like the owner David Chang).  The sichuan beef noodles actually had well cooked noodles that were slightly al dente but the flavor was a miss that felt like a cross between chef boyardee and cheap Chinese noodles with pepper flavor.  Oysters were oysters and overpriced (this is the theme btw).  Shishito were not truly shishito peppers and 50% were spicy.  The flavor used were for these peppers weren't bad though.  Lamb... was gamey... pretty sure they don't know how to make it.  Between the seven of us and the bill coming out to approximately $100/person, it's NEVER worth it.  Nothing authentic about anything and they need to change before we ever come back.

Slr8gYk1eNcjEwr143F4cw.text: Came here to try the food once, and I have to say, I was very delighted with what I got.  The food was amazing and the service was fantastic.  I gave this place a 5 star because not only the food was great, but the service was respectful, fun, and most importantly fast.  The pork belly was amazing and was juicy.  However, the ramen wasn't spectacular or different, but that didn't damper the experience.  For a quality place, the price was a little on the higher end.  The bread that was provided with the Pork Belly was very tasty and fluffy as well.  Don't worry about finishing the bread quick, they will provide more.  The corn was a letdown, nothing really special about that.  I'd say the spicy cucumbers were actually surprising the most.  I'm not a fan of cucumbers in general, but these gave a nice fresh crunch to start the meal.    P.S.  I think my time there was also cooler, the fact I saw Seth Rogen eating with his wife there too.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Rack of Beef Short Ribs.

slNW-EvzsnYf7FYbQf7vFw.text: Finally got a chance to try this place out with a couple of friends.  I've been meaning to try out their food for awhile now since didn't get a chance to when I was last in NYC.   The interior is nice and modern and they have a well stock bar with lots of Japanese whiskey. We ordered the following:   - Spicy cucumbers - very refreshing,  the togarashi over the nuts gave it a different taste - shishito peppers - did not have the grilled marks,  but was served with smoked salt - tasted pretty good - 5 spice rotessiere duck - a definite stand out and super flavorful (also was the longest dish we had to wait for)  - slow roasted pork shoulder - the meat literally falls apart when you use your utensil to grab it; goes well with the kimchi and lettuce - shoyu pork ramen - it came out kind of lukewarm and seemed to have a lot of things in it. I was not too impressed with it.  Overall,  a cool place to check out. It can be a bit pricey for what you get,  but then again - it's in the Cosmo in Vegas.

uMyh2vgr0WQyC8uXd3FHMQ.text: Probably the best ramen I've had in the US.  The ramen was just so beautiful in front of my eyes. Each topping was just glistening with the broth that is bathing it. And I still remember that first bite of the pork belly was just absolutely heavenly. Then the taste of the ramen felt like something was lacking. Although the ramen was stunning and aesthetically beautiful. It needed some kick in my opinion to change up the taste. But this has to do a lot of ramen places. Nothing to really balance the heaviness with something different, like something vinegary or spicy.  Seriously, that pork belly was sooo amazinnggg. Makes me want to try their other meat platters because the pork belly was perfect.  Would I come back ? When I have more cash to try the more expensive items on the menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States

L0CyQjQFsFyV25M2Om0LBg.text: It was nice that they let my group order items not listed on the menu-- we had heard of the ramen before and it was what we wanted to try. They were good about separating bills. The ramen itself was fine. I've had better and I've had worse.

photos.caption: Photo of Momofuku - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ramen

Edz2f69phn_By51FHgEqfg.text: My favorite restaurant in Vegas! The interior is really cool - very dark & trendy with amazing views of the strip. Definitely make reservations - this place gets busy!  I came here with 10 people. Two people in our group ate their own meals and the rest of us ate everything family style.  For those of who ate family style we ordered the following:  Starters: Pork belly buns Shrimp buns Shishito Peppers Horizon Rice Cakes  Mains: Rack of Beef Short Rib 5 Spice Rotisserie Duck   Everything was amazing! I preferred the shrimp buns over the pork belly buns so if you limit yourself to one - I'd recommend the shrimp. Don't be intimidated by the shishito peppers - only 1 in 20 is spicy. We ate the whole bowl and none of ours were spicy! Very delicious, especially if you did then in the hot sauce they bring out (the hot sauce isn't that hot).  The Rice Cakes were simply amazing - I'd compare these to gnocchi, sooo good! I love that they were crispy.   The beef short rib and 5 spice duck were phenomenal. The presentation is really impressive too. The waitstaff bring the whole duck out, cut it in front of you, and then deep fry the bones and bring those back to the table! Please do yourself a favor and get them both!   As a bonus - stop next door to Milk Bar and pick yourself up a piece of crack pie! Amazing.   And if you don't know the history behind this restaurant or the one next door (Milk Bar), I'd recommend watching the episode of chef's table about Christina Tosi (on Netflix)!

VXUug8DO6CSabi0PfBhvWw.text: We came here on a Saturday night for a party of four without reservations. They told us an hour wait, but we were seated in 20 minutes. YAY.  We came here for the pork ramen. Even though it's not on the dinner menu, we were stil able to order it!   It's definitely pricier than your typical ramen bowl elsewhere, but no lie, it  was amazing!!! The pork belly was fatty and juicy, and the broth was so flavorful.   It is definitely one of my favorite ramen places which I did not expect for Las Vegas.
